DOC.HEAD: Bush Presses Saddam for Early Baker Meeting, Weighs Appeal to Congress
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS grafs 4: ``Meanwhile, CIA,'' and grafs 14-15: ``Webster, interviewed,'' report of intelligence conclusions
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Friday prodded Saddam Hussein to agree to talks on the Persian Gulf crisis by Jan. 3 and said he may ask Congress to authorize an attack against Iraq unless Saddam pulls out of Kuwait by Jan. 15. Bush said he had offered Iraq a choice of 15 dates in the next three weeks for high-level talks. ``He ought to take one of them,'' Bush declared at a news conference. For the first time, Bush said he was considering asking Congress for approval for a military strike against Iraq unless Saddam's army is withdrawn by the Jan. 15 deadline set by the United Nations. Meanwhile, CIA Director William Webster said U.S. analysts have concluded that Saddam will not leave Kuwait until convinced ``he is in peril of imminent military attack,'' according to a report of an interview with Webester. Bush said ``I think it would send a very strong, clear signal to the world'' if Congress endorsed his Persian Gulf policy or the U.N. resolution authorizing force against Iraq. ``I want a peaceful solution to this crisis but I will not be a party to circumventing or diluting the United Nations' deadline,'' Bush said. As Bush turned up the heat on Iraq, there was a hero's welcome for Ambassador Nathaniel Howell, who led a four-month holdout of American diplomats at the besieged U.S. Embassy compound in Kuwait City. ``Welcome home and thanks for a job well done,'' Secretary of State James A. Baker III told Howell at Andrews Air Force Base outside Washington as the ambassador stepped off a plane with about 50 American and foreign hostages he led from Iraq and Kuwait. ``As you were freed, now too we must see Kuwait freed of Iraqi occupation,'' Baker declared. The group was welcomed by a crowd of cheering friends and family members waving flags and bearing balloons. U.S. insistence on manning the embassy - until all Americans who wanted to leave Kuwait were given that chance - had dramatized U.S. refusal to recognize Iraq's claim of sovereignty over Kuwait. Bush met with reporters on the South Lawn moments before boarding a helicopter to fly to Camp David for a weekend with his family. Webster, interviewed by reporters and editors of The Washington Post, was quoted as saying Saddam's army has 1,000 tons of lethal chemicals, ``much of it loaded ... in almost every type of weapon,'' including some in Kuwait. A report of the interview appeared in Saturday editions of the newspaper. Saddam may not know what his own decision will be and he will be more likely to fight `if he thought our end goal was his destruction,'' Webster said. The White House indicated it was ready to pounce if Iraq and the United States failed to agree on a date for gulf talks. ``It gives us a very strong propaganda point - that he's (Saddam) not willing to even consider discussions that might lead to a peaceful resolution,'' presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said. Two weeks ago, Bush had said Baker could go to Baghdad anytime up to Jan. 15, but he acknowledged that he has backed away from that. ``I wish I'd been a little more explicit in my first announcement about what I meant about mutually convenient dates,'' the president said. Iraq proposed that Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz come to the United States next Monday and that Baker go to Baghdad on Jan. 12. But Bush said the date proposed by Baghdad wouldn't leave time for Iraqi forces to leave Kuwait by the deadline set by the U.N. ``That deadline is real,'' Bush said, adding that Iraqi forces must be ``totally out, totally out'' by then. The administration says the purpose of the prospective trip to Baghdad by Baker is not to negotiate a settlement, but to issue a face-to-face demand that Saddam withdraw his troops. ``It simply is not credible that he cannot over a two week period make a couple of hours available for the secretary of state on an issue of this importance, unless of course he is seeking to circumvent the United Nations deadline,'' the president said. Bush added, ``We've offered 15 days and he ought to get moving and do something reasonable if he really wants to move the peace effort.'' He refused to say if he would bend on his insistence that Baker's trip must occur by Jan. 3. ``I don't want to draw deadlines in the sand here, but there would have to be some compelling reason for me to change it,'' Bush said. Two Republican senators - Richard Lugar of Indiana and John McCain of Arizona - met with Bush and said afterward that he was prepared to call off the meetings with Iraq because of the impasse over dates. However, Fitzwater disputed their account. On Capitol Hill, Joint Chiefs of Staff Chairman Colin Powell said the Pentagon can keep its forces deployed in the gulf region ``as long as the president wants them deployed.'' Both Powell and Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said that continuation of the military effort could require the callup of additional U.S. reserve units, and Powell suggested that the force could shrink if needed for long-term sustainability. Cheney also said the administration hopes that Congress will give it a vote of confidence early next year on the objectives of the deployment - getting Iraq out of Kuwait and restoring its government. But he added: ``I can't think of anything more damaging ... than an indication from Congress that they are not supportive of the president's policies.'' Meanwhile, other military officials said the Pentagon is sending more doctors, blood supplies and field hospitals to the Persian Gulf to handle American and allied casualties that could occur in a land war against Iraq. Navy officials said that up to 8,000 more reservists will be ordered to active duty to support the expansion of combat medical care in and around Saudi Arabia, though the total numbers of hospitals, beds, medical people and supplies for Operation Desert Shield are kept secret. On the financial markets, meanwhile, traders said the continued stalemate of U.S.-Iraqi talks drove oil prices up in trading Friday. In a new sampling of public opinion, Americans surveyed for a New York Times-CBS News poll were almost evenly divided on whether the United States should begin military action against Iraq if Saddam does not withdraw from Kuwait by Jan. 15. In the telephone poll of 1,044 adults, conducted Sunday through Tuesday, 48 percent said the United States should wait longer to see if economic sanctions work, 45 percent said military action should be started, and the rest either didn't know or didn't answer.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Army Raises Death Toll of Panama Invasion
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to CORRECT revised figure lower sted higher, ADD 202 civilian deaths. Picks up 5th graf pvs, `The opposition ...'
DOC.TEXT: One year after the U.S. military invasion of Panama, the Army has revised downward its estimate of the dead, based on Panamanian government statistics, the Southern Command said Friday. It said in a news release that figures from the Panamanian Institute of Legal Medicine show a maximum of 345 soldiers and civilians may have died in the Dec. 21, 1989 invasion to oust Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. Positive identifications were made of 270 dead and 75 additional bodies are missing. At the time of the invasion, the Army calculated 314 military and 202 civilian deaths, the release said. The opposition to President Guillermo Endara's government says thousands died, but the Southern Command said, ``The allegations have turned out to be without foundation.'' The Panamanian Human Rights Committee estimated 295 to 385 died. The Army said 65 bodies were identified as military personnel, 155 as civilians, and 50 not classified. ``It is impossible to determine exactly how many have died as a direct consequence of the military action or to attribute specific causes to each of the deaths,'' it said. Many died in a huge fire; some died during looting, murders, in traffic accidents and from natural causes during the invasion, it added. All are included in the new estimate. The Army said it investigated 14 of 24 complaints it received about serious misconduct of soldiers. It said it threw out nine complaints as not meriting investigation, and has one case pending. The Southern Command said 11 of the complaints investigated were forwarded through legal channels and three were found to be without basis.

DOC.HEAD: Tentative Peace Agreement Reached in Angolan Civil War
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 4th graf: ``In Lisbon,'' comments of Angolan foreign minister
DOC.TEXT: A U.S.-armed guerrilla organization has reached tentative agreement with the Soviet-backed government of Angola on a plan to end 15 years of civil war, rebel leader Jonas Savimbi said Friday. At a lengthy session Thursday under the auspices of the United States, Soviet Union and Portugal, the warring sides agreed to set a date for free elections and then immediately sign a cease-fire, Savimbi told reporters. The breakthrough in the tortuous peace efforts followed a flurry of meetings here this week, including an unprecedented session between Savimbi and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze. Savimbi, who until now had been vilified by the Kremlin as an anti-Communist menace, also met with President Bush Thursday. In Lisbon, Angolan Foreign Minister Pedro de Castro van Dunem said a cease fire could be signed next month. He spoke during a stopover on his return tom Angola from a trip to Washington. Washington and Moscow have been pressing their allies in Angola to stop the fighting, which has killed over 300,000 people and left the mineral-rich country in ruin. The United States has shipped UNITA as much as $50 million in weapons every year since 1986; the Soviets have given the Angolan government as much as $800 million annually, U.S. officials say. Under the proposed agreement reached Thursday, both sides would stop sending weapons once a cease-fire is signed, U.S. officials said. Savimbi said that at Thursday's meeting, the highest-level gathering between the sides, UNITA and the second-ranking official in Angola's ruling party, Lopo do Nascimento, had agreed on five points. Among them is agreement that signing of a cease-fire should be preceded by setting a date for free elections; a cease-fire should be guaranteed by international observers; and outside military assistance will stop once a cease-fire agreement is signed. The other two points called for a democratic system of government and international monitoring of elections. The sides agreed that international peace-keepers will be sent to Angola under the banner of the United Nations, he said. Still to be settled, he said, are differences over the nations who will take part. Savimbi said all the participants except for the Angolan government were ready to sign the five-point plan at Thursday's session. The Angolan government official asked for more time to confer with his superiors in Luanda, Savimbi said. But, he added, ``there is no question'' that the government will agree in principle. The U.S., Soviet and Portuguese participants in the talks held a news conference late Thursday saying ``significant progress'' was made, but declined to elaborate at that time. But a U.S. official, speaking on condition of anonymity, on Friday confirmed the gist of Savimbi's account of the meeting. ``UNITA is optimistic that the remaining differences between the two parties can be successfully addressed and that signature of a cease-fire will be possible during the sixth round of negotiations,'' he said. The talks are scheduled next month in Portugal, the former colonial ruler of Angola. If the Angolan government approves the five points and proposes a date for elections, the sides can sign a cease-fire at the January session, Savimbi said. Elections could be held within nine months to a year from the cease-fire date, he added. ``If my party nominates me, I'll run'' for president, Savimbi said. At the outset of the negotiations last year, the government demanded that Savimbi go into exile. It later dropped that demand. Responding to military pressure from UNITA and to the democratic changes sweeping Eastern Europe, the government also gradually moved away from a state-controlled economy toward a market system. Last week Angola's ruling party agreed to allow multiparty democracy and free elections.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney Orders Navy to Justify A-12 or Drop Attack Plane Project
DOC.NOTE: EDs: ADDS one graf company comments
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney has ordered the Navy to justify the A-12 attack plane in three weeks or else kill it because of intolerable problems, the Pentagon announced Friday night. ``If we cannot spend the taxpayers' money wisely, we will not spend it,'' Cheney said in a directive to Navy Secretary Lawrence Garrett. The secretary gave the Navy until Jan 4 to justify the plane. The announcement said a special team would meet with the contractors, General Dynamics Corp. and McDonnell Douglas Corp., both based in St. Louis, to review the situation. ``The A-12 program is in serious trouble. The apparent schedule slippage, cost growth and management deficiences in this program are intolerable,'' Cheney said. The A-12 was supposed to replace the elderly A-6 as the Navy's primary all-weather, carrier-borne attack plane starting in 1995. The plane was to use radar-evading ``stealth'' techniques and carry the nickname ``Avenger.'' The Navy had planned purchase of 620 planes for an estimated $52 billion and deployment starting in 1995. But a $4.7 billion development program, supposed to deliver six prototypes, is $1 billion over budget and 18 months behind schedule. Garrett recently ordered the admiral heading the program to retire and reassigned two other officers because the three failed to pass news of problems up the chain of command. The Navy has begun a criminal investigation of excessive payments to the contractors. Also, John A. Betti, the Pentagon's top procurement officer, said Wednesday he would resign as undersecretary of defense for acquisitions at the end of the year to avoid the bite of new ethics laws that take effect Jan. 1. Officials said he had planned to leave anyway, but the timing of his announcement was influenced by news of the A-12's problems. The department's inspector general said Betti had failed to report conclusions of his own staff that the A-12 was in trouble, but had relied on assurances from the contractors and the Navy that development would be completed under budget. The contractors, she said, controlled the work of the government's inspectors. Garrett refused to block the promotion to rear admiral of one of the officers, Capt. Lawrence S. Elberfeld. Garrett defended the current procurement system, but noted people ``find it very hard to push bad news up to the top.'' Large weapons purchases are not often cancelled, many analysts have noted. Instead, Congress and the Pentagon tend to look for ways to strech out production and buyj fewer models, a tactic that frequently slows the production pace to inefficient rates and can even raise total costs. If the A-12 is cancelled, it will be a rarity for such a large program. Cheney was particularly upset at being sandbagged by bad news with the A-12 because he had reassured Congress in April the plane was doing well, five weeks before news of the cost overruns and delays became known. At the time, Cheney announced a reduction in planned purchases from more than 800 to 620. Few details of the A-12, or what has gone wrong with it, have been released, but stealth technology is brand new and known to be difficult. An official sketch of the A-12 shows a flying-wing design like the new Air Force B-2 bomber, another stealth plane that cost far more to develop than expected. Congress has committed funds to only 15 B-2s, and some estimates have reached $800 million a copy. Stealth techology, much of it secret, is known to involve novel shapes like the flying wing to deflect radar beams away rather than reflect them back to the antenna, radar-absorbing materials on exterior surfaces and non-metallic composites in the places structure that won't reflect radar. The A-6, called the ``Intruder,'' first flew in 1960 and early versions have long since been converted to tankers or other special-purpose craft. The last 10 airplanes of the series are being built by Grumman Corp. under a contract calling for final delivery in September 1991. Still, almost all carriers carry the A-6. No other plane in the Navy has the elaborate electronics that make possible attacks at night and in storms combined with the huge munitions load - up to 18,000 pounds - of the A-6. Cheney's statement said that no matter what happens to the A-12, ``We will continue to need to develop a basic strike airplane for our aircraft carrier force. The A-6, our current carrier strike plane, is aging, and we must move ahead with an alternative that incorporates the technological advances necessary to maintain U.S. naval air superiority.'' ``Older, slower and less maneuverable A-6 planes will be less able to penetrate enemy defenses and conduct their attacks. Stealth technology will be required if attack aircraft are to elude advanced fighters and surface-to-air missiles in the future. The U.S. needs to maintain the capability to project power through the use of naval strike forces,'' Cheney said. A prominent congressional critic of the A-12, Rep. John Conyers, D-Mich., chairman of the House Government Operations Committee, said Friday night he welcomed Cheney's decision. But the A-12 is ``only the tip of the iceberg'' of the Pentagon's procurement problems, Conyers said. A spokesman for Chris Schildz, a spokesman for General Dynamics, said when asked for comment, ``Our representatives will be available to meet with government officials anytime.'' Jim Reed, spokesman for McDonnell Douglas, said the company was ``hopeful that the current difficulties can be resolved quickly to everyone's satisfaction. We feel that the A-12 program is very important for the defense of our country as well as to McDonnell Douglas.''

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``She's a mother who knows the need for child care. She's a professional who understands the business-labor relationship. And, as a congresswoman, she spent years dealing with the concerns and aspirations of the working Americans from every walk of life.'' - President Bush, announcing his nomination of Rep. Lynn Martin of Illinois for Secretary of Labor. --- ``Conservatives are so disillusioned with Bush that anybody he picks is really not going to be much of a help to him. Many conservatives in the country are saying it's time to get off the bus, turn it over and set it on fire. The bus driver has serious problems.'' - GOP activist Richard Viguerie, commenting about a possible bid to wrest the 1992 presidential nomination from Bush. --- ``Gloom is something I don't feel. I'm sure that somehow during the next four years we'll find a way to learn to live with this problem.'' - Willis Meeks, Ulysses project manager at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory, commenting on a wobble in the spacecraft that threatens to cripple its $750 million mission to study the sun's poles.

DOC.HEAD: NYC Radio Host Retires; Son Taking Over
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Saturday AMs report. ^By LARRY McSHANE
DOC.TEXT: When John A. Gambling took over his dad's radio show, America still liked Ike. Elvis was waiting for his draft notice. The Chicago White Sox were playing in the World Series. On Friday, John A. retired. Eisenhower is dead; Presley's supposed to be dead; the White Sox may be coming back from the dead. But John A.'s son, John R., becomes Gambling generation No. 3 to be host of the local morning radio show as it wraps up its 65th year. ``You could always turn on the radio and find old John, young John, or in-between John,'' says John A., who took over in 1959 from the show's founder (and his father), John B. Gambling. ``If people wake up and hear about problems - a strike, a war, assassination, whatever - they turn us on and know the world hasn't come to an end. Their world has some continuity.'' Much like New York radio's first family. ``Rambling with Gambling'' has been a Gotham fixture since the Roaring '20s, outlasting a dozen mayors, 11 presidents, Billy Martin (five times) and three wars. Their show is not typical Big Apple. In a city known for Ed Koch's abrasiveness and George Steinbrenner's arrogance, the Gamblings provide a quiet morning introduction to what's going on. ``I firmly believe that the last thing listeners want to hear in this controlled mayhem is more noise, more confusion. There's enough of that in their own kitchens,'' says John A., 60, in explaining his theory of broadcasting. The Gambling family introduction into the radio business offered no indication of the dynasty to come. John B. Gambling was an engineer at WOR-AM in 1925 when he subbed for the regular announcer on a morning calisthenics show (there WERE no aerobics back then). John A. officially took over the show 34 years later, with his son John R. joining him in January 1985. Eighteen months ago, The Guinness Book of World Records proclaimed ``Rambling with Gambling'' the world's longest-running radio show, after its 20,000th broadcast. John A. cites that, along with a 30th anniversary broadcast from Madison Square Garden, as the highlights of his career. Gambling says he'll miss the camaraderie of the crew doing his show, along with the loyal listeners who've kept his ratings high through the years. ``We have an opportunity to touch millions of lives. You're never quite sure how, but you hope you do it in a positive way,'' said John A. ``Every once in a while, there's feedback, and you find out how you touched someone. That makes it all worthwhile.'' In addition to longevity, there's been innovation: the Gamblings are credited with providing the city's first radio newscast, first helicopter traffic report, and its first school closings bulletins. There are additional Gamblings waiting to grab the microphone down the line; John R. has three sons. Much to John A.'s dismay, they are named Andrew, Bradley and William - although he's quick to point out they all have the middle name John. ``The really marvelous part is the passing of the baton along to my son,'' says Gambling. ``And he's got a few of his own waiting in the wings.''

DOC.HEAD: Chronology of Nancy Cruzan Right-To-Die Case
With PM-Right-To-Die, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a chronology of major events in the Nancy Cruzan right-to-die case: -Jan. 11, 1983: Nancy Cruzan, then 25, has a wreck on a country road southeast of Carthage, in the Ozarks of southwest Missouri and is thrown from the car. Paramedics restart her breathing, but her brain was without oxygen for so long she never regains consciousness. -Feb. 5, 1983: Doctors implant a feeding tube in Ms. Cruzan's stomach. She isn't on any life support system, such as a respirator. -Oct. 19, 1983: Ms. Cruzan is moved to the Missouri Rehabilitation Center in Mount Vernon, where she remains. -Oct. 23, 1987: Her parents, Joe and Joyce Cruzan of Carterville ask Jasper County Probate Judge Charles Teel for a judgment on their request that they be allowed to have Ms. Cruzan's feeding tube removed, so she can die as they believe she would want. -March 9, 1988: A three-day hearing begins on the family's request. The Cruzans say their daughter has a common-law right to be free from unwanted medical treatment, and state and federal constitutional rights to privacy that protect her right to refuse unwanted medical treatment. -July 27, 1988: Teel issues a judgment authorizing the Cruzans, acting as Nancy's legal guardians, to request the withholding of food and water from their daughter. -Aug. 3, 1988: Missouri Attorney General William Webster files notice that the state will appeal to the state Supreme Court. -Sept. 29, 1988: The court hears arguments. -Nov. 16, 1988: In a 4-3 decision, the state Supreme Court overturns the lower court, holding there is no legal authority to grant the Cruzans' request. The family appeals to the U.S. Supreme Court. -Dec. 6, 1989: The U.S. Supreme Court hears arguments, the first time it has considered a right-to-die case. -June 25, 1990: In a 5-4 decision, the court blocks the Cruzans from halting their daughter's food and water. It says the state could keep a patient on life support in the absence of ``clear and convincing'' evidence the person would want to die. -Aug. 30, 1990: Ms. Cruzan's parents ask Teel for a second hearing, saying they have new evidence their daughter once indicated to three people she would rather die than live in her present condition. -Sept. 17, 1990: Webster, saying the state no longer has a ``recognizable legal interest'' in the case, asks the judge to drop the state Health Department and the director of the Missouri Rehabilitation Center from future litigation. -Oct. 23, 1990: Teel drops the state as a defendant, leaving the parents and court-appointed guardian Thad McCanse in the case. -Nov. 1, 1990: Three former co-workers tell Teel they recalled conversations with Ms. Cruzan in which she said she never would want to live ``like a vegetable'' on medical machines. Ms. Cruzan's physician, who previously opposed removing the feeding tube, terms her life ``a living hell'' and testifies she should be allowed to die. -Dec. 5, 1990: Ms. Cruzan's court-appointed guardians recommend the feeding tube be removed so Ms. Cruzan may die. -Dec. 14, 1990: Teel authorizes removal of feeding tubes.

DOC.HEAD: Researchers Find Seasonal, Age Risk for Sudden Infant Death
With PM-Cancer Report, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Babies are twice as likely to die of sudden infant death syndrome in the winter than in the summer and at age 2 months than age 4 months, a new federal study shows. ut even though SIDS experts long presumed those facts to be true, they still don't know why. The national Centers for Disease Control, analyzing eight years of infant mortality data, reported Thursday that the SIDS risk is twice as high in January as in July, and more than twice as high at 2 months as at 4 months. The findings are important to researchers looking for the cause of SIDS, which kills about 6,000 American infants a year. ``What we suspect is that an infectious process is somehow triggering death in these infants during cold weather,'' said Dr. Jose Becerra, an infant health specialist with the Atlanta-based CDC. ``There's also a remarkably similar pattern (for age and season) in infectious diseases - very similar,'' he said. ``It's intriguing.'' A 1988 study suggested a possible relationship between respiratory infections and SIDS, pointing to episodes of vomiting or diarrhea in the two weeks preceding death in some cases. That study indicated that breast-feeding could be protective against SIDS, by guarding against gastrointestinal or respiratory infections. Breast-feeding might help ``avert some of the gastrointestinal illnesses which we know are more common in the winter months,'' Becerra said. ``Obviously, if there's a correlation with respiratory infections or G-I infections, it's patently reasonable that maybe the infection there is responsible,'' said Dr. Alfred Steinschneider, president of the Atlanta-based American SIDS Institute. ``We know babies ... who die of SIDS must have an underlying, chronic abnormality,'' he said. ``Respiratory infections or G-I illnesses might act as a trigger to convert the predisposition to die into death.'' Nationwide, the SIDS rate is 13 deaths for every 10,000 live births, according to CDC. Analyzing infant death statistics from 1980 to 1987, the CDC also reported that SIDS rates were nearly twice as high for black babies as white babies, and half again as high for baby boys as for baby girls. The rate was highest for infants in the West and lowest in the Northeast. Broken down by age, SIDS rates were highest between 1 and 4 completed months of life. The SIDS risk peaks at 2 months: 144 percent higher, or more than double, the risk just two months later. Meanwhile, SIDS risk peaked in December, January and February. The risk in July was 50 percent lower than that in January, the highest month. Steinschneider stressed, however, that SIDS occurs all year, often among premature or underweight babies. ``What is important,'' he said, ``is a very practical thing: get darned good pre-natal care.''

DOC.HEAD: Fewer Drunken Driving Fatalities, Feds Report
With PM-Cancer Report, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A shift in public awareness, along with stricter laws and enforcement, may be why drunken-driving fatalities decreased 12 percent in seven years, a new federal study shows. In 1989, 39.2 percent of traffic deaths involved at least one person who was legally drunk, down from 46.3 percent in 1982, the national Centers for Disease Control reported Thursday. In actual numbers, 17,849 Americans died in such accidents in 1989, down 12 percent from 20,356 in 1982. Reasons for the improvement may include increased public distaste for drunken drivers, changes in state laws penalizing drunken driving, increased enforcement and higher drinking ages, the CDC concluded. ``It's probably a combination of things, not the least of which is public awareness,'' said a science researcher with the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, who cited an administration policy and asked not to be named. ``In the early '80s, we had big decreases, which had to do with the peaks in public awareness,'' he said. ``Then ... new laws kicked in, along with the 21 drinking age, and there's been a steady decrease based upon those laws.'' The CDC also reported that 24.2 percent of drivers involved in fatal crashes in 1989 were legally drunk, down from 30 percent in 1982. The numbers showed 14,644 drunken drivers involved in fatal crashes in 1989, down 13 percent from 16,793 in 1982. The declines have been fairly steady throughout the '80s. In 1989, the nation recorded 45,555 traffic fatalities. In addition to the 17,849, or 39.2 percent, involving a drunken driver, pedestrian or cyclist, another 4,566, or 10 percent, involved at least one person who had been drinking, but wasn't legally drunk. The Atlanta-based CDC noted that the percentage of fatalities in crashes involving someone drinking, but not drunk, has remained fairly constant: between 10.0 percent and 11.1 percent in each of the eight years studied. A total of 23,140, or 50.8 percent, involved no parties with a blood-alcohol reading. Meanwhile, of the 60,398 drivers involved in fatal crashes in 1989, 24.2 percent, or 14,644, were drunk, the CDC reported. Another 4,540, or 7.5 percent, had been drinking, while 41,214, or 68.2 percent, hadn't been.

DOC.HEAD: Ford Grants $2.5 Million To Aid Community College Transfers
DOC.TEXT: The Ford Foundation has awarded $2.5 million in grants to help community college students successfully transfer to four-year schools granting bachelor's degrees. Some of the money will also support efforts to increase the number of minority and female administrators at community colleges, said Franklin A. Thomas, the foundation's president. He announced the grants Thursday. Only about 15 percent of community college students successfully transfer to four-year institutions, Thomas said, adding the grants are aimed especially at increasing the number of minority students who do so. The bulk of the Ford grant, $2 million, will go to the American Council on Education's National Center for Academic Achievement and Transfer. It will distribute the funds to pairs of two- and four-year institutions to establish joint curricula and take other steps to smooth the transition for students. The Washington-based council, which represents some 1,800 colleges and other institutions, will name the schools getting grants in April. Four pairs will receive $200,000 each to create joint core curricula to ensure community college students are prepared to transfer. Ten other pairs will get $25,000 grants to help them establish partnerships aimed at fostering the skills necessary for minority youngsters to advance from community colleges to four-year schools. The rest of the grant to ACE will be used to collect information on transfer rates, to produce publications on those rates and to support the center. ``This initiative will encourage two- and four-year institutions to work together so more community college students can earn the credits necessary to transfer,'' Thomas said. The remaining $500,000 will go to nine institutions to help more women and minorities gain administrative jobs in higher education. Those institutions, which will each get approximately $50,000, are: North Carolina State University; Texas A&M University; the Michigan Community College Consortium; the Association of California Community College Administrators, in Cupertino, Calif.; the Maricopa (Ariz.) Community College District; the National Community College Hispanic Council in Fort Worth, Texas; Harvard University's Institute for Educational Management; Salish Kootenai Community College in Pablo, Mont.; and the American Council on Education. Ford has awarded more than $7.5 million in the last six years to programs aimed at helping talented community college students go on to four-year colleges. Much of the money has been targeted at minority youngsters in urban schools.

DOC.HEAD: When Tree Lights Burn Out, Patrick Fay Doesn't Curse the Darkness
LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: Unlike most of us, Patrick J. Fay never worries about making a panicky, late-night dash to the drugstore to find replacement bulbs for his burnt-out Christmas tree lights. When the lights go out, Fay doesn't curse the darkness. Instead, he chuckles and descends to his cozy basement, where his antique collection of 700 or 800 tree lights - all in good working order - and about 2,000 ornaments is safely stored. He has so many, in fact, that his suburban Washington, D.C., home boasts not one but three Christmas trees, their branches sagging under the weight of brightly colored baubles and twinkling, blinking bulbs. ``I've gone a little overboard on the lights,'' he says, smiling ruefully. ``I have so many lights that I feel guilty not using them all, so we change them and the ornaments every week or so. We have ever-changing trees.'' The trees are artificial, the better to withstand all the changing of lights and ornaments and because they don't require watering. They are put up the day after Thanksgiving and sometimes aren't taken down until mid-January, he says. Fay's oldest ornament is a teardrop-shaped, red and silver ``kugel'' or ``witch's ball,'' made in Germany of molded blown glass in the 1870s. It is nestled in the branches of a rare old German ``feather tree.'' The feather tree looks like a real, though somewhat scraggly, pine tree. It consists of green-dyed goose feather ``needles'' wired to the thin metal branches of a tall wooden stick. Many German immigrants folded these cherished holiday artifacts into their luggage and brought them to America in the 1800s, Fay said. His rarest set of Christmas tree lights is an eight-bulb string of carbon-filament Edison lamps stamped 1904. That was only a year after the small, pear-shaped bulbs first hit the U.S. market as substitutes for the centuries-old tradition of tree candles. ``At the turn of the century, electric tree lights were only for the very rich,'' Fay said. ``The bulbs cost about $1 each, which was a tremendous sum in those days. You had to have an electrician come to your home to wire them, and they were screwed into a ceiling fixture. ``The carbon filaments burned very hot and used a lot of electricity,'' he said. ``The bulbs overheated, burned down trees and really made the meter go around.'' They were replaced by cooler, brighter tungsten-filament bulbs shortly after World War II, which also was the beginning of the golden era of fancy Christmas tree ornaments. Fay's trees are full of lavish glass baubles from Germany, beaded-glass novelties from Czechoslovakia, tiny illuminated houses, kewpie dolls in snowsuits, dirigibles, fruits and vegetables, miniature airplanes and ocean liners. There are spun-glass butterflies, double-faced angels, barnyard animals, feather-tailed peacocks, windmills, chicks popping out of eggshells and lights covered with revolving painted lampshades. There are elaborately scissored-paper ``Dresdens'' from Germany, tree balls from World War II with caps of cardboard instead of scarce tin, bubble lights from the 1950s and midget lights from the 1960s. Fay, a 42-year-old hotel banquet waiter, began collecting Christmas tree antiques more than a decade ago, when he and his wife, Flora, a real estate agent, found a large box of ``quite rare, quite expensive'' ornaments in the attic of a home they had just bought. ``Some people think I'm absolutely crazy, but it's a hobby that has grown by leaps and bounds,'' he said. ``We have friends and neighbors over for show-and-tell, and they are always stunned. The older ones always see something on the trees that reminds them of their youth.''

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: Superpowers Moving to Close Down Costly War
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Superpower diplomacy may yet rescue the tragic country of Afghanistan after 12 years of war, 1 million deaths and staggering devastation that has made refugees of 5 million people. The children, as is often the case in war, have suffered the most. About half of the dead and displaced are children. Infant mortality is extremely high, rivaled only by the death rate in Cambodia and Sudan. Tuberculosis and malaria are the biggest killers - inside the camps in Pakistan and Iran and within Afghanistan itself. This week, the United States and the Soviet Union took some serious steps to end the fighting. They agreed in principle to stop providing the combatants with weapons and decided an election should be held under international supervision. ``There is a wide area of agreement between us,'' Secretary of State James A. Baker III said after talks with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze. But, he said, ``there are still questions that have to be answered.'' Among them is the scope of an assistance program to rehabilitate the country. The job is immense. ``The fragile Afghan social fabric has been torn apart,'' writer Selig S. Harrison said in his recent book, ``After The Wars.'' More than 100,000 of the country's educated elite have resettled abroad. Tensions among diverse ethnic groups have been exacerbated as the Soviet Union, Pakistan, Saudi Arabia and other outsiders sought to manipulate the outcome of the war to suit their own interests. The Soviets wanted a client state. Pakistan, which had inherited part of the country lopped off by British imperialists, wanted a government in Kabul it could influence. And the Saudis used their wealth to try to swing Afghanistan into the Moslem camp. The United States, recognizing even before the Cold War thawed that the Soviet Union would not put up with having a hostile regime on its border, dubbed the guerrillas ``freedom fighters'' and armed them to combat Soviet influence. Apart from the 1 million deaths, the war has left 700,000 widows and orphans and 535,000 disabled veterans, destroyed one-third of the country's villages and two-thirds of its paved roads and created 2 million internal refugees out of a pre-war population of ll.7 million. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev withdrew the Red Army last year after more than nine years of warfare against guerrillas armed by the United States, Pakistan and Saudi Arabia. Many U.S. analysts assumed President Najibullah's pro-Moscow government would collapse. They underestimated his skills and also the frictions among the guerrillas, some of whom are controlled by Pakistan and inclined to a Moslem fundamentalism at odds with democratic principles. Gorbachev's move did not remove the superpowers from the conflict, however. The Soviets provide the Kabul government with about $500 million a year in military assistance. The United States and Saudi Arabia each help the guerrillas with about $300 million in weapons and other military aid. The improvement in U.S.-Soviet relations is having a positive impact on regional conflicts like the one in Afghanistan. For instance, the two powers are cooperating to try to end the fighting in Cambodia and Angola. Afghanistan, which was founded in 1747, was ruled by kings until Zahir Shah was overthrown in 1973. A Marxist coup in 1978 touched off a war that continues to tear the country apart. In the meantime, the United Nations has launched a reconstruction program. U.S. contributions have been dwarfed by some other nations - $45.5 million compared, for instance, with a $600 million Soviet pledge and $145 million by Japan. Ekrem Birerdinc, who coordinates the U.N. Children's Fund program for Afghanistan, described the awful impact of the war in an interview Thursday. Most of the children in refugee camps in Pakistan and Iran were born there. ``They don't know their own country, their own culture,'' he said. The Children's Fund and other organizations have managed to immunize about 60 percent of the children against killer diseases. Within Afghanistan, he estimated, only about 20 percent are immunized. ``We cannot reach the children inside because the war is going on and there are clashes,'' he said. Three million children are not going to school, Birerdinc said, contributing ``to an army of illiterates.'' Literacy in Afghanistan was always a problem. Before the war, only 3 percent of the Afghan women had been taught to read and write. ``What you need to do now is to rebuild the whole country,'' Birerdinc said. ``If the war stops then we can say it is not the bomb, it is the water you are drinking that is hurting you.'' --- EDITOR'S NOTE: Barry Schweid heads the AP's State Department staff in Washington.

DOC.HEAD: Former Hostages Meet With Bush; Praise His Gulf Policies
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Last hostages' arrival in Washington from Germany expected about 4 p.m. EST; lead not expected
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WX7
DOC.TEXT: Seven former Persian Gulf hostages got a festive White House welcome even as images of the destruction they had left behind lingered in their minds. The newly freed captives met with President Bush for an hour Thursday, and five tagged along as he lit the national Christmas tree in a nearby park. They provided a united vote of confidence for Bush's efforts to free Kuwait from Iraq. ``To a man, we were in agreement with the care and the diligence which is being taken by the president,'' said Ralph Montgomery, who spent four months hiding in Kuwait. The hostages urged Bush to see that the international coalition against Iraq stands firm, said Montgomery. The 57-year-old architect from Indian Rocks Beach, Fla., hid with his son-in-law, who was a teacher at the American school in Kuwait. Montgomery praised his son's Palestinian neighbors for protecting them throughout the ordeal. Gunfire and explosions could frequently be heard nearby, he said. Antonio Mireles, who holed up at the U.S. Embassy compound in Kuwait, said the hostages told Bush the Kuwaitis are a peace-loving people and ``what has happened here cannot be left unattended. ... It was atrocious what occurred here.'' ``Even if I do not go back, I would like them to get their country back,'' he said. Mireles, 48, was a civil engineer working for the Kuwaiti government. Ernest Alexander, who was in hiding in Kuwait, said Bush's policies and his efforts on behalf of the hostages were ``one of the things that heartened us'' while the captives awaited freedom. Alexander, a 38-year-old lawyer who had lived in Kuwait for several years, said that two weeks ago he never would have expected to back in the United States before Christmas. He suggested it bodes well for further progress on the gulf crisis. ``Maybe he'll blink,'' Alexander said, referring to Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. Bush called his session with the hostages and some of their relatives ``a very moving experience'' and rejected the idea that Saddam should get a reward for letting them go. ``Hell, no. Not one thing,'' the president said. ``You don't reward a kidnapper. You don't reward somebody who has done something he shouldn't have done in the first place.'' Asked if he expected to be able to defuse the tensions in the Persian Gulf, Bush snapped, ``One way or another we will.'' ``What this man (Saddam) put the world through - I just can't express it. And I think you all expressed it coming home with a clarity that has brought this home to the American people,'' Bush told the hostages. The president met with the hostages as 32 of their countrymen left the Persian Gulf on Thursday on what could be the last U.S. charter flight out. The group included the U.S. ambassador to Kuwait, Nathaniel Howell, and his staff. They were arriving this afternoon at Andrews Air Force Base outside Washington. The besieged diplomats left the embassy only after they were satisfied that all Americans had been given a chance to leave the country, U.S. officials said. An estimated 500 Americans - many of them children with dual citizenship - have decided to remain in Iraq and Kuwait. The other hostages who met Thursday with Bush were four men who were held as so-called human shields at sensitive Iraqi installations: Bill Rodebush of McAlester, Okla.; John Cole of Odessa, Texas; Glenn Coleman of Boston, and Robert Hanby of Gahanna, Ohio.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Advises Shevardnadze About Heavy-Handed Domestic Measures
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III told his Soviet counterpart this week that heavy-handed measures to enforce control of the economy and in the restive Baltic republics could jeopardize a massive U.S. aid package, U.S. officials say. Baker made the point privately to Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze as the Soviet described Moscow's drive to assert central authority in a country beset by economic problems and separatist movements, a knowledgeable official said. ``I wouldn't describe it as a major warning,'' the official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Thursday night. The conversation occurred in Houston before President Bush's announcement Wednesday that he would help the Soviets meet anticipated winter shortages by approving up to $1 billion in federally guaranteed loans for purchases of food and other agricultural goods. Baker, a former Treasury secretary, and Shevardnadze often candidly discuss the Soviets' attempt to reconstruct their economy and the hardships encountered along the way, said officials who recounted the conversations. Shevardnadze explained how the central government was trying to tighten control of the distribution of food to make sure it gets to the marketplace. The foreign minister said one problem was coping with profiteers who buy food at prices set by the government and then sell it, sometimes at 10 times what they paid, to consumers trying to overcome shortages. Without approving profiteering, Baker told Shevardnadze it's one thing to maintain order and another to use a heavy hand to root out attempts to stifle a market economy. Baker said a violent crackdown in dealing with the independence movements in Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania could strain the improved U.S.-Soviet relationship and that Bush's assistance program might be jeopardized, the officials said. Baker's advice came in a general discussion and Shevardnadze did not take it as a confrontation the officials said. Shevardnadze requested U.S. assistance from Baker on Tuesday in Houston. The aid package announced by Bush the next day at the White House exceeded Shevardnadze's request, according to U.S. officials who briefed reporters afterward. Bush lifted a 16-year-old ban on guaranteed credits, said he would propose that the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund give the Soviets a ``special association'' and offered help in dealing with transportation problems. None of the U.S. aid is in the form of a gift and Baker stressed at a news conference in Houston that it was temporary and that the Soviets eventually would have to depend on their own vast resources.

DOC.HEAD: School to Pay Rowdy Students to Stay Calm
DOC.TEXT: A Swedish school wants to make a deal with class troublemakers: stay out of mischief and pocket a few kroner for your trouble. A school official in the southern town of Perstorp said Thursday that authorities will pay 1,500 kroner a month, the equivalent of $270, if students accused of drinking, cutting class and vandalizing turn a new leaf. That will mean working in a community park or swimming pool and taking school lessons during their spare time, said Kaj Seger, of Perstorp Central School. ``We do this for two reasons: to save these boys a costly future stay at a reformatory, and to give the others in the class peace and quiet,'' he said. Five boys have been offered the deal, which will go into effect after the Christmas holiday if they accept.

DOC.HEAD: NRA Pushing Suit to Overturn Ban on Machine Gun Ownership
DOC.TEXT: The National Rifle Association is pushing a suit that would overturn a government ban on civilian ownership of new machine guns, but police groups supporting gun control want the Supreme Court to ignore it. ``Machine guns are designed to kill large groups of people and do so quickly,'' Don Cahill of the National Fraternal Order of Police said during a Thursday news conference. ``Drug dealers and others bent on violence are the only ones who need machine guns.'' At issue is a 1986 amendment to the Gun Control Act. The Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms says the amendment prohibits private ownership of machine guns made after May 18, 1986. Still legal is civilian possession of the 125,000 privately owned machine guns made before then and the transfer of those older weapons as long as new owners obtain ATF's approval. To own an old machine gun, a person must be fingerprinted, undergo a background check, obtain endorsement from the local police chief or sheriff and pay a $200 fee per weapon. But NRA attorney Richard E. Gardiner said the government is misinterpreting the 1986 legislation. ``What it says is that any machine gun made after that date can be ... possessed under the authority of the United States,'' Gardiner said in an interview. While the government said it limits ownership of new machine guns to law enforcement agencies and the military, Gardiner said it means ownership is open to anyone meeting ATF standards such as those established for individuals buying the older weapons. ``There's a section in the Gun Control Act that specifically exempts all government agencies from the act,'' the NRA lawyer said. ``It would be meaningless for Congress to create two exemptions for the same people.'' The NRA is supporting a case brought by gunsmith J.D. Farmer Jr. of Smyrna, Ga. against ATF Director Stephen E. Higgins. Farmer wanted to make and own a machine gun, and he gave ATF all the documents needed for possession of an old weapon. The bureau rejected the application, saying the 1986 legislation was the sole reason for doing so, according to Farmer's petition to the Supreme Court. U.S. District Judge J. Owen Forrester of Atlanta ruled in Farmer's favor in January 1989, but a three-member panel of the 11th Circuit Court of Appeals unanimously overturned that decision on July 11, 1990. The Supreme Court has not decided whether to hear Farmer's appeal. The Center to Prevent Handgun Violence and seven police organizations submitted a brief Thursday urging the top court not to take the case. ``A great deal is at stake,'' Dennis A. Henigan, director of the Center to Prevent Handgun Violence Legal Action Project, said at the news conference. ``If the Supreme Court were to endorse anything close to the NRA's doctrine, it would threaten every sensible gun law in this country.'' District of Columbia Police Chief Isaac Fulwood, speaking for the International Association of Chiefs of Police, said: ``It is absolutely vital that the sale and possession of new machine guns stay illegal. ... Machine guns have no place in civilized society.'' David B. Mitchell, police chief of Prince George's County, Md., noted that ``more than a dozen cities have already broken all-time murder records, and many others are approaching these frightening marks.'' Mitchell, representing the Police Executive Research Forum, said, ``Every concerned American must truly believe that gun violence will escalate even more if these military weapons are available again to the general public.'' But Gardiner rejected the idea that drug dealers and other lawbreakers would rush to buy new machine guns. ``They're not the kind of people who like to submit forms to the federal government,'' he said. Other groups asking the Supreme Court to reject the Farmer case were the National Association of Police Organizations, the National Organization of Black Law Enforcement Executives, the Major City Chiefs and the Police Foundation.

DOC.HEAD: Stone Chariot Horses Fetch $606,000
DOC.TEXT: A broken stone relief of two chariot horses from 5th century Persepolis have sold at a Sotheby's auction for $606,000. The fragment sold Thursday shows the heads of two steeds with their forelocks tied in knots with tassels. Sotheby's said it formed part of a staircase in the great palace of Persepolis, founded by Darius the Great in the early 5th century. It matches another fragment from the same relief at the British Museum. The relief was brought to England in the early 19th century by Sir Gore Ouseley, British ambassador to the Court of Persia, according to Sotheby's. An antique dealer from Cheltenham sold it Thursday to an unidentified buyer.

DOC.HEAD: Facts And Figures On Albania
With PM-Albania, Bjt
By The Associated Press
DOC.TEXT: Here are some facts and figures on Albania: --- THE LAND - Albania covers 10,600 square miles, and is slightly larger than Maryland. It is in southeastern Europe on the coast of the Adriatic Sea, and its neighbors are Yugoslavia and Greece. --- THE PEOPLE - Albania's 3.2 million people are made up primarly of the Geg ethnic group in the north and the Tosks in the south. Ethnic Greeks make up about 2.5 percent of the populace. --- THE ECONOMY - The chief industries of the country are mining, chemical fertilizer and textiles. Its chief crops are corn, wheat, cotton, potatoes, tobacco, citrus fruits and grapes. --- THE GOVERNMENT - Albania is last remaining Stalinist republic in Eastern Europe. The Communist-run People's Assembly, a single-chamber legislature of 250 deputies, meets a few days a year essentially to ratify actions taken in its name by the presidium of the assembly. The presidium is led by Ramiz Alia, the head of state and Communist Party leader. On Tuesday, the party agreed to permit alternative political organizations, and one day later the country's first non-Communist party, the Democratic Party of Albania, was founded. New parliamentary elections are scheduled for Feb. 10.

DOC.HEAD: Political Events In Albania
With PM-Albania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT:
Here is a list of major political developments in Albania:
1945 - Elections are held based on a single slate of candidates sponsored by the Communists headed by Enver Hoxha. 1946 - King Zog is deposed and the People's Republic of Albania is proclaimed. 1949 - Albania, seeking protection from Yugoslav expansionism, joins the Moscow-based CMEA (Council for Mutual Economic Assistance, or Comecon). 1955 - Albania joins the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact military alliance. 1961 - The Soviet Union denounces Albania's ties with Beijing and breaks off relations. 1962 - Albania withdraws from the CMEA and turns increasingly to China for support. 1968 - Albania withdraws from the Warsaw Pact. 1972 - Following the improvement of U.S.-China relations, Albania becomes disenchanted with Beijing. 1978 - Beijing formally terminates all economic and military support. 1982 - The government stops an attempted coup by a group of Albanian exiles. The pretender to the throne, while not directly involved, admits knowing the rebels' leader. 1985 - Enver Hoxha dies, and is replaced by Ramiz Alia who vows to continue Hoxha's policies. 1987 - Alia re-elected as President of the Presidium and head of the Party of Labor of Albania (Communist Party). 1989 - Alia resists the reforms sweeping away the repressive Communist leaderships in Eastern Europe and refuses to relinquish the Communist Party's constitutional monopoly on power. 1990 - May: Communist leaders begin announcing cautious political, economic and foreign policy reforms and signal willingness to re-establish ties with Washington and Moscow. The reforms include liberalized travel, the lifting of a ban on religious propaganda and the abolition of the death penalty for defectors. July: Thousands of Albanians storm foreign embassies and refuse to leave until they are granted permission to emigrate; Albania and the Soviet Union re-establish diplomatic ties. October: Balkan foreign ministers hold a meeting in Tirana. The country's leading writer, Ismail Kadare, defects while in France. November: Parliament adopts legislation to allow independent candidates to stand in secret ballot elections. Dec. 11: The Communist Party says it will allow non-Communist political parties to form. Dec. 12: Students and others found the first alternative party called the Democratic Party of Albania. Dec. 13: Police and troops move to put down rioting ``hooligans'' in the northern city of Shkodra.

DOC.HEAD: Bennett Rejects Top GOP Job Two Weeks After Accepting It
DOC.TEXT: Blood and law, in the form of advice from his brother, convinced William Bennett he should reverse himself and reject the chairmanship of the Republican National Committee. Bennett's brother Robert is the special counsel investigating one of Congress' most sensitive ethics cases - the propriety of five senators' actions on behalf of financier Charles H. Keating Jr., a major contributor. And from brother Bill's perspective, that case and his own ``are not totally unrelated.'' Bennett, in an interview Thursday, said he asked his brother whether he should take the top GOP position. ``He said, `My advice to you is not to take this job,''' Bennett said. ``I said, `Is it a close call?' and he said, `90-10.''' Bennett, who resigned in November as national drug policy director, is not supposed to lobby or come into extensive contact with the White House for a year after leaving the administration. He also was told by White House lawyers that he would have to give up a book contract and other outside income. ``I didn't take a vow of poverty,'' Bennett told reporters as he rejected the RNC job he had accepted from President Bush two weeks earlier. The surprise development was an embarrassment to Bush and Bennett. The White House now must find a new candidate to take over day-to-day party operations from the ailing Lee Atwater. The RNC position, which would involve constant contact with the administration as well as raising money from many individuals and groups with special interests, falls into a murky area. Some lawyers say there would be no conflict, but others - including Robert Bennett - predicted trouble. ``Bob said to me, `Look, you'll be very public in your views. You'll be controversial. People will want to target you and if they can find some vulnerability, they'll be looking for it,''' Bennett recounted. Complicating the ethics tangle was the fact that Bennett would have had to repay his book advance, listed at $187,500 on financial disclosure forms. Bennett reported receiving $240,000 in speaking fees during the four months between his resignation as education secretary in September 1988 and when he was given the drug czar job in January. But he said he would be hard-pressed to repay the advance. ``I would have to earn that money by consulting and giving speeches. I would be engaged in activity which I am precluded from doing for a year,'' he said. White House Counsel C. Boyden Gray decided this week that Bennett would violate the no-contact law if he took money beyond his $125,100-a-year RNC paycheck. Gray told The Associated Press he had warned Bennett all along that his speeches would have to be restricted. ``At the time it was hypothetical who he would speak to,'' Gray said of his initial advice. But he said Bennett subsequently lined up speaking engagements with industry and trade groups that had direct interests in lobbying the administration on policy matters. ``The question here is not strictly legal. It's a question of appearance, a question of prudence and ultimately a question of politics,'' Gray said. Bennett, however, maintained that the advice from the White House changed. In his view, his green light had turned red and he turned to his brother. ``That's when things became very clear,'' he said. ``I have been at this for nine years and I have a reputation for being a lot of things. But no one has ever raised any questions about propriety or ethics and I will not allow them to be raised.'' One administration source familiar with the situation said Gray had cautioned Bennett early on about the risks of appearance of impropriety, but backed off under pressure from White House chief of staff John Sununu, who wanted Bennett to be able to take the job. The source spoke on condition of anonymity. Bennett, 47, is a fellow at the Hudson Institute, a conservative political research organization. His publishing contract with Simon & Schuster calls for him to write two books. A couple of Cabinet members have been mentioned as potential RNC chairmen, and Bennett said they probably would not be under financial pressure to make outside money through speeches or consulting. But he said the White House contact and fund-raising duties alone could prove risky to anyone coming from the administration.

DOC.HEAD: Businessman's Ashes Buried at Resort
DOC.TEXT: The ashes of American financier Malcolm Forbes have been buried at an island resort he owned in Fiji, the resort managers said today. The service for Forbes, who died in February at age 70, was held last week, but the managers declined to give any details. Forbes's ashes were buried at the exclusive Laucala Island resort, 120 miles east of Suva, which he started in 1987. Forbes often flew to Fiji on his gold-and-green private jet, the ``Capitalist's Tool,'' and the plane apparently also brought Forbes' remains to the island. A spokesman for the Forbes family in New York could not immediately be reached for comment.

DOC.HEAD: NRC Cutting Maximum Exposure Levels
DOC.TEXT: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission is reducing the amount of radiation to which workers at atomic plants and nearby residents may be exposed, but critics contend the new ceilings already are outdated and inadequate. The NRC's action on Thursday represents the first broad revamping of radiation exposure limits for nuclear plant workers in 33 years. Officials said it reflects new scientific findings on radiation risks. Radiation exposure to most atomic workers and people living near nuclear facilities already is well within the new requirements and few operational changes are expected, said Donald Cool, chief of the NRC's radiation protection and health effects branch. The NRC has debated tighter controls on radiation exposure at nuclear facilities for a decade. The final action comes 13 years after an international scientific advisory group recommended lower exposure ceilings - levels identical to those required by the new rules. Under the new NRC requirements, atomic plant workers may be exposed to no more than 5 rems of radiation per year and exposure to the general public may be no more than 100 millirems per year, about one-fifth of the current limit. A rem, which is the standard measure of radiation, equals 1,000 millirems. The NRC rules affect commercial nuclear power plants, various laboratories and facilities involved in uranium production. According to government studies, people on average are exposed from normal background radiation and medical treatments to about 360 millirems of radiation annually. Radiation from an X-ray is about 6 to 7 millirems. The average exposure to plant workers is about 400 millirems a year and there has been no case reported where members of the general population have been exposed to levels anywhere near the new 100-millirem ceiling, said NRC spokesman Joe Fouchard. Critics, however, accused the NRC of not going far enough and of issuing new rules that will be outdated before they even go into effect beginning in 1993. The NRC's lower radiation exposure levels reflect recommendations made as early as 1977 by the International Commission on Radiological Protection, a key scientific advisory body. However, the same group announced last summer that it considers its 1977 recommendations to be outdated. The group is expected shortly to recommend maximum radiation exposure levels for atomic workers of 2 rems per year. The lower ceiling is based on a number of recent studies on radiation health risks including one by the National Academy of Sciences earlier this year that put cancer risks from radiation two to five times greater than a similar study did in 1980. ``The commission is straining its credibility by adopting an obsolete standard,'' said Michael Mariotte, executive director of the Nuclear Information and Resource Service, an anti-nuclear umbrella group. The NRC, in explaining the regulatory change, said the new requirements ``reflect changes in the basic philosophy of radiation protection'' and take into account recent scientific studies on the risks of radiation. The commission said it didn't believe the imposition of even lower radiation exposure ceiling for nuclear workers is needed because actual contamination of most workers already is much lower than the 5-rem-per-year standard being proposed. In 1987, 97 percent of all workers at nuclear plants and other atomic facilities were exposed to less than 2 rems of radiation annually, the NRC said. The new regulations also establish tighter standards that apply to pregnant workers at atomic facilities, limiting exposure to 500 millirems over the duration of the pregnancy, and require that plants adopt formal policies to keep radiation doses ``as low as reasonably achievable.''

DOC.HEAD: Galileo Photographs Moon's Far Side for First Time Since Apollo
LaserPhoto WX8
DOC.TEXT: The far side of the moon, last photographed by Apollo astronauts two decades ago, was captured on film again by the Galileo spacecraft when it zoomed past the Earth on its long voyage to Jupiter. ``It's staggering to realize we've been neglecting our own satellite,'' said Torrence Johnson, Galileo's chief scientist at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory. Astronauts with the 1969-1972 Apollo lunar missions photographed the back side of the moon, but Johnson said Thursday the last good pictures before Galileo were made by unmanned lunar orbiters during the 1960s. Galileo passed the moon after it swooped 597 miles above the southwest Atlantic Ocean on Saturday. It used Earth's gravity as a slingshot to help expand the spacecraft's orbit around the sun so it can reach Jupiter in 1995. It used Venus for the same purpose last February and will fly past Earth again in December 1992. The planetary encounters are meant solely to help propel Galileo on its $1.4 billion mission to Jupiter. But scientists took the opportunity to use the spacecraft to study Venus and Earth in dress rehearsals for exploring Jupiter. Three of Galileo's new photographs of the moon and Earth were released Thursday by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration as Galileo zoomed away from Earth, snapping more pictures of its home planet from a distance of 2.33 million miles. One photo shows the crescent moon, while another shows Mare Orientale, a 550-mile-wide meteorite impact crater on the far side of the moon, which is always pointed away from Earth. Because of the way the moon orbits Earth, only five-eighths of its surface can be seen from Earth. Galileo's third picture shows half of Antarctica, including the Ross Ice Shelf and mountains poking through ice near McMurdo Sound. ``This is the first time we've had a chance to use a spacecraft designed to explore another planet to come back and look at our own Earth and moon as if we were alien observers,'' Johnson said. ``In the process, we're learning some new scientific things about our own world and its companion, but perhaps more importantly, it's providing us a different perspective on our own home planet as a fragile world,'' he said. Galileo is the first craft equipped with modern instruments to study the far side of the moon and photographed some regions for the first time, said Clark Chapman, a researcher from the Planetary Science Institute in Tucson, Ariz. ``We're going to learn a lot about the geology of the back side of the moon,'' Chapman said. ``It's been a fantastic lunar mission already.'' NASA plans to release more pictures Wednesday and hopes to display a movie made of 1,400 still images showing clouds moving above the spinning Earth. Some unreleased pictures were displayed Thursday during a NASA closed-circuit television broadcast. They showed closeup views of clouds drifting above Australia and more distant peeks at Asia, India, Baja California and the Andes. Galileo was launched from space shuttle Atlantis on Oct. 18, 1989. It was to have been sent on a direct, two-year flight to Jupiter. But after the 1986 explosion that destroyed the shuttle Challenger, NASA decided it was too risky to launch Galileo from the shuttle using a powerful liquid-fueled rocket. A weaker booster was used, requiring Galileo to use the gravity of Venus and Earth to make a looping 2.4-billion-mile, six-year voyage.

DOC.HEAD: 12 Found Dead, 7 Seriously Ill in Tijuana Religious Ceremony
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 9 grafs to include description of religious practice, LA Times report the victims drank poison punch, picks up 8th graf pvs, `Authorities found ...
DOC.TEXT: Twelve people taking part in a ceremony to call up spirits were found dead Thursday in a home in this Mexican border city. Seven others found sprawled on the floor in a circle formed by rope were in serious condition, said a Baja California police spokeswoman. One officer said the 19 men, women and children were the apparent victims of a mass suicide attempt by poison. Others said it could be an accidental asphyxiation or poisoning. Relatives of the victims said they had previously attended healing rites in the house that were a mixture of Christianity and spiritualism, which involves calling the spirits of the dead for consultation. ``They were holding a session in which they communicated with the spirits,'' said Tijuana state judicial police commander Jaime Sam Fierro. He said the victims might have been poisoned by butane gas, which is used in Mexico for home heating or stoves - or by something they ate or drank. An autopsy is to be completed Friday, said police spokeswomen Sara Yolanda Gonzalez in Mexicali, the state capital. Authorities said the deaths could have been caused by industrial-strength alcohol believed to be in a fruit punch participants shared during the ceremony, the Los Angeles Times reported Friday. ``We believe we've ruled out both suicide and homicide,'' Jose Nunez de Caceres, a commander of the Baja California state police, told the Times. Officers were conducting tests on the punch and a bowl of cooked chicken found in the house where the 12 bodies were found, Gonzalez said. Police said a witness told them the house smelled strongly of gas when the bodies were discovered Thursday morning, she said. Police said the group leader and house owner, Federico Padres, 72, was among four survivors in a coma. One of the survivors was an 18-month-old baby. Authorities found the bodies, some piled upon each other, on couches, chairs and the floor of the well-kept house in the Florido neighborhood, a poor district of shanties and squatter camps. A rope with 13 knots tied in it was laid in a circle on the living room floor around four or five of the bodies, said officers who saw the inside of the house. Neighbors said chanting had filtered from the house over the past several nights; the last time starting Wednesday night and continuing into the morning. Officer Jorge Gamala quoted a neighbor as saying she had overheard people at the house talking about when they were going to ``do it.'' ``She overheard them say that their god was waiting for them and they had to get it done by the end of the year,'' Gamala said. A young woman who lives in the house reported the bodies to state judicial police, Gonzalez said. The woman, Ana Faviola Miranda, 17, said Padres frequently held healing ceremonies there and held one Wednesday night, Gonzalez said. Miranda said she went home at 8 p.m. Wednesday and Padres told her to leave and come back later, according to police. When she returned at 8:55 p.m., she said the house smelled strongly of gas, police reports said. They said Padres told her to wait outside. From Padres' car, where she waited, Miranda said she heard shouts and whining, but didn't do anything because she was used to that kind of carrying on, Gonzalez said. After spending the night in the car, Miranda asked a neighbor for help, and the two entered the house through a window, the woman testified. Upon seeing the bodies, Miranda said she thought the ceremony participants were asleep or in a trance, Gonzalez said. Gonzalez said Miranda informed police at 11 a.m. Thursday. Police said they found four men, seven women and a 6-year-old girl dead. Padres and Miranda's mother Gloria Miranda, 38, were among the dead, Gonzalez said. She said police had not yet identified the rest of the dead. According to a report by KFMB-TV of San Diego, Mexican State Judicial Police said they believe the victims had ingested poison. The victims, the report said, suffered a purplish discoloration of the skin.

DOC.HEAD: Concern Over Public Alarm Delays EPA Report
DOC.TEXT: White House fears of unduly alarming the public have delayed until next week the release of an Environmental Protection Agency report linking electromagnetic fields to leukemia and brain cancer in children, the EPA says. The report, which was to have been released last month, suggests, but does not prove, that electromagnetic fields can cause cancer, EPA officials said Thursday. D. Allan Bromley, a White House science adviser, and James O. Mason, assistant secretary of health and human services, told EPA officials they were concerned the public would misinterpret the report's conclusions. ``They were concerned not about the accuracy of the report,'' said Robert McGaughy, who supervised the report's preparation. ``They were concerned about how people would react to the news. There is a concern that people will take too seriously the suggestions that there may be some connection with cancer.'' Neither Bromley nor Mason were available for interviews Thursday, their offices said. Some EPA scientists were angry about the delay, said David Bayliss, one of the report's authors. It initially was scheduled for release Nov. 27, he said. ``What is the use of having an Environmental Protection Agency if you're going to withhold information from the public?'' Bayliss said. ``I thought the EPA was for letting people know about health problems, or possible health problems.'' The report looked at all kinds of electromagnetic fields, from those produced by high-power electrical transmission lines to those produced by household applinces. Virtually everyone is exposed to such fields every day. Epidemiological, or statistical, studies have linked residential exposures to childhood cancer, and studies have linked occupational exposures to cancer in adults, said David Savitz of the University of North Carolina in Chapel Hill, the author of one of the most important of those studies. Laboratory experiments have suggested that living cells can respond to electromagnetic fields. And researchers have hypotheses as to why the fields might cause cancer, Savitz said. ``There are credible scientific suggestions of adverse health effects from these exposures, but the overall body of evidence is not conclusive,'' he said. The EPA report is a review of all existing studies on electromagnetic fields and cancer. A draft prepared last summer concluded that the studies ``show a consistent pattern of response which suggests, but does not prove, a causal link'' between household power distribution systems and certain cancers in children. The children's cancers were leukemia, brain cancer and lymphoma, the report said. The draft has been revised once, but ``our current conclusions are very similar,'' McGaughy said. McGaughy said questions raised by Bromley at a meeting Nov. 26 with McGaughy and other EPA officials in Bromley's office delayed the report's scheduled release the following day. Mason expressed similar objections Dec. 6, McGaughy said. Erich Bretthauer, the EPA's assistant administrator for research and development, said both men were involved because an interagency federal committee that they oversee also is studying electromagnetic fields and health hazards. Bretthauer said the report will be released next week. He said Bromley and Mason disagreed with the EPA over nuances of the epidemiological studies considered in the report. ``I don't think they see the data the way we do,'' Bretthauer said. When asked to clarify the disagreements, he said, ``I'm going to refer you to them.'' In an earlier version, prepared last spring, the agency tentatively proposed classifying electromagnetic fields as a ``class B1'' carcinogen, meaning that they are a probable source of human cancer. ``But when it went through the peer review inside the agency, that recommendation was taken out - some say with malice, and some say without,'' said David Janes, a now-retired EPA administrator who commissioned the study. Janes said he thought the EPA report would have a great impact, because of the nature of the risk. ``I think it will create a lot of apprehension among folks, especially since this is one of those `you can't see it, feel it or taste it.' And an individual's exposure is not under an individual's control.''

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Close Lower
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 24,349.50 points, down 293.47 points or 1.19 percent, on the Tokyo Stock Exchange on Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Many States Facing Budget Cuts or Tax Boosts
DOC.TEXT: Welcome to crunch time for state governments. Spending is up considerably, but revenue isn't. The result: budget cuts or tax increases are in the offing in many states. ``This is the worst I've ever seen it in Mississippi,'' said Republican state Sen. Dick Hall. ``The joyride had to end. It just ended a year or so sooner than we thought it would.'' Hall's comments echoed those of other state lawmakers attending a convention of the National Conference of State Legislatures this week. Amid a weakening national economy, revenue in 25 states is far behind projections. Two-thirds of state governments will have to cut budgets or raise taxes next year to balance their books, a conference survey found. Corporate income tax collections in Mississippi, for instance, have been running below earlier estimates for the past 14 months. The state legislature and Democratic Gov. Ray Mabus now must figure out how to cover a $100 million shortfall. It promises to be an ugly fight because all legislative seats and the governorship are up for election next year in Mississippi.
