The amount of political posturing is bound to be greater than usual, Hall said. Nowhere are state finances more dismal than in the Northeast. Connecticut faces a deficit of $562 million for the next six months plus a shortfall of $1.5 billion, 20 percent of the budget, for fiscal 1992. When recession hit, revenue in Connecticut took a nosedive. ``This is a roller-coaster tax structure'' that relies heavily on sales taxes, said state Rep. Mary Mushinsky, whose constituents are starting to experience layoffs. Connecticut's financial problems in the recession of the early 1980s were ``a small blip'' compared to the current difficulties, she said. Gov.-elect Lowell Weicker is considering a state income tax to fix the problem. The economic slump ``is as serious as it was in 1982'' and the slide seems ``to be progressing at a faster rate'' than in the early '80s, Maine House Speaker John Martin told reporters Thursday. Each of the six New England states is a candidate for tax increases, state legislative leaders reported. The Midwest won't escape the crunch, either. Ohio faces a $262 million deficit and the legislature will meet next week to act on a package of budget cuts. Congress is contributing to the states' woes, state lawmakers complained at the conference. Rep. Dale Kildee, D-Mich., got a hostile reception when he spoke to the legislators. Congress has revised programs such as Medicaid and left it to the states to pay for the changes. ``You lay all of these mandates on us'' and don't provide the money to pay for them, Ohio state Sen. Richard Finan told Kildee. Finan, a Republican, is chairman of the state Senate ways and means committee and will be one of the major players as the Ohio legislature tries to bridge the budget gap. The coming months promise to be a battle royal in many state capitals. In California, Gov.-elect Pete Wilson faces a stern test - dealing with a projected budget deficit of $800 million in the fast-growing state. Wilson had better not try to cut needed services for low-income people, warned California state Rep. Dianne Watson, who represents part of Los Angeles. She pointed to the defeat the Democratic-controlled legislature handed Republican Gov. George Deukmejian this month. It rejected his bid to reduce an income tax credit for renters, a move that would have saved the state $200 million. The situation is likely to get worse in California. For the fiscal year starting next July, revenue is expected to fall short of spending by $5.9 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Report Seen Unlikely to Recommend Massive Boost in Western Aid
DOC.TEXT: A long-awaited study of the Soviet economy is unlikely to recommend a flood of direct Western assistance when it is released next week, Bush administration officials said. Rather, they said, the report will provide the most detailed analysis to date of the problems besetting the Soviet economy and recommend ways in which technical assistance can be provided to the Soviets. A senior Treasury Department official, speaking on condition his name not be used, said Thursday that the report should ``provide the most comprehensive and timely assessment that has been seen on the Soviet economy.'' But the official said he did not expect the document to support any push for large amounts of Western aid until the Soviets make greater strides toward a market-based economy. The report, which is expected to be released Dec. 20, was ordered by President Bush and the leaders of Japan, Germany, Britain, France, Italy and Canada last July in Houston during the annual economic summit meeting of the world's seven largest industrial countries. The study has been conducted by the International Monetary Fund and its sister lending organization, the World Bank, along with the Paris-based Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development and the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, a lending agency created this year to promote economic development in Eastern Europe. The study represented a way at the Houston summit to reach a compromise between the demands of the French and Germans for an immediate $15 billion Western aid package and resistance to direct economic aid by Bush and the other summit leaders. Bush announced Wednesday that he was granting the Soviet Union up to $1.3 billion in federal loan guarantees for the purchase of American food and manufactured goods. He also promised to provide emergency medical supplies to the Soviets and dispatch a team of U.S. experts to provide technical advice on ways to unclog the Soviet food distribution system. While Bush's announcement represented the biggest package the administration has been willing to come up with so far, it stopped far short of the hefty direct financial assistance that some European countries, notably Germany, are providing to the Soviets. The $1.3 billion in credit guarantees is not a direct expenditure by the U.S. government. Instead, the government is promising to stand behind the loans that commercial banks make to the Soviets to finance the purchase of American farm and manufactured products. As part of the aid package, Bush also directed Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady to present a proposal to the IMF and the World Bank to grant the Soviets the status of a ``special associate'' at the two giant multinational lending institutions. That designation falls far short of the full membership the Soviets covet. Only full members of the IMF and the World Bank qualify for the billions of dollars in loans the two institutions make each year. But the administration argued that the designation of ``special associate'' would serve as an important way-station for the Soviets and did not preclude their admission as full members of the two organizations later. In the meantime, the initial ties with the IMF and the World Bank would allow the Soviets to tap the considerable expertise the two agencies have in a variety of financial areas such as how to establish a stable currency system. ``There is a tremendous experience and education gap and we hope this will fill that gap,'' the Treasury official said. While the initial reaction among other Western countries has been favorable to the U.S. proposals, the Treasury official said more consultations would be necessary before putting the plan into operation. But he indicated the details should be wrapped up fairly quickly, possibly at an expected meeting in January of Brady and finance ministers from the six other major industrialized countries.

DOC.HEAD: Deal Struck to Send First American Cosmonaut Into Space
DOC.TEXT: Expect to read one day soon that a U.S. company will pay millions of dollars to the Soviet Union for the privilege of having an American ride to the space station Mir. The deal has been made, say two officials of Space Commerce Corp. in Houston, which markets Soviet space services in the United States. But they won't identify the company, or how much was paid, or why. The contract and its purpose - and the name of the American cosmonaut-to-be - wasn't supposed to be revealed until January. But the weekly newspaper Space News printed sketchy details Monday. Space News said only that the unknown company's cost will be more than the $12 million paid by the Tokyo Broadcasting Service to the Glavkosmos space agency for Japanese journalist Toyohiro Akiyama's ride. ``We executed a contract with NPO Energia, which is the manned part of the Soviet space program,'' said Art Dula, one of the Space Commerce Corp. officials. But, he said, the contract forbids him from saying any more. The Soviets - for a hefty price - have transported passengers of a variety of nationalities to their space station for stays of varying duration. They have included a Frenchman, a Cuban, an East German, and Japan's Akiyama. But there's never been an American. Dula's associate, Bill Wirin of Colorado Springs, Colo., said Space Commerce Corp. signed the deal in Moscow on Nov. 30. ``Our company policy is that we never discuss what we are doing without approval from our partners,'' he said. Wirin called the contract ``another sign of the warming relationship between the Soviets and the United States on a commercial basis, at a time when the U.S. is talking about giving them food.'' Wirin, like Dula, said he'd like to say more. But he referred calls to Brown, Nelson and Associates, a Houston public relations company. ``This company has a big announcement to make, but the plan was to make that announcement in January,'' said Guy Brown, one of the principals in the company. ``The client doesn't want to be disclosed by name. It's an American company. I'd like to disclose more, but I'm under a restriction from them,'' he said. Brown said the unidentified company would select the American cosmonaut. ``One check has passed hands, probably earnest money,'' Brown said. ``It's pretty much a fait accompli.''

DOC.HEAD: Coppola's Long-Awaited `Godfather III' Goes Before the Critics
LaserPhoto LA1
DOC.TEXT: It's coming out over budget, behind schedule and 16 years after its predecessor, but Paramount executives are betting ``The Godfather Part III'' will be a movie audiences can't refuse. After a frantic month of round-the-clock editing and polishing, the final film in Francis Ford Coppola's Mafia trilogy was unveiled Wednesday to critics and movie theater owners in New York, San Francisco, Los Angeles and other key markets across the country. The response was mixed. Disappointment ran higher among New York viewers, while those who watched in Los Angeles applauded. The movie will open on Christmas Day on 1,800 screens in the United States and Canada. It originally was scheduled for a Thanksgiving release, but was moved back because of production delays. For a while, it was uncertain whether ``Godfather III'' would be released at all this year. Paramount Pictures, gunning for the lucrative holiday market, decided to rush it out at the end of the year after Chairman Frank Mancuso and other executives saw a rough cut in October. ``Without question, this is the one everybody's talking about,'' said John Krier, president of Exhibitor Relations Co. Inc. ``Ever since `Dick Tracy,' all the talk has been about `Godfather.''' With preview screenings held this week, the movie qualifies for this year's award consideration from the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences and Los Angeles Film Critics Association. The $58 million film - triple the industry's average cost - was burdened with problems throughout production. Real-life lovers Al Pacino and Diane Keaton, reprising their roles as Michael and Kay Corleone, split up during the filming. Rising star Winona Ryder (``Edward Scissorhands'') was unable to co-star as Michael's love-struck daughter because of exhaustion. She was replaced at the last minute by Coppola's daughter Sofia, who had never had a major film role before. The first two ``Godfather'' films are considered masterpieces of American cinema and either made or solidified the careers of some of today's leading actors, including Pacino, Keaton, Robert De Niro, James Caan, Robert Duvall and Talia Shire. The first ``Godfather'' made $133.7 million in 1972 and its 1974 sequel had ticket sales of $45.5 million. Both films won best picture and screenplay Oscars; Marlon Brando won the Academy Award for best actor in the first installment; and Coppola (for directing) and Robert De Niro (supporting actor) won Oscars for the second. In the latest sequel, set in 1979, Michael Corleone attempts to bury his gangland roots but realizes, ``Just when I thought I was out, they pull me back in.'' Despite a $100 million gift to the Catholic Church and induction into an honorary church order, Michael soon finds himself plotting Vatican politics and Sicilian executions. In a climactic scene filmed during a performance of the opera ``Cavalleria Rusticana'' at Italy's historic Teatro Massimo opera house, Coppola intercuts between the melodious performance and grisly murders. Reviewers in New York were largely critical of ``Godfather III,'' complaining that at two hours and 42 minutes it was too long and that it lacked a hard edge and keen focus. Its ending, meant to evoke feelings of tragedy, was greeted with laughter. But Los Angeles critics applauded robustly as the final credits rolled. Movie exhibitors who saw a separate screening generally expressed satisfaction. ``The consensus is it's a very satisfying sequel to the two previous `Godfathers,''' said Dan Harkins of Harkins Amusement Enterprises, which will show the film in Arizona theaters. ``But I'm not sure it's as brilliant as the first one.'' Paramount, which has had an up-and-down year at the box office, is counting on ``Godfather III'' to deliver a hefty share of holiday ticket sales. Other recent films by Coppola, including ``Tucker: The Man and His Dream'' and ``One From the Heart,'' were flops. Such 1990 Paramount releases as ``Another 48 HRS.'' and ``The Two Jakes'' also performed badly, but Paramount's ``Ghost'' has been the year's biggest moneymaker, collecting more than $200 million to date.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Up, Stocks Down Slightly in Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: Prices fell moderately on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Friday while the dollar firmed against the Japanese yen. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average shed 293.47 points, or 1.19 percent, to settle at 24,349.50 points by the close of trading at 3 p.m. (1 a.m. EST). The dollar settled at 131.87 yen, up .57 yen from Thursday's close. The currency opened at 132.09 yen and ranged between 131.82 yen and 132.15 yen. In bond dealings, the price of benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds was 87.61, down from Thursday's close of 87.82. The yield was 7.145 percent, compared with 7.100 percent Thursday. Traders described the decline in stock prices as a correction after a gain over the past seven trading days of 2,780.36 points, or 12.7 percent, in the Nikkei index, the Tokyo market's main barometer. Thursday's trading brought the index above 24,000 points for the first time in nearly six weeks. ``Yesterday, it went up too much,'' said Amy Yip, manager of sales for Baring Securities. Traders earlier attributed the recent bullish market to optimism about the possibility of averting war in the Middle East. Lower crude oil prices and interest rates have also encouraged investors. The correction Friday might also prevent the market from becoming too ``tired'' to put on a strong rally toward the end of the year, Yip said. Weakness in Friday's stock, currency and bond markets also reflected some returning fears that the gulf crisis will not be as easy to solve as market players hoped at the beginning of the week, she said. Action on the currency market is ``very quiet,'' said Minori Takeuchi in the Chemical Bank currency dealing department. ``Market players are sidelined,'' she said, because of the upcoming holiday season, and because market factors are ``mixed.'' Buyers are shying away from the dollar, fearing that it will weaken because of the lagging U.S. economy, while renewed fears of war in the Middle East have dimmed the attractiveness of the yen, she said.

DOC.HEAD: President Bush Lights National Christmas Tree
DOC.TEXT: President Bush lit the national Christmas tree with a special welcome for the recently returned hostages and a prayer for those still in the Persian Gulf area. ``We feel pride thinking of our young men and women standing strong in the harsh distant deserts and on the waters of the Persian Gulf,'' the president said. ``And we think of their parents and their loved ones ... and we join them in praying for their safe return.'' The president was joined at Thursday's celebration around the 35-foot blue spruce by his wife Barbara and several Bush grandchildren. Five of the seven newly released hostages who met with Bush earlier in the day also attended. ``As we gather here, we're doing what generations before us have done, watching our national Christmas tree become a brilliant symbol of hope, of peace and of compassion for all the world,'' the president said as he illuminated the tree. The National Park Service estimated that about 15,000 people watched the ceremony on an unusually warm evening in the capital. The national Christmas tree is a living tree transplanted to its permanent spot in the Ellipse in 1978. The theme for this year's ``Pageant of Peace'' national Christmas tree celebration is discovery. Four thousand lights decorate the tree and a white star shines from the top. Surrounding the tree are 57 smaller trees representing each state and territory, a tradition since 1981. For the first time this year, the trees were grown on land from a reclaimed mine in an effort by the Park Service to demonstrate the use of recycled land. Presidents have been lighting the nation's tree in the Ellipse just south of the White House every year except two since Calvin Coolidge first threw the switch in 1923. In 1979, President Carter ordered that the tree remain dark to honor Americans hostages being held in Iran. In 1980, the tree was lighted for only 417 seconds - one second for each day the hostages had been in captivity.

DOC.HEAD: USA Today Considering Baseball Weekly
DOC.TEXT: USA Today officials are considering publishing a weekly tabloid about baseball. The decision will come by the end of the year, Tom Curley, president and chief operating officer of USA Today, said Thursday. He said a task force is looking into the possibility of such a publication, with the tentative title USA Today Baseball Weekly. If the company decides to proceed with the publication, it would be launched during spring training, preceding the 1991 baseball season. The tabloid would provide more statistics than can be published in the regular sports section of the five-day-a-week national newspaper, Curley said. ``It's a bit too soon to tell'' what else might be in the paper, Curley said. ``There is an opportunity to provide more depth in all sorts of basic sports coverage, from viewing to aarticipating to statistics,'' he said. James Goss, a newspaper business analyst at the New York investment firm of Dustin Phelps, said sports coverage is considered one of USA Today's strong points and the weekly would provide ``a way to get some more mileage out of what they are putting together anyway for the newspaper.'' Goss said also that The National, the New York-based daily sports paper launched in a number of markets beginning last January, might be cutting into USA Today markets and this could be a factor in the decision. Curley, however, said, ``That's old news by now.'' He said the tabloid, if it is launched, might provide USA Today with ``a sixth day, in effect.'' Executives at The National could not be reached immediately. The task force will be headed by Thomas J. Farrell, executive vice president and general manager for USA Today, assisted by Gene Policinski, the newspaper's managing editor for sports. ``Seeing the reaction to our daily newspaper, there seems to be a strong demand for more statistical information regarding the nation's pastime,'' Farrell said. ``In looking at USA Today Baseball Weekly, we'd like to become to USA Today's sports section what Barron's is to The Wall Street Journal.'' Policinski said, ``We feel there is a real market in the hard-core baseball fan for to satisfy an appetite for statistics that has not been filled.'' USA Today, published by Gannett Inc., says it has a circulation of some 1.8 million in the United States. It also has an international edition.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Yakov Smirnoff, the Soviet-born comedian who built his career on jokes about his homeland, is serious about doing what he can to ease the food shortage gripping the Soviet Union. Smirnoff joined with members of the CARE charity organization Thursday in putting together a package of tuna fish, chicken, soap and other necessities for Soviet people. The naturalized American citizen said that although his homeland has more freedom now than when he left in 1978, the economy has declined. ``The Soviet people are inspired by the freedoms they are getting, but unfortunately, the food shortages have gotten worse,'' Smirnoff said. ``We used to stay in lines all the time. Now they don't because there's no food.'' --- NEW YORK (AP) - Former ballerina Shenikwa Dawn Nowlin said she was overwhelmed with pain and often considered killing herself after she was paralyzed in a car crash involving former Yankee infielder Andre Robertson. ``I became almost irrational,'' Nowlin, now a Dallas prosecutor, testified in state Supreme Court on Thursday. ``I was afraid I was going to die. Then I was afraid someone was trying to kill me. ... it was horrible. ``I thought many times about killing myself,'' she said as she fought back tears. Nowlin, 31, has filed a $20 million lawsuit against New York City, saying the car she was riding in on Aug. 18, 1983, crashed on the Henry Hudson Parkway because a sign warning of a sharp curve was improperly placed. Robertson, who was driving the car, is named as a defendant in the lawsuit. The two testified separately Friday that the warning sign was posted in the middle of the curve. ``Where I live they usually give you some warning to stop a car,'' said Robertson who now lives in Orange, Texas. ---
DOC.NOTE: Eds: The WORx is cq, 2nd graf
DOC.TEXT: Actor Dudley Moore, best known as the free-spending millionaire in the 1981 movie ``Arthur,'' has gone on another spending spree, to benefit the poor and homeless. On Thursday, Moore dropped by The WORx, a gift shop owned by the Venice Family Clinic, of which Moore is a member of the board of directors. The shop's proceeds go to help pay for medical services for poor and homeless people. During his visit, Moore picked up a picture frame with images of cats on it, catnip and a wooden cow. ``Everything I bought has animals on it,'' he said. ``I have an obsession, it seems.'' --- AUSTIN, Texas (AP) - A country club, golf course and recording studio owned by Willie Nelson are going on the auction block two days after Christmas to help pay $16.7 million in back taxes the country music star owes. Internal Revenue Service spokeswoman Sally Sassen said it is likely that other Nelson property will go on sale after the first of the year. The IRS confiscated property Nelson owns in Colorado, Washington and Alabama last month. Nelson, 57, has said his tax problems were caused by a former manager's poor handling of his finances. Friends and fans have raised several thousand dollars on Nelson's behalf in recent weeks. Earlier this month more than 300 people paid $10 each to attend a benefit dance at the Broken Spoke, a South Austin nightclub where Nelson often performed in the 1960s. --- CHARLESTON, W.Va. (AP) - Outgoing Education Secretary Lauro Cavazos will deliver the commencement speech to 300 students at West Virginia State College on Saturday, his last day on the job. Cavazos, 63, the first Hispanic-American Cabinet secretary, was fired by President Bush, who gave him until the end of the month to quit, according to White House sources who insisted upon anonymity. Cavazos resigned Wednesday. College spokesman David Hall said Thursday there were no plans to cancel the speech. ``We've had this planned for over a year now,'' he said. ``We're in touch with him and he's going to continue to fulfill his obligations.''

DOC.HEAD: EC To Launch Political And Monetary Union, Consider $2.4 Billion For Soviets
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Lead expected after meeting begins at 5 a.m. EST.
DOC.TEXT: European Community leaders gathered today for a summit aimed at launching the trading bloc on the road to a federated Europe. Britain, the prime objector, is in a more conciliatory mood since the resignation of Margaret Thatcher. The 12 leaders beginning their two-day meeting today in the flag-bedecked Italian Parliament also will consider granting a $2.4 billion aid package to the Soviet Union and increased help to other East European countries. The Europeans received a new exhortation from President Bush to stand firm on the Persian Gulf crisis. In a letter Thursday to Italian Premier Giulio Andreotti, current holder of the rotating summit chairmanship, Bush said Iraq's blanket release of foreign hostages should not lessen pressure on Iraq to pull out of Kuwait. ``We must continue to maintain a very rigid attitude,'' Bush said, according to Italian officials. British Prime Minister John Major, who succeeded Mrs. Thatcher Nov. 28 and is virtually unknown to the other summiteers, joined them at the opera for a performance of ``Tosca'' on Thursday night. Major, 47, was holding separate prior talks with Andreotti, Dutch Prime Minister Ruud Lubbers and German Chancellor Helmut Kohl. Kohl and French President Francois Mitterrand are pressing for economic union and a single currency, perhaps by the year 2000, and for a form of political union that would strip member nations of many sovereign powers. Major, keen to avoid a repeat of the Britain-versus-the-rest showdown that helped topple Mrs. Thatcher after the summit in Rome in October, was optimistic despite Britain's continued opposition to key unity proposals, his aides said. ``We see ways in which significant progress can be made,'' a senior British source said Thursday night. ``But there are areas where we will reaffirm our positions quite clearly, including our opposition to having a single currency imposed upon us,'' he said, speaking on condition of anonymity. The European Parliament in Strasbourg, France, on Thursday urged the 12 EC heads of state to work on restarting talks to liberalize world trade. The global trade negotiations broke down in Brussels last week, in part due to the EC's refusal to cut farm subsidies enough to satisfy the United States. The talks are to resume at a lower level next month in Geneva. Soviet aid, which topped the agenda of this summit, was given fresh impetus by the U.S. decision Wednesday to give the Soviet Union $1 billion in loan guarantees to buy American farm products and manufactured goods. Andreotti's spokesman, Pio Mastrobuoni, said he was confident of agreement, despite some arguments that the Soviet Union needs help in managing its huge resources, including distributing its harvest, rather than handouts and loans it will have trouble repaying. On financial union, Andreotti cornered Mrs. Thatcher at the October summit by getting the others to agree to establish a single central banking system - the prelude to one currency - by January 1994. Mrs. Thatcher objected loudly. In a change of tone, Major planned to argue the British alternative of a European currency that would circulate alongside the 12 existing currencies, without ruling out an eventual sole currency. On political union, Britain has shifted toward French and German proposals for giving the EC a formal role in security. And aides said Major was confident Britain will not be alone in opposing other proposals that would give the community far-reaching powers over issues ranging from health, social policy and education to taxation and transport. The EC nations are Italy, France, Britain, Ireland, Spain, Portugal, Belgium, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, Greece, Denmark and Germany.

DOC.HEAD: Boschwitz Admits Interest in Agriculture Post
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Rudy Boschwitz has ruled out several administration jobs but says he has found one post he'd like. The only trouble is it isn't vacant. The Minnesota Republican, who lost to Democrat Paul Wellstone in the November election, said Thursday he would be interested in becoming secretary of agriculture should Clayton Yeutter leave that position. ``I might very well consider that,'' Boschwitz said in a session with reporters from his home state. Boschwitz said the high point of his 12-year Senate career was his work on farm issues. Yeutter has denied rumors that he plans to return to private business now that the five-year farm bill has been completed and international trade talks have collapsed. Boschwitz said he planned to call Yeutter to tell him he was not trying to take over the job. ``I don't want people to feel I'm breathing down their neck,'' Boschwitz said. ``I don't expect him to step down.'' Boschwitz met with President Bush on Tuesday to talk about his future plans. Bush has some major vacancies to fill, but Boschwitz said he would not be a candidate for any of them. Boschwitz said he was not qualified to be education secretary and might not be confirmed by the Senate as labor secretary. The chairmanship of the Republican National Committee also is open, but Boschwitz said that slot did not interest him.
DOC.HEAD: AIDS-Infected Cells May Poison Brain, Causing Mental Confusion, Study Says
DOC.TEXT: New laboratory studies suggest that some types of cells infected with the AIDS virus may release a poison that disrupts thinking processes and causes the mental decline seen in 70 percent of AIDS patients. ``We've found that one class of cells when infected (with the AIDS virus) will release a toxin that can disrupt the nervous system,'' said Dr. Dana Giulian, a researcher at the Baylor College of Medicine in Houston. A research paper on the discovery is to be published today in the journal Science. In an interview, Giulian said test tube experiments showed that monocytes, an immune system cell in the blood, will secrete poison molecules when infected with the human immunodeficiency virus, or HIV, which causes AIDS. When these molecules were exposed to neurons, it would cause the nerve cells to either die or stop functioning, Giulian said. This suggests, said the researcher, that similar cells in the brain, called macrophages, could react the same way when infected by HIV. Guilian said the finding must be confirmed by further research. Physicians and scientists have long been puzzled as to why AIDS patients develop mental decline. The toxin secreted by the infected cells could be the answer. Giulian said the next job is to identify the secreted molecule that is toxic to the brain. This, he said, may be a difficult job. Giulian's coauthors of the Science report were Ken Vaca and Christine A. Noonan, also of Baylor. Science is the journal of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.
DOC.HEAD: Movie Association Official Top Paid Lobbyist in Washington
DOC.TEXT: Fulltime top executives at trade and professional associations that lobby in Washington earned an average of $202,767 last year, a magazine reported. Topping the list was Jack Valenti of the Motion Picture Association at $672,590, the magazine National Journal said Thursday. Like many other executives in the survey, he is chief Washington lobbyist for the people he represents. The magazine said its survey was based primarily on Internal Revenue Service records. It said the figures given excluded benefits and expense allowances. They showed that the average top salary was $146,659 at labor unions, $133,336 at research organizations and $102,254 at interest groups, those not representing a specific industry. Ranking second to Valenti in pay among trade and professional association officials was James H. Sammons, executive vice president of the American Medical Association, who earned $623,167. He has since been replaced by James S. Todd, who makes $411,000. Jason S. Berman, president of the Recording Industry Association of America, was third at $551,731. The highest paid labor executive was William J. McCarthy, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, at $283,145. Among executives of research organizations, Edwin J. Feulner Jr., president of the Heritage Foundation, was in first place at $258,721. Horace Deets, executive director of the American Association of Retired Persons, was the highest paid among representatives of interest groups, earning $220,000.

DOC.HEAD: OPEC Shows No Sign of Reducing Oil Target Prices
With PM-Gulf-Former Hostages, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Despite the surge in oil prices since Iraq invaded Kuwait, OPEC isn't about to give up its efforts to secure high revenues. ``All the countries need money now,'' OPEC President Sadek Boussena said Thursday at the end of the cartel's winter strategy session. During the two-day meeting, the ministers of the 13-nation Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries agreed to continue pumping extra oil to meet any shortfall during the Persian Gulf crisis. But Saudi Arabia and the other OPEC members also agreed to cut production once the crisis ends. In doing so, officials hope to avoid a sharp drop in prices that would hurt their struggling economies. Following the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, OPEC agreed to suspend its quota system and increase pumping to make up for 4 million barrels of Iraqi and Kuwaiti crude kept off the international market by a U.N. embargo. Current OPEC production is around 23 million barrels a day and unlikely to go much higher. ``We are producing more or less at the maximum level,'' said Boussena. Oil prices rallied Thursday, moving up about $1 per barrel to $26.42 on the New York Mercantile Exchange, as traders renewed their focus on the possibility of war in the gulf. Oil was around $20 a barrel just before the crisis. Higher prices during the crisis have brought millions of dollars into the coffers of oil producers. Some OPEC members, such as Algeria, Nigeria and Ecuador, badly need the money to support their impoverished economies. Saudi Arabia, OPEC's largest oil producer, has contributed much of its windfall to nations suffering from the economic impact of the gulf crisis. Some of the money has also been used to help pay for the U.S.-led multinational force stationed on Saudi soil. Boussena, who is Algeria's mines minister, hinted the cartel might consider lifting its target price above $21 a barrel after the crisis. Last July, for the first time since 1986, the ministers raised the benchmark price from $19 a barrel. ``I am certain people need more money. It is clear. It is stated by all of us,'' said Boussena. After Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, oil prices for a time topped $40 on fears that an outbreak of war in the gulf could cut off crude oil supplies. Analysts say OPEC's aggressive production during the gulf crisis could lead to a glut on the market next year - and plunging prices. Peter Bogin, associate director for oil markets at Cambridge Energy Research Associates in Paris, predicted that at winter's end, crude prices could slide below $20 a barrel. Demand for crude has eased because of the slumping American economy and warmer-than-expected weather in the United States and other consuming nations. Moreover, industrialized nations have been filling their storage tanks to prepare for possible war and an oil cut off in the Gulf. OPEC members are: Algeria, Ecuador, Gabon, Indonesia, Iran, Iraq, Kuwait, Libya, Nigeria, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates and Venezuela.

DOC.HEAD: Police Suspect Two Women in Possible Serial Killings in Florida
DOC.TEXT: Investigators are considering the unusual possibility that two female serial killers are responsible for the shooting deaths of eight middle-aged male motorists and disappearances of two others in the past year. Authorities are reluctant to say publicly the deaths are related. But they did distribute composite drawings of two women wanted for questioning. All the known victims were white, roughly between the ages of 40 and 60. All were shot, some repeatedly. Some were stripped naked and robbed, their bodies dumped along rural roads. One victim's body was found in southern Georgia, the rest in various places around the northern half of Florida. The first body was found a year ago Thursday. Two missing men also may be part of the bloody chain. Their abandoned cars have been recovered. One vehicle, belonging to a part-time missionary, had traces of blood in it. The suspects last were seen leaving an accident involving the missionary's car on the Fourth of July. ``We're not 100 percent sure all the homicides are related,'' said Capt. Steve Binegar of the Marion County Sheriff's Department, the lead investigator. ``The main thing that links them together are the profiles of the victims: They are all similar,'' he said. Serial killers are ``certainly a possibility we can't discount.'' ``Robbery appears to be part of the motive. But some of the bodies were nude, leading to all kinds of conjecture,'' Binegar said. ``I'll say this: It doesn't appear that they (the killer or killers) would be able to support themselves with the money stolen.'' If the killings are related and the killers are women, the criminals would be highly unusual, sociologists and psychologists say. Female serial killers are extremely rare. ``Women who kill usually do so with people they know,'' said Richard Hollinger, a University of Florida sociology professor. Reconstructed police renderings of the suspects show an oval-faced, stringy-haired blonde and a chubby, round-faced, dark-complexioned woman wearing a baseball-type cap. The women were seen leaving an accident scene July 4 on a county road near Orange Springs, 35 miles east of Gainesville, not far from Interstate 75. Their car evidently missed a curve, ran through a fence and tore down a gate. The women abandoned the car. It later was traced to the missing missionary, Peter Siems, 65, of Jupiter. Witnesses described the blonde woman as about 5-foot-8, 25 to 30 years old, wearing blue jeans and a white T-shirt, with a tattoo on her right arm, possibly in the shape of a heart. The other woman was described as about 5-foot-4, weighing 175 to 200 pounds and wearing a cap or a hat. A pattern in the killings emerged slowly because the victims' bodies were discovered in widely scattered areas. The first victim found was Richard Mallory, who owned an electronics repair shop in Clearwater. His body was found under a scrap of carpet near Interstate 95, north of Daytona Beach. Three victims were found near Ocala in Marion County, another in neighboring Citrus County, in northern central Florida. Another victim was found in June in Pasco County, about 20 miles north of Tampa. Another was discovered in May in Adel, Ga., along Interstate 75 about 40 miles north of the Florida line. The latest victim added to the list of possibly connected slayings is Gino Antonio, 60, of Cocoa. Hunters found his body last month in the Dixie County woods near Cross City, about 120 miles north of St. Petersburg. He was nude except for socks. Also, a car belonging to a missing Kennedy Space Center engineer was found in a shopping center near Orlando International Airport in September. Binegar said no formal investigative team has been formed, but his office is coordinating information gathered from other police agencies and sending it to the FBI.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Down, Dollar Up in Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: Prices were down slightly on the Tokyo Stock Exchange today, while year-end demand for dollars pushed the United States currency up against the Japanese yen. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average shed 293.47 points, or 1.19 percent, to settle at 24,349.50 points by the 3 p.m. (1 a.m. EST) close. Estimated volume on the first section was heavy, with 800 million shares trading hands. Today's fall combined a rush of year-end transactions with ``unwinding selling from arbitrage trading'' after the surges of the last seven trading days, said Satoshi Hirasawa, an analyst for Kokusai Securities. Volume surged in the morning before special quotations were issued by the Tokyo Stock Exchange this morning for futures and options for December delivery, traders said. Traders also said the market is positioning itself for the traditional December rally. ``Gradually the market is taking on a much better tone. But it could turn at any point (if) a sudden weakness of the yen'' triggers profit-taking on long positions, said Darrel Whitten, an analyst at Prudential Bache Securities. The Bank of Japan has not yet seen enough of a slowdown in the economy to bring interest rates down considerably, and is still fighting the inflationary effects of high oil prices and the labor shortage, he said. High interest rates probably will continue to firm the yen against the dollar until the end of the year, and interest rates will continue to lead stock market action, he said. On currency markets, ``nothing much is happening,'' said Gary Lee, Citibank's chief currency dealer. The dollar settled at 131.87 yen, up .57 yen from Thursday's close. The currency opened at 132.09 yen, and trading ranged between 131.82 yen and 132.15 yen. Trading by companies that are closing their books or have a special need of dollars, such as oil companies facing high-priced oil supplies, is helping keep the dollar above 130 yen despite falling interest rates and continued weakness in the United States economy, he said. In bond dealings, the price of benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds was 87.61 at 3 p.m., down from Thursday's close of 87.82. Their yield was 7.145 percent, compared with 7.100 percent Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Job Opportunities for 1991 College Grads Slightly Under 1990
DOC.TEXT: Most college graduates should have a slightly harder time landing a job in 1991 than their counterparts did this year, according to an annual survey of the nation's businesses. But engineers will be in demand, and people with master's degrees will be hired at a 25 percent higher rate than 1990, according to the 45th annual Lindquist-Endicott Report released Thursday. The report found that businesses plan to hire 1 percent fewer graduates overall because of concerns over the recession, inflation, the federal budget deficit and the Persian Gulf crisis. The report also found that a job applicant's lack of knowledge about the company is the biggest ``turnoff'' for recruiters. ``The market is going to be more competitive. The students are going to have to work harder and be more creative and imaginative, but the jobs are going to be there. They're just going to be more difficult to uncover,'' said Victor R. Lindquist, director of placement at Northwestern University. Accountants, teachers and health care professionals will be in great demand in a few years, Lindquist said at a news conference. The highest average starting salary - $43,200 - will go to job applicants with MBA degrees, the report said. Employers plan to increase starting salaries at a rate averaging 4.4 percent, the same as last year's increase but below the yearly inflation rate, the report said. Lindquist said 61 percent of the 320 surveyed companies, covering a wide range of industries, expect business to stay the same or decline. He said 39 percent believe business will improve. Also, nearly one-third of the companies did worse in 1990 than in 1989, he indicated. ``Some grads will be working in jobs with less status, salary or prestige, but I've always found that it's still better to be in the ballpark than out in left field,'' Lindquist said.

DOC.HEAD: General Assembly Calls For Peace Conference, Halt to Aid to Israel
With PM-Gulf-Freed Hostages, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The General Assembly has urged member nations to halt all aid to Israel over its occupation of Arab territories and called anew for a peace conference on the Palestinian issue. The United States voted against the measures Thursday night after its representative Jack Stein complained to the assembly that ``such divisive language does not promote the cause of peace.'' The assembly adopted the measures by wide margins. The United States has been struggling to remove language endorsing a Mideast peace conference from a draft resolution of the more influential U.N. Security Council, fearing it would look like a concession to Iraq. Israel, a traditional U.S. ally, vehemently opposes any such conference. A U.S. veto of the proposal could jeopardize the tenuous Arab coalition the United States has aligned against Iraq, which has championed the Palestinian call for a homeland since it invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. A Security Council vote on the resolution has been put off six times in a week. Another one is tentatively planned for Monday. Cuban Ambassador Ricardo Alarcon, in rallying the assembly to endorse a peace conference, declared, ``There is a need for a comprehensive peace in the Middle East based on the withdrawal of Israeli from the occupied territories.'' The resolution endorsing a peace conference was adopted 99 to 19 with 32 abstentions. Israel, the United States and several European nations were among those voting against it. The resolution also condemned ``Israel's aggression'' against the Palestinians and declared that U.S. military and economic aid has ``encouraged Israel to pursue its aggressive and expansionist policies'' in the occupied lands. It also declared that strategic U.S.-Israeli cooperation has ``had adverse effects on efforts for the establishment of a comprehensive, just and lasting peace in the Middle East.'' Stein protested that ``the United States remains firmly supportive of efforts to achieve a comprehensive peace,'' but added that ``the shape of a final settlement cannot be dictated by any party in advance.'' The General Assembly adopted another resolution condemning Israeli occupation and called on member states ``to put an end to the flow to Israel of any military, economic, financial and technological aid.'' Stein said a call to halt aid to Israel was ``unacceptable'' and objected to the ``critical reference to the United States'' in the clause on U.S.-Israeli cooperation. The assembly also passed resolutions declaring Israeli administration of Jerusalem ``illegal'' and calling for greater cooperation between the United Nations and the Arab League. Israel seized the Gaza Strip from Egypt and the West Bank, including east Jerusalem, from Jordan in the 1967 Middle East war.

DOC.HEAD: Mystery Surrounds Former East German Foreign Trade Boss
DOC.TEXT: A mysterious former East German official, whose alleged gun running and other business deals kept the Communist government supplied with Western cash, is the central figure in a high-level probe in newly unified Germany. Alexander Schalck-Golodkowski, the former East German boss of foreign trade, fled to the West when the hard-line regime collapsed a year ago. His activities are now making headlines because of allegations that the new government gave him refuge. Various German news reports have described him as living in a Bavarian villa or visiting a CIA debriefing center in the United States. Schalck reportedly held the rank of lieutenant general in the East German secret police, in addition to his foreign trade post, before finding refuge in the West. Berlin prosecutors, acting on tips from eastern investigators, launched an investigation of Schalck on suspicion of corruption and gun running. But they are having difficulty finding any incriminating documents. Seventy police officers searched 15 locations around Germany on Monday for evidence that could link Schalck to $162 million missing from East German coffers. Authorities said they failed to uncover information about foreign bank accounts rumored to have been set up by Schalck in Switzerland. As chief of East Germany's foreign trade, Schalck supervised sales of export goods that produced Western revenues sorely needed by the Communist government. He is suspected of using a household goods factory near Rostock as a cover for exporting weapons to countries in South America, Africa and the Middle East. Another allegation is that Schalck helped former East German economic czar Guenther Mittag finance a new house with money generated from government business. Schalck's current whereabouts are unclear. Lutz Stavenhagen, the Bonn chancellery official in charge of German intelligence, told a news conference Wednesday that federal intelligence agents had questioned Schalck several times this year. However, Stavenhagen denied Schalck is living under protection of the intelligence agency and added: ``I don't know where he is.'' Citing unidentified sources, Stern magazine said Schalck went to the United States with Bonn's knowledge to provide information to the Central Intelligence Agency. But Schalck's lawyer, Peter Danckert, said in a television interview Wednesday that his client was at a villa in Bavaria. Danckert also rejected allegations of wrongdoing against his client. The collapse of East Germany and its merger with West Germany on Oct. 3 did nothing to allay suspicions that Schalck retained control of a corrupt financial empire. There is also speculation that he was able to exploit his ties to officials in Bonn for his own benefit. Stern this week described a so-called ``Bonn connection'' that allegedly arranged for Schalck to evade East German criminal charges during last year's political revolution. Stern said West German Interior Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble intervened when East German criminal police were closing in on Schalck last December. Schaeuble denied the magazine's allegations. As the East German government's envoy for business dealings with the West, Schalck met many of the top political players in Bonn. He disappeared while on an official visit to West Germany on Dec. 2, 1989. Four days later, he surfced in West Berlin where he turned himself over to police. Schalck remained in a West Berlin jail for one month until West German police set him free, denying an East German extradition request on the grounds he could not get a fair trial there. While other leading party officials sweated out the revolution in jail or under house arrest, Schalck soon found himself living in a villa on a lake near Munich. Schalck's phone number is unlisted, and he has not spoken to news reporters since the case began dominating German news reports a few weeks ago. After the downfall of East Germany's hard-line leaders in autumn 1989, reformist Communists targeted Schalck and other former top officials for corruption charges. The allegations were applauded by East Germans who were shocked by revelations about the handsome homes used by senior Communist party officials. Schalck was always listed among these officials.

DOC.HEAD: Prince Johannes von Thurn und Taxis Dies
DOC.TEXT: Prince Johannes von Thurn und Taxis, one of Europe's richest men, died today, a spokesman for a Munich hospital said. He was 64. The prince, whose accestors founded the German postal system nearly 500 years ago, had recently received a second heart transplant. Dietmar Schmidt, a spokesman for the Munich University hospital, said the prince had died of complications resulting from the second transplant. The prince's financial empire included huge amounts of land as well as breweries and art collections. Experts have valued his wealth at at least $1.3 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Rights Complaints Target Attorney General's Office
DOC.TEXT: The government's human rights commission says the top anti-drug agency has been the target of scores of complaints, and the panel is recommending firing and prosecuting agents accused of involvement in rights abuses. ``My government does not hide abuses,'' President Carlos Salinas de Gortari told reporters as he accepted the 400-page report Thursday from his National Human Rights Commission. He vowed to ``to continue fighting crime, eradicating (official) impunity and putting all efforts toward the most strict respect for human rights.'' The president noted that his government has banned prosecutions based on confessions, a step taken due to complaints that police routinely torture defendants into making false confessions. Commission President Jorge Carpizo said his agency had dealt with 1,343 complaints, ranging from murder and torture to unjust loss of housing. He said it has finished 397 cases since Salinas had inaugurated it on June 6. The report said the federal attorney general's office and the judicial police under its control were accused of 171 cases of rights violations, nearly three times as many as those filed against any other agency. Ten of the 33 recommendations for action issued by the commission also were directed against the federal police. No other agency received more than one. Many of the recommendations urged firing and prosecuting agents accused of involvement in human rights abuses. The Federal Judicial Police are Mexico's main narcotics-fighting agency and the primary partner of U.S. drug enforcement agents attempting to block the international flow of drugs. Salinas vowed that his fight against drug traffic ``has been unconditional and definitive. We will not permit this threat to remain against the society nor against the state. ``But at the same time, neither will we tolerate it becoming a pretext for injuring the rights, none of them, of people.'' On Sunday, the president ordered the attorney general's office to release an opposition party mayor who had been jailed since May on what the rights commission termed false drug charges. The president had also vowed to prosecute eight federal drug agents accused of involvement in the shooting deaths of six people earlier this month. Other leading targets of complaints were the prosecutor's offices in the capital and states, as well as the federal prison service. The report said illegal arrest was the most common complaint, followed by torture, homicide, abuse of authority, threats, injuries and false accusation. From the reports, ``it can be deduced that Mexico has problems in the complete observance of human rights, which it could not hide if it wanted to,'' Carpizo said. But he added that ``if the problems are recognized, it is because there is political will to resolve them, and they are going to be resolved ... Not to do it ... would be suicide.''

DOC.HEAD: Judge to Rule on Whether Comatose Woman's Feeding Tube Can Be Removed
With PM-Suicide Device, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Ruling expected 3 p.m. EST
DOC.TEXT: The parents of a woman who has been comatose for seven years awaited a ruling today on whether the feeding tube keeping her alive should be removed. Nancy Cruzan's father, Joe, said late Thursday he planned to be with his daughter when Probate Judge Charles E. Teel Jr. announced his decision this afternoon. ``You know, it's strange. I don't feel very emotional,'' he said. ``I just kind of feel burned out.'' Ms. Cruzan, 33, has been in a coma since suffering severe brain damage in a 1983 traffic accident. Doctors have said her condition is irreversible, and her parents have argued since 1987 that she should be allowed to die. The U.S. Supreme Court ruled last June that Ms. Cruzan could be permitted to die, but only if ``clear and convincing evidence'' proved that would be what she wanted. Several of Ms. Cruzan's former co-workers since have testified that she told them she wouldn't want to be kept alive in a vegetative state. He and his wife, Joyce, have said if the judge rejects their request to remove their daughter's feeding tube they will ask him to let them move her to another state where it would be allowed. Cruzan said Thursday that if the judge ruled in their favor he wasn't sure how soon he would ask workers at the Missouri Rehabilitation Center to remove the tube. State health officials have promised to abide by today's decision. Workers at the rehabilitation center had been preparing themselves emotionally for a decision in favor of removing the tube, said center spokeswoman Barbara Shoun. ``I would say months of soul searching on the part of the staff are coming to a head at this time,'' she said. Teel ruled in favor of disconnecting the tube in 1988, but his decision was overturned by the Missouri Supreme Court. After the U.S. Supreme Court's decision, the case was returned to Teel's court to determine if Ms. Cruzan really would want to be allowed to die. The woman has been in a vegetative state since the Jan. 11, 1983, accident, and lies in a bed, her body stiff and her hands bent like claws. She also suffers from seizures, vomiting, bleeding gums and contorted limbs. Doctors have said if she keeps receiving nourishment she could continue in that condition for another 40 years. If her feeding tube is disconnected, she would probably die in about two weeks, said Dr. Ronald Cranford, a Minneapolis neurologist who has examined her. ``It will be a peaceful death,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Slayer Of Three Women Dies In Virginia Electric Chair
LaserPhoto RM3 of Dec. 13
DOC.TEXT: A man convicted of killing three women in three states nodded to a sheriff who pursued him and smiled at a prison minister before he died in Virginia's electric chair. Buddy Earl Justus, 37, had no final words Thursday before he was executed at the State Peniteniary. He was pronounced dead shortly after 11 p.m. ``Be strong, you'll move on,'' the Rev. Russ Ford, a prison chaplain, told Justus as the inmate gave him a slight smile. After he was strapped in the oak electric chair, Justus nodded at Montgomery County Sheriff Louis E. Barber, who investigated the 1978 rape-slaying of Ida Mae Moses, 21, when she was nearly nine months pregnant. Barber said he has been haunted by the crime ever since. ``He was afforded a great deal more dignity than Ida Moses. At least he had his minister present,'' the sheriff said after watching the execution. Justus was convicted of raping and shooting Mrs. Moses three times in the head on Oct. 3, 1978. He also received death sentences for murdering Rosemary Jackson, 32, in Gwinnett County, Ga., and Stephanie Hawkins, 21, in Tampa, Fla., later that month. Justus was the 11th person to die in the electric chair since Virginia resumed executions in 1982. He was the 143rd person to be executed nationwide since the U.S. Supreme Court allowed states to revive the death penalty in 1976. Gov. L. Douglas Wilder rejected Justus' request for clemency a few hours before the execution. Justus' lawyer, John C. Copacino, had argued that the inmate suffered from brain damage. He also said Justus was abused as a child. Earlier Thursday, Justus apologized to his victims' families and urged that the death penalty be abolished.

DOC.HEAD: Souvenirs Of Slain Ecologist Hot Sellers During Murder Trial
With Brazil-Mendes Trial
DOC.TEXT: Souvenir hawkers are doing a lucrative business outside the courthouse of this remote Amazon jungle outpost, where ranchers are on trial in the slaying of ecologist Chico Mendes. A mere $600 fetches a 20-inch-by-28 inch oil painting of the chubby rain forest defender staring stern as Gen. Douglas MacArthur, as the Acre River meanders through the jungle into the sunset. Short on cash? No problem. Artist Jorge Rivasplata, who came all the way from Lima, Peru to sell the gem can cut a deal: $500 without the wood frame. ``Of course I'm really here in support of Chico Mendes,'' he said. ``But why not make some money while I'm at it?'' So goes the philosophy of many merchants in this sleepy Amazon town: cash in for as long as Brazil's most important trial of the decade lasts. The trial's objective is to decide who is responsible for the murder of Mendes on the night of Dec. 22, 1988. But some residents and traveling salesmen have other objectives: mainly making quick bucks off the hundreds of ecologists, politicians, journalists and officials that have flocked to this town to see the trial. Anything is fair game for the face of the slain rain forest defender and rubber tapper. He appears on buttons, lags, ashtrays, can openers, t-shirts, caps, and wooden cups. There are even Chico Mendes Christmas cards going for $3 apiece. ``How much?'' cried Ilzamar Mendes, widow of the slain ecologist and head of the Chico Mendes Foundation. ``I wouldn't even buy one at that price.'' Not many of the rubber tappers that live in this river town can. The exploitation proves irritating to some. Especially for those like Luiz Vieira de Souza, a 63-year-old tapper who traveled eight hours in a dugout canoe eating solely manioc root to get to Xapuri. ``This is crazy,'' bristled the leathery-skinned tapper, as he refused a bottle of mineral water selling for $1. ``I may have to leave early if my money runs out.'' Some profiteers are imaginative. One barrel-shaped elderly woman from Brazil's northern Atlantic coastal state of Bahia set up a stand in front of the town courthouse to sell shrimp stew. ``Shrimp in the Amazon?'' asked a visitor. The gentle, round woman called Isaura smiled. ``Yes sir, and just $2 per ladle,'' she said. Down the dusty brick and cobblestone street, Zamir Jose Teixeira was loading a four-foot-high chestnut tree into an ox-drawn cart. The buyer was counting a wad of bills under a banner that said `Progress in the Jungle.' Had Teixeira legally cut the trees? No one knew and Teixeira wasn't telling. Forest produce was a bit more reasonable if the buyer comparison shopped. A 2{-ounce box of powdered Guarana, a tart Amazon fruit used in its powdered form as a stimulant, was selling for the equivalent of $5. A plate of white rice, red beans, lettuce, tomatoes and heavily salted beef seemed reasonable at $4. ``Did I say 500 cruzeiros?'' asked the red-faced waitress with a giggle. ``I'm sorry, I meant 1,500.''

DOC.HEAD: Jury Rejects Insanity Defense, Convicts Shawcross
DOC.TEXT: The foreman of a jury that convicted a paroled child killer of slaying 10 women during a 22-month murder spree said jurors decided the man wasn't insane. The Monroe County Court jury convicted Arthur J. Shawcross on Thursday of 10 counts of second-degree murder in the deaths of eight prostitutes and two other women between March 1988 and January 1990. He faces up to 25 years in prison on each count when he is sentenced Feb. 1. Jury foreman Robert Edwards said the panel was particularly skeptical of the testimony of Dr. Dorothy Lewis, a psychiatrist who testified that Shawcross suffered brain damage and post-traumatic stress disorder brought on by child sexual abuse and his experiences during the Vietnam War. ``If she kept her feet on the floor instead of in her mouth she'd have been all right,'' Edwards said. He said jurors never believed defense allegations that Shawcross was legally insane when he killed the women or even that he was emotionally disturbed, which would have required they convict him of the lesser charge of manslaughter. ``We didn't buy it,'' he said. Shawcross, who confessed to the killings, was arrested Jan. 4, a day after state police spotted him lingering near the body of one of his victims. Relatives of the victims embraced and cried as the verdicts were announced. Afterward they thanked prosecutor Charles Siragusa. ``Hopefully, Arthur Shawcross will never see the light of day again,'' Siragusa said. Defense lawyer Thomas Cocuzzi said he would appeal. At the time of the murders, Shawcross was on parole after serving 15 years in prison for the 1972 stranglings of an 8-year-old girl and 10-year-old boy. He faces trial next year for the killing of an 11th woman. Shawcross did not testify during the trial, but jurors watched videotapes of him being interviewed under hypnosis by Lewis. He appeared to re-enact episodes of abuse and to take on the personalities of his mother, his sister and a cannibal from medieval England. Prosecution psychiatrist Dr. Park Dietz argued that Shawcross was faking mental illness to avoid being sent to prison.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Major Fire Burning in Residential Area
DOC.TEXT: A wind-whipped 10-alarm fire was raging in a residential area early today. At least seven three-decker homes were destroyed. Officials said the fire may have been set. Three people were taken to a hospital, but no serious injuries were immediately reported. Officials at the scene said all fire equipment in the Boston metropolitan area was committed to fighting the fire. As many as 17 fire companies were at the scene at 5 a.m., three hours after the fire broke out. Flames could be seen shooting into the sky from a mile away. Winds up to 30 mph fanned the flames, and firefighters were hampered by temperatures in the 20s, with a wind-chill factor near zero. Larry Doane, a Metropolitan police officer on the scene, said officials ``believe someone is lighting these.'' Another Metropolitan officer, Peter Sparuk, said Revere police called for extra help to patrol streets because of reports of looting.

DOC.HEAD: Disney Acquisition of Henson Productions Falls Through
DOC.TEXT: Walt Disney Co. and the family of the late Jim Henson, creator of the Muppets, broke off talks after failing to reach agreement in Disney's 18-month bid to acquire Henson Associates Inc. Disney also had sought an exclusive production agreement in the deal valued at $100 million to $150 million. ``We truly regret we could not come to terms,'' Disney chairman Michael D. Eisner said Thursday. Erwin Okun, a Disney Co. vice president, said it was too early to tell whether the failed acquisition would preclude the two companies from attempting future joint productions. He noted that statements issued by both companies were cordial. The Henson family, which has owned Henson Associates since the puppeteer's death in May, said current projects with Disney would not be affected by the termination of talks. Those projects include a Disney Channel television series, ``Jim Henson's Mother Goose''; a television sitcom involving dinosaurs, to be aired in January on ABC; and a 3-D film visitors would see at Walt Disney World in Florida. ``We would have liked to see this deal succeed,'' the Henson family said in a statement. ``Unfortunately, after 18 months of negotiating, the companies could not reach a mutually satisfactory agreement.'' Henson, the genius behind such characters as Kermit the Frog and Miss Piggy, founded his production company in 1958 as Muppets Inc. to produce all his properties. Recent negotiations had centered around the lower price Disney offered after Henson died of pneumonia May 18. Industry analysts at first speculated that Henson's death lessened the value of the acquisition. Henson's personal talents formed part of Eisner's original strategy to cross-market Muppet characters with Disney creations. Jeffrey Logsdon, an analyst with Crowell Weedon & Co., said it was more likely that Disney was scared off by hefty estate taxes owed on Henson properties.

DOC.HEAD: Rain Across South; Snow in Northern Tier
DOC.TEXT: Rain fell across the South early today, and a cold winterlike blast with some snow hit the northern United States. Much of the nation was under cloudy skies. Temperatures early today along the lower Eastern seaboard and Gulf coast were in the 60s. Rain fell along the mid-Mississippi valley, central Alabama and the South Carolina coast. Temperatures dipped into the high teens and low 20s from Montana, across the Great Plains and into New York state. Snow fell in Boston, Buffalo, N.Y., and Sault Ste. Marie, Mich., as well as in Denver. Up to a foot of snow was likely in California's northern Sierra Nevada. Light snow mixed with ice was expected in parts of the northern Plains. Snow was likely in Wyoming. Rain fell in Oregon early today, and a cold front moving in from the Pacific was expected to bring heavy snow later in the day to the mountains of Oregon and Northern California. The nation's high on Thursday was 84 degrees at Alice, Kingsville and McAllen, Texas. DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf-Freed Hostages, PM-Bush Hostages
DOC.TEXT: ``I did not close the embassy, but I vacated it. The flag flies.'' - Nathaniel Howell, U.S. Ambassador to Kuwait, after leaving the Iraqi-occupied nation. --- ``My poor sisters and their kids are still hostages there. I don't think I'll be able to enjoy this freedom.'' - Layla Cox, a Kuwaiti married to an American who flew out on the same plane with Howell. --- ``You don't reward a kidnapper. You don't reward somebody who has done something he shouldn't have done in the first place.'' - President Bush on the idea Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein deserves consideration for freeing hostages. --- ``To a man, we were in agreement with the care and the diligence which is being taken by the president.'' - Ralph Montgomery, who spent four months hiding in Kuwait, speaking for other himself and other hostages who met with Bush at the White House.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mixed, Gold Higher
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was mixed against major foreign currencies today in early European trading. Gold prices were higher. Dealers said the dollar was sticking to a narrow range in thin, pre-holiday trading. In Tokyo, the dollar rose 0.57 yen to a closing 131.87 yen. Later in London, it was quoted at a higher rate of 132.35 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Thursday: -1.4795 German marks, down from 1.4805 -1.2677 Swiss francs, up from 1.2660 -5.0283 French francs, down from 5.0305 -1.6680 Dutch guilders, down from 1.6700 -1,115.65 Italian lire, down from 1,115.75 -1.1600 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1595 In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.9440, unchanged from late Thursday. London's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended gold price of $373.15 per ounce at midmorning, up from $372.25 bid per ounce late Thursday. In Zurich, the bid price was $373, up from $372.25 late Thursday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose 76 cents to close at $374.24. Silver traded in London at $4 a troy ounce, from Thursday's $4.02.

DOC.HEAD: Two Quakes Hit Taiwan; Two Dead
DOC.TEXT: A strong earthquake shook a wide area of Taiwan before dawn today, hours after another quake on the island killed two people. Today's temblor caused power blackouts and landslides in the eastern city of Hualien, but there were no immediate reports of casualties. The Central Weather Bureau said today's quake struck at 3:49 a.m. and had a preliminary reading of 6.7 on the Richter scale. Its epicenter was located in the Pacific about 18 miles southeast of Hualien. More than 430 aftershocks hit the island, including one at 7:18 a.m. with a reading of 5.7 on the Richter scale, the bureau said. Today's quake was felt in Taipei, 100 miles northwest of Hualien. It was the strongest to hit Taiwan since November 1986, when 13 people were killed by a tremor measuring 6.8 on the Richter scale. On Thursday, a tremor measuring 6.5 shook northeastern Taiwan and more than 200 aftershocks were recorded, the bureau reported. Two workers in Hualien were killed in that quake. Residents were shaken awake by today's first tremor and many fled outdoors, said Lee Lai-fe, a policeman in Hualien. Several roads were blocked by landslides, and power blackouts affected about 10,000 households in the city, Lee said. A fire caused by a short circuit in a power line destroyed three houses but injured no one. Police said a 12-story building in downtown Hualien was tilting and several other buildings showed cracks. Elementary and high schools in Hualien were ordered closed today to allow authorities to check for possible structural damage, officials said. The Richter scale measures ground motion as recorded on seismographs. Every increase of one unit represents a tenfold increase in intensity. An earthquake with a magnitude of 6 can cause severe damage in a populated area, while one of magnitude 7 is classified as a major earthquake, capable of causing widespread, heavy damage.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Army Helping in Food Distribution; Shoppers Just Want Basics
With PM-EC Summit, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Shoppers asked what they would like to see in Moscow's food stores have simple tastes: meat, butter and milk. ``Basic food - canned goods, sausage, meat products,'' said Viktor Rozhkov, a Muscovite who was buying bread Thursday evening with his wife. ``Nowadays, we have practically nothing.'' Raisa L. Lebedinskaya, another shopper, also said she would like to see ``the elementary things'' in the stores, such as milk and butter. ``I want to see all those things that were freely available in the shops a year ago,'' Mrs. Lebedinskaya said. The Soviet government says deliveries of most food products are running 15 percent to 44 percent below 1989 levels, mostly due to pilfering and profiteering. To combat this, officials said Thursday the Red Army has been enlisted to help unload thousands of tons of government-purchased food that are stuck at ports and railway stations. More than 1.6 million metric tons of imported goods await unloading or shipment from Soviet ports, and about 7,000 railways cars are waiting at border stations. The soldiers also will help ease the backlog of foreign food aid that is flooding into the Soviet Union. Shoppers interviewed Thursday evening said they were confident that the KGB secret police, Interior Ministry troops and other law officers would ensure that the foreign food aid gets to Soviet stores. They also welcomed news that the Bush administration promised the Soviet Union up to $1 billion in loan guarantees to buy U.S. wheat, corn and other farm products to help out during the coming hard winter. The shoppers did not think such aid was humiliating for the Soviet Union to accept, because it was not a handout. ``If it was simply free of charge, it would be humiliating,'' said Rozhkov, 55. ``But as it's credit, it's not humiliating.'' Vasily I. Tarasov, hurrying along the street carrying a plastic shopping bag in each hand, also welcomed the help from the United States, and likened it to American assistance during World War II. ``We fought together against the fascists, and if they help us (again), we favor it,'' said Tarasov, 75. Under orders from President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the KGB has set up a special unit to combat economic sabotage, including taking control of distributing the foreign food aid and preventing its theft. Deputy Prime Minister Lev Voronin, who heads a government commissioin overseeing the aid distribution, and KGB Maj. Gen. Alexander N. Karbainov stressed at separate news briefings Thursday that the majority of foreign humanitarian aid was reaching its destination. Both admitted, however, that some has fallen into the hands of black marketeers who can sell it to speculators taking advantage of widespread shortages in state-run stores. ``There are some disorders,'' Voronin said. ``The harshest measures have been taken to eliminate all such phenomena.'' He did not elaborate. Voronin said the army had been enlisted to unload cargo planes, and 1,000 soldiers were ordered to Brest on the Polish border to help clear the rail backlog. He said 1,000 trucks were found to help distribute aid arriving at Moscow railway stations after Pravda quoted the Railways Ministry as saying the situation was ``catastrophic.'' Voronin predicted it would be under control by Dec. 20. As of Wednesday night, the Soviet Union had received 1,700 metric tons of food aid and 800 tons of medicines, cribs and construction materials, Voronin said. He said the single largest donor country was Germany, which gave 1,900 metric tons, followed by Italy at 117 metric tons, the United States at 93 metric tons, Austria at 75 metric tons, and Switzerland and the Netherlands at 45 metric tons each. First priority for receiving aid goes to schools and orphanages followed by ecologically damaged areas like Chernobyl and the Aral Sea; next come pensioners, the disabled and low income families.

DOC.HEAD: Investigator Says Brake Failure May Have Caused Crash
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 13th graf, `The force...', to fix garbled phrasing.
DOC.TEXT: Failed brakes may have caused an Amtrak train to derail and smash into a commuter train, injuring 264 people, federal safety officials said. They also said Thursday that the Amtrak train may have been traveling too fast along a curve where the crash occurred, but that the speed may never be determined because one speed recorder on the train was not working and the other was destroyed in the crash. An apprentice engineer operating the Amtrak train told investigators he tried to brake three times as the Night Owl from Washington approached a Boston station, said Susan Coughlin, vice chairwoman of the National Transportation Safety Board. ``He indicated that in his three attempts to brake the train, the brakes failed to set up properly to stop it,'' Coughlin said at a news conference. The apprentice, Richard Abramson, also told authorities that senior engineer Willis Copeland tried to stop the Night Owl using emergency brakes, she said. Coughlin said brakes on Amtrak cars that did not derail were working normally. Brakes from the derailed cars were sent to Washington for testing. The rush-hour crash Wednesday morning near the Back Bay Station injured 264 people. Copeland, 53, of Bethany, Conn., and Abramson, 41, of Trumbull, Conn., were among 11 of those Thursday still hospitalized. Coughlin said that one of the Night Owl's speed recorders was destroyed in the crash and the other, for unknown reasons, did not record during the last five miles. ``We will never know the exact speed of impact. I regret the fact that we don't have'' that data, she said. ``The last time he (Abramson) looked at the speedometer, he was going between 60 and 70 mph,'' she said. Coughlin said data from signals tripped by the train showed it traveled the last 1\ miles in 49 seconds at an average speed of 91.8 mph. Before that last stretch, the train could travel safely at 100 mph. But it should have slowed down to 30 mph by the time it reached the point where it derailed, on a curve 500 feet from the station, she said. It was the first time Copeland had taken over operation of a regular train run, authorities said. The Herald and The Boston Globe said drug and alcohol tests on Copeland were negative. The results of those on Abramson were awaited. The force of the crash bent the Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority's 120-ton locomotive around a concrete barrier in an L-shape. Three Amtrak cars, including the locomotive that carried the two Amtrak engineers, became a mesh of broken metal parts, barely distinguishable as separate units. Thomas Glynn, MBTA general manager, said the accident caused $3.1 million in damage to MBTA equipment and ``extensive'' damage to Amtrak equipment. The Herald reported today that Copeland was fired from Conrail after a derailment in the late 1970s but was later rehired. More recently, the paper said, he agreed to a lifetime ban from Metro-North Railroad, the commuter railroad that serves New York's northern suburbs, following signal violations in 1988 and last year. He also was at the controls of an Amtrak train involved in a July 1984 crash that was blamed on a signal problem. The National Transportation safety Board cleared him of wrongdoing. John P. Cole, a Washington lawyer representing crash victims, said he planned to file a $475 million class action suit in U.S. District Court in Washington against Amtrak because of the accident.

DOC.HEAD: Boat People Set Themselves on Fire to Protest Restrictions
DOC.TEXT: Seven Vietnamese boat people suffered burns today after wrapping themselves in blankets and setting themselves on fire to protest the government's refusal to settle them in the West, authorities said. Two members of the group were hospitalized with severe burns, in guarded and fair condition, respectively. The others were briefly treated at hospitals. The protesters at the Whitehead Detention Center had been refused refugee status and thus the chance to settle in the West. They had been on a hunger strike for four days. The act was an attempt at mass suicide, said Raymond Hall, a spokesman for the Office of the U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees in Geneva. The Whitehead Detention Center is the largest of Hong Kong's 15 refugee camps. It houses 22,800 boat people. Raymond Lai, the assistant commissioner of correctional services, said the government regretted the boat people ``should have resorted to such actions that might harm themselves.''
