The British colonial government instituted a screening process in June 1988 to separate what it called genuine refugees, who have a right to be resettled in the West, from ``economic migrants,'' who will be sent back to Vietnam. Of the 45,000 boat people now in Hong Kong's detention centers, 17 percent are genuine refugees. The rest will have to go home, the government says. So far plans to return the Vietnamese have not been too successful. Britain backed down after intense international criticism followed Hong Kong's forced repatriation of 51 boat people last December. Under a voluntary repatriation program, more than 6,000 Vietnamese have been flown home since March 1989. But about 40,000 boat people have arrived since then. Another program was started Dec. 1 to return Vietnamese who do not strongly oppose repatriation although they did not volunteer for it. Only 23 people have returned home under that program. A group of University of Hong Kong lawyers recently issued a report that obtaining refugee status was a matter of luck. They said Hong Kong officials didn't know enough about Vietnam to be informed interviewers, and furthermore were prejudiced against Vietnamese. Hong Kong claims the screening process has been improved, and U.N. officials agree. Nine Vietnamese denied refugee status are currently challenging the screening process in court. If the court rules in their favor, some lawyers believe it could upset the screening process, forcing the government to re-screen tens of thousands of cases.

DOC.HEAD: Army Doctor with Orders to Saudi Arabia Goes on Hunger Strike
With PM-Gulf-Freed Hostages, Bjt ^LaserPhoto DN3
DOC.TEXT: A flight surgeon who has been denied conscientious objector status is hoping his 2-week-old hunger strike will get him out of the Army before he is due to be deployed to Saudi Arabia next week. Capt. David Wiggins says he has lost 17 of the 167 pounds he carried on his 5-foot-10-inch frame before he began subsisting on vitamins and water Nov. 30. Wiggins, 28, said Thursday that he expects to be deployed from Fort Hood to the Persian Gulf on Monday. ``I haven't heard anything to change that belief from the Army,'' he said. ``My bags are packed. ... I'm just waiting for a phone call, I guess.'' He says he is philosophically opposed to war and has been trying to get out of the Army since February. He began the fast after a federal judge refused to overturn the Army's ruling that he could not be discharged as a conscientious objector. He said he is not a coward and doesn't want out of the Army to avoid being sent to the Persian Gulf. ``My purpose is to be discharged from the Army, because contributing to an organization whose sole purpose is killing is reprehensible to me,'' he said. Wiggins said he first began to have doubts about the military while still a cadet at West Point. He said the feelings became stronger after Communist governments were toppled across Eastern Europe by peaceful means last year. ``War is not a necessary evil, because non-violent political change is possible,'' he said. He said he has offered to pay the government back for his education at New York Medical College if he is released from service. He estimated he can go without food for about two more weeks before he becomes unable to work. ``I can only assume (Army officials) are content to let me starve to the point I am hospitalized,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: 12 Ritual Ceremony Celebrants Die, Possibly from Alcohol Poisoning
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with hospital officials now saying only group leader in coma, CORRECTS Padres' age to 62 sted 72, adds quotes from survivor, details on materials taken from scene. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos GO2,3,4,5 of Dec. 13; GO1,2
DOC.TEXT: Twelve people have died in a religious ritual, apparently after drinking a poisoned sacrament, and the leader of the ceremony clung to life in a coma today, officials said. Authorities who went to the house Thursday night in the impoverished El Florido neighborhood of this border city found twelve bodies strewn about the living room, with five survivors. Another ritual participant later checked into a hospital. The dead included four men, seven women and a 6-year-old girl, police said. The victims' faces were contorted in pain and had suffered a purplish discoloration of the skin, apparently caused by poisoning, the judicial police report said. Autopsy reports were expected later today. Authorities in this city south of San Diego speculated the deaths were caused by an industrial alcohol, perhaps rubbing alcohol, that was poured accidentally into a fruit punch the participants shared during a religious ceremony. ``We believe we've ruled out both suicide and homicide,'' said Jose Nunez de Caceres, a commander of the Baja California state police. Officers were conducting tests on the punch and a bowl of cooked chicken found in the house where the 12 bodies were found, said Baja California Police spokeswoman Sara Yolanda Gonzalez. The group leader and owner of the home, Federico Padres Mejia, 62, was in a coma, hospital officials said. Also hospitalized were Ana Osuna, aged four months; Consuelo Ponce, 35; Juan Jose Sarabia, 49; Moises Merida Gonzalez, 32, and Hernandez. Hospital officials did not describe their conditions. Relatives of the victims said they had previously attended healing rites in the house that were a mixture of Christianity and spiritualism, calling the spirits of the dead for consultation. In a hospital interview, survivor Alfredo Osuna Hernandez said the people gathered round a cardboard Virgin Mary and drank the punch as a sacrament. Several hours later, people began falling ill, Hernandez said. ``People started complaining of stomach pains and some of them began to vomit. Some of them started to get scared and they started to scream from the pain,'' Hernandez said. His sister-in-law, Margarita Ramos de Osuna, 25, was among the first to fall, he told The Associated Press. She was listed among the dead. ``I didn't try to help her because the Lord was there,'' Hernandez said. Asked why no one left to seek help, he said: ``It is very damaging to leave the circle.'' Hernandez said the gathering was a cleansing or purification ritual. An unemployed auto body repairman, he took part with hopes the ceremony would change his luck. He wanted ``a little of the Lord's coin,'' Hernandez said. ``I was looking for a key to a job, a key to work.'' A neighbor, Gerardo Barrios, said he did small construction jobs at the house and had been invited by Padres to take part in one ceremony. ``He said he had died twice and that his spirit left him and returned,'' said Barrios. Ritual participants sat in a circle within a rope and spread oil on their bodies, which Padres said would cleanse their souls, Barrios said. ``He would talk about eternal sleep and tell us to go to sleep,'' Barrios said. Officers who saw the living room said a rope with 13 knots tied in it had been laid in a circle on the floor around four or five of the bodies. A book of prayers dealing with the ``sith seal'' reportedly was also found, apparently related to the biblical prophesies of Armageddon. Neighbors said chanting had filtered from the house over the past several nights, the last time starting Wednesday night and continuing into the morning. The house was located in a cluster of shanties typical of the grubby suburbs of Tijuana, Mexico's fourth-largest city with about 2 million people. Authorities found the bodies sprawled in contorted poses on couches, chairs and the floor of the home. Ana Faviola Miranda, 17, the daughter of a woman who died in the tragedy, discovered the bodies and reported them to police, said Ms. Gonzalez, the police spokeswoman. Miranda, 17, said she went to the house at 8 p.m. Wednesday and Padres told her to leave and come back later, according to police. After spending the night outside in a car, Miranda asked a neighbor for help, and the two entered the house through a window. Miranda at first thought healing ceremony participants were asleep or in a trance, police said.

DOC.HEAD: Lawyer: Man Would Have Dropped Suit For Apology, Expenses
DOC.TEXT: An apology and money for legal expenses would have saved Dover police $1 million, says the lawyer for a man police mistook for a jewel thief. Kenneth Duval, 50, of Lawrence, Mass., won a $1 million federal lawsuit Monday against the police department. Duval had argued that police violated his constitutional rights by arresting him in 1984 and accusing him of belonging to an East Coast diamond theft gang. ``It was not a money case for Kenneth Duval,'' said his lawyer, Andrew Isaac. ``If they had called him back in 1985 and said they were sorry and tried to cover his expenses and said, `Thank you for trying to help us,' it would have ended there.'' Police alleged that Duval helped steal a diamond from a department store. They charged him with being an accomplice to theft, and also accused him of belonging to a gang that stole diamonds in New England, New Jersey, Pennsylvania and New York. Strafford County Attorney Lincoln Soldati dropped the charges a year later, admitting police had the wrong man. Soldati ``had the grace and common sense to write Mr. Duval and tell him it was an unfortunate case of mistaken identity,'' Isaac said. Duval's defense cost him $33,000, his lawyer said. Isaac said Dover police originally investigated another man, but that man led them to Duval. ``He was a recent Russian immigrant. They showed him a picture and the man said, `It looks like a guy who lives where I used to live. ... It looks like Ken,' '' Isaac said. ``Ken, like most people, talked to police for two hours. He showed them his business diary and appointments.'' Dover police are considering appealing the award.

DOC.HEAD: Reputed Bolivian Cocaine Kingpin rrrested
DOC.TEXT: A Bolivian described by officials as a powerful cocaine trafficker and lead supplier of unrefined coca to the Colombian cartels was arrested at his 19-room estate by federal drug agents. Jorge Roca Suarez and his wife, Cecilia Beatrice Roca Torres, were arrested Thursday for investigation of conspiracy to possess cocaine with intent to distribute, said Julius C. Beretta, the Drug Enforcement Administration special agent in San Diego. Both were in federal custody. Bail was not immediately set. Beretta described Roca Suarez, a resident immigrant, as ``one of the most significant cocaine traffickers in the United States, on par with Medellin or Cali cartel leaders.'' A federal indictment against the couple was expected to be unsealed at their arraignment today. Roca Suarez was arrested at 2 p.m. Thursday by San Marino police and DEA, U.S. Customs and Internal Revenue Service agents, said police Officer Armando Rodriguez. The 38-year-old Bolivian was taken into custody at his estate on a manicured hillside in an exclusive enclave of this town 10 miles northeast of downtown Los Angeles. His wife, 40, was arrested in nearby Monterey Park, Beretta said. Roca Suarez is the nephew of Roberto Suarez Gomez, who's serving a 15-year sentence on drug charges in La Paz, Bolivia. Bolivian officials have refused U.S. extradition requests for Suarez, who built a reputation as that country's king of cocaine in the 1970s and early 1980s. Roca Suarez once offered to pay the Bolivian foreign debt. The Bolivian government rejected the offer. DEA officials said Roca Suarez allegedly undercut his uncle by selling cocaine paste at prices lower than those charged by Suarez. He reputedly is the most powerful figure in Bolivia's coca trade, arranging cocaine shipments to U.S. and European markets, the officials alleged.

DOC.HEAD: ANC Leader Calls on Group to Reconsider Sanctons Against SAfrica
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 4th graf, `We should...' with 1 graf to RESTORE dropped words in quote. Pickup 5th graf, `If the...'
DOC.TEXT: The president of the African National Congress today said the black opposition group should reconsider its support for international sanctions imposed on South Africa to protest apartheid. Oliver Tambo, who a day earlier returned to South Africa after 30 years in exile, told the opening session of the ANC's consultative conference the group had to reconsider its strategy to recognize the changing political situation in South Africa. ``It is no longer enough for us to repeat the tried slogans,'' he said in a speech that could mark a major change in the ANC's position on sanctions. It was the first conference of the formerly banned ANC in South Africa in more than 30 years. ``We should therefore carefully re-evaluate the advisability of insisting on the retention of sanctions given the new developments in the country and abroad,'' the 73-year-old leader said. If the ANC sticks to outdated policies, the white-led government could gain the strategic initiative in talks on the future of South Africa, Tambo said. Some ANC leaders are concerned the government's push for reforms is upstaging the opposition. But Tambo also urged the cheering delegates to step up the struggle against apartheid and win the freedom of blacks. ``Whatever our tactics, our absolute determination is to regain our freedom,'' Tambo said. ``The struggle against apartheid should be intensified on all fronts.'' The conference, which began today with some 1,600 delegates, is considering ANC policies and the course of talks with the government on sharing power with the black majority. Moderates who support the talks are expected to face tough opposition from radicals who doubt the government's willingness to give up power. The ANC has opposed government calls for an easing of sanctions. ANC Deputy President Nelson Mandela said recently it was too soon to lift sanctions, despite reforms by President F.W. de Klerk. Many nations have imposed various bans on economic, cultural and sporting ties with South Africa to protest the apartheid system of government. Tambo did not say which sanctions might be eased. De Klerk has said lifting sanctions will help boost the economy and ease black unemployment, homelessness and other problems. Tambo is to spend about three weeks in South Africa before going to London for treatment for a stroke he suffered last year. Mandela, in a speech after Tambo, charged that recent black factional fighting was part of an orchestrated campaign to destroy confidence in the ANC. He alleged some members of the government were trying to weaken the ANC before talks on power sharing are held. ``As it has unfolded and taken hold over the past three months, it is evident that it is targeted at the ANC,'' he said. The ANC claims security force members are behind fighting that has claimed more than 1,000 lives in the Johannesburg area since August. The fighting pits Xhosas and other blacks who support the ANC against Zulus of the Inkatha Freedom Party. The government and the police have denied they are behind the violence, which also has claimed more than 5,000 lives in Natal Province in recent years. De Klerk unbanned the ANC and other opposition groups Feb. 11 and talks are expected to begin next year on power sharing. De Klerk has already begun dismantling parts of the apartheid system.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Ambassador, Other Former Hostages Leave For Washington
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 10 grafs to UPDATE with Howell, Bodine comments, 23 Americans aboard flight. Pickup 20th pvs, `One American...' Plane expected to land in Washington at 4 p.m. EST
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. ambassador to Kuwait flew back to the United States today with about 50 American and other foreign hostages he led from Iraq and the occupied emirate. Joining a U.S. Air Force honor guard, Ambassador Nathaniel Howell saluted the members of his bare-bones embassy staff as they boarded a C-5 military transport plane for the flight to Andrews Air Force Base outside Washington. Aboard were 23 Americans and 10 non-U.S. citizen family members, as well as 15 people going to Canada, officials said. All had come from Iraq or Kuwait on Thursday. A U.S. Consulate spokesman, Craig Springer, said several Americans evacuated Thursday who were not aboard the C-5 today have chosen to return home independently. Looking surprisingly fit after months of surviving on canned tuna, Howell told reporters before departing Frankfurt that he slept well at an airport hotel, got a haircut and feasted on sausage, bacon and eggs for breakfast. ``We have a lot of cholesterol to make up for,'' he joked, a reference to the nearly four-month ordeal at the besieged U.S. Embassy in Kuwait following Iraq's invasion of the emirate Aug. 2. Iraq's government of President Saddam Hussein ordered all foreign missions in Kuwait to close Aug. 24, and those that defied the order had services cut off by authorities who took over the emirate after the Aug. 2 invasion. Barbara Bodine, the deputy chief of mission at the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait, said after checking into the hotel: ``First I took a shower. Then I took a bath. Then I had dinner. Then I had another bubble bath.'' Howell and his staff left Iraq on Thursday on the last U.S. charter to evacuate Westerners who had been held by Saddam to deter a U.S. attack. Hundreds of Westerners have left since Saddam announced a blanket release of hostages on Dec. 6, and U.S. officials said all other Americans who wish to leave can take commercial transportation. Former hostages who would talk to reporters were very bitter about their experiences and accused Iraq of a host of atrocities. One American, who said his mother was from Indiana and his father from Kuwait, said several people who had been imprisoned after the invasion later told tales of torture. He said he knew of one 15-year-old boy who was arrested by Iraqi authorities after protesting the shooting death of his younger brother. The younger boy had been caught spray-painting anti-Saddam Hussein graffitti and shot on the spot, he said. The young American, who went to Kuwait last summer to marry a Kuwaiti woman, said he planned to return to Indiana and continue his studies at Purdue University. He declined to give his name for fear those he left behind would be harassed. Layla Cox, a Kuwaiti married to an American, was emotional as she walked away from the plane Thursday carrying her baby daughter: ``It's terrible. You had to be there,'' she told reporters. Later, as she waited with her husband, Wayne, and three children to check into their room, she explained that she couldn't join in the euphoria of the other hostages when the plane touched down in the West because of her three sisters left in Kuwait. ``My poor sisters and their kids are still hostages there. I don't think I'll be able to enjoy this freedom.''

DOC.HEAD: Grant sWill Help Refurbish Andrew Jackson's Tennessee Home
DOC.TEXT: Andrew Jackson's Tennessee home will get some refurbishing and schoolchildren in the Southwest will participate in archaeological digs as a result of grants from the National Endowment for the Humanities. The endowment announced Thursday more than $13.8 million in Challenge Grants to 36 educational and cultural institutions. The money will be matched with more than $49.9 million from non-federal sources. The endowment is a federal agency that supports education, research, preservation and public programs in the humanities. Recipients include the Crow Canyon Archaeological Center in Cortez, Colo., which provides archaeological experiences for youngsters, and The Hermitage, Hermitage, Tenn., which will use the money for renovation of President Jackson's home. Other winners include the American Council of Learned Societies, New York City; Center for Conservation and Technical Studies, Cambridge, Mass.; New England Foundation for the Humanities, Boston; African Studies Association, Atlanta; and the Library Company of Philadelphia. Museums receiving awards included the Abigail Adams Smith Museum, New York City; Fairbanks Museum and Planetarium, St. Johnsbury, Vt.; Judah L. Magnes Memorial Museum, Berkeley, Calif.; Morris Arboretum of the University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia; Museum of Modern Art, New York City; Octagon Museum, Washington; Public Museum of Grand Rapids, Mich.; Reynolds House, Winston-Salem, N.C.; Rochester Museum and Science Center, Rochester, N.Y.; South Street Seaport Museum, New York City; and Valentine Museum, Richmond, Va. Four-year colleges among the winners were Austin College, Sherman, Texas; Dana College, Blair, Neb.; Hampshire College, Amherst, Mass.; Hope College, Holland, Mich.; Sweet Briar College, Sweet Briar, Va.; Shimer College, Waukegan, Ill.; and Wheaton College, Norton, Mass. Universities receiving awards were Cornell University, Ithaca, N.Y.; Johnson C. Smith University, Charlotte, N.C.; Memphis State University, Memphis; North Carolina State University, Raleigh; and the University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill. Grants also went to these historical institutions: the Amana Heritage Society, Amana, Iowa; Atlanta Historical Society, Atlanta; Bostonian Society, Boston; Dubuque County Historical Society, Dubuque, Iowa; Old Salem, Inc., Winston-Salem, N.C.; and Virginia Historical Society, Richmond.

DOC.HEAD: Doctor: Ruling Will Encourage More Physician-Assisted Suicides
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, `Michael Modelski ...' to CLARIFY that prosecutor could ask court to reinstate murder charge. INSERTS 4 grafs after 19th graf, ``I respected ...' to add further Kevorkian quotes. Picks up penultimate graf: `Derek Humphrey ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto DT2
DOC.TEXT: A judge dismissed a murder charge against a doctor who invented a device that an Alzheimer's disease victim used to kill herself, but he didn't clear the doctor to use the machine again. District Judge Gerald McNally on Thursday threw out a first-degree murder charge against Dr. Jack Kevorkian in the June 4 death of Janet Adkins. She died after activating a machine Kevorkian invented that sent poison into her veins. Kevorkian was with her at the time of her death. McNally ruled at the end of a two-day preliminary hearing that Michigan has no law against suicide or assisting in it. Michael Modelski, chief assistant Oakland County prosecutor, said the prosecutor's office might ask the Circuit Court to reinstate the murder charge or bring lesser charges such as second-degree murder or manslaughter against Kevorkian. ``I think everyone realizes this isn't the final step,'' Modelski said. The ruling doesn't let Kevorkian use the suicide device again. It remains in police custody after prosecutors obtained a temporary court order preventing its further use. A civil trial, probably in January, will decide whether or not to make that order permanent, said Kevorkian's attorney, Geoffrey Fieger. Once hooked up to the device, Mrs. Adkins, 54, of Portland, Ore., pressed a button on the machine, starting a flow of lethal chemical into her veins. She died in the back of Kevorkian's van. Kevorkian said several motels and funeral homes had refused his request to let him use their sites for the suicide. Kevorkian notified authorities of the death, and state police questioned him. But he wasn't charged with murder until nearly six months later. ``I was always convinced that I was doing the right thing, but it was under terrible conditions, and no one would want to repeat that,'' Kevorkian, 62, a retired pathologist from Royal Oak, said after McNally's ruling. He said the ruling bolstered his longtime support of what he calls physician-assisted suicide for the terminally ill. ``We need a rational system to meet a crying need,'' Kevorkian said. ``I'm going to work with the authorities and in the (medical) system. We've got to re-establish the nobility of the profession.'' In announcing his decision, McNally called on the Legislature to address the issues raised by Kevorkian. A bill introduced by state Sen. Fred Dillingham would make assisting in a suicide a felony punishable by four years in prison and a $2,000 fine. The judge ruled after viewing a videotape of Mrs. Adkins and Kevorkian discussing her fight against Alzheimer's, which causes loss of memory and irreversible brain degeneration. The tape was made two days before her death. ``My life before was wonderful,'' she says. ``I could play the piano and read. I can't do any of those things (now) ... it's too taxing.'' ``Why do you want your life to end?'' Kevorkian asks. ``I've had enough,'' Mrs. Adkins answers, her voice breaking. Mrs. Adkins' husband, Ronald, said from his home in Portland that he was pleased with the judge's ruling and had no regrets about his wife's decision. ``I respected Janet's wishes. She was a very intelligent woman and had it very well thought out,'' he said. ``Its concept was something we had thought and talked about years before.'' For his part, Kevorkian said after the hearing that he didn't expect to assist in other suicides on his own but wanted to enlist the medical establishment's cooperation. ``I'm going to work with the authorities,'' he said. On the videotape with the Adkinses, Kevorkian repeated his longstanding views favoring assisted suicide. ``These tough decisions have got to be made, and who's in better position to decide them than the physicians?'' he tells the couple. ``One of the hardest things they're going to have to do is this ... no matter how distasteful it is.'' Derek Humphrey, head of the National Hemlock Society in Eugene, Ore., welcomed the ruling. The organization advocates a person's right to choose death if facing a terminal illness. But Humphrey said: ``We would wish to see euthanasia performed for the dying in a more dignified way, in home or hospital by the doctor who is treating the patient, and of course according to a clear law.''

DOC.HEAD: Giving Is Up but Some Charities Feel Pinch of Economic Slump
LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: U.S. charities are taking in more money this year than last, but the needs of the poor are also rising, and in the nation's economically depressed Northeast the organizations report giving has fallen off drastically. Charities across the country report increased demand for food, shelter and clothing - problems they blame on layoffs, economic woes and government cutbacks. ``It's looking real scary,'' said Vicky Wheeler of the Central Vermont Community Action Council. She said the number of daily visitors to the council's food bank is up from 15 to 35 in the past six months while donations have held steady. The council has cut the size of its food packages by a third to make supplies last. ``If we run out of food and can't help them, there's not really any other place to turn,'' she said. Other charities in the heavily industrialized Northeast say contributions are down by as much as 67 percent from a year ago and their budgets are stretched pitifully thin. Nationally, donations to the Salvation Army and Goodwill Industries of America Inc. are running about 8 percent above last year's levels, according to the national headquarters of those organizations. Two New York-based groups that keep tabs on charities - the American Association of Fundraising Council and the National Charities Information Bureau - also said the 1990 philanthropy tally is unlikely to fall below 1989's $115 billion. ``Giving for 1990 is expected to be up, as it has been every year since 1955,'' said Charities Information Bureau President Ken Albrecht. But the United Way of America, which projects a 4.5 percent gain in contributions to local United Way campaigns, said collection levels fluctuate widely from region to region. ``If you want to talk about New England, we're down there a couple percentage points. If you want to talk about the Pacific Northwest, Seattle is up in the double digits,'' said Richard Fusco, United Way vice president for resource development. Of 80 local organizations contacted by The Associated Press, 54 said donations were flat or below year-ago levels and 49 reported increased demand for their services. Fourteen said they stepped up their efforts this year because they expected hard times, and 12 said they either had cut budgets and staff or were considering doing so. ``We are two months behind on our $3,800-a-month rent, one month behind on utilities,'' said Kent Beittel, executive director of the Open Shelter in Columbus, Ohio, a homeless-aid center considering layoffs. Many charities in the economically depressed Northeast report large dropoffs in giving. The American Red Cross chapter in Bridgeport, Conn., had raised $2,300 toward a $30,000 goal at the end of last week, compared with $7,000 raised at the same time last year. In Boston, donations to Salvation Army kettles are averaging about 50 percent of last year, said chief bell ringer William Edmonds. Meanwhile, requests for assistance in Massachusetts are up about 25 percent, said Charles Williams, director of Salvation Army social services in the state. Applications for Salvation Army assistance nationally are up 15 percent from a year ago, national spokesman Leon Ferraez said Wednesday. Goodwill Industries anticipates a 7 percent increase in requests for services, said spokeswoman Jeanne Hamrick. Charities in the Sunbelt states, the West and some pockets of the Midwest reported increased donations, but most also said they had gone after funds more aggressively. Many California charities surveyed also said collections had increased or were holding steady, but a few reported problems. The Salt Lake City United Way said giving was up 12 percent over last year, the Miami Salvation Army reported an increase, and contributions were up at the United Way of Central Iowa, the Easter Seals Society of Iowa and the Iowa March of Dimes. Several charities complained of a drop in corporate contributions. But corporate, foundation and bequest donations together account for just 15 percent of U.S. philanthropy, said Joanne Hayes, president of the American Association of Fundraising Council. ``The biggest donors are not upper middle-class people. They are people of modest means,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Lawyers For Ethics Committee and Senators Linked to Keating
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to UPDATE with Bennett denouncing report, recast. Picks up 4th graf pvs, `Keating was...'. Subs the 9th graf, `Bennett declined...', to add full Bennett quote.
DOC.TEXT: The special counsel for the Senate committee investigating whether five senators improperly helped Charles H. Keating is a partner in a law firm once tied to Keating, a report published today said. The San Francisco Chronicle also said three of the senators' lawyers work for firms with previous connections to the Lincoln Savings add Loan Association owner. The Chronicle said Robert Bennett, special counsel for the Senate Ethics Committee, and two of the senators' lawyers already were working on the panel's investigation when they took jobs at firms with former Keating links. Bennett today denounced the report. Keating was a major contributor to all five senators. The Ethics Committee is considering whether the $1.3 million he and associates donated to their campaigns and related political causes was tied to their help in dealing with federal thrift regulators. Keating's parent company, American Continental Co., went bankrupt in April 1989, and Lincoln Savings was seized by regulators. The cost to taxpayers to cover insured deposits is expected to top $2 billion, and Keating is under a state fraud indictment in California. It's the most prominent case in the nation's burgeoning savings and loan scandal. Bennett and his staff of lawyers and investigators have worked on the Keating case for the Ethics Committee since last fall. They joined the Washington office of the New York-based Skadden, Arps firm on April 15 of this year, the Chronicle said. In 1985, Skadden, Arps received about $4 million in fees from a limited partnership in which Lincoln invested $35.9 million, an 18.3 percent interest. The fees were for work on the partnership's takeover of Crown Zellerbach, according to the newspaper. Bennett called the news report ``just one more very clear effort to discredit me, to distract from the issues in this case, and it's not going to work.'' Thomas C. Green, lawyer for Sen. Donald Riegle, D-Mich., joined the Washington firm of Sidley and Austin on June 11. That was 2{ months after the firm was added as a defendant in a $250 million lawsuit filed on behalf of 23,000 people who bought now worthless American Continental bonds, the Chronicle said. Another Sidley and Austin attorney, Margery Waxman, helped develop Keating's strategy for dealing with politicians and top federal regulators. John Dowd, attorney for Sen. John McCain, R-Ariz., joined the law firm of Akin, Gump and Strauss in January, shortly after McCain retained him for the Ethics Committee investigation. Keating employed the firm in 1986 and 1987. Another lawyer for the firm appears on Keating's appointment logs for 1986 regarding efforts to get Keating associate Lee Henkel appointed to the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, according to the Chronicle. The board was then the top S&L regulatory body. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation has said that Akin, Gump is not on its list for handling the government's side of S&L matters because the firm has clients whose interests conflict with the FDIC's. Henkel's lawyer has been James Hamilton, also the attorney for Sen. Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz., in the Ethics Committee hearings. A key part of Bennett's case against DeConcini is that the senator may have withheld a vote that could have defeated a controversial White House judicial appointment in exchange for the Reagan administration's agreement to appoint Henkel to the bank board. The lawyers for the other two Keating Five senators - Alan Cranston of California and John Glenn of Ohio, both Democrats - are with firms that have no known past relationship with Keating or his dealings, the Chronicle said. It was unclear late Thursday whether Bennett had informed the committee of his new law firm's past relations with Keating, the Chronicle said. Tom McMahon, spokesman for committee chairman Sen. Howell Heflin, D-Ala., said Heflin had no comment. Bob Stevenson, spokesman for committee vice chairman Sen. Warren Rudman, R-N.H., said the committee was told that Skadden, Arps had ``conducted a conflict investigation, found no conflict.'' New York University law professor Stephen Gillers, a specialist in legal ethics, said Bennett could have legitimately determined that the ``scope of his responsibility to the Ethics Committee'' does not include investigation of the Crown Zellerbach takeover that Keating's Lincoln was involved in. But Yale law Professor Geoffrey Hazard said, ``I think it would have been wise for Bennett to hold off the affiliation with his new firm just because it would foreclose public anxiety and public criticism.'' Michael Waldman, director of Ralph Nader's Public Citizen Congress, said the senators' lawyers' ties to firms with former Keating links showed ``not so much a conflict of interest as a unity of interest.''

DOC.HEAD: Man Accused of Impersonating Cheerleader Ready for Plea Bargain
DOC.TEXT: A man accused of impersonating a female to enroll at Coronado High School and become a cheerleader is ready for a plea bargain, his lawyer said. Charles Daugherty, 26, who has been diagnosed as having multiple personalities, is charged with forging documents and impersonation. His lawyer, Kent Gray, said Thursday that Daugherty will enter a guilty plea Jan. 3, but to which charge has not been decided. Daugherty would like a deferred sentence so the charge would be dismissed if he complies with court orders for two years, Gray said. ``But the district attorney doesn't want that, and probation with no jail is more likely,'' he said. Mental health treatment would be a requirement. Daugherty said he already is undergoing such treatment. The district attorney's office declined to comment. Daugherty enrolled at Coronado in September and soon joined the cheerleading squad. Students were shocked when it was disclosed he was a male, and the story was highly publicized.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney Says `Patience is Not Producing Results'
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Combines pvs; editing thruout to tighten; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, responding to Democratic calls to give economic sanctions against Iraq more time, said today ``patience is not producing results.'' ``Those who would have us rely indefinitely on economic sanctions alone need to face the possibility that they will fail to achieve our aims,'' Cheney told the House Armed Services Committee. The testimony from the Pentagon chief and Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, comes amid the urgings of several Democrats for a go-slow approach in the gulf rather than the immediate use of military force. But Cheney told the panel that if the economic attempts and diplomatic efforts to solve the crisis fail, the United States must have the option of using force to oust Iraq from the oil-rich emirate of Kuwait. ``Having a capacity for patience does not mean we must remain patient when patience is not producing results. We must always have other options, and that is what the new deployments and the recent United Nations action are all about,'' Cheney said. President Bush has announced that Secretary of State James A. Baker III will travel to Iraq to try to resolve the crisis. But Cheney said the United States has given Iraq ``15 separate dates and then turned all those down and said he can only come on the 12th'' of January. Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., chairman of the Armed Service panel and a supporter of Bush's policy, opened the hearing stressing the need for Cheney and Powell to answer a key question. ``We want to explore with our witnesses today whether we've created a use-it-or-lose-it force in the Persian Gulf that will prematurely bring us to the question of peace or war,'' Aspin said. On Thursday, several former U.S. military officials and defense experts said they believe military force - not a year of economic sanctions - is the only way to oust Iraqi forces from Kuwait. ``If we wait for sanctions to succeed, Saddam knows we're waiting and he will outlast us,'' said retired Army Col. Trevor Dupuy. Cheney and Powell received a more receptive audience today than when they appeared before the Senate Armed Services Committee less than two weeks ago. The Senate panel's chairman, Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., has been an outspoken critic of President Bush's decision to deploy an additional 200,000 troops to the Persian Gulf region. Nunn also believes the administration should give the United Nations sanctions time to work before opting for war. Aspin has doubts about the sanctions. He has endorsed Bush's added deployment of forces and looks more favorably on using the military to neutralize Saddam Hussein's troops. In hearings before the House panel Wednesday and Thursday, witnesses selected by Aspin bolstered his and the Bush administration's perspective on solving the crisis. The witnesses endorsed using an air offensive against Iraqi forces and then possibly opting for a ground attack. However, they warned the United States will have to pay a price for war. ``We may have to take those first few rounds in the teeth in order to be able to have ultimate victory in the air,'' said retired Air Force Gen. Charles Donnelly Jr., former commander of the U.S. Air Forces in Europe. Dupuy estimated that an air and ground attack would result in about 9,000 casualties, including 1,000 to 1,500 American dead. The witnesses said the first target should be the Iraqi command and if possible in the early days of an attack, the country's potential nuclear capability. The lone note of dissent came from Rep. Nicholas Mavroules, D-Mass., who questioned whether Arab allies would help in the effort to defeat Iraq. ``Who's going to fight this war? Does anyone truly believe that a Saudi or Arab pilot will bomb Iraq?'' Mavroules asked the witnesses. ``It's going to be a U.S. war. We're going to lose thousands of men and women.'' To shore up its offensive air capability, the Air Force said Thursday it is sending an undisclosed number of F-16 fighter jets and A-10 anti-armor aircraft to Saudi Arabia from Germany and Britain. Officials have declined to provide details on numbers of planes and aviators being sent, but it is believed that at least 300 additional Air Force planes are headed to the gulf, along with at least 10,000 personnel. Meanwhile, the Navy announced the activation of hundreds of reservists for medical duty in the gulf region. Also, the Pentagon said Cheney and Powell will travel to Saudi Arabia next week to visit American troops and to meet with Saudi government officials.

DOC.HEAD: EC Leaders Agree on Major Aid Package for Soviets
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 8 grafs to ADD concerns about greater Soviet debt, worries about Gorbachev remaining in power, details of U.S. aid approved this week. Pickup 6th graf pvs, `The Soviet...'
DOC.TEXT: European Community leaders today approved a $1 billion emergency aid package for the Soviet Union designed to fight food shortages and bolster President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. The proportion of grants and loans still had to be decided, however, and Britain, France, and Germany cautioned against overloading the troubled Soviet economy with debt. Approval of the emergency aid came at the start of a two-day EC summit. ``All, without expection, are in agreement to give immediate help to the Soviet Union,'' said summit spokesman Pio Mastrobuoni. The European leaders said the Soviet food problem had more to do with poor distribution than with shortages. Italian officials said the EC food would be targeted for Moscow and Leningrad. The EC leaders also were worried about saving Gorbachev, whose political hold is under constant challenge from opponents, including hard-liners and various quarters of Soviet society. German Chancellor Helmut Kohl denounced attempts to undermine Gorbachev and warned it would be a lot more costly to the rest of the world should Gorbachev fall than to offer emergency aid now. The United States joined 20 other countries this week in promising or delivering food aid for the Soviet Union. The U.S. package included $1.3 billion in loan guarantees to buy U.S. farm products and manufactured goods. The Soviet government said on Thursday it had already received 1,700 tons of food and 800 tons of medicine and other aid for the difficult winter ahead. As the Soviet Union tries to move from a command to a market economy, it has been unable to prevent shortages caused by its inadequate distribution system. Many countries believe that food aid is necessary to give Gorbachev breathing room to implement his political and economic reforms. Earlier today, Prime Minister John Major of Britain urged the European Community at the start of the key summit today not to rush into a single currency in its drive for European unity. ``I don't think anybody in the community wants confrontation,'' said Major, who replaced Margaret Thatcher last month after her combative stance in Europe helped topple the longtime British leader. But he added, ``We can't just leap at it (a single currency). ... We need to see if it works. We need to see if people want it.'' His remarks appeared aimed at signaling that Britain without Mrs. Thatcher will not be trapped into going along with radical union plans rather than face continued isolation. But in a tone markedly different from the resounding denunciations of Mrs. Thatcher, Major cautioned, ``Europe has to march together ... We (Britain) must negotiate in a constructive spirit, and so must our partners.'' Major, 47, spoke to reporters at his hotel in between a pre-summit round of separate talks with Italian Premier Giulio Andreotti, the summit chairman, Dutch Prime Minister Ruud Lubbers and Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany. The two-day summit, held in the flag-bedecked Italian Parliament, also will debate the Persian Gulf crisis. In a letter Thursday to Andreotti, President Bush said Iraq's release of foreign hostages should not lessen pressure on Iraq to pull out of Kuwait. ``We must continue to maintain a very rigid attitude,'' Bush said, according to Italian officials. In the pre-summit meetings, Major told Kohl ``most people of his generation and younger take a very positive view of the community - it's in the national self-interest,'' said a British official. He spoke on condition of anonymity. But despite the warmth, Major faced treading a difficult path between ending British isolation and being swept up in the French-German drive for European union. At the October summit, Andreotti cornered Mrs. Thatcher by getting the others to agree to establish a single central banking system - the prelude to one currency - by January 1994. On political union, Britain has shifted toward French and German proposals for giving the Community a formal role in security. The EC nations are Italy, France, Britain, Ireland, Spain, Portugal, Belgium, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, Greece, Denmark and Germany.

DOC.HEAD: Sun Exploration Mission Threatened By Ulysses Malfunction
DOC.TEXT: A $750 million mission to study the sun's poles is in danger because the Ulysses spacecraft is wobbling for reasons U.S. and European flight controllers don't fully understand. The malfunction developed Nov. 4, about four weeks after the spacecraft was launched by the shuttle Discovery, The Associated Press has learned. The spacecraft was 40.6 million miles from Earth today. Officials of NASA and the European Space Agency confirmed the problem's existence during interviews this week. Willis Meeks, Ulysses project manager at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory, said he is optimistic engineers can repeatedly use the spacecraft's thrusters to minimize the wobble when Ulysses becomes the first spacecraft to orbit the sun's poles during 1994 and 1995. ``I don't foresee that anybody here or in Europe is going to write off this mission as a failure,'' said Ed Smith, NASA's chief scientist for Ulysses. ``It's a question of how much of the cake you want to have.'' If corrective maneuvering is successful, Ulysses would lose only 20 percent of the information it was designed to collect, but if it fails, ``we would stand to lose 90 percent of the data,'' said Edgar Page, Ulysses science coordinator for the European Space Agency. Smith was less pessimistic than Page, saying that at worst, Ulysses would be unable to transmit 70 percent to 75 percent of the information it was designed to collect. The wobble threatens the mission because it makes it difficult for Ulysses to keep its main dish-shaped antenna pointed at Earth to transmit the information it collects. The malfunctioning spacecraft is the latest headache for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, which has been bedeviled by space shuttle fuel leaks, trouble with the Hubble Space Telescope and major glitches with an observatory that flew aboard shuttle Columbia this month. Ulysses is a joint mission of the European Space Agency, which supplied the spacecraft and half its science instruments, and NASA, which built the remaining instruments, launched the spacecraft and is tracking it. The mission cost is $750 million, including $250 million for the spacecraft. Ulysses is now flying toward Jupiter. The planet's gravity will act like a slingshot in 1992 to hurl Ulysses out of the plane in which the planets orbit the sun. Ulysses then will fly over the sun's polar regions in 1994 and 1995. The slow wobble unexpectedly developed Nov. 4 when Ulysses extended a 24{-foot-long antenna boom, which is different than the main antenna. The boom was designed to study radio signals and solar wind waves. ``We aren't sure why it's happening,'' Page said. Meeks said the leading theory is that heat from the sun is warming one side of the boom while the other side remains cool, causing the boom to bend. The boom then makes the entire spacecraft wobble like an off-balance washing machine when it spins. It was designed to spin to prevent wobbling.

DOC.HEAD: Gulf Crisis at a Glance
DOC.TEXT: Here are the latest developments in the Persian Gulf crisis: ---= A C-5 military transport plane took off Friday from Frankfurt carrying Ambassador to Kuwait Nathaniel Howell among the 23 Americans aboard and 10 non-U.S. citizen family members, officials said. The plane was headed to Andrews Air Force Base outside Washington. Looking surprisingly fit after months of surviving on canned tuna, Howell told reporters before departing that he slept well at an airport hotel, got a haircut and feasted on sausage, bacon and eggs for breakfast. --- Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, testified Friday before the House Armed Services Committee. On Thursday, several military officers told the panel that bombs and bullets, not economic sanctions, were the way to pry Saddam Hussein from Kuwait. The Pentagon said Cheney and Powell will travel to Saudi Arabia on Tuesday to visit American troops and to meet with Saudi government officials. --- In London, a report released Friday by the Medical Campaign Against Nuclear Weapons said plans being made for gulf war casualties will be inadequate. The group, citing a report last month by the Washington-based Center for Defense Information, anticipates military and civilian casualties of 314,000, including 63,000 dead, in a conflict between Iraq and the U.S.-led multinational force arrayed against it in the gulf. A British Ministry of Defense spokeswoman, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the medical group was speculating wildly on numbers. --- A flight surgeon who has been denied conscientious objector status is hoping his 2-week-old hunger strike will get him out of the Army before he is due to be deployed to Saudi Arabia next week. Capt. David Wiggins says he has lost 17 of the 167 pounds he carried on his 5-foot-10-inch frame before he began subsisting on vitamins and water Nov. 30. Wiggins, 28, said on Thursday that he expects to be deployed from Fort Hood, Texas to the gulf on Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands of Sudanese Famine Deaths Likely, Says U.S. Official
DOC.TEXT: Tens of thousands of people will die in Sudan next year even if the government permits an international relief effort, a senior U.S. aid official said today. ``It will be impossible under the best possible circumstances to avoid starvation deaths in Sudan,'' said Andrew Natsios, head of the U.S. Office for Disaster Assistance. ``We don't have that situation.'' Natsios said 1.2 million tons of food will be needed to feed a third of the nation in 1991. Of that amount, only about 200,000 tons has been pledged by donor nations. All of Sudan apart from some eastern regions has been struck by two years of drought. People already have begun moving to Sudan's capital, Khartoum, from the most seriously effected regions and are forming feeding camps, said Rich Machmer, the head of the U.S. International Agency for Development (AID) office in Khartoum. Many of the estimated 1 million people who died in the 1984-85 Ethiopia famine did so in such unhygienic camps from disease and diarrhea. Machmer, who was AID's chief in Ethiopia during that famine, said the food crisis in Sudan is more severe and threatens 8 to 9 million people. Hindering the launch of a major relief effort is the Sudan government's refusal to admit it has an emergency. ``We have got to get the cooperation of the Sudanese government in this whole effort or it's not going to work,'' said Natsios in a briefing on the work of a regional meeting to coordinate the U.S. response to famines in Sudan and Ethiopia. ``It is safe to say there will be tens of thousands of deaths,'' said Natsios. ``But we want to keep them as low as possible.'' The military regime of Lt. Gen. Omar Hassan el-Bashir has acknowledged a ``food gap'' of a million tons, but has refused to respond to Western donors' urgings that he declare a state of emergency. On Monday, el-Bashir said he would accept food donations only if his government is in charge of transportaion and distribution. Natsios did not comment on the demand, but the United States has criticized the government for alleged attacks on grain stocks to keep them from reaching areas controlled by southern rebels. In the past, Western donors and the United Nations have insisted on at least partial involvement in transportation and distribution to make sure the aid gets to those in need. The relief effort also faces severe logistical problems in Sudan, a vast impoverished nation of 24 million people where trains don't run, river barges don't move and telephones don't work. The neglected road network does not extend far beyond Khartoum. Those most imperiled by the current famine are in western an southern regions difficult to reach. In order to get aid to people before it's too late, 125,000 tons of relief food needs to arrive at Port Sudan in the next two weeks and continue arriving monthly throughout the year, said Machmer.

DOC.HEAD: China Rejects Human Rights Pressure Before U.S. Visit
DOC.TEXT: Foreign Minister Qian Qichen indicated today that China will not be moved by the forthcoming visit of a U.S. human rights envoy who is expected to call for the release of jailed democracy activists. In a lengthy article excerpted in the official Guangming Daily, Qian said Western countries that criticized China's domestic policies, especially the United States, already have relaxed their stance without China making concessions. ``China was not forced to submit, nor was it isolated,'' he wrote in the article, which is to appear in full in this week's issue of the Communist Party magazine ``Seek Truth.'' ``There are still some Americans making indiscreet remarks about other countries' internal affairs. We hope they will clearly see that although it gives us some difficulties if they cause trouble for China, it also hurts American interests,'' Qian said. The same hard line was reflected in a protest the Foreign Ministry lodged today with the Norwegian government. The ministry said a recent meeting between Norwegian Foreign Minister Thorvald Stotenberg and escaped Chinese dissident Chai Ling was a ``gross interference in China's internal affairs.'' Ms. Chai, a student, is wanted by Chinese police for her leading role in last year's massive pro-democracy protests. She fled after the Chinese army opened fire on the demonstrators, killing hundreds. Qian's article appeared three days before the arrival of Richard Schifter, U.S. assistant secretary of state for human rights and humanitarian affairs. The U.S. government announced two weeks ago, while Qian was in Washington, that Schifter would visit but has not said what he plans to discuss. He is expected to plead the cause of hundreds of students, intellectuals and others who remain jailed for taking part in the demonstrations. The visit is an attempt by the Bush administration to demonstrate its concern for human rights in China even while it eases sanctions against Beijing. The United States and other industrialized democracies halted easy-term loans and weapons sales to China and froze high-level exchanges after the democracy movement was crushed. Most of the sanctions have crumbled as the West has sought China's cooperation in the United Nations in pressuring Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait. The European Community lifted all sanctions except the ban on weapons sales in October. Although Washington said its ban on high-level exchanges remains in place, Qian's official visit to Washington appeared to rob the sanction of its meaning. The United States also has restored credits for exports to China, allowed the World Bank to resume lending to China and ended special restrictions on technology transfers. Qian wrote that the lifting of sanctions showed the West recognized China's role in the United Nations in solving the gulf crisis and the Cambodian conflict ``is a weighty one.'' Official and ordinary Americans ``all want to restore Chinese-American relations as quickly as possible,'' he said. He said China wants to increase its foreign ties but added, ``We won't beg from any country.''

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Receiving Food From Many Sources
With PM-Soviet-Food
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 4 grafs to UPDATE with EC aid. Pickup 5th, `President Bush..'
DOC.TEXT: The European Community today approved a $1 billion emergency food aid package for the Soviet Union in the latest promise to help feed the Soviets during their long, harsh winter. The Swedish and U.S. governments, which had hesitated at sending food aid to the Soviet Union, joined 19 other countries this week in promising or delivering help. The Soviet government said Thursday it had already received 1,700 tons of food and 800 tons of medicine and other aid. Here is a breakdown of the international aid offered so far: -The $1 billion from the European Community will be in grants and loans but the proportion of each has not been decided. -President Bush said Wednesday he was making the Soviets eligible for up to $1 billion in credits to buy U.S. agricultural products ranging from grain to cheese. U.S. private aid groups, including AmeriCares and CARE, have sent at least 50 tons of medical supplies and food packages. -The German government has approved shipment of the Berlin stockpile 214,500 tons of meat, milk and medicine stored for 40 years to thwart another Soviet blockade - plus 35,000 tons of army reserve supplies. The Red Cross, CARE, Roman Catholic and Lutheran aid agencies have sent truck convoys and air shipments with tons of food worth several hundred thousand dollars. -The Japanese government says it will provide technological assistance in transportation and distribution. The municipal government of Kawasaki, south of Tokyo, sent the first Japanese aid Tuesday - 92,300 dollars worth of hypodermic needles, syringes and other medical supplies. -The Swedish government has granted export credits for Soviet buyers to import 500,000 tons of wheat, and would soon grant credits for another one million tons. A private doctors' relief group sent three trucks to Leningrad this week carrying meat, powdered milk and medicines. -The Norwegian government has appropriated $1.7 million for food aid to be distributed mainly in the Arctic border region. Individual Norwegians and church groups have sent food and clothes. -The British government in November established a ``know-how fund'' of nearly $10 million to give technical assistance in agriculture and food distribution over two years. British schoolchildren are collecting canned food. -Swiss Army volunteers plan to drive a convoy of 320 tons of food from army stocks to Moscow and Leningrad after Jan. 1. The Swiss government promised a 40-ton emergency airlift and said 1,000 tons of Swiss cheese were available. -The Italian group Together for Peace has shipped nearly 100 tons of cheese, milk, vegetables and medical supplies. -In Israel, the Jewish Agency, a quasi-governmental group which resettles Soviet emigres, sent 25 tons of fruit, vegetables and powdered milk. -Austria has promised 100,000 food parcels and medical supplies. -Australia signed an agreement in Moscow on Nov. 25 to give the Soviet Union up to $400 million worth of credits to buy Australian wool, wheat and other commodities. -Spain, France and Canada have offered financial aid to buy food. -India plans to loan the Soviets 1 million tons of wheat and to give 20,000 tons of rice as well as medicines, medical supplies and processed food.

DOC.HEAD: Fire Destroys Seven Buildings in Revere, Mass., Residential Area
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 13 grafs to UPDATE with state of emergency, estimate of evacuees tops 100, raise wind chill reference, additional fire chief quote and recast, picking up at 12th graf pvs, `Police Capt...'. Name Yn Koeut is cq in 7th graf.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos BX8, BX9, BX11
DOC.TEXT: A suspicious fire whipped by high wind roared through a densely populated city block early today, destroying at least seven three-family houses and forcing dozens of families to flee. No deaths or serious injuries were reported, but at least seven firefighters and three residents suffered minor injuries. ``It's amazing there is no loss of life,'' said Revere Fire Inspector Gene Dougherty, who described the neighborhood as ``the most congested in the city.'' Authorities said the fire was one of three suspicious blazes overnight within a half-mile or so in this working-class suburb north of Boston. The other two were far less serious. All fire equipment in the Boston metropolitan area was made available to Revere, and at least 17 departments sent men. Revere Mayor George Colella declared a state of emergency in the city. He said the blaze displaced 125 to 160 residents of the neighborhood of mostly Asian, Hispanic and Portuguese residents. ``I could smell the fire,'' said Yn Koeut, who fled with his son, Savam, 13. ``I wake up and saw the burning on Highland (Avenue). I call police. They told me to go to the Red Cross.'' The third and worst of the three suspicious fires started about 2:45 a.m. in a boarded-up building, and wind gusting up to 30 mph blew embers that spread the blaze to nearby occupied homes. It was declared under control at 6:40 a.m. The wind combined with temperatures in the 20s to produce a wind-chill effect of near zero, and firemen had to work on ice-covered streets. Some fire engines were completely encased in ice. The three-story frame buildings, common to the region, are called ``triple-deckers'' and were built to accommodate three families. Fire Chief James Connery declared the fire a conflagration, ``the highest level of fire you can declare. When you declare a conflagration, mutual aid automatically takes over.'' Asked if the fire was related to the two other suspicious fires in the city overnight, Connery said said it seemed to be. Police said they were looking for a white car that had been seen behind buildings in the area. ``I can't tell definitely that they were deliberately set, but it certainly looks that way,'' Connery said. ``There were too many fires in too short a time.'' Police Capt. Harold Fulton said officers were patrolling to prevent looting. He said there were no reports of any looting. Al Barbosa, 25, whose house escaped the flames, said he and others helped evacuate three buildings. He said some of those rescued were invalids, ``and some didn't even know there was a fire. They were still asleep.'' ``My tenant and I went up on the roof with buckets of water to try to keep the embers from catching, but eventually the firemen ordered us out,'' said David Coderre, owner of the tenement across the street from where the fire started. The fire gutted his building. ``I had everything in there,'' said Roberta Stairs, his third-floor tenant and the mother of eight. ``I don't know what we'll do for Christmas now.''

DOC.HEAD: South Korean President Meets with Gorbachev
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with details of leaders' declaration. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: South Korean President Roh Tae-woo and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today signed a declaration of ``trust and cooperation'' between the two countries, the Tass news agency reported. Roh, the first leader in South Korea's history to visit the Soviet Union, was also expected to sign a trade agreement with the Soviets. He arrived in Moscow on Thursday and concluded talks with Gorbachev today. Reports in South Korea said Roh would offer loans of $2.5 billion to the Soviet Union during his trip. Diplomatic sources in Seoul said Gorbachev is expected to visit South Korea before or after his trip to Japan in the spring. The preamble of the declaration signed today said the two countries ``are fully determined to build their relations in the spirit of good-neighborliness, trust and cooperation,'' Tass said. The declaration called for easing tensions between North and South Korea and ``the establishment of a climate of trust for the sake of future unification.'' It said the two sides will coordinate efforts to fight international terrorism, organized crime and illegal drug trafficking, as well joining forces to protect the environment. Gorbachev and Roh also agreed to establish relations in the political, economic, trade, cultural, scientific, and humanitarian fields, Tass said. Roh is scheduled to hold two rounds of talks with Gorbachev and visit Leningrad before returning home Monday. Roh and his wife were welcomed in a formal ceremony at St. George's Hall in the Kremlin Thursday by Gorbachev and his wife, Raisa. ``Our two countries have closed the chapter on the Cold War and opened a new era of peace and cooperation,'' Roh said in an arrival statement distributed by Tass. Before he left Seoul, Roh said his trip signified the imminent end of hostilities with his country's bitter rival North Korea, a longtime ally of the Soviet Union. ``The opening of the road for friendship and cooperation between us and the Soviet Union is directly related to opening a road for peace and unification of the Korean Peninsula,'' he said. After reaching a low point in 1983 when a Soviet fighter jet shot down Korean Air Flight 007 that had strayed over Soviet airspace, killing all 269 people aboard, relations between the two countries improved rapidly after Moscow sent a large delegation to the 1988 Summer Olympics in Seoul. In June, Gorbachev and Roh met in San Francisco and agreed to normalize relations. Formal diplomatic ties were established Sept. 30.

DOC.HEAD: Union Leader Murdered in Northeastern Brazil
With PM-Slain Ecologist
DOC.TEXT: Assailants shot and killed a rural union leader who had defied powerful sugar barons in northeastern Brazil, police said today. Police said Jose Helio da Silva was shot down in a sugar cane field Thursday near the Farm Workers Union in Palmares, a sugar-producing town in Pernambuco state, 1,600 miles northeast of Sao Paulo. Palmares police chief Joaquim Donati said da Silva and union treasurer Jose Cicero Leite were driving along a highway when a car started chasing them. ``They stopped the car and hid in a cane field but the gunmen found them,'' Donati said in a telephone interview. He said da Silva was ``shot once in the back and died instantly. Leite was wounded in the left leg.'' The slaying occurred on the second day of the trial of two ranchers accused of ambushing and killing environmentalist and union leader Chico Mendes in Brazil's Amazon region in 1988. The trial has focused worldwide attention on a cause advocated by Mendes, preserving the Brazilian rain forest from ranchers and farmers who are cutting it down and, according to some environomentalists, thereby threatening a vital ecosystem and the lifestyles of jungle residents. Da Silva recently received an anonymous letter warning that he would ``end up like Chico Mendes,'' according to the president of the Farm Workers Union, Joao Luca da Silva. ``We are sure the gunmen were hired by our enemies, the sugar and (fuel) alcohol producers of the region,'' said Luca da Silva, who is not related to the victim. ``They wanted him dead because he was an excellent strike organizer and was always demanding better working conditions and decent wages for sugar cane cutters.'' Donati said the shooting ``could have been a personal vendetta. Da Silva had a daily radio program in which he always offended all kinds of people in the region.'' Donati would not say if sugar and fuel alcohol producers were among those da Silva insulted in his program. The Association of Sugar and Alcohol Producers, reached by telephone, said no one was available to comment on the union accusations.

DOC.HEAD: Former Rep. Dennis Sieminski, D-N.J., Dies
DOC.TEXT: Alfred Dennis Sieminski, a onetime Democratic member of Congress from New Jersey who served as an Army officer in World War II and Korea, died Thursday. He was 79. Friends said Sieminski collapsed and died while attending the annual Christmas party of the McLean, Va., Kiwanis Club. He was a resident of the nearby suburb of Vienna. A native of Jersey City, N.J., and a 1934 graduate of Princeton University, Sieminski also studied at Hamburg Uuniversity in Germany, the University of Warsaw and Harvard University Law School. At Princeton he was a member of the university boxing team and was a member of the Princeton crew which raced at the Henley Regatta in England. When the United States entered World War II he enlisted as a private. He ended the war as a captain in the military government division in Austria after service in the Italian campaign. He was discharged to the infantry reserve as a major in 1950 and promoted to lieutenant colonel in the reserves in 1956. Sieminski was elected to Congress in 1951. He won re-election three times but was an unsuccessful candidate for renomination in 1958. He worked at the Medical and General Reference Library at the Veterans' Administration from 1962 to 1973. He is survived by his wife, the former Countess Marie Felice Czarkowski-Golejewska; two stepdaughters, Isabella Noyes of San Francisco and Christine Elizabeth Andreoni of Sydney, Australia; a stepson, Professor Roman Mycielski of the University of Warsaw, and five grandchildren.

DOC.HEAD: Dozens Visit Grave on Anniversary of Sakharov Death
DOC.TEXT: Dozens of mourners came to a Moscow cemetery today to pay homage to Andrei D. Sakharov, the Nobel Peace Prize laureate and human rights campaigner who died a year ago. The legislature of the Russian republic opened today's session with a tribute to Sakharov, and national newspapers published articles praising him. At the Vostyakovsky cemetery in southwest Moscow, Sakharov's headstone was covered in evergreen branches and carnations of all colors. Red sashes were hung on wreaths, including one from the Congress of People's Deputies of Russia. ``It's common knowledge that Sakharov was a man of genius, but he also linked genius with civil courage, which I value even more,'' said Valery Zlemin, who had come to the cemetery to mark the anniversary of Sakharov's death. ``Civil courage is turning words into action.'' In the year since Sakahrov's death at age 68, friends and colleagues in the human rights movement have battled for his cause, but they say no one has emerged to take his place. Baruch Froyimovich, a 67-year-old pensioner, said: ``I can't see anybody today who could take his place.'' But, Froyimovich said, he was optimistic about the future. ``There are enough people in Russia who are intelligent, talented and loyal.'' The Moscow newspaper Leninskoye Znamiya said, ``History has already had its say on Sakharov. He belongs to it. At the same time, he is near us, he stayed in the hearts of all who wanted to have him.'' Other newspapers printed pictures of Sakharov and reprinted speeches he made at demonstrations and at the national Supreme Soviet parliament. Since he died of heart failure last year, public esteem has continued to climb for the physicist who helped invent the Soviet hydrogen bomb and later won the Nobel Peace Prize for his political dissidence. A decade ago, Sakharov was denounced in the official press as an ``utterly ignorant person'' and banished to the industrial city of Gorky for criticizing the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan. He spent seven years in exile before being recalled to Moscow by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev in 1986. He later became an outspoken deputy in the Supreme Soviet parliament and champion of the human rights movement.

DOC.HEAD: Palestinians Blamed For Stabbing Deaths of Three Jews; Mob Demands Revenge
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 21 grafs to UPDATE with Arab stabbed, police version of events. Pickup 21st pvs, `A witness...' ^LaserPhotos TLV1,3,5
DOC.TEXT: Palestinians today fatally stabbed three Jews in a factory in this Tel Aviv suburb, and an angry mob of Israelis responded by attacking Arab cars and passers-by. The slayings were carried out to mark the third anniversary of the founding of Hamas, or Zeal, an extremist Moslem fundamentalist movement that backs the Palestinian uprising, police said. Tel Aviv police spokeswoman Ettie Grinberg said the bodies of the victims, two male factory workers and a woman secretary, were discovered in a factory building beneath slogans attributing the deaths to Hamas. Police detained Arab workers from nearby factories for questioning. Hundreds of angry Jews gathered at the site, shouting ``Death to the Arabs!'' and ``No work for the Arabs!'' and accusing police of lack of action. The windows of one car were smashed as the Arab driver fled, and it was later set on fire. Two other cars were damaged by stones, an Arab suffered a minor stab injury and three Jewish rioters were arrested, police said. Reinforcements of paramilitary border police poured into Jaffa to help control the mob. ``Let's do to them what they do to us,'' bellowed one man. ``If we aren't safe among them, they shouldn't be safe among us.'' Police Minister Roni Milo said he would propose to the Cabinet new limitations on Palestinians from the Gaza Strip and the West Bank entering Israel. He told Israel radio he already had ordered police to step up efforts to find Arabs staying illegally in the Jewish state. ``All the elements using terrorism must know that cruel terrorism of the kind we see today will get a harsh and unequivocal response,'' he said. Police blocked journalists from entering the factory, apparently an aluminum plant. When police brought out the bodies, wrapped in black plastic bags, the crowd charged at police officers and reporters, punching and beating them. Police Commissioner Yaacov Terner described the slaying as a ``grave event ... The reason for this murder is one, nationalism. The slogans written in Arabic on the walls inside are clear.'' Hamas, or Zeal, had called for a day of escalation in the 3-year-old Palestinian uprising today to mark the third anniversary of the group's founding. The call was issued in a clandestine leaflet distributed earlier in December. The leaflet also urged ``the escalation of Jihad (Holy War) operation inside and outside Israel.'' Terner said police were pursuing two Palestinians, one of whom worked at the factory. Both were from the occupied Gaza Strip, a stronghold of Hamas. Many Gazans work in Tel Aviv and Jaffa, a mixed Arab-Jewish suburb. The army radio described the two as brothers and Hamas members. Two suspects were reported detained but released after questioning. Police later said they were holding no suspects. Police officials said roadblocks were erected throughout Tel Aviv and every car entering Gaza was being carefully searched. Police gave the following order of events: At about 7 a.m. an Arab from the Gaza Strip who works at the plant arrived with an accomplice and waited for Jewish staff to come and open the premises. About an hour later Iris Asraf, a 22-year-old secretary, arrived with Moshe Awan, 40, a metalcutter, and the four entered the plant. Yehoshua Hakmaz, 30, an upholsterer working next door, heard screams soon afterward and ran to help. At 8:30 a.m. another secretary, Penina Arbiv, arrived and entered the plant. She found pools of blood and knives lying on the floor. She ran out crying for help, and a policeman went in and found Awan, Hakmaz and Ms. Asraf dead. A witness who did not give his name told Israel radio he saw one man ``lying on the steps, folded like a bag.... The knives were thrown near the body, long knives with wide blades, real commando knives.'' At least 54 Jews have been killed by Palestinians in the revolt against Israeli rule in the occupied West Bank and the Gaza Strip that began Dec. 9 1987. On Dec. 2 this year, three West Bank Arabs boarded a bus in Tel Aviv, stabbed a Jew to death and wounded three others. In the uprising, 778 Arabs have been killed by Israeli troops or civilians. In addition, Palestinians have murdered 316 fellow Arabs on suspicion of collaborating with Israel.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Delegation in Europe to Free Noriega Accounts
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. government delegation is in Europe seeking to unfreeze Manuel Noriega's bank accounts for use in his legal defense, a federal prosecutor said today. The delegation consists of State Department and Justice Department officials who are visiting Austria and Switzerland, but most details of their visit are secret, said Assistant U.S. Attorney Michael Sullivan. About $20 million is sitting in 27 Noriega-linked accounts, and U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler has ordered $6 million of those funds paid into a trust account to cover attorneys fees and expenses for the deposed Panamanian dictator, who says he has no other funds. The delegation's visit is ``to discuss the possibility of unfreezing the accounts that are being designated as the general's,'' Sullivan said. ``the discussions are ongoing.'' Until the funds are freed, the judge asked Noriega's defense counsel to take a temporary appointment as government-paid attorneys, but they id not immediately respond. Lead attorney Frank Rubino has previously rejected that arrangement because fees are limited to a maximum of $75 an hour, far less than the $350 an hour he says is appropriate in a complex drug-trafficking case. The U.S. delegation was sent to Europe after Hoeveler said he would hold a formal hearing to make prosecutors justify freezing the assets. That would force them to reveal much of their case in advance, the defense has said. The funds were originally frozen at U.S. request following the December 1989 invasion of Panama and the subsequent capture of Noriega. But in June, the judge ordered the money unfrozen for Noriega's defense. Last month, however, federal prosecutors told the judge that foreign governments had initiated their own forfeiture proceedings, tying up the money. Also at today's hearing, the judge said he would set a new trial date for Noriega, although some of his co-defendants could be tried on Jan. 28 as planned. Rubino said the defense could not be ready before June at the earliest, and Hoeveler said he would take that under advisement. The judge also said he wanted a contempt hearing soon against CNN to determine if the network violated a court order by telecasting a taped prison telephone call between Noriega and his defense team. While transcripts from the tapes eventually were made public, CNN's decision last month to telecast parts of them despite a court order is still at issue. Noriega attorney Jon May said the network had informed him it will present a full defense against the contempt citation, a defense which legal experts have said could once again test the balance between freedom of speech and the right to a fair trial. Noriega is confined in the Metropolitan Correctional Center outside Miami facing charges of accepting $4.6 million in bribes to turn Panama into a way station for Colombian drug traffickers.

DOC.HEAD: Canadian Lawmakers Pass Hated Consumption Tax
DOC.TEXT: Canadian lawmakers have passed an unpopular new tax on goods and services, ending months of procedural delays. The bill, pushed through the Senate on Thursday night by Prime Minister Brian Mulroney's Conservatives, now only needs the formality of royal consent to become law. The vote was 55-49. The opposition Liberals were outraged, saying the Conservative maneuver to end an 11-month filibuster to force the vote was illegal. The goods and services tax, known familiarly as the GST, imposes a 7 percent federal levy on nearly all merchandise and services beginning Jan. 1. The tax is added on top of provincial sales taxes, which range from 8 to 10 percent. That means the buying public will have 15 to 17 percent tacked on to nearly all purchases, including such things as haircuts, music lessons and even postage.
