The GST has been languishing in the unelected Senate since it was passed by the House of Commons in April. The bill was taken up actively with the opening of the autumn session of Parliament on Sept. 25. The Liberals pledged to kill the tax, which polls showed was opposed by 75 percent to 85 percent of the people. More recent polls indicated people were tiring of the debate. Delaying tactics in the Senate included hooting, catcalls, shouting, blowing kazoos, interminable reading of petitions name by name and other delaying measures. More than 1.3 million businesses will help the government collect the tax. Many have spent the last few months reprograming their cash registers and computers and adjusting their pricing in anticipation of the tax. Any delay from the original Jan. 1 deadline for implementation could throw much of Canadian business into confusion. The Liberals held a majority in the Senate until recently. In October, Mulroney used an obscure, never-before implemented section of the constitution that allowed him to ask Queen Elizabeth II to appoint eight extra senators. By filling vacant seats and getting the queen to appoint eight more, Mulroney succeeded in packing the Senate in his favor. Angry Liberals said the forced vote violated Senate rules. The GST is supposed to replace the 13.5 percent manufacturers sales tax, which raises about $10 billion a year but is considered inefficient and levied on a very narrow base. The argument is that the manufacturers sales tax discriminates heavily against industry and hurts Canadian exporting firms. One of the great fears of the public is that once the GST is passed, government will be tempted to increase the rate. With such a broad base, small rate increases can raise enormous amounts of revenue.

DOC.HEAD: With Bennett Suddenly Out, GOP Seeks New Leader
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2 grafs for graf 3 pvs with reax from Loeffler associate.
DOC.TEXT: William Bennett's abrupt decision to reject the Republican Party's top job leaves the GOP scrambling for a leader while still reeling from a dispiriting performance in 1990 elections. But there are indications the vacuum won't exist too long. Administration and party sources said Thursday that President Bush hopes to choose a replacement soon and that the list of candidates likely will be short. Mentioned most frequently as possibilities following Bennett's surprise announcement Thursday were three Cabinet secretaries - Samuel Skinner of Transportation, Robert Mosbacher of Commerce and Jack Kemp of Housing and Urban Development - and attorney Thomas Loeffler, a former Texas congressman and a close friend of Bush. One GOP source said the president spoke with Loeffler about the job Thursday but had not offered it. A Loeffler associate said today that Loeffler had spoken to White House chief of staff John Sununu about the post. The associate said he did not believe Loeffler had spoken directly to the president. ``He is of course interested,'' said the associate, Mike Johnson, who said Loeffler was in Texas. Others mentioned for the job included longtime GOP operative Rich Bond and Republican National Committeeman Haley Barbour of Mississippi, a key party strategist in the South. Republican sources said Bond is lobbying for the job. But Barbour said in a telephone interview he wasn't interested, adding, ``I just don't have an interest in it. I am not soliciting the job and would not want it if asked.'' Two Republican House members who lost Senate bids, Lynn Martin of Illinois and Pat Saiki of Hawaii, were considered long shots, as was Minnesota Sen. Rudy Boschwitz, who lost his re-election bid. Martin and Saiki are contenders for vacant Cabinet posts at the Labor and Education departments. Bennett, saying ``I didn't take a vow of poverty,'' spurned Bush's offer to head the Republican National Committee after White House lawyers told him he'd have to give up a book contract and other outside income. Bush's penchant for surprises left GOP analysts reluctant to make predictions. ``Sam (Skinner) would be a good possibility - there are a lot of people out there who would be good as chairman but I can't say anyone is at the top of the list right now,'' said Charles Black, a political consultant who has been the top RNC spokesman during Chairman Lee Atwater's battle against an inoperable brain tumor. Black, too, was among those mentioned as a potential successor to his close friend Atwater. But he said he told Bush he was not interested. Democrats took delight in the GOP's embarrassment. ``It is appropriate that Bill Bennett's tenure at the RNC lasted about as long as most of President Bush's campaign promises,'' Democratic Chairman Ron Brown said. The RNC meets Jan. 25, with its top priority installing a new chairman to lead the party into the crucial 1992 elections. The GOP had a disappointing performance in the Nov. 6 off-year elections, as Democrats strengthened their hold on Congress and captured the governorships of Florida and Texas from the GOP. Bennett emerged as Bush's pick within weeks of announcing he was resigning as the nation's drug czar, and Bush made his choice official on Nov. 30. The choice of Bennett was widely interpreted as an attempt by Bush to make amends with the party's vocal conservative wing, never high on Bush and openly at war with the White House since the president dumped his ``no new taxes'' campaign pledge. Conservatives demanded that one of their own be tapped in Bennett's stead. ``Now, if the party chairmanship went to a member of the Bush wing, conservatives would feel seduced and abandoned even more than before,'' said Richard Viguerie, chairman of United Conservatives of America. ``The clear message to conservatives would be: we don't need you.'' Vigueie and his allies were pushing Kemp for the post. But a top Kemp aide said the housing secretary was not interested, and Kemp has several differences with the president on domestic issues, including taxes.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Distributor Recalls U.S.-Made Game Because of Derogatory Terms
DOC.TEXT: A U.S.-manufactured board game that uses derogatory language toward Japanese minorities is being pulled from store shelves by its Japanese distributor, a company official said today. The instruction manual for the game, ``Land of Ninja,'' uses a disparaging name for a former Japanese outcast class and calls another minority group ``barbarians.'' ``We have decided to completely stop selling the game because some people have objected to it,'' said Kosuke Fukumoto, an official of Hobby Japan Co., the distributor. He said the company also has halted plans to produce a Japanese-language version of the role-playing game, which is based on feudal Japanese society. Although less than 200 copies of the game were sold in Japan at a list price of $35, the distributor moved quickly to withdraw it after it was criticized by the Buraku Liberation League. The league, which claims 200,000 members, has fought discrimination faced by burakumin, a former outcast group estimated to number between 1 million and 3 million out of Japan's total population of 123 million. Hundreds of years ago, the burakumin, or village people, worked in religiously proscribed occupations such as butchering and leather working. They lived in special neighborhoods, or buraku, and when maps were drawn, the buraku were omitted. Although racially identical to other Japanese, the burakumin continue to face difficulties in employment and marriage more than 100 years after their outcast status was officially abolished in 1871. Japan's family registry system allows people to be traced to their ancestral communities, although public access to the registries has been limited in recent years. ``We definitely feel there are serious problems with the game,'' a league official said. The league said it plans to send a delegation to the United States to meet with the maker of the game, Baltimore-based Avalon Hill Game Co. In the game, players make a journey after being assigned roles such as samurai warrior, ninja, or Buddhist priest. The manual describes feudal Japan by dividing all occupations into four descending hierarchical groups - nobles, samurai, commoners and eta. The latter term, a derogatory name for burakumin meaning ``great filth,'' is defined in the game as ``those outside normal society such as ninja, thieves and entertainers.'' The game, introduced in 1987, also refers to native Ainu people, another minority, as ``barbarian inhabitants'' of northern Japan. In reporting the game's withdrawal, several Japanese newspapers suggested a comparison between U.S. insensitivity to Japanese minority issues and Japanese insensitivity to American racial problems. In September, U.S. minority groups demanded the dismissal of Justice Minister Seiroku Kajiyama after he compared American blacks to prostitutes in Japan. He said prostitutes ``ruin the atmosphere of the neighborhoods they move into. The area is becoming mixed just like in America, where blacks move in and whites are forced out.'' Kajiyama apologized for the remarks, and Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu pledged to improve Japanese understanding of U.S. minority issues.

DOC.HEAD: Labor Official Says Tentative Settlement Reached in NYC Garbage Strike
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 4 grafs to UPDATE with union confirmation of agreement, raise reference to garbage. Picks up 5th graf pvs, `The walkout...'.
DOC.TEXT: Private sanitation workers have agreed to a tentative settlement of a strike that has left mounds of uncollected garbage growing on sidewalks, union and city officials said. City Labor Relations Commissioner Eric Schmertz announced the agreement Thursday evening after meeting with union and management representatives for about seven hours. Teamsters Local 813 recording secretary Marty Adelstein confirmed the agreement today and said the union was recommending its passage. A ratification vote was scheduled for this afternoon. Neither Adelstein nor Schmertz would disclose the terms of the contract. A spokesman for management did not return phone messages left this morning. The walkout was in its fifth day today. The 2,100 striking workers pick up trash from some 250,000 businesses citywide. Residential garbage collection - done by the city - is unaffected. Besides better wages, the unions want private carters to pay a fee for using out-of-state workers to haul trash to out-of-state dumps - a demand the companies have rejected. New York's $1 billion private sanitation industry was last struck in 1981 for 17 days, during which frigid weather helped ease the public health threat. In that case, the strike ended just as the mayor's office issued a citywide order for municipal crews to start collecting the garbage. This year the weather has been mild - Thursday's high was around 60 degrees. Businesses who fear their garbage could be a health or fire hazard can request an emergency pickup from the city Sanitation Department.

DOC.HEAD: News Report Says Libya Was Responsible For Flight 103 Bombing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 11 grafs to UPDATE with comment from Briish spokesman. Pickup 8th pvs, `The paper...'
DOC.TEXT: A London newspaper today quoted sources close to the public inquiry into the 1988 Pan Am Flight 103 bombing as saying they have proof that Libya was responsible. The Independent quoted the unidentified high-level sources as saying the conclusion was based on analysis of a detonator fragment found in a field close to the southern Scottish town of Lockerbie. It said the evidence had come to light only in the past three months. The newspaper said the confirmation of Libyan involvement refutes a theory that Syrian-based Palestinian faction was responsible for the bombing. It quoted the sources as saying action now against Libya could alienate Arab members of the international force in the Persian Gulf - and for that reason no indictments had been issued against the major suspects. A spokesman for the Lord Advocate, Lord Fraser, Scotland's senior law officer, said he could not comment on ``media speculation.'' ``But indictments are not being drawn up,'' said the spokesman, speaking on condition of anonymity. The Boeing 747 was blown up over Lockerbie on Dec. 21, 1988 while on its way to New York. All 259 people on board and 11 others on the ground were killed. The flight originated in Frankfurt, Germany, with a stop at London's Heathrow airport. Investigators have concluded that a bomb hidden in a radio-cassette recorder was responsible for the explosion, but speculation has varied wildly on which group planned the bombing. A public inquiry into the bombing opened at Dumfries near Lockerbie on Oct. 1. It was adjourned on Dec. 7 until Jan. 22. Previous reports had speculated that the bombing was planned by a German-based cell of the radical Damascus-based Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine-General Command, headed by Ahmed Jibril. The Palestinians reportedly made the bomb with Semtex, a Czechoslovak explosive. The Independent quoted the sources as saying the detonator fragment was identical to a Swiss-manufactured fragment found in a radio-cassette bomb seized from two Libyan secret agents arrested at Dakar airport in Senegal in February 1988, 10 months before the Flight 103 attack. The paper reported: ``Reports of possible Libyan involvement have surfaced recently in the French and U.S. media but, for the first time, senior sources have now confirmed that proof exists implicating (Libyan leader) Col. Moammar Gadhafi's regime.'' It quoted one of the sources as saying: ``Not only do we now know Gadhafi was responsible, he also knows we know.'' The paper quoted the sources as saying any U.S. action against Libya would risk alienating Arab members of the U.S.-led multinational force arrayed against Iraq in the Persian Gulf. ``For that reason no indictments have yet been issued against the prime suspects and the force of Scottish detectives in charge of the criminal investigation into the bombing has not formally been given the new evidence by other elements of the international inquiry team,'' it reported. The team includes members of the FBI, CIA and German and British intelligence agencies.

DOC.HEAD: Last Year's Megabucks Christmas Present is This Year's Court Battle
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs the 5-9th grafs, bgng `In the suit...', with 10 grafs to update with comment from lawyer on background of suit. Picks up at penultimate graf.
DOC.TEXT: They were last year's heartwarming Christmas story - a man giving his brother a $9 million lottery ticket. But the gift Earl Havlock gave his brother this year was a lawsuit demanding the money back. The suit was filed in Superior Court on Monday, the same day the commission that operates the Tri-State Megabucks lottery issued a news release recalling last year's events and saying the brothers epitomized ``the spirit of the holidays.'' ``They did last year, that's for sure,'' New Hampshire Sweepstakes Director James Wimsatt said Thursday. ``Times change.'' Earl, 43, won the Tri-State Megabucks lottery jackpot two days before Christmas last year and turned his winning ticket over to Elwood, 50. After taxes, the prize amounted to 20 annual payments of $357,600. The first payment was made last December. Earl, three other brothers and a sister claim that Earl is mentally disabled and had no intention of giving away his winnings. The petition says Earl told sweeps officials and the public that he bought the winning ticket as a Christmas present for Elwood - which wasn't true - after Elwood told him that holding onto the jackpot would jeopardize his monthly disability payments. Earl, who is unable to work, was getting by on Social Security checks and money from Elwood last year when he bought the ticket. At the time, he said that the ticket for the Maine-New Hampshire-Vermont lottery was a Christmas gift and he never considered keeping it, even after he knew it was a winner. ``His brother's advice was to misrepresent to the Tri-State Megabucks Commission that this was a gift from Earl to Elwood,'' said the plaintiffs' lawyer, Robert Foley. ``But a side deal to require Elwood to share the money with all six was not made public. That's the deception that is coming back to haunt all of them.'' Foley said it boils down to an agreement that has not worked out as the brothers and sister had hoped. ``It is important for the Havlocks to let people know they are not angry at their brother, Elwood,'' he said. ``They felt this litigation is necessary to set the record straight.'' Foley said Earl has a mental disability, saying he is ``very unsophisicated, perhaps gullible and not very knowledgeable about money or the law.'' Foley said part of the reason for filing the suit was that Elwood's wife, Rowena, is claiming a portion of the winnings in a divorce action. ``Rowena was making claim on half the jackpot,'' he said. There was no answer at Elwood's home this morning. His lawyer, Stephen Kain of Laconia, could not comment because he was in a meeting, a secretary said today. Wimsatt said unless the court rules otherwise, the money will continue to go to Elwood because he signed the form claiming the lottery prize. ``We honor the winner claim form as presented,'' he said. ``He gave it to his brother and his brother filed a claim.''

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Receives Nobel Medal and Cash in Kremlin Ceremony
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Friday received the Nobel Peace Prize medal and a cash award in a Kremlin ceremony, and he said he would donate the money to medical centers, Tass reported. The diploma, medal and cash were given to Gorbachev by First Deputy Foreign Minister Anatoly Kovalev, who traveled to Oslo, Norway, on Monday to receive the prize on behalf of the Soviet president. Gorbachev said he had decided to donate the $715,000 prize money, and the $450,000 from Italy's Fiuggi Prize given him earlier this year, to children's medical centers. ``I think the money should be spent on health-promoting activities for children, first of all in ecological disasters,'' Tass quoted Gorbachev as saying. The Norwegian Nobel Committee said in Oslo that the 71st Peace Prize was a recognition of Gorbachev's international efforts more than his domestic policies. Domestic problems prevented the Soviet leader from traveling to Oslo to collect the prize.

DOC.HEAD: Former Interior Minister Taken Into Custody
DOC.TEXT: The former interior minister under Communist rule, Frantisek Kincl, was taken into custody on charges of abusing his power, the CTK news agency said Friday. Other news reports said Kincl had been charged and faced up to 10 years in prison if found guilty. CTK quoted the prosecutor's office as saying the former interior minister was interrogated at a military prosecutor's office in Pribram in central Bohemia, then arrested. The daily Lidove Noviny said Kincl's former first deputy, Alojz Lorenz, and counter-intelligence chief Karel Vykypel also were charged with abuse of power. It said the three were accused of trying to stop dissident activities in 1988-1989 by detaining or harassing activists. So far, former Prague Communist Party chief Miroslav Stepan is the only leading official to have been convicted since the country's revolution against communism last year. He was given a 30-month prison term.

DOC.HEAD: Lost Church Money Returned
DOC.TEXT: A department store sales clerk proved to be the main ingredient to a heartwarming recipe when he found a money bag containing proceeds from a church bake sale and luncheon. Donald Lavoie, 39, was driving Thursday when he spotted it. ``I picked up the bag and it jingled,'' said Lavoie. ``I saw that it was a bank bag and immediately took it to the police department. I didn't even open it, but I knew there had to be a lot of money in there.'' Police discovered a bank deposit slip inside. It turned out that Carol Chapman had placed the bag on her car's roof when she went to run errands - which were supposed to include the bank deposit - and it fell off. She wasn't aware the bag was missing until she reached the bank. ``That was when panic set in,'' Chapman said. ``I called the police and lo and behold, this wonderful man had picked it up and turned it in.'' Police said the bag contained $547 in cash and $249 in checks raised at the First Congregational Church of Christ. Chapman offered Lavoie a $100 reward. He initially refused to take it. But she insisted, telling him he could donate the money to charity if he desired. Lavoie, who recently retired from te Air Force after 20 years, said he donated the money to the Special Olympics because his son is mentally handicapped and the program has helped him. ``It was a wonderful, wonderful experience,'' Chapman said. ``It certainly restored my faith in mankind.''

DOC.HEAD: Casino Head Takes Sting Out of Mosquito Remark
DOC.TEXT: A casino executive apologized to Gov. Jim Florio for elevating the mosquito to the status of New Jersey state bird and gave the governor a 12-foot pink flyswatter to take the sting out of the remark. John Allan, president of Carnival's Crystal Palace in Nassau, The Bahamas, conceded at a news conference Thursday with Florio that promotional material for his casino maligned the state. The material distributed earlier this year contained a flyswatter and the text read: ``It's muggy out there. That's why they've made the mosquito New Jersey's state bird.'' Florio protested and called on Allan to recant in a strongly worded letter in August. Allan told The Associated Press at the time that the governor was overreacting. Allan, who lives in Absecon, said he pays the state a high compliment by ``living in New Jersey and commuting to the Bahamas.'' ``I'd like to take a last swat if I could,'' Allan said Thursday, grabbing the 12-foot flyswatter and throwing it to the floor of the governor's outer office. ``The mosquito as New Jersey's bird ... that bugged me a lot,'' Florio said, accepting the apology.

DOC.HEAD: Former Member of Congress Dead at 79
DOC.TEXT: Former Rep. Alfred Dennis Sieminski, a decorated veteran who won election to Congress while he was fighting in the Korean War, has died at 79. The Jersey City, N.J., Democrat served in the House from 1951 to 1959. Sieminski died suddenly Thursday while attending the annual Christmas dinner of the McLean, Va., Kiwanis Club. He lived in nearby Vienna, Va. He earned a political science degree in 1934 from Princeton University, where he was a member of a crew team that raced at the Henley Regatta in England. He also studied at Hamburg University in Germany, the University of Warsaw and the Harvard Law School. Sieminski, who attended the New York Military Academy before college, enlisted in the Army as a private in 1941. After serving in Korea, he was discharged into the reserves as a lieutenant colonel. During his military career, he was a recipient of the Legion of Mrit and the Bronze Star. Siemsinki was a life member of the 7th Regiment, New York National Guard and the Association of Former Members of Congress. Sieminski is survived by his wife, the former Countess Marie Felice Czarkowska-Golejewska; two step-daughters, Isabella Noyes of San Francisco and Christine Elizabeth Andreoni of Sydney, Australia; a stepson, Roman Mycielski, a professor at the University of Warsaw; and five grandchildren. Funeral services will be private, with burial in Arlington National Cemetery.

DOC.HEAD: Ozone Hole Shrinking as Summer Returns to Antarctica
DOC.TEXT: With spring arriving in the Southern Hemisphere, the Antarctic ozone hole is closing for the season, National Oceanic and Atmospheric Adminsitration scientists reported Friday. The hole is filling in late this year, said Samuel B. Oltmans of NOAA's Climate Monitoring and Diagnostics Laboratory in Boulder, Colo. The delay was caused by a circle of persistent winds surrounding the Antarctic continent, which prevented air there from mixing with the atmosphere from other regions. NOAA reported that ozone levels over Antarctica climbed to 220 dobson units on Dec. 6 and to 270 units by Dec. 10, according to measurements made by instruments sent aloft by balloons. Ozone over the South Pole reached a low of 130 dobson units in early October, only marginally above the record low measured in 1987. That thinning of the layer is sometimes referred to as a hole, although it amounts to somewhat less than half of the normal ozone level of over 300 units in that part of the world. Ozone, while considered a pollutant at ground level, is vital in the upper atmosphere, where it blocks a portion of the hazardous ultraviolet radiation from the sun. A reduction in ozone could lead to damage to crops and animal life and an increase in skin cancer among humans, some scientists warm. Researchers are concerned that loss of ozone over the Antarctic could indicate a reduction in other areas also, although evidence has yet to be found of such a reduction. The ozone thinning occurs as chemicals react with that gas in the extreme cold of the upper atmosphere in winter. Now that summer is returning to Antarctica, warmer temperatures inhibit those chemical reactions and the ozone hole begins to fill in again. The dobson unit is a measurement of ozone made by comparing how much of each of two wavelengths of sunlight is absorbed by the air. That ratio changes depending on the concentration of ozone.

DOC.HEAD: American Diplomats Flying Home, Cheney Faces Congress
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 2nd graf, `Two Republicans...' with 1 graf and the 14th, `On the...' with 3 grafs to UPDATE with White House disclaimer and UPDATE on oil prices.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf-Freed Hostages, Bjt
LaserPhotos FRA14,WX7
DOC.TEXT: The last U.S. evacuation flight headed home today as Defense Secretary Dick Cheney kept the pressure on Baghdad, telling Congress that ``patience is not producing results'' in world efforts to push Iraq from Kuwait. Two Republican senators said today that President Bush is prepared to call off planned U.S.-Iraqi talks on the Persian Gulf crisis because the two nations have been unable to agree when to meet. But the White House said that while Bush is upset with Iraq he is not prepared to abandon efforts to hold talks. A group of pacifist physicians said today the West is unprepared to cope with the thousands of people who could be injured or killed if fighting breaks out in the gulf, while other doctors headed to the region to try to avert war. A C-5 military transport plane took off from Frankfurt carrying Ambassador to Kuwait Nathaniel Howell among the 23 Americans aboard, 10 non-U.S. citizen family members, officials said. Also aboard were 15 people going to Canada. The plane was headed to Andrews Air Force Base outside Washington. Looking surprisingly fit after months of surviving on canned tuna, Howell told reporters before departing that he slept well at an airport hotel, got a haircut and feasted on sausage, bacon and eggs for breakfast. ``We have a lot of cholesterol to make up for,'' he joked, a reference to the 110-day ordeal at the besieged U.S. Embassy in Kuwait following Iraq's invasion of the emirate Aug. 2. Until Washington said he could leave Thursday, Hoell and his four-member staff in Kuwait had defied Iraqi orders to close foreign missions. British envoys, who had been the only other holdouts, were also expected to leave. Howell and his staff left on the last U.S. charter to evacuate Westerners who had been held by Iraqi President Saddam Hussein to deter a U.S. attack. Hundreds of Westerners have left since Saddam announced a blanket release of hostages on Dec. 6, and U.S. officials said all other Americans who wish to leave can take commercial transportation. In Washington, Cheney told the House Armed Services Committee that if the economic attempts and diplomatic efforts to solve the crisis fail, the United States must have the option of using force to oust Iraq from Kuwait. ``Having a capacity for patience does not mean we must remain patient when patience is not producing results. We must always have other options,'' Cheney said. He was responding to Democratic calls to give economic sanctions against Iraq more time. Sens. Richard Lugar, R-Ind., and John McCain, R-Ariz., met with Bush this morning and said Bush is prepared to call off U.S. talks with Baghdad aimed at heading off war. The two governments have been unable to agree on a date for Secretary of State James A. Baker III to visit Baghdad to talk to Saddam, and for Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz to meet with Bush in Washington. The administration wants the Aziz meeting next week and the Baker talks by early January. ``The president - as I gather his mood today - is prepared to have no meetings rather than to see a lot of shoving around ... if we have no meetings so be it,'' Lugar told reporters. But White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said the two senators who met with Bush went too far when they told reporters the president was prepared to abandon efforts to set dates for the talks. ``The president's concerned and he's upset that Saddam'' can't set an acceptable date for the Baker talks, but ``the president proposed them (the talks) and wants them to happen,'' Fitzwater said. On the financial markets, meanwhile, traders said the continued statemate of U.S.-Iraqi talks drove oil prices up in trading today. Light sweet crude oil for January delivery was up $1.43 per barrel at $27.85 early this afternoon on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Saddam has an estimated 500,000 troops massed in Kuwait and southern Iraq, facing about 350,000 anti-Iraqi soldiers, including an American force of 250,000 that should grow to 400,000 by mid-January. In London, a report released today by the Medical Campaign Against Nuclear Weapons said plans being made for gulf war casualties will be inadequate. The group, citing a report last month by the Washington-based Center for Defense Information, anticipates military and civilian casualties of 314,000, including 63,000 dead, in a gulf conflict. A British Ministry of Defense spokeswoman, speaking on condition of anonymity, said medical group was speculating wildly on numbers. The Medical Campaign Against Nuclear War is the British affiliate of the International Physicians for the Prevention of Nuclear War, which announced Thursday it was sending a peace delegation to the gulf today. The organization represents more than 200,000 doctors.

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon Send Cruise Ship to Gulf as R&R Station
With AM-US-Gulf, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: As promised, the Pentagon is sending a cruise ship to the Persian Gulf to serve as a floating rest and recreation station for desert-weary troops. The Defense Department on Friday said it had awarded a $31 million contract to the Cunard Line to lease the 564-foot-long Princess for six months. The project has been in the works for some time, and the deadline for submitting bids was two weeks ago. The ship is headed for Bahrain, an island emirate in the gulf off Saudi Arabia, and will be open for R&R before Christmas. It can accommodate more than 800 people and features a swimming pool, a health club, entertainment and full food and bar service.

DOC.HEAD: Ulysses Spacecraft Wobbles, Imperiling Solar Exploration Mission
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 19th graf, `If the ...' to DELETE extraneous words
DOC.HEAD: LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: The Ulysses spacecraft is wobbling like an off-balance washing machine, threatening to cripple the $750 million U.S.-European mission to study the sun's poles. Ulysses, launched from space shuttle Discovery on Oct. 6, started gyrating on Nov. 4, The Associated Press learned. Officials this week confirmed the problem's existence, and said they hope they can work around the malfunction so it doesn't significantly harm Ulysses' five-year mission. The wobble will leave the spacecraft's main dish-shaped antenna unable to point at Earth continuously. ``If we can't do anything about it, it's very serious,'' said Edgar Page, Ulysses science coordinator for the European Space Agency. The loss of data could range from 20 percent to 90 percent, he said. The data is to be transmitted to Earth during 1994-1995, when the spacecraft would be the first to orbit the sun's polar regions. Engineers hope to minimize the wobble during critical periods by repeatedly firing the spacecraft's thrusters. ``Gloom is something I don't feel,'' said Willis Meeks, Ulysses project manager at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory. ``I'm sure that somehow during the next four years we'll find a way to learn to live with this problem.'' Page said that for several tense days late last month, mission officials worried that they might permanently lose contact with the $250 million spacecraft. Ulysses' trouble is yet another in a series of problems for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. Others include a flawed mirror on the Hubble Space Telescope, space shuttle fuel leaks and a malfunctioning Astro observatory on the most recent shuttle flight. The Jet Propulsion Laboratory here has successfully handled balky spacecraft, including a stuck camera platform on one of the Voyagers and Magellan's radio blackouts. Ulysses is a joint mission of the European Space Agency, which supplied the spacecraft and half its science instruments, and NASA, which built the remaining instruments, launched the spacecraft and is tracking it. On Friday, it was 40.6 million miles from Earth, flying toward a 1992 encounter with Jupiter. The planet's gravity will act like a slingshot to hurl Ulysses toward solar orbit. Ulysses is supposed to loop around the sun's south pole during May-September 1994 and over its north pole during May-September 1995. The slow wobble, technically called ``nutation,'' suddenly developed Nov. 4 when Ulysses extended a 24{-foot-long antenna boom. The boom, designed to study radio signals in space and waves in the solar wind, may have become bent. ``It is a very big wobble. We were all amazed,'' Page told AP Network News. The wobble diminished in recent days as Ulysses moved farther from the sun and the antenna is shaded by the spacecraft, Meeks said. Because of that, the leading suspected culprit is that heat from the sun bent the boom, Meeks and Page said. If the theory is right, the wobble soon should disappear for a while, but Page said it will return during the critical times when Ulysses is studying the sun's poles. Ulysses doesn't need to get close to the sun, only fly past the poles. So it never will be closer to the sun than it was on the day it was launched. Engineers theorize the bent boom makes Ulysses wobble as it spins, much like an off-centered washing machine agitator. The spacecraft was designed to spin so it wouldn't wobble. The boom can't be retracted. Page said he didn't think Ulysses' builder, Dornier Deutsche Aerospace of Germany, was to blame. The company ``appeared to satisfy all the test requirements we had,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Industrial Production Skids 1.7 Percent
With AM-Economy Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Industrial production plunged 1.7 percent in November, its steepest drop since the last recession, the Federal Reserve said Friday. Many analysts expressed concern over the quickness and severity of the slump in the manufacturing sector. ``All notions that the economy might skirt a recession are dashed'' by the report, said William K. MacReynolds, an economist with the U.S. Chamber of Commerce. ``Clearly the economy rapidly is falling to a degree not anticipated by most analysts just two short months ago.'' ``It's pretty clear that the weakness in the last couple of months has been pretty severe,'' added economist Robert Brusca of Nikko Securities Co. International in New York. ``If this isn't what a recession is, I don't know what one is.'' The Fed said the drop was the steepest since output sank 2.0 percent in December 1982 as the nation began crawling out of the last recession. The decline began with a 0.1 percent tumble in September, followed by a 0.9 percent fall in October. Both months were revised downward - from a positive 0.2 percent in September and a negative 0.8 percent in October. ``The dramatic declines indicate the manufacturing sector is suffering along with the rest of the economy as the business cycle takes a turn for the worse,'' said economist Mark M. Zandi of Regional Financial Associates in West Chester, Pa. But Zandi and others, while acknowledging the ``bleak'' industrial production report, found some hope in Friday's Commerce Department report that business inventories grew a modest 0.4 percent in October while sales expanded 0.9 percent. That resulted in an inventory-to-sales ratio of 1.47, down from 1.48 the previous month. The ratio means it would take 1.47 months to exhaust the backlog of goods at the October sales pace. The ratio reached a 1.74 in January 1982 during the last recession. ``The fact that inventories remained lean suggests that although we're in a slowdown, there's not a lot of inventory correction needed and that will keep the slowdown mild and of shorter duration,'' he said. Evelina Tainer, an economist with First National Bank of Chicago, said the ratio suggests ``unemployment will go up, but not as much as in past recessions.'' Major inventory accumulations could cause growing production cutbacks and even larger job layoffs as businesses attempt to sell off the backlog. Nevertheless, the Labor Department still reported that 200,000 factory jobs were lost in November, the biggest one-month drop since 1982. Since reaching a post-recession peak in January 1989, manufacturing employment has declined by 800,000. ``A 20 percent drop in motor vehicle assemblies coupled with a sharp curtailment in output of related parts and materials accounted for more than half of the overall loss'' in industrial output, the Fed said. But all categories posted declines. Production at manufacturing plants making both durable and non-durable goods also plummeted 1.7 percent for its third consecutive drop. Output of durable goods - usually expensive products expected to last more than three years - sank 2.5 percent after a 1.1 percent drop in October. Manufacturing of non-durable goods, which has been declining since July, dropped 0.6 percent after 0.4 percent drops in both September and October. Utility production fell 3.6 percent, its third straight decline, while output at mines inched down 0.1 percent after a 1.0 percent drop in October. The Fed said its industrial production index in November stood at 107.5 percent of its 1987 base, down from 109.4 percent a month earlier. It matched the level of last January, which was the lowest since the index stood at 107.4 percent in December 1988. The Fed also said the operating rate of the nation's factories, mines and utilities dropped 1.5 percentage point to 80.9 percent of capacity. The operating rate measures not only output but also changes in productivity levels. The operating rate at factories was 80.0 percent, down from 81.6 percent in October. The operating rate at mines was unchanged at 89.6 percent. For utilities, it fell to 82.7 percent from 85.9 percent a month earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Boschwitz Appeals For Job For Formerly Homeless Worker
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Rudy Boschwitz, who leaves office in January, has appealed to colleagues to hire a woman who was homeless when she went to work for him two years ago. ``I have an employee who can't wait,'' the Minnesota Republican wrote his fellow senators. Some of Boschwitz's workers have found jobs since he lost his re-election bid in November, but Valerie Gaines, a 36-year-old typist, has had just two interviews without success so far. Her husband has been disabled by two strokes and cannot work, she says. She has two daughters, aged 6 and 8. ``Valerie hasn't found a new job ... and we need to place her quickly to avoid another debilitating bout with homelessness,'' Boschwitz wrote. ``Valerie Gaines will be an asset to your office.'' Boschwitz called Gaines an ``excellent employee.'' Gaines had worked for then-Sen. Lawton Chiles, D-Fla., for two years but lost her job when he retired in 1988. During three weeks of being out of work, her family was evicted and their belongings were stolen. Boschwitz's staff hired her without knowing that the address she had given was that of a homeless shelter. She now lives in an apartment in suburban Maryland. Gaines said Friday she has had two interviews about jobs in the Department of Agriculture but no overtures from other members of Congress. ``I'm trying to keep optimistic that the someone will call soon and say they want me to work on their staff in some capacity,'' she said. ``It's Christmas time; we're being merry.''

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
WASHN: years ago.
DOC.TEXT: Martin had been rumored to be a shoo-in for the job, because of her gender, status as a veteran House member and because her appointment would give Bush a chance to reward her for giving up a safe congressional seat to run against Sen. Paul Simon, D-Ill. She lost the race by nearly 1 million votes. Administration sources who said Bush had settled on Martin said they were not positive when the official announcement would be made, but that it could be this afternoon. It was the first of two Cabinet openings to be filled by Bush. Still vacant is the Education spot opened by the forced resignation earlier this week by Lauro Cavazos. In addition, Bush is looking for a new Republican National Committee chairman since Thursday's announcement by William Bennett that he had changed his mind about taking the job.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
WASHN: the job.
DOC.TEXT: Others who had been mentioned as candidates for the post included Rep. Patricia Saiki of Hawaii, another losing GOP candidate for the Senate. Saiki, also speculated to be in the running for the Education post, had been considered an underdog for the labor job, partly because she had backed Sen. Bob Dole of Kansas over Bush in the 1988 primaries. Republican sources said today that Dole had called White House Chief of Staff John Sununu, pushing Saiki for a Cabinet post. Besides close personal and professional ties to Bush, Martin would give the administration a Labor Department chief with strong congressional ties. However, Martin has never had a close alliance with organized labor. Her best voting score from the AFL-CIO came in 1988, when she got a 46 out of a possible 100 on issues tracked by the 14.2 million-member labor federation. When Bush tapped Mrs. Dole for the labor post two years ago, his action was seen as a way for Republicans to mend fences with organized labor leaders who had endured a hostile relationship with the Reagan administration. A fiscal conservative who is pro-choice, Martin's 1989 voting record received rating of 35 out of 100 from the liberal Americans for Democratic Action and scored 69 with the American Conservative Union. She was born in Chicago and now resides in Loves Park, Ill. A graduate of the University of Illinois, she taught high school economics, government and English before beginning her political career. As secretary of labor, Martin duties would include overseeing the enforcement of federal job health and safety laws, pensions and job training.

DOC.HEAD: Tambo Urges Review of ANC Support for Sanctions
LaserPhoto JOH2
DOC.TEXT: ANC President Oliver Tambo on Friday urged the black opposition group to review its stand on international sanctions against South Africa, a cornerstone of the anti-apartheid campaign. Tambo, who returned Thursday from 30 years of exile, told the opening session of the African National Congress' consultative conference that it had to revamp its strategy in step with the evolving political situation in South Africa. Noting worldwide support for President F.W. de Klerk's reforms, Tambo suggested that the ANC would be wise to develop a more lenient policy on sanctions before foreign nations dropped them altogether. ``It is no longer enough for us to repeat the tried slogans,'' Tambo said in a speech that could mark a major change in the ANC's position. ``We should, therefore, carefully reevaluate the advisability of insisting on the retention of sanctions, given the new developments in the country and abroad.'' Both Tambo and Nelson Mandela, the ANC deputy president, praised changes in the white-led government that made the historic three-day conference possible. But they said the fight against white domination would continue. It was the ANC's first meeting in South Africa since the group was outlawed 30 years ago, and it brought together scores of black activists who spent years in prison or exile for anti-apartheid activities. More than 40 black activists sat at a long table draped with the green, black and gold colors of the ANC. Behind them, a checkerboard of 25 television screens gave the 1,600 delegates close-up views of their aged leaders. Tambo, 73, who is still suffering the effects of a stroke 16 months ago, received a standing ovation as he walked slowly to his place at the head of the table amid chants of ``Tambo, Tambo.'' Speaking haltingly at first, Tambo's voice gained strength during the nearly hourlong opening address. In a tribute to the activists who were imprisoned or died during the past three decades, he said: ``It is thanks to you that today the dignity of a black person is being restored, and together with it the dignity of our beloved country.'' Of de Klerk's reforms, which include legalization of the ANC and the repeal of some apartheid laws, Tambo said, ``Naturally, our hopes are raised.'' But he urged blacks not to let down their guard and called the ongoing political unrest a ``painful reminder that apartheid is firmly in place.'' Tambo thanked foreign nations for imposing sanctions on South Africa, but noted that pressure was building from some countries to lift them. Leaders of the 12-nation European Community are expected to discuss whether to continue sanctions at a summit that opened Friday in Rome. Mandela did not specifically refer to sanctions in a 22-page speech, but he said ``continuing pressure from the international community...must be maintained.'' Foreign governments have also imposed sports and cultural boycotts against South Africa and limited diplomatic contacts. A draft discussion document on sanctions, which was to be reviewed privately by ANC delegates, said the economic measures should remain because the white minority continues to govern the country. The pamphlet was marked ``confidential'' and was contained in media packets. The independent South African Press Association said the ANC accidentally leaked the document. It suggested that boycotts on sports and cultural exchanges could be eased. ``It is...clear that we cannot continue to call for the maintenance of existing measures without running the risk of placing ourselves in a position in which we will be seen to have suffered a major defeat'' if countries begin loosening the sanctions, the pamphlet said. Mandela was far more militant than Tambo, warning that the suspension of the ANC's armed struggle was just that, a temporary suspension. ``The rallying cry of the day, to all our members wherever they are deployed, is - remain at your posts,'' he said. The focus of the meeting, which ends Sunday, is to plan ANC strategy and the group's approach to talks with the white-led government on power sharing with the black majority. De Klerk has promised to end apartheid and negotiate a new constitution to include the nation's 30 million blacks, who currently have no voice in national affairs. The 5 million whites control the government.

DOC.HEAD: Appeals Court Criticizes Judge's `Bimbo' Comment; Reverses Ruling
DOC.TEXT: A judge who told a woman in a divorce case to find a new husband in a singles bar because ``bimbos'' go there was criticized by a state appeals court. A three-judge panel called the remarks by Broward Circuit Judge Paul M. Marko III inappropriate and reversed his decisions. It returned the case to the Circuit Court and suggested Marko withdraw because he could not be fair. At the Nov. 27, 1989, divorce trial, Marko repeatedly told 33-year-old Marianne Price she couldn't make it on her own, suggesting she try a singles bar to find another spouse. He also ordered her not to have a man live in her house. And he told her then-husband, Gordon J. Price, he could have the ``entire Dolphins cheerleading squad running through his apartment naked.'' Marko, 58, a divorced father of two who has been a judge since 1969, later apologized to Marianne Price and expressed his regrets for what he called a poor choice of words. The judge was not available Thursday when called at his office. Marianne Price said the judge's remarks devastated her at the time but was too afraid of Marko to object to his treatment of her. She said she was pleased with the appeals court action. ``It renews my faith in the judicial system,'' Ms. Price said. ``No useful purpose could be served by a recitation of the many comments made by the trial judge to or concerning the wife during the trial,'' the court said Wednesday. In its decision, the appeals court said Marko wrongfully restricted Marianne Price from having a man live in her house while saying her husband could have as many women as he wanted in his home. The court also reversed Marko's refusal to order alimony for Marianne Price, and ordered it set by a Broward judge.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Nominates Lynn Martin As Labor Secretary
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Combines pvs; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said today he would nominate outgoing Illinois Rep. Lynn Martin as his new secretary of labor. Bush called Martin a ``distinguished public servant and cherished friend'' in naming her to the post. Martin, 51, will succeed Elizabeth Dole, who stepped down to head the American Red Cross. A 10-year House Republican, Martin has longstanding ties to Bush. She backed him in his first presidential bid in 1980, helped him prepare for his vice presidential debate with Democrat Geraldine Ferraro in 1984 and was a national co-chairman of his presidential campaign two years ago. Bush, speaking to reporters on the White House lawn before leaving for a weekend trip to Camp David, said Martin had been an ``outstanding member of Congress'' who had served as an ``unofficial adviser to me.'' ``She's a mother who knows the need for child care. She's a professional who understands'' the relationship between business and labor, the president said. ``I know that she will serve with great distinction in our Cabinet,'' Bush said of Martin, whose nomination must be confirmed by the Senate. Martin was at her home in Rockford, Ill., when Bush made the announcement. Martin had been rumored to be a shoo-in for the job, because of her gender, status as a veteran House member and because her appointment would give Bush a chance to reward her for giving up a safe congressional seat to run against Sen. Paul Simon, D-Ill. She lost the race by nearly 1 million votes. It was the first of two Cabinet openings to be filled by Bush. Still vacant is the Education spot opened by the forced resignation earlier this week by Lauro Cavazos. In addition, Bush is looking for a new Republican National Committee chairman since Thursday's announcement by William Bennett that he had changed his mind about taking the job. Others who had been mentioned as candidates for the post included Rep. Patricia Saiki of Hawaii, another losing GOP candidate for the Senate. Saiki, also speculated to be in the running for the Education post, had been considered an underdog for the labor job, partly because she had backed Sen. Bob Dole of Kansas over Bush in the 1988 primaries. Republican sources said today that Dole had called White House Chief of Staff John Sununu, pushing Saiki for a Cabinet post. Besides close personal and professional ties to Bush, Martin would give the administration a Labor Department chief with strong congressional ties. However, Martin has never had a close alliance with organized labor. Her best voting score from the AFL-CIO came in 1988, when she got a 46 out of a possible 100 on issues tracked by the 14.2 million-member labor federation. When Bush tapped Mrs. Dole for the labor post two years ago, his action was seen as a way for Republicans to mend fences with organized labor leaders who had endured a hostile relationship with the Reagan administration. A fiscal conservative who is pro-choice, Martin's 1989 voting record received a rating of 35 out of 100 from the liberal Americans for Democratic Action and scored 69 with the American Conservative Union. She was born in Chicago and now resides in Loves Park, Ill. A graduate of the University of Illinois, she taught high school economics, government and English before beginning her political career. As secretary of labor, Martin duties would include overseeing the enforcement of federal job health and safety laws, pensions and job training.

DOC.HEAD: Troops Move Into Albanian City On Second Day Of Rioting
DOC.TEXT: Troops moved into a central Albanian city on Friday to quell rioting by a crowd of about 1,000 people who ``destroyed everything in their way,'' an Albanian journalist said. An editor of the official Albanian news agency ATA said the city of Elbasan, about 18 miles southeast of the capital of Tirana, was quiet Friday night after soldiers and security forces moved in. It was the second day of rioting in Albania, the tiny Balkan nation that is ruled by the last Stalinist regime remaining in Europe. Also Friday, Communist President Ramiz Alia met with leaders of the country's first non-Communist party, which was formed on Wednesday. Both sides appealed for calm. Alia, who decided this week to allow alternative parties, appears to be trying to avoid an explosion of popular discontent over poor living conditions and decades of Communist repression. Popular uprisings last year toppled the other Communist governments in Eastern Europe. The angry crowd in Elbasan stoned official buildings, ``broke windows, looted food shops, put fire to different shops, cars and machinery,'' said the ATA journalist, who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``They destroyed everything in their way,'' he said, adding that local police had failed to stop the crowd. The journalist said he had no reports of injuries in Elbasan, a city of about 80,000. The city has a giant steel mill. On Thursday, 10 people were injured and 30 arrested in clashes in the northern Albanian city of Shkodra, Albanian media reported. An intellectual in Tirana said there were peaceful protests Thursday in the southern Albanian town of Saranda on the Adriatic coast. The intellectual, who also spoke on condition of anonymity, added that crowds in Tirana gathered outside the Palace of Congresses on Friday evening in anticipation of the historic meeting between the Communist president and the new Democratic Party of Albania. The party was formed Wednesday and was cheered by tens of thousands of people at a peaceful rally. There was no immediate report from Friday's meeting, in which the opposition was expected to present its platform for economic reforms and adherence to international human rights guidelines. On Wednesday, Alia appealed on nationwide television and radio for peaceful change in Albania, which has been under rigid Communist rule since 1944. His surprising decision this week to allow alternative political movements may have touched off resistance among conservative elements of the ruling Communists and the Sigurimi, the secret police. Alia also fired five hard-line members of his ruling Politburo. Police and troops moved into Shkodra on Thursday to deal with hundreds of ``hooligans'' who attacked officials and buildings, wounding the local police chief and two other officers, official reports said. The reports said the attackers were armed with knives and iron bars and used dynamite in attacks on local Communist Party and government buildings in the town. They also sacked the local radio station. There was no assessment of the damage. There have been persistent reports this year, many from neighboring Yugoslavia and Greece, of unrest in Shkodra and other northern areas that traditionally were Roman Catholic before the Communists took over. There also have been reports of unrest in southern Albania, home to an estimated 40,000 ethnic Greeks. Official newspapers carried a statement Friday from the new party condemning the Shkodra violence. It was also read on state by one of the party's leaders, Arben Imame. The unprecedented statement specifically hailed Alia's decision to introduce pluralism and condemned the acts of violence, which it said were aimed against democracy, according to an ATA correspondent. It urged Albanians to ``use the traditional wisdom'' to show ``that we are a civilized nation,'' the journalist on condition of anonymity. The ruling Communists, who a month ago rejected the idea of alternative parties, reversed themselves on Tuesday after four days of student protests, reportedly touched off by demands for more heat and light in their Tirana dormitories.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Troops Move into Another Albanian City to Stop Riot
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with rioting in second city. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: For the second time in as many days, troops reportedly moved into an Albanian city today to quell rioting. The unrest came as Albania's hard-line Communist government began granting some freedoms. An Albanian journalist said the soldiers moved into the central city of Elbasan to stop 1,000 people who ``destroyed everything in their way.'' The editor of the Albanian news agency ATA said that by nightfall soldiers had controlled the violence in Elbasan, 20 miles southeast of the capital. Earlier today in the capital, Tirana, Communist President Ramiz Alia met with leaders of Albania's first non-Communist political party as both sides appealed for calm and a halt to unrest in provincial cities. Albania's official newspapers also published a statement by the new opposition Democratic Party of Albania today condemning civil violence Thursday in a northern city as an obstacle to democratic change. ``They broke windows, looted food shops, put fire to different shops, cars and machinery,'' the editor said of the angry crowd in Elbasan today. ``They destroyed everything in their way,'' he added, indicating local police had failed to stop the angry crowd. The ATA journalist, who did not give his name, said he had no reports of injuries in Elbasan, a city of 80,000 people with a giant steel mill. The rioters were also reported to have thrown stones at official buildings, and committed other acts of violence. Ten people were injured and 30 were arrested in violent clashes in th northern Albanian city of Shkodra on Thursday, Albanian media reported. An intellectual in Tirana also reported peaceful protests in the southern Albanian town of Saranda on the Adriatic coast. Earlier, the intellectual and an ATA correspondent said Alia was meeting with leaders of the Democratic Party of Albania. There was no immediate report from the meeting. In its published statement today, the new political party asked Albanians to show ``that we are a civilized nation.'' Observers were surprised the hard-line Communist government of the isolated country was willing to give the new party access to the official press. The party was only founded Wednesday after the ruling Communist Party agreed to allow alternative parties. The motive for the violence today in Elbasan and Thursday in Shkodra was not immediately clear. Although it comes as the government is granting some concessions to pro-democracy forces, it is not known if the people behind the unrest are anti-government protesters. In Shkodra, hundreds of ``hooligans'' attacked officials and buildings, wounding the local police chief and two other officers, official reports said. The reports said the attackers were armed with knives and iron bars and used dynamite in attacks on Communist Party and government buildings in the town. They also ransacked the local radio station. Journalists reached in Tirana said at least 1,000 citizens also took to the streets in an effort to stop the violence. A reporter with the state news agency ATA said 30 people were detained. The Democratic Party of Albania denounced the unrest. The statement from the party was carried in official newspapers today and read on government TV late Thursday by one of the party's leaders, Arben Imame. The ATA journalist quoted the statement as saying the violence was aimed at destroying what had been achieved by protesters who forced the Communist leaders to accelerate reform. It appealed for calm and urged Albanians to ``use the traditional wisdom,'' the journalist said. The Democratic Party also welcomed Alia's ``new initiative, opening the way to pluralism,'' said a diplomat reached in Tirana. The party plans to run candidates in elections in February.

DOC.HEAD: Arts Endowment Chief Says He Won't Be `Decency Czar'
DOC.TEXT: The National Endowment for the Arts was told Friday to comply with Congress' new ``decency standard'' by ensuring its grant-judging panels reflect the widest possible diversity of American cultural values. This procedural solution was approved by members of the National Council on the Arts, the NEA's presidentially appointed advisory body, who met informally at a downtown hotel to discuss the implications of legislation Congress approved in October. Council members effectively rejected a stronger alternative that would have required written or oral guidelines on decency for the NEA panels of outside experts who review applications for federal arts grants. After the vote, endowment chairman John E. Frohnmayer expressed approval of the council's approach and said, ``I'm not going to be the decency czar here.'' When it approved a $174 million budget for the arts endowment this year, Congress repealed a year-old obscenity ban and substituted a requirement that the NEA take ``general standards of decency'' into account when awarding federal grant money. Both restrictions were prompted by conservative lawmakers' criticism of NEA support for exhibitions of controversial works by photographer Robert Mapplethorpe and artist Andres Serrano that were denounced as obscene and blasphemous. Though milder than the obscenity ban, the new decency standard has stirred emotional fire from some artists and arts supporters, who contend that it also would hamper freedom of expression. In a statement read at Friday's council meeting, members of the NEA panel on opera and musical theater declared their unanimous opposition to the decency standard and said they would disregard it. ``Standards of decency are subjective, indefinable and irrelevant to the consideration of artistic excellence, which is the primary concern of this panel and the National Endowment for the Arts,'' said their signed statement. ``We have vehemently opposed and avoided any consideration of `decency' as a funding criteria during our deliberations,'' the panelists wrote. NEA general counsel Julie Davis told council members that decency was ``a very slippery, very broad and very vague standard'' that almost defies definition. She recommended that the NEA comply with the new standard by broadening the membership of its grant-judging panels, giving oral instructions to panelists or writing the standard into the endowment's formal guidelines. On a unanimous voice vote, council members approved the NEA lawyer's first option, under which panelists would be appointed to represent a broad range of ethnic, racial and geographic backgrounds and diverse cultural viewpoints. Such an all-inclusive membership, Ms. Davis said, would provide the best assurance that ``general standards of decency'' would be considered in selecting works of artistic excellence for federal support. Rep. Paul Henry, R-Mich., a leading House advocate of the decency standard, said in a telephone interview from Grand Rapids that he was satisfied with the arts council's approach. ``I have no objection to that whatsoever, so long as general standards of decency are honored,'' he said. Henry said the decency standard was inserted into the law because Congress wanted the arts endowment - not legislators - to be the judges of which works are suitable for support with federal funds. The two-day council meeting, which began Friday, was attended by a dozen of the council's 26 members. Their recommendations will be referred to the full council for action at its next quarterly meeting in February.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Economy Bjt
Mortgage Rates Decline to 9.56 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Fixed-rate mortgages averaged 9.56 percent this week, the lowest level in more than three years, according to a national survey released Friday by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. The average, down from 9.81 percent the previous week, was the lowest since it fell to 9.43 percent during the week ending April 10, 1987. By Oct. 16, however, the average had jumped to 11.58 percent. On one-year adjustable rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 7.91 percent, the lowest since it hit 7.90 on Aug. 5, 1988. The ARMs average peaked at 9.41 percent on Nov. 11, 1989. The rate was 8.04 percent last week. The rates do not include add-on fees known as points.

DOC.HEAD: Tuna Boat Sinks At Canal Entrance; Four Dead
DOC.TEXT: A docked U.S. tuna ship exploded and sank Friday near the Pacific Ocean entrance to the Panama Canal. At least four people died, an official said, and hundreds of dockside residents were evacuated. Port officials were investigating the cause of the explosion, which broke out in the engine room of the 400-foot-long ship, the Odette Theres. Jaime Beitiav, spokesman for the port authority, said two Americans were among those killed. He identified those killed as Lionel Correia, 37, and Richard Balelo, 51, of the United States, Chun Suk Kwon, 47, of South Korea, and the Panamanian watchman, Delfino Felipe Romero. He gave no hometowns for the U.S. citizens. The tuna ship was carrying a crew of 20, under American captain Anthony Virisimo, he said. The incident did not affect traffic in the canal, but firefighters were forced to evacuate hundreds of U.S. citizens who live near the dock called La Boca, which is near an oil storage area. The ship was taking on supplies for a return to the Pacific for fishing.

DOC.HEAD: Conrail Eyes Layoffs
DOC.TEXT: James A. Hagen, chairman and chief executive officer of Conrail, said on Friday he cannot rule out employee layoffs next year if freight revenue is cut by the expected economic downturn. Hagen said he was not actually predicting layoffs in Conrail's labor force of 28,000. ``But when you look at that economic situation you'd be foolish to say no, no layoffs,'' he said. ``We're not looking for a strong 1991,'' Hagen told the Transportation Table, a biweekly meeting of professionals with an interest in the transportation industry. He said he believes the year will see a downturn in housing starts and the auto and steel industry, all of which would translate to less railroad freight. The Gross National Product (GNP) probably will be off by about one percent next year, he said. Facing a decline in revenue, Conrail will attempt to reduce costs without effecting the quality of its freight service, he said. ``It's not going to be a good economic year,'' Hagen said. ``But we'll probably do OK.''

DOC.HEAD: TV Industry Lobbies FCC for Right to Control Prime Time Programs
DOC.TEXT: A who's who of Hollywood and network TV executives descended upon the Federal Communications Commission on Friday to do battle over ownership and syndication rights to prime-time programs. More than 30 witnesses, including the heads of ABC, NBC, CBS, Fox Broadcasting and top-level studio executives, rubbed elbows in a rare public hearing before the five-member FCC to debate changing the commission's financial interest and syndication rule. Commission Chairman Alfred Sikes, ringed by a half-dozen TV cameras, said it was the largest-ever Washington gathering of TV executives. The rule, adopted in 1970, prohibits TV networks from holding a financial interest in prime-time programs they obtain from outside sources or selling them in the U.S. rerun marketplace. The networks want out from under fin-syn, as it's known, and since 1983 have been locked in acrimonious negotiations with producers over changing the rule. Commissioner James Quello said fin-syn has generated the most intense lobbying of his 16 years at the FCC. Fox Inc. Chairman Barry Diller, whose network has a one-year exemption to fin-syn, said the issue no longer was producer access to mass audiences but ``a battle about money - about greed.'' The FCC tentatively decided in 1983 to revamp the rule but backed off under pressure from Congress and then-President Reagan. The commission will decide the issue next year. Thursday, one witness after another told the commissioners why the rule was - or was not - vital to both the TV industry and the American viewing public. ABC, NBC and CBS claim the rule is outdated in an era in which they no longer are the only outlets for programs and when they must compete against foreign companies that are not bound by fin-syn. Network executives complained that advertising sales were down and their audiences were at historic lows because of cable TV, VCRs and other competitors. ``The existing regulatory structure, created both by the commission and by the Congress, provides an enormous advantage to the Hollywood and cable interests,'' Laurence Tisch, president of CBS Inc., told the hearing. ``The future of free broadcasting in America is seriously threatened, not just for the networks, but for our 600 affiliated stations. ... Repealing these rules is important because it will allow us to compete for the best programming.'' Producers, however, claimed that while the industry has changed dramatically since fin-syn was imposed 20 years ago, the three networks still have bottleneck control of major, high-quality programming. Without fin-syn, they said, the networks could once again extract many concessions from producers in return for putting a program on the air. ``Perhaps whereas they were once 900-pound gorillas, today they weigh in at only 850 pounds,'' said Richard Frank, president of Walt Disney Studios. But John Agoglia, president of NBC Enterprises, and Robert Iger, president of ABC Entertainment, said it was the producers, not networks, that have the most bargaining power and that the networks needed to foster as many program suppliers as possible. ``No network executive has the leverage to force a producer, with or without a studio, to enter into a transaction,'' Iger said. ``Over 70 percent of our series come from major studios,'' said Jeff Sagansky, president of CBS Entertainment. He said CBS would lose ``tens of millions of dollars'' this year on ``Dallas'' because its producers threatened to go to Fox unless CBS accepted the aging series along with ``Knot's Landing'' and ``Falcon Crest.'' The fin-syn rule was designed to stem network power, encourage independent production of TV shows and keep the networks from denying reruns to non-network TV stations. Since 1970, the network's share of audiences has dropped from about 95 percent to less than 60 percent as cable viewing has grown. ``The advertising marketplace is the worst it's been in two decades,'' said Robert Wright, president of NBC. ``The three network percentage of prime time viewing'' fell to 58 percent in November, a historic low. The Justice Department has sided with the networks, but a wide array of groups are on the other side. ``The rule has fueled the growth of independent stations and - contrary to network contentions - has also promoted a substantial increase in the number of program producers,'' Warner Bros. Chairman Robert Daly said. ``The networks' want repeal so that they may use their tremendous leverage to take valuable financial interests and syndication rights.'' Producers say they could accepted limited network ownership of their programs, but that syndication and other rights must be negotiated separately, after a show is placed on the network schedule.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Cabinet Shuffle, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here, at a glance, is a look at Rep. Lynn Martin, R-Ill., named Friday by President Bush as the next labor secretary. Age: 51 Married: To Harry D. Leinenweber, a federaljudge, in January 1987. Children: Two, from a previous marriage. Her husband has five from an earlier marriage. Home: Loves Park, Ill. Education: Bachelor's degree, University of Illinois, 1960. Professional background: High school economics, government and English teacher, 1960-69; Winnebago County Board, 1972-76; Illinois House, 1977-79; Illinois Senate, 1979-81; U.S. House, 1980-90. Congressional Committee: Rules Committee; ranking member on the panel's Legislative Process Subcommittee. 1990 Campaign: Martin ran unsuccessfully against Democratic Sen. Paul Simon and received 35 percent of the vote.

DOC.HEAD: Talks ``On Hold'' Pending Agreement on Dates, Bush Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Oil prices up, Pentagon adds medical personnel -- grafs 6-7. Edits to eliminate duplication of several paragraphs.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said today direct talks with Iraq to resolve the Persian Gulf crisis are ``on hold'' pending an agreement with Saddam Hussein on a date for Secretary of State James A. Baker's trip to Baghdad. The foreign minister of Iraq, Tariq Aziz, had been expected in Washington next week for the first round of talks but Bush said Saddam's proposal of Jan. 12 for a return visit from Baker was too close to the U.N. deadline for Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait. ``We have offered 15 dates and he ought to get moving'' and accept one, Bush said of Saddam. He added, ``Saddam Hussein is not too busy to see on short notice'' such figures as Muhammad Ali, Ramsey Clark and former British Prime Minister Edward Heath. Bush said Jan. 12 wouldn't leave time for Iraqi forces to leave Kuwait by the United Nations deadline three days later. ``That deadline is real,'' Bush said, adding that Iraqi forces must be ``totally out, totally out'' by then. On the financial markets, meanwhile, traders said the continued statemate of U.S.-Iraqi talks drove oil prices up in trading today. Light sweet crude oil for January delivery was up $1.43 per barrel at $27.85 early this afternoon on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Meanwhile, Pentagon officials said thousands more medical personnel were being dispatched to join the U.S. deployment in Saudi Arabia. Bush made his comments on the White House lawn before boarding a helicopter for a weekend trip to the presidential retreat at Camp David. He said he has been considering seeking congressional support for offensive military action in the Persian Gulf if Iraq doesn't withdraw from Kuwait by the Jan. 15 deadline. ``I think it would send a very strong signal to the world'' if Congress explicity endorsed his Persian Gulf policy, he said. Democratic critics have complained that Bush was abandoning reliance on economic sanctions too early for them to have taken effect. Bush has said the sole purpose of Baker's talks is not to negotiate a settlement, but to issue a face-to-face demand that Saddam withdraw his troops. Since Bush called for the talks, Saddam has permitted the release of hundreds of United State and other westerners held in Kuwait and Iraq since the crisis began on Aug. 2, and Bush withdrew the small diplomatic team that had been holed up in the besieged US embassy in Kuwait. Interest was now turning to the diplomatic front, but Bush said Aziz' planned visit to the United States to see Bush ``is on hold, I guess,'' pending an agreement on the date Baker will see Saddam. Bush originally invited Saddam to receive Baker in Iraq any time between Dec. 15 and Jan. 15. ``I wish now I had been a little more explicit in my first announcement,'' he said. ``I did not offer to be a part to Saddam Hussein's manipulation,'' Bush said, adding that ``The Aziz meeting is on hold, I guess,'' pending agreement on a date for Baker's trip. Earlier today, White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater addressed the subject of the stalemate. ``The president's concerned and he's upset that Saddam can find time to meet with everybody else under the sun with 24 hours notice but somehow he can't find one out of 15 days,'' to meet with Baker, he said. Bush met earlier in the day with lawmakers to discuss the Persian Gulf, and two senators emerged to say the president was prepared to call off the talks with Iraq because the two countries have been unable to agree on meeting dates. ``The president - as I gather his mood today - is prepared to have no meetings rather than to see a lot of shoving around ... if we have no meetings so be it,'' Sen. Richard Lugar, R-Ind., said. Lugar is a member of the Committee for Peace and Security in the Gulf, a bipartisan group formed to support the president's gulf policy that met with Bush this morning. Sen. John McCain, R-Ariz., another member of the group, told reporters: ``The president feels he has taken the necessary steps that encourages dialogue, and if they fail to respond in a reasonable and mature fashion, then he's made his best effort and that's it.'' Bush was intent that the purpose of the meetings was that Saddam understand the strength and conviction of the international coalition arrayed against him since his Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, said Lugar. ``If he understands that already, by watching television, I think the president is prepared to let it go at that,'' said Lugar. Bush is ``tired of hearing'' people's assumptions that there was some other agenda or negotiating intent to his proposal for talks with Iraq. ``If we're not going to have any meetings, it would clear that up for good,'' Lugar said. Joseph Wilson IV, the deputy U.S. ambassador to Iraq, has talked daily to foreign ministry officials in Baghdad about setting a date for Baker's visit to Baghdad. But Margaret D. Tutwiler, the State Department spokeswoman, said Thursday the Iraqis had not offered an alternative to Jan. 12. Wilson met again Thursday with Deputy Foreign Minister Nizar Hamdoon ``and there is no substantive change in their position,'' a U.S. official, who demanded anonymity, said.

DOC.HEAD: Former Keating Aide Says Riegle Arranged Meeting
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New material, including Cranston, top 9 grafs; picks up 5th graf pvs, Committee special
DOC.TEXT: A former top aide to savings and loan owner Charles H. Keating Jr. testified today that Sen. Donald Riegle arranged a meeting between senators and the top federal thrift regulator to discuss Keating's concerns. Riegle has denied setting up the meeting. James Grogan, once corporate counsel to Keating's parent company, told the Senate Ethics Committee that Riegle suggested the meeting when he visited the Arizona facilities of Keating's American Continental Corp., and met privately with Keating. Grogan testified under a grant of immunity from prosecution. The meeting, on April 2, 1987, was held by four senators with then-top regulator Edwin J. Gray. Gray has charged that the senators improperly pressured him in that session to drop a regulatory control of Lincoln Savings and Loan that Keating was protesting. Riegle did not attend that meeting, and Grogan said he was surprised by the senator's absence. Riegle did attend a meeting with the other four senators and San Francisco-based regulators a week later. Grogan said he urged Riegle to attend the second meeting and wanted ``to keep the team together,'' referring to the senators. Grogan also testified that Sen. Alan Cranston, D-Calif., agreed to call Gray's successor, M. Danny Wall, to arrange a meeting between the regulator and Keating in late 1987.
