Grogan said Keating made the request to Keating after Grogan delivered $250,000 in checks for a voter-registration drive Cranston was supporting, and together they placed a call by speaker phone to Keating in Arizona. Grogan said Riegle had suggested that the two Arizona senators, Democrat Dennis DeConcini and Republican John McCain, attend the session with Gray on April 2. He said Riegle asked that the other senators then invite him to attend. Committee special counsel Robert S. Bennett asked Grogan, ``Is there any doubt in your mind Senator Riegle agreed to arrange the meeting for the senators?'' Grogan replied, ``No, sir.'' Grogan recalled that Riegle said ``he would talk with Ed Gray and he thought he could set up a meeting ... and perhaps set up a process of disengaging from the feud or fighting that was going on'' between Keating and the regulators. Riegle, in earlier testimony before the committee in its Keating Five hearings, denied setting up that meeting or one a week later with all five senators, including himself, and regulators. ``No, I didn't arrange either meeting,'' Riegle has testified. Grogan said that while Riegle and Keating met privately, he met with Kevin Gotlieb, Riegle's staffer on the Senate Banking Committee, and discussed a fundraiser Keating was organizing for Riegle in Detroit. Keating owned a prominent downtown hotel there. Bennett asked Grogan, ``Did Senator Riegle ever tell you why he wanted you to ask Senator McCain to ask Senator Riegle to come to the meeting?'' Grogan replied, ``It was apparent to me that ... Senator Riegle knew as a shrewd politician that this was a potentially politically explosive situation because there was tremendous media at the time about Mr. Keating and Mr. Gray and the regulators and all the fighting.'' Grogan said that when he asked McCain, he refused to invite Riegle but did agree ``to at least talk to Riegle about it.'' The panel granted Grogan limited immunity from prosecution to compel his testimony about Keating's ties to five senators who have been accused of intervening improperly with federal thrift regulators on behalf of Keating's Lincoln Savings and Loan Association. Grogan, 36, of Scottsdale, Ariz., gave his first public testimony with his lawyer sitting behind him. None of the five senators under scrutiny was present. Grogan said he had earned $300,000 a year working for Keating's company, before resigning last June. He described his relations with Keating as ``strained.'' Keating had extensive contacts with the senators and their staffs. He was a big contributor to each lawmaker, and the committee is considering whether the $1.3 million he and associates donated to their campaigns and related political causes was tied to their assistance. Keating's parent company, American Continental Co., went bankrupt in April 1989, and Lincoln was seized by federal regulators. The cost to taxpayers to cover insured deposits is expected to top $2 billion, and Keating is under a state fraud indictment in California. Grogan was vice president of Lincoln, based in Irvine, Calif., and corporate counsel to American Continental, based in Phoenix. The five senators are Republican John McCain of Arizona and Democrats Alan Cranston of California, Dennis DeConcini of Arizona, John Glenn of Ohio and Donald Riegle of Michigan. Keating, Grogan and other aides invoked their Fifth Amendment rights against self-incrimination in refusing to testify. In granting Grogan immunity to compel his testimony, the committee said it would not do so for Keating. Evidence in the previous four weeks of public hearings has shown that Grogan arranged for political donations to lawmakers and was point man in soliciting congressional help for Keating's ``all-out war'' with regulators who were closing in on Lincoln. A memo introduced into evidence last week showed that Keating directed Grogan to try to have a senior career regulator fired for his tough actions against Lincoln.

DOC.HEAD: Bombing at Honduran Liberal Party Candidates' Office Injures 1
DOC.TEXT: A crude explosive went off near a Liberal Party office in San Pedro Sula, injuring a watchman and damaging three buildings, officials said Friday. Police Sgt. Edgardo Zeron Larios said the guard, Eduardo Aquino, 38, was hospitalized with shrapnel wounds over much of his body. He said the explosion Thursday night shattered windows in three buildings, including the party office, and damaged the front. ``The device was very powerful. Apparently it was fabricated in a rudimentary fashion,'' he said. San Pedro Sula, 125 miles north of Tegucigalpa, is Honduras' second-largest city.

DOC.HEAD: Chronology of Nancy Cruzan Right-To-Die Case
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS one graf to UPDATE with ruling
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Right-To-Die, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a chronology of major events in the Nancy Cruzan right-to-die case: -Jan. 11, 1983: Nancy Cruzan, then 25, has a wreck on a country road southeast of Carthage, in the Ozarks of southwest Missouri and is thrown from the car. Paramedics restart her breathing, but her brain was without oxygen for so long she never regains consciousness. -Feb. 5, 1983: Doctors implant a feeding tube in Ms. Cruzan's stomach. She isn't on any life support system, such as a respirator. -Oct. 19, 1983: Ms. Cruzan is moved to the Missouri Rehabilitation Center in Mount Vernon, where she remains. -Oct. 23, 1987: Her parents, Joe and Joyce Cruzan of Carterville ask Jasper County Probate Judge Charles Teel for a judgment on their request that they be allowed to have Ms. Cruzan's feeding tube removed, so she can die as they believe she would want. -March 9, 1988: A three-day hearing begins on the family's request. The Cruzans say their daughter has a common-law right to be free from unwanted medical treatment, and state and federal constitutional rights to privacy that protect her right to refuse unwanted medical treatment. -July 27, 1988: Teel issues a judgment authorizing the Cruzans, acting as Nancy's legal guardians, to request the withholding of food and water from their daughter. -Aug. 3, 1988: Missouri Attorney General William Webster files notice that the state will appeal to the state Supreme Court. -Sept. 29, 1988: The court hears arguments. -Nov. 16, 1988: In a 4-3 decision, the state Supreme Court overturns the lower court, holding there is no legal authority to grant the Cruzans' request. The family appeals to the U.S. Supreme Court. -Dec. 6, 1989: The U.S. Supreme Court hears arguments, the first time it has considered a right-to-die case. -June 25, 1990: In a 5-4 decision, the court blocks the Cruzans from halting their daughter's food and water. It says the state could keep a patient on life support in the absence of ``clear and convincing'' evidence the person would want to die. -Aug. 30, 1990: Ms. Cruzan's parents ask Teel for a second hearing, saying they have new evidence their daughter once indicated to three people she would rather die than live in her present condition. -Sept. 17, 1990: Webster, saying the state no longer has a ``recognizable legal interest'' in the case, asks the judge to drop the state Health Department and the director of the Missouri Rehabilitation Center from future litigation. -Oct. 23, 1990: Teel drops the state as a defendant, leaving the parents and court-appointed guardian Thad McCanse in the case. -Nov. 1, 1990: Three former co-workers tell Teel they recalled conversations with Ms. Cruzan in which she said she never would want to live ``like a vegetable'' on medical machines. Ms. Cruzan's physician, who previously opposed removing the feeding tube, terms her life ``a living hell'' and testifies she should be allowed to die. -Dec. 5, 1990: Ms. Cruzan's court-appointed guardians recommend the feeding tube be removed so Ms. Cruzan may die. -Dec. 14, 1990: Teel authorizes removal of feeding tubes.

DOC.HEAD: Delta Pride Workers Ratify Contract, Ending 3-Month Strike
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs the 3rd graf to update with union recount of vote results. Neel is cq in 18th graf
DOC.TEXT: Union workers overwhelming approved a new contract Friday with Delta Pride Catfish Inc., ending a bitter three-month strike that brought out allegations of racial discrimination. The plight of the workers in one of the nation's most economically depressed regions attracted support from the NAACP and other civil rights organizations and led to a national boycott of Delta Pride products. The contract vote was 479-1. Union officials said the lone vote against appeared to be a misunderstanding over wage provisions in the pact. ``This is a great Christmas present,'' said Sarah White, a shop steward who has been with Delta Pride since 1983, one year after the nation's largest catfish processor opened. ``I feel good about this contract and I've talked with several co-workers and they are satisfied. ``We finally got some of the things we wanted ... including things that should make the workplace better for all of us.'' The strike began Sept. 13 when members of United Food and Commercial Workers Union Local 1529 rejected a contract. About 900 workers walked off the job at Delta Pride's Indianola and Inverness plants. A third plant in Belzoni employs non-union workers. The company had no immediate comment on the contract vote. Provisions in the contract include wage increases and assurances that striking workers will be rehired, union officials said. The contract grants immediate raises of 60 to 65 cents an hour for all workers with at least one year of seniority. Pay averaged $4.05 an hour before the strike. The pact also establishes a worker-management health and safety committee to monitor conditions at the plant. While there were scattered reports of violence, including rock-throwing, early in the strike, officials said recent weeks were quiet. Aaron Henry, president of the Mississippi NAACP, said the worker's anger arose from ``a combination of race and economics coupled with the philosophy of the plantation.'' Besides wages, the union also raised concerns about working conditions. A common complaint among workers has been about repetitive motion injury. Workers complained that they were timed with a stopwatch when skinning, gutting, slicing and packaging fish. The also complained of limited restroom breaks - six five-minute bathroom breaks per week. Violators risked dismissal. White, who has two children, said the three months she has been on strike created financial problems but ``the union helped take care of our bills and provided groceries for us. We really sacrificed but we had help with the basics.'' White, 32, of Moorhead, said she planned to be in St. Louis this weekend to attend a support rally for the striking workers. ``Now I can tell them it is over and tell them to start buying catfish ... we need the hours at work,'' she said. E. Dale Cline of Memphis, Tenn., the federal mediator who helped work out the new contract, said he is ``tickled to death that this is finally over.'' Union spokesman Neel Lattimore said the contract goes a long way toward improving working conditions. ``We feel like there is language in the contract to make Delta Pride more sensitive (to working conditions) and by all of us working together we can get along,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Germany to Question Soviet Ambassador about Honecker
DOC.TEXT: Germany said Friday it will summon the Soviet ambassador to explain why Moscow has not handed over ousted East German Communist leader Erich Honecker for trial. Berlin state justice authorities issued an arrest warrant on Nov. 30 for Honecker, accusing him of signing shoot-to-kill orders that resulted in the deaths of would-be escapees from East Germany. On Thursday, they asked for Bonn's help in persuading the Soviet Union to turn him over, federal government spokesman Dieter Vogel said Friday. The Soviets say they have admitted Honecker to a Soviet military hospital in Beelitz, outside Berlin, for humanitarian reasons. Honecker's lawyers claim he is seriously ill and under treatment for high blood pressure. The Soviets' sheltering of Honecker, 78, who was toppled in 1989's peaceful revolution in East Germany, is complicating Bonn's relations with Moscow. In recent months the two governments have drawn closer together through Moscow's blessing of German unity and German promises of huge financial aid for the Soviets. Vogel said that ``in a short time'' the Foreign Ministry will invite the Soviet ambassador in Bonn for talks abot Honecker. Under German law, the prosecution of Honecker is not a federal matter but one for justice officials in Berlin, whose eastern half was East Germany's seat of government. On Thursday, sources said Bonn may try to persuade Soviet authorities to let a German doctor into the Soviet military hospital to examine Honecker and determine whether he is fit to stand trial. Also Friday, the Berlin state court said it has rejected a challenge of the arrest warrant by Honecker's lawyers. The lawyers argued that Honecker could not be penalized for following the law of former East Germany. The court did not say on what grounds it had dismissed the appeal. Under German law, former East Germans can be prosecuted for crimes committed in eastern Germany before unification in October. The defense lawyers said they would take the matter to Germany's Supreme Court. About 200 East Germans were gunned down while trying to escape to the West in the years following the 1961 construction of the Berlin Wall. Honecker came to power in 1971.

DOC.HEAD: Mourners Mark Anniversary Of Sakharov's Death
DOC.TEXT: Mourners remembered human rights activist Andrei D. Sakharov on Friday, a year after his death, as an extraordinary moral force whose place in politics and in their hearts has yet to be matched by anyone else. ``I can't see anybody now whose ideas I could agree with. He was a man whose thoughts could find a response in people's souls,'' said Bela Kleshchenko, an activist standing beside Sakharov's grave at a snowy cemetery in southwest Moscow. ``I can't see anybody today who could take his place,'' said 67-year-old pensioner Baruch Froyimovich, teary-eyed as he looked at the grave. ``You need a man who has very high culture - heart, soul and brains. He was man of the highest culture.'' Sakharov was a top Soviet physicist who helped develop the hydrogen bomb in the 1950s and later won the 1975 Nobel Peace Prize for his campaigns on behalf of disarmament and human rights. He died a year ago at age 68 after three vigorous years of political activism following his emergence from forced internal exile. Controversial for much of his political life, Sakharov has gained steadily in public esteem since his death. Groups scramble to attach his name to their cause, and his words are quoted by politicians and commentators alike as the country deals with worsening political and economic crises. In 1980, Sakharov was denounced in the official press as an ``utterly ignorant person'' and exiled to the closed city of Gorky for criticizing the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev released him in December 1986, and he returned to Moscow, where he became an outspoken deputy in the Supreme Soviet parliament. Russian Federation President Boris Yeltsin opened Friday's session of the Russian parliament with a tribute to Sakharov, and national newspapers published articles praising him. The government plans to make a museum out of his old apartment in Gorky, which has since been renamed Nizhni-Novgorod. But at the cemetery, Ms. Kleshchenko said politicians were cashing in on Sakharov's name without fulfilling his ideals. ``The powers that be ... brought about his death, and now they are preparing to establish a museum in his honor,'' said Ms. Kleshchenko, a member of the Sakharov Order of Charity and Social Defense. ``Our politicians are too busy with politics and they don't really have any human qualities,'' she said. ``What was so special about Sakharov was that he was a scholar, a politician and a man - he was still human.'' At the huge cemetery, the rumble of trucks on a nearby highway was barely audible next to Sakharov's grave, which was covered by a blanket of evergreen twigs and carnations of all colors. A black-and-white portrait of the physicist hung from the headstone, flanked by evergreen wreaths that bore sashes from the Russian parliament and democratic activists. A half-dozen candles flickered in the sub-freezing breeze in front of the grave. Pairs of policemen stood at each corner of a path leading to the gravesite, apparently on guard in case of any demonstrations. But the mood was solemn, and people spoke softly or not at all. At the parliament, Sergei Kovalev, a deputy and close friend, said, ``Sakharov was intrepid and unselfish in the quest of truth. He was always outside the turmoil of political passions and ambitions. He took interest in nothing but the truth.'' The Moscow newspaper Leninskoye Znamiya said, ``History has already had its say on Sakharov. He belongs to it. At the same time, he is near us, he stayed in the hearts of all who wanted to have him.''

DOC.HEAD: With AM-US-Gulf, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a text of President Bush's question-and-answer session on the White House lawn Friday: Bush: I have two brief statements that I'd like to make this afternoon. And first, I have today asked a distinguished public servant and a cherished friend to become secretary of the Department of Labor. Lynn Martin, a former congresswoman from Illinois, has agreed to assume the direction of this very important Cabinet office. She and I have known each other for many years. She was an outstanding member of Congress and an unofficial adviser to me. She has shared with me her wisdom on any number of legislative issues and I am delighted to have her working at my side on labor matters as we enter the decade of the '90s. She's a mother who knows the need for child care. She's a professional who understands the business-labor relationship. And, as a congresswoman, she spent years dealing with the concerns and aspirations of the working Americans from every walk of life. And I know that she will serve with great distinction in our Cabinet. Lynn was in Illinois this afternoon when I called her. And she will be in Washington on Monday, and I look forward to meeting her here in the White House to talk about the direction of the Department of Labor. And now I'd like to take up another subject, a second one. On Nov. 30, in offering direct meetings between the United States and Iraq, I offered to go the extra mile for a peaceful solution to the gulf question. And I wanted to make clear to Saddam Hussein the absolute determination of the coalition that he comply fully with the Security Council resolutions. Iraqi aggression cannot be rewarded. And so I have asked the secretary of sate to be available to go to Baghdad any time up to and including Jan. 3, which is over five months after the invasion of Kuwait and only 12 days before the United Nations deadline for withdrawal. That deadline is real. To show flexibility, I have offered any one of 15 dates for Secretary Baker to go to Baghdad, and the Iraqis have offered only one date. In offering to go the extra mile for peace, however, I did not offer to be a party to Saddam Hussein's manipulation. Saddam Hussein is not too busy to see, on short notice, Kurt Waldheim, Willy Brandt, Muhammad Ali, Ted Heath, John Connally, Ramsey Clark, and many, many others on very short notice. And it simply is not credible that he cannot, over a two-week period, make a couple of hours available for the secretary of state on an issue of this importance, unless, of course, he is seeking to circumvent the United Nations deadline. Look, I want a peaceful solution to this crisis. But I will not be a party to circumventing or diluting the United Nations deadline, which I think offers the very best chance for a peaceful solution. And so I wanted to get out my feeling about these proposed meetings. Q. Mr. President, what's wrong with the Jan. 12 date that he set? Why would that dilute it, unless you're afraid that he might come up with some offer? A. Well, in the first place, the United Nations resolutions that pertain say that he has to be out of Kuwait. I wish now that I had been a little more explicit in my first announcement on what I meant by ``mutually convenient dates.'' But I was not then, but now - and am not now prepared to have this man manipulate the purpose of the secretary of state's visit. So we will - we have made an offer of many, many dates, but remember, the United Nations resolution calls for total withdrawal by this date. Q. And does your statement today indicate that you would not accept Jan. 5 or 6? A. We've offered 15 days, and he ought to get moving and do something reasonable, if he really wants to move for peace. Q. Mr. President, is there a date at which you would withdraw the offer to meet. The senators this morning say you're willing to forgo talks now? A. Well, we're not going to do them on terms that are - would appear to the world to be an effort to circumvent the United Nations resolution. I mean, he's got a massive force there, and that force has to be out on the 15th of January under the United Nations resolutions. So we'll see how it goes. I would say that we've given so many alternatives here that he ought to stay with - accept one of these. If he's serious. Now, if it's simply that he is trying to manipulate, that is what I will have no part of. Q. Is there a deadline for him to accept your offer? A. No, we're not putting down deadlines on it. The Aziz meeting is on hold, I guess. I mean, I say ``I guess'' because we've made clear to them that it's kind of a home-and-home arrangement here. Q. You've said the deadline is real, so that means you think you have carte blanche to start a war after Jan. 15 or on Jan. 15? A. I'm saying that the United Nations resolution is very clear as it regards Jan. 15, and I will continue now to work for a peaceful solution. MORE

DOC.HEAD: Swiss Playwright Is Dead of Heart Failure
DOC.TEXT: Friedrich Duerrenmatt, the Swiss writer whose plays display a sardonic mix of realism and absurd visions, died Friday of heart failure. He was 69. The author of ``The Visit'' and ``The Physicists'' died at his home in the lakeside town of Neuchatel in western Switzerland, the Diogenes Publishing House announced. It was three weeks before his 70th birthday. Duerrenmatt's collected works comprise more than 30 volumes and have been translated from the German into over 50 languages. He is believed to have been the most widely played contemporary dramatist since Bertolt Brecht. Besides plays, Duerrenmatt also wrote novels, essays and his convoluted ``Stoffe,'' or ``Materials,'' which blend fiction with autobiographical notes. His worldwide reputation was established by ``The Visit,'' which premiered in 1955. In the play, an entire town slowly yields to the temptation of murdering one of its citizens for the sake of a promised fortune. In another popular play, ``The Physicists,'' first performed in 1961, the main characters escape nuclear age realities in a madhouse. His novels included ``Justice,'' which has a complicated murder plot. His paintings also won considerable attention at several exhibitions. Duerrenmatt's last play was titled ``Achterloo'', a farcical theater-of-the-absurd parable inspired by the martial law clampdown on Poland's Solidarity movement. It premiered in 1983. He said the play tried to show that ``the modern world is changing into a theater...The consequences will be disastrous.'' The son of a Protestant pastor, Duerrenmatt was born Jan. 5, 1921 at Konolfingen, a town near the Swiss capital of Bern. Originally, he wanted to become a painter and also studied theology, philosophy, literature and natural sciences. His first success as writer came in 1949 with ``Romulus the Great,'' which he called an ``unhistorical historical comedy'' about the fall of the Roman Empire. Gloom mingled typically with impish irony and jocular paradoxes in Duerrenmatt's parable-type plays which he preferred to call comedies despite their tragic quality. Tragedy, he once observed, could no longer be written because the modern world, lacking established standards of guilt and retribution, was not suited for it. The world, he said, stands as ``an enigma of calamity that has to be accepted but to which there must be no surrender.'' Several plays were turned into movies, including ''The Visit'' starring Ingrid Bergman and Anthony Quinn. Deurrenmatt suffered from a heart condition for more than 20 years and was a diabetic. Funeral arrangements were not immediately known. He is survived by his second wife, Charlotte, a German TV director and writer, whom he married in 1984. His first wife, Lotti, and mother of his three children, Peter, Barbara and Ruth, died in early 1983.

DOC.HEAD: Waiter Wins Settlement in Claim of Heart Disease From Second-Hand Smoke
DOC.TEXT: A non-smoking waiter has received a settlement ina workers' compensation case in which he claimed his heart attack was caused by exposure to other people's cigarette smoke, his attorney said Friday. ``They've admitted that our claim is substantial enough that if they went to trial they'd probably lose,'' said the attorney, Charles Crane. In the settlement, the California Compensation Insurance Fund agreed to take care of the 54-year-old waiter's medical bills, which amount to about $85,000. Stanton Glantz, a researcher who testified in the case as an authority on passive smoking, said he believed it was the first time a workers' compensation decision was based on passive smoking-induced heart disease. ``And this was successful,'' said Glantz, of the University of California, San Francisco. He is co-author of a study that shows that second-hand cigarette smoke causes 32,000 heart disease deaths per year in the United States. The settlement of the case could have important ramifications for employers, Crane said. ``Basically what this says is that employers who have to pay for workers' compensation insurance better make sure their employees are not breathing in stuff they shouldn't be breathing in,'' Crane said. Jo-Linda Thompson, general counsel with the California Restaurant Association, said she had not yet reviewed the case so she did not know how it might affect restaurant owners. ``Maybe this is a very special case,'' she said. ``Maybe it's not.'' Michael Mowrey, the attorney who represented the State Compensation Insurance Fund, did not return two phone calls to his office. The waiter, Avtar Uhbi, did not smoke, had no family history of heart disease, ate a mostly vegetarian diet and otherwise had little risk or heart disease, Crane said. Yet he suffered a heart attack on March 14, 1989, which led to complications and 15 days in the hospital. ``There are just no environmental or hereditary factors other than what we found in his workplace,'' Crane said. ``This place was your real smoky bar.'' Uhbi said he worked at the combination bar and restaurant in Sausalito, just north of San Francisco, for five years. He has since left to open his own restaurant down the road. ``New Year's we are putting in a `no smoking sign','' he said.

DOC.HEAD: State Penitentiary Closes A Day After Executing Inmate
DOC.TEXT: The decrepit Virginia State Penitentiary was shut down Friday, a day after one of its last five inmates was put to death for raping and murdering a woman 12 years ago. For the first time since the Civil War, the cells in the 190-year-old prison were empty. The last four inmates were loaded in handcuffs into a van and taken to a prison in Greensville 55 miles away. In a ceremony a few minutes later, Warden Raymond Muncy asked for the official prison population count. A few people smiled as Maj. E.T. Turner stepped forward and declared, ``The count at the Virginia State Penitentiary is zero.'' ``Accordingly, in my capacity as the current warden, I now declare the Virginia State Penitentiary closed,'' the warden said. ``Major, strike the colors.'' Five guards walked in formation, lowered the Virginia and American flags, folded them into triangles and saluted. About 12 hours earlier, Buddy Early Justus was executed in the state's electric chair for the Oct. 3, 1978, rape-slaying of Ida Moses. He also had received death sentences for murdering Rosemary Jackson, 32, in Gwinnett County, Ga., and Stephanie Hawkins, 21, in Tampa, Fla., later that month. No other prison in the state has the electrical hookup for the chair, and the execution chamber will remain at the prison until April, when a new death chamber at the Greensville prison is expected to be completed. The antiquated prison will be torn down after the death chamber is relocated. State law requires a working execution chamber. Justus was the 11th person to die in the electric chair since Virginia resumed executions in 1982. He was the 143rd person to be executed nationwide since the U.S. Supreme Court allowed states to revive the death penalty in 1976. The electric chair is bolted to the floor in a basement cell block. ``It's the first time since 1865 there's been no prisoners,'' said Bill Linkous, chief of operations for adult institutions. ``In 1865, the whole population escaped,'' said former warden James P. Mitchell, who is helping close the prison. When Union soldiers entered Richmond, the prison guards fled. With no one to watch them, the inmates left, too, he said. Eighty-seven of the 187 prisoners were recaptured, Mitchell said. The original penitentiary, built 190 years ago, was torn down in 1928. The oldest of the existing prison buildings is the factory shops building, built in 1888.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Mum On Party Leadership; Conservatives' Criticism Rises
DOC.TEXT: President Bush kept mum Friday on his new search for a Republican Party chairman as conservatives, betting they won't like his pick, said turmoil within the GOP makes it more likely Bush will face a 1992 challenge from the right. Bush headed to Camp David for the weekend still having said nothing publicly about William Bennett's abrupt decision not to take over the Republican National Committee or his new search to fill the GOP's leadership vacuum. Party officials and GOP analysts predicted Bush would act quickly to fill the vacancy. The name of former Texas congressman Tom Loeffler figured prominently in the speculation, with some party officials saying he appeared to be the early favorite. At the White House, one source said Loeffler was in the running but that there was no frontrunner. Another White House source said bluntly that Loeffler ``is history,'' indicating a fight may be brewing within the administration over the vacancy and whether Bush needed a high-profile chairman to put the Bennett embarrassment behind him. ``Tom is on the list, but a lot of people are on the list,'' said the first source, both of whom spoke on the condition of anonymity. ``The president has not given a nod or a wink or a whisper about his thinking.'' Others mentioned in speculation included longtime Republican operative and Bush loyalist Rich Bond, Housing Secretary Jack Kemp, Transportation Secretary Samuel Skinner and several congressional Republicans who lost 1990 elections or are retiring. Among them, retiring Sen. William Armstrong of Colorado surfaced as a favorite of conservatives, including administration aides. Bush filled one administration vacancy - nominating Rep. Lynn Martin of Illinois as labor secretary - before heading to Camp David for the weekend. The vacancy at the RNC did not come up during a brief Bush meeting with reporters. An administration official said the list ``was in no order other than alphabetical.'' With the RNC annual meeting a month away and Bush facing increasing criticism even within his party, there was little doubt he would pick a chairman soon. ``The way the Bennett thing was handled, it looks like they waffled back and forth,'' said Lyn Nofziger, who ran the political operation in the Reagan White House. ``They seemed to have handled it the same way they handled the tax thing, going back and forth. I think he ought to do this pretty quickly and get it behind him.'' Said another party official with ties to the White House: ``They'll be burning a little oil at Camp David to get this done.'' A Loeffler associate said the former four-term congressman ``had a good exchange of views about the job'' during a telephone conversation Thursday with presidential Chief of Staff John Sununu. But the administration official said Sununu had spoken to others as well. Loeffler, 44, was a rising star in the GOP leadership when he left the House, where he was known for his political skill and had a conservative voting record, including votes in favor of school prayer and limits on abortions. Armstrong also is a staunch, anti-abortion conservative. Bond, who did not return a telephone message, was said to be actively pursuing the position as well, and getting support from some in the party who favor a campaign strategist for chairman. Another strategist whose name surfaced was Spence Abraham, the Michigan GOP chairman. Bush decided in November to replace the ailing Lee Atwater as chairman of the Republican National Committee, and selected Bennett not long after he resigned as presidential drug policy chief. But Bennett said Thursday that he would not take the job because of a White House ruling severely limiting his options to make outside income. That dramatic decision left conservatives, suspicious of Bush's motives for selecting Bennett but happy nonetheless to have an ally with access to the president, renewing talk of mounting a longshot bid to wrest the 1992 nomination from the incumbent president. ``Conservatives are so disillusioned with Bush that anybody he picks is really not going to be much of a help to him,'' said GOP activist Richard Viguerie, echoing comments of several conservatives. ``Many conservatives in the country are saying it's time to get off the bus, turn it over and set it on fire. The bus driver has serious problems.'' But Nofziger said the conservative criticism was unlikely to mushroom into a serious threat to Bush. ``There are an awful lot of conservatives who would rather go fight somebody than run something,'' Nofziger said. ``I'm one of them at heart but it just doesn't make sense. I don't see anyway that anyone is going to mount a significant challenge.''

DOC.HEAD: Ponderous Peanut Poundage Pared
DOC.TEXT: The 1991 national peanut poundage quota will be 1,555,000 tons, or 3.1 billion pounds, the Agriculture Department said Friday. Deputy Secretary Jack C. Parnell said 1991 quota - the amount determined that will be required to meet domestic edible and seed needs - is down 10,000 tons, or 20 million pounds, from the 1990 quota. Under the program, states and qualified farms will be allocated shares of the national quota. Peanuts grown under a quota are qualified for higher federal price supports than non-quota peanuts.

DOC.HEAD: Sanitation Workers Consider New Contract
DOC.TEXT: Private sanitation workers ratified a new three-year contract Friday, ending a five-day strike that left tons of uncollected garbage piled high on sidewalks. The 2,100 workers pick up trash from about 250,000 businesses citywide. The vote to end the walkout was 269 to 24. Many of the workers who did not vote had crossed picket lines. ``We're going back to work immediately,'' said Bernard Adelstein, leader of Teamsters Local 813. Under the deal, the lowest-paid sanitation workers will get an increase of 12.5 percent over three years, Adelstein said. A $15-a-week raise kicks in June 1, 1991; $30-a-week raises will follow Dec. 1, 1991, and Dec. 1, 1992, he said. The union set up picket lines Sunday night after rejecting an offer that raised salaries $70 a week over three years. The union sought a $90 increase in a three-year contract. The workers earn $600 to $700 a week under the old contract. Union leaders reached a tentative settlement Thursday during a seven-hour session with city officials. A spokesman for management did not return telephone messages left Friday. Besides better wages, the unions want private carters to pay a fee for using out-of-state workers to haul trash to out-of-state dumps. The companies agreed the union would have the right to organize any such workers. The strike, the first by private sanitation workers since a 17-day walkout nine years ago, resulted in mounds of trash bags outside fast food restaurants and movie theaters. Residential garbage collection - done by the city - was not affected.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON: peaceful solution.
DOC.TEXT: Q. Well, you do think you can go to war after that, is that right? A. What do you mean, ``can go to war''? Q. You can start a war. A. I think that the United Nations resolutions should be fully implemented. Q. Mr. President, when Congress comes back in January, will you ask Congress for specific authority to take offensive action? A. I - we're talking about that, and I'm very pleased with the support we've had in Congress, and I'm very pleased with the level of support from the American people. You see, as these hostages have come home, I think the people have understood much more clealy what's at stake. As they've seen the testimony about the brutality to the Kuwaiti people that was so compelling at the United Nations, I think people have said, ``Wait a minute, this policy deserves support.'' So I am pleased with the support I think that's being manifested in more support by the Congress. But I will be talking to the leaders, continuing to consult. And what I told the leaders in the Cabinet Room a few weeks ago, if you want to come in here and strongly endorse what I am doing or endorse the United Nations resolution, I welcome that because I think it would send a very strong, clear signal to the world. Q. Well, sir, why are you afraid to go before Congress and consult with them and get their advice and get their approval? A. Hey, listen, Sarah, I was consulting with them as recently as this morning - five members of Congress. And we will continue to consult with them. Q. That's not 535 members of the House and Senate. A. We're doing it all the time. I'm on the phone almost every day to them. We've had leadership meeting after leadership meeting. Oh listen. I explained this to you in the press room a while back - this same question. Come on. Q. But you should see my mail. A. You ought to see mine. Q. Are you saying if Saddam Hussein won't meet by Jan. 3, there simply will be no meeting? A. I'm saying that he - we've given him 15 dates and he ought to take one of them. I don't like to draw deadlines in the sand here. But I - there'd have to be some compelling reason for me to change it, because I don't want to move this up against the United Nations deadline. If you'll read the U.N. resolutions, you'll see that he should be totally out, totally out of Kuwait by Jan. 15. That's a massive undertaking. Q. Mr. President, if I may follow up, are you saying that you may meet Jan. 4 or 5? Q. I'm not saying that. You're saying that. I've put it as clearly as I can. I hope there's no obfuscation. Q. Mr. President, what is your thinking today about Saddam Hussein's nuclear and chemical capabilities? A. I am very much concerned about it. I think that Congress and the American people are getting increasingly concerned about his - it's not just nuclear which concerns me, but it's other unconventional war capabilities. I'm talking about, for example in this context, chemical weapons that he has used on his own people already. So yes, I am very concerned about it, and any arrangement that is going to keep the rest of the world happy will have to address itself to these - this unconventional war capability of Saddam Hussein. Anybody that will take the reckless action he has taken militarily against a neighbor must be contained in this era when we're all concerned about nuclear proliferation. So I'm glad you brought it up, because this morning I met with a group of people who are supportive of our policy and they are emphasizing to me, as they go across the country, the concern by the American people - on the part of the American people - about his possession of these unconventional weapons and his desire to acquire nuclear weapons. And I told - I believe that it was a press conference with most of you present - I said if I've got to err on the side of how long - I addressed myself to the question, how long does he - will it take for him to get weapons, I will err on the cautious side, on the conservative side. And I am concerned that he could acquire weapons in a very short period of time - a weapon in a very short period of time. And that is a factor that is serious as I contemplate how he is compelled to live up to the United Nations resolution. Q. Mr. President, do you support the Department of Education regulations barring race-based scholarships, or do you plan to rescind them? A. We're looking at it right now. The man that had something to do with them - I was looking at his background today - is an extraordinarily sensitive, very intelligent person. So I've asked our staff here to give me a quick readout on that so we can make a determination. But I don't think in this case anybody would accuse the person that promulgated those resolutions of doing it on a racist basis. That's one thing I'm very pleased about. I've got time for one more, and then I really do have to go. Q. Mr. President, right now the issue of chemical - possession of weapons and nuclear weapons is not part of the United Nations resolutions. Will you go back to the U.N. and get that made part of one of the requirements for Saddam Hussein or will you move on that unilaterally? A. Well, I don't think it's unilateral because I think all our coalition partners share my concerns about his possession of unconventional weapons and his attempt to get more. But I don't have plans at this moment to take this to the United Nations. But believe me, it is very much in my thinking as I contemplate what action to take to enforce the United Nations resolutions. Thank you all and have a great weekend.

DOC.HEAD: Tobacco Quota Unchanged
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS headline, quota sted quote
DOC.TEXT: The 1991 federal marketing quota for flue-cured tobacco was announced Friday by the Agriculture Department at 877.7 million pounds, unchanged from the 1990 quota. The acreage allotment was pegged at 420,354 acres, unchanged from 1990. Officials said each farm's 1991 basic quota and acreage allotments will remain the same as this year. Officials said the 1991 price support will be $1.528 per pound, up four cents from 1990. The 1991 marketing quota assessment under the Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1990 will be 0.764 cents per pound on both growers and buyers, meaning a total assessment of 1.528 cents per pound for the 1991 crop of flue-cured tobacco. The no-net-cost program assessment will be announced later, the department said.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Doctors' Income Up 7.7 Percent in 1989
LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: The average income of physicians increased about $11,000 to more than $155,000 in 1989, according to a study by the American Medical Association. The 7.7 percent increase outstripped the rate of inflation, as measured by the Consumer Price Index, which increased 4.6 percent in 1989. The president-elect of the AMA, the nation's largest organization of doctors, said Friday he could see public concern about the increase but he didn't think doctors as a group ``are overpaid or underpaid.'' ``I would expect the average person's reaction to be surprise, but when you think about the number of hours a doctor works in a week, and some of the training, the intensity of some of the work in some of the specialties, I think it's understandable,'' said Dr. John J. Ring. Ring, a family physician in suburban Mundelein, noted that the increase in 1989, the last year in which the figures were available, was actually smaller than most years since 1981. Average physician income nationally was $155,800 in 1989, up from the 1988 average of $144,700, the AMA said. The median physician income - the statistical midpoint between the highest and lowest salaries - was $125,000 in 1989, up from $120,000 in 1988. The AMA says it prefers the median figure because higher paid doctors tend to raise the average, making it a poor measure of ``typical'' earnings. The figures are from the Chicago-based AMA's Socioeconomic Monitoring System Report, which surveyed 4,000 doctors. The figures represent income before taxes but after all professional expenses. In 1981, the first year of the survey, the average was $89,900. Family physicians earned the least, an average of $95,900 in 1989 compared with $94,600 in 1988. Surgeons earned the most among specialists, a 1989 average of $220,500 compared with $207,500 in 1988. Charles Inlander, president of the People's Medical Society, a consumer interest group in suburban Philadelphia, called the figures ``another example of how doctors gouge the public.'' ``It is immoral for doctors to have this kind of income when 15 percent of the population has no health-care insurance,'' he said. A survey conducted last year for the AMA found that two-thirds of Americans think doctors are too interested in making money. But the salary survey can be misleading, said one central Illinois family physician with a solo practice. ``Some kinds of doctors are overpaid, some are not paid what they're worth,'' said Dr. George Savvas of Champaign. General practitioners in Champaign make closer to $75,000 than $95,000, Savvas said. ``It's not very easy money. I get myself up at 5 o'clock in the morning and I go home at night and most of the time I don't even get a break,'' Savvas said. There is also the cost of malpractice insurance and difficulties getting paid through the Medicare system, Savvas said. Primary care doctors often lose their Medicare payments to specialists they have referred their patients to, he said. Insurers have long paid high fees for technical procedures and operations and much less for the hours that primary care doctors spend figuring out which treatments their patients need. But beginning in 1992, Medicare will reimburse doctors more for their time managing and evaluating patients and less for technical services and operations. Here are some other average 1989 incomes for specialties other than surgeons, according to the AMA survey: -Internal medicine, $146,500; -Pediatrics, $104,700; -Obstetrics-gynecology, $194,300; -Radiology, $210,500; -Psychiatry, $111,700; -Anesthesiologist, $185,800; -Pathologist, $154,500;

DOC.HEAD: Kosovo Leaders Encouraged by Changes in Albania
With AM-Albania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: An ethnic Albanian leader said Friday changes in neighboring Albania would bolster efforts for autonomy in Yugoslavia's troubled Kosovo province. ``The victory of democracy in Albania would represent great support and encouragement for the struggle of Albanian people in Yugoslavia,'' said Dr. Fehmi Agani, leader of the Democratic Union of Kovoso. The first non-Communist political party was formed in Albania this week. There also have been reports of street violence, despite a string of concessions by authorities in Europe's last Stalinist nation. Agani said his group was concerned about reports of clashes in Albania, but ``we believe ... that there is enough wisdom, strength and resolution in Albania to safeguard a peaceful, accelerated democratic transformation of the country.'' Ethnic Albanians comprise about 90 percent of the 1.9 million people in Kosovo, a Yugoslav province now tightly controlled by the Serbian republic. Last Sunday, most ethnic Albanians boycotted the first free elections in more than 50 years in Serbia. After the Kosovo parliament proclaimed sovereignty this summer, the Serbian government dismissed legislators and shut down all influential Albanian-language media in the province. Serbia sees the region as its historic homeland, and refuses to grant Kosovo greater independence. Serbian authorities charge that Albanians are seeking to secede and join Albania. Leading ethnic Albanian dissident author Rexhep Qosja said in a telephone interview that ``it is natural for'' Albanians to live together. ``Why would the people of Kosovo be an exception?'' Qosja asked. ``I believe that Serbia will one day rather negotiate with Albania about Kosovo than to allow the province to become a republic.'' ``There is no turning back in Albania and the democracy will win there,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Army Canceling Plan For New Air Defense Missile
DOC.TEXT: The Army said Friday it has canceled plans to build a new air-defense missile under development by Boeing Aerospace and Electronics Co. and Hughes Aircraft Co. The estimated cost of fully developing of the weapon, called the Non-Line of Sight missile, has tripled over the past two years, to nearly $400 million, the Army said in explaining why it decided to end the project after spending $131 million. The missile was being designed with a fiber-optic guidance system that would enable Army gunners to use it against helicopters and armored vehicles hidden by ground cover. The missile's launcher and fire control station were to be mounted on a Hum-vee, the all-purpose vehicle that replaced the Army jeep. The proposed missile was part of the Army's plan for an integrated air-defense system for front-line combat operations. The plan, still in effect, includes the air-to-air Stinger missile deployed on helicopters, improved tank ammunition for air defense and an improved command and control system.

DOC.HEAD: Squid Could Hold Weapon Against Chemical Warfare
DOC.TEXT: Saddam Hussein take notice: squid swimming off the shores of Cape Cod have a secret weapon against nerve gas. An enzyme within squid nerve cells breaks down nerve gas and has the attention of military researchers, who are trying to find practical uses for it on the battlefield. ``When you know that some people have chemical weapons, you need to know how to get rid of them,'' said Shirley Tove of the Army Research Office in Research Triangle Park, N.C. The U.S. military has had more reason lately to fear nerve gas, as troops face the threat of Iraqi chemical weapons in the Persian Gulf. The squid nerve gas defense was discovered by Francis Hoskin, who has spent his summers collecting squid at the Marine Biological Laboratory in Woods Hole. More than two decades ago, Hoskin applied nerve poison to a squid nerve and was astonished when the nerve kept functioning. ``What was happening was most of the nerve gas solution was being detoxified, or chewed up, by the enzyme,'' he said in a recent interview. Hoskin, a research professor of biology at the Illinois Institute of Technology in Chicago, continued studying the enzyme. The Defense Department has helped fund Hoskin's research through much of the past decade, Tove said. Scientists envision attaching the enzyme to fabric, thus enabling the Army to create protective uniforms. Another possibility is enzyme-laden soap, which could be used to wash the chemicals off the skin or equipment. Such applications, however, probably will not be seen for years, Tove said. First of all, scientists must develop ways to clone the enzyme, since each squid produces only a microscopic amount of the substance. And the Army is not banking completely on squid. A similar enzyme produced by soil bacteria also is being studied, Tove said. Hoskin said military officials have been asking him more questions about his work since Iraq invaded Kuwait in August. But Hoskin, who was a pilot in World War II and describes himself as ``not the world's greatest pacifist,'' says that for now he's more interested in pure science than military strategy. ``Why should a squid that has been evolving for almost 1 billion years, why should it have an enzyme to deal with a compound that was only synthesized in the 1920s?'' Hoskin asked.

DOC.HEAD: Small Quake Shakes Owens Valley Along Eastern Sierra Nevada
DOC.TEXT: Owens Valley along the eastern Sierra Nevada was jolted by an earthquake Friday, but no damage was reported, officials said. The magnitude-3.4 temblor struck at 6:22 a.m. and was centered 11 miles south of Lone Pine, said seismologist Rick McKenzie of the University of California seismographic station at Berkeley. A few residents of Lone Pine, 175 miles north of Los Angeles, called the Inyo County Sheriff's Department, but none reported damage or injuries. ``It was reported as being a very sharp jolt but lasting only a second,'' said dispatcher Ray Roe in Independence, 15 miles to the north. Owens Valley was the site of one of three great earthquakes in California's recorded history, a jolt that measured 8 on the Richter scale. The quake March 26, 1872, killed 27 people and injured 56 others.

DOC.HEAD: Palestinians Stab to Death Three Jews, Israelis Seek Revenge
LaserPhotos TLV1,2,3,101
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with Milo warning of `unprecedented measures,' bar on Hanukkah celebration at Temple Mount, right-wing call for deportations and dismissals, new collaborating suspect killed. Edits to trim. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Palestinians stabbed three Jews to death in an aluminum factory Friday and sprayed Moslem fundamentalist slogans on the walls before fleeing, police said. The killings set off anti-Arab riots and cries for vengeance. The latest in a string of knife attacks on Jewish civilians also brought demands from Israeli right-wingers for a crackdown on Palestinians. Police Minister Roni Milo promised ``unprecedented measures'' and said he had decided to support use of the death penalty. Capital punishment exists on Israeli military law books but is never imposed. He said he would limit the hours per day that Arabs from the occupied territories can stay in Israel. Right-wing politicians, including members of the governing coalition, demanded the deportation of 1,000 leaders of the anti-Israeli uprising and the dismissal of the more than 100,000 Arabs who live in the occupied lands but work in Israel. Moderate Israelis blamed Friday's killings on the failure of Arab-Israeli peace moves. The slayings in the mixed Arab-Jewish town of Jaffa, adjacent to Tel Aviv, brought Jewish mobs onto the streets, stoning cars, assaulting Arab passersby and clamoring for revenge. Police said the attack was thought to be the work of an Arab from the occupied Gaza Strip who works at the factory, and one accomplice. Both were still being sought, they said. The attackers apparently waited outside the Alum Shin plant until two Jewish employees arrived and escorted them in. They then stabbed Iris Asraf, a 22-year-old secretary; metal cutter Moshe Awan, 40; and Yehoshua Hakmaz, 30, an upholsterer working next door who ran to help after hearing screams, police said. The bodies were found at about 8:30 a.m. when another secretary arrived, found knives and pools of blood on the floor and called for help, police said. An unidentified witness told Israel radio he saw one man ``lying on the steps, folded like a bag. ... The knives were thrown near the body, long knives with wide blades, real commando knives.'' Police said slogans in black paint on the walls claimed responsibility on behalf of Hamas, or Zeal, an Islamic fundamentalist underground group. Hamas, which marked the third anniversary of its foundation Friday, had called on Palestinians to mark the date by escalating their uprising against Israel. Police commissioner Yaacov Terner rushed to the scene and said: ``The sole reason for this murder is nationalism. The slogans written in Arabic on the walls inside are clear.'' ``Hamas did it, they did it for the purpose of killing to mark the Hamas anniversary,'' he said. There were shouts of ``Death to Arabs!'' and ``Terner go Home!'' from Jews accusing police of not doing enough to protect Israelis, and angry people gathered near murder victim Hakmaz's house in neighboring Bat Yam. ``I feel great pain that every day Jews die in every corner of the country. Now it came to us. I'm afraid to let my wife go out ... at night, I have to get downstairs and accompany them,'' one man said on Israel radio. Paramilitary border police poured into Jaffa to reinforce police coping with crowds of angry Jews. The rioters torched a car with a Gaza license plate and besieged a coffee shop where an Arab had taken refuge behind the police. ``Let's do to them what they do to us,'' bellowed one man. ``If we aren't safe among them, they shouldn't be safe among us.'' Police said three Arab cars were damaged, one Arab was slightly injured by a knife, and three Jews were arrested. Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, returning from talks with President Bush in Washington, said he would consult colleagues about the killings, but added he was sensitive to U.S. appeals for restraint. Asked about reports that Israel was planning to deport 12 uprising leaders and that Washington had urged him not to do it, Shamir said: ``Nothing explicit was said to me'' about canceling any particular measure. But, Shamir added, he found ``sensitivity'' in the administration ``to drastic measures against Palestinian rioters and disturbers of the peace.'' Asked if this would influence his actions, Shamir replied that ``of course, we are sensitive to this sensibility.'' Friday's deaths raised to 57 the number of Israelis killed by Palestinians in the three-year revolt in the occupied West Bank and the Gaza Strip. In the last attack on Dec. 2, three West Bank Arabs boarded a bus in Tel Aviv, stabbed a Jew to death and wounded three others. The recent wave of attacks followed the Temple Mount riot, in which 17 Palestinians were shot and killed by Israeli police. In another announcement Friday, Police Minister Milo said he will prohibit Jewish extremists from celebrating the Jewish holiday of Hanukkah at the site next week. At least 778 Arabs have been killed by Israeli troops or civilians in the uprising. Palestinians have murdered 317 fellow Arabs, most on suspicion of collaborating with Israel.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Gorbachev Issues Crackdown to Ensure Supplies to Moscow ^Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with Gorbachev's presidential decree to ensure food supplies, restore order to economy. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev acted on Friday to try to restore order to the chaotic Soviet economy, nullifying decisions by the republics and local authorities that have disrupted food supplies. He also decreed that government enterprises must carry out all contracts through the rest of this year and the first quarter of 1991 to ensure a steady flow of supplies. His move represented a crackdown on those regions that have broken the discipline that for years has guided the Soviet Union's command economy. Parliament has pressured Gorbachev to improve food supplies, particularly in Moscow and Leningrad, where state stores have little milk, sugar, eggs, butter, cheese and meat. Some right-wing lawmakers demand a state of emergency. Moscow city officials accuse surrounding regions that usually supply the capital with food of reneging on contracts and stopping deliveries. Gorbachev's presidential decree ``On Combatting Disorganization of the Soviet Economy'' was read Friday night on Soviet television. In it, Gorbachev complained that government economic decisions ``have not been carried out.'' He declared ``null and void all economic decisions by local and republic bodies which undermine normal trade.'' He also ordered local and republic officials to reverse decisions to stop supplying Russian regions and Moscow. The decree ordered the government to apply tough sanctions on exporters who fail to secure proper licenses and contracts to sell raw materials and other goods abroad. This appeared aimed at preventing any of the 15 republics from signing contracts with foreign firms to export resources without central government consent. Earlier Friday, presidential economic adviser Stanislav Shatalin blamed food shortages entirely to distribution problems and economic disarray. He urged that emergency steps be taken, without specifying what he had in mind. Soviet ports and borders have been swamped by shipments. More than 1.6 million metric tons of imported goods were waiting to be unloaded or transported from ports and about 7,000 railways cars were waiting at border stations. The government says deliveries of most products are running 15 percent to 44 percent below 1989 levels, mostly due to theft and profiteering. ``Hunger is not an issue. There's enough food,'' Shatalin said in an interview. ``The issue is how to find it and distribute it so that it doesn't get into the hands of the mafia, sabateours and corrupted elements.'' Shatalin had spearheaded a radical economic reform plan at the center of recent political battles. Black marketeers have pilfered state supplies. Heavy-handed economic control makes it more profitable for farmers to sell their products through unofficial channels. Friday's Moskovskaya Pravda reported that the KGB secret police, searching Moscow warehouses for hidden food, found in one shop nearly two metric tons of meat, 750 cans of instant coffee and 880 pounds of butter. One Moscow fish distribution enterprise had 193 metric tons of black caviar whose date of sale had already expired, the newspaper said. Shatalin said efforts at economic and political change are linked beyond recall with the food problem. But in the course of working out reforms, ``there were things we didn't know how to do, and couldn't do, and a difficult situation emerged. And these have to be resolved by emergency measures,'' he said. Foreign countries continued to send the Soviet Union tons of humanitarian aid. At a summit meeting in Rome, the European Community on Friday approved a $1 billion emergency aid package to help the Soviet economy and support Gorbachev. About 1,700 metric tons and 800 tons of medicine and other supplies have arrived, with most going to hospitals and children's homes, officials said. The aid also is meant to bolster Gorbachev, who has been attacked by hard-liners and radicals during the nation's economic and political turmoil. Gorbachev ordered the KGB and other law enforcement bodies to halt pilfering, and government commissions have been formed to monitor the problem and direct the distribution of food. Workers' committees and other informal groups also are tracking food on the way to its destination, Shatalin said. But the heart of the problem remains land ownership and the chance to produce food profitably, he said. Individuals must be given farmland from the state-owned farms and from collective farms that now can reserve only some of their produce for private use. Individual Soviets already have the right to own tiny plots of land, which alone account for an estimated 30 percent of the country's food sold through high-priced private markets. Shatalin last autumn championed radical economic reforms that, among other things, would allow private property ownership. But Gorbachev rejected the plan in October in favor of a conservative compromise. The move precipitated a split with Boris Yeltsin, president of the Russian republic, who pushed ahead with the radical plan on Russian territory. Russia and other republics began issuing orders that conflicted with Gorbachev's decrees, causing a paralysis of power that has contributed to the food problem. KGB chairman Vladimir Kryuchkov, in a nationally televised address Tuesday, also accused unidentified foreign powers of supporting Soviet radicals, who were in turn exploiting spot food shortages.

DOC.HEAD: Expect City Loan Request Next Week, Pension Board Told
DOC.TEXT: Philadelphia missed a self-imposed deadline Friday for solving its cash crunch, but the city treasurer said he expected a deal to be ready by next week. Several parties interested in lending money have declined to commit themselves, pending resolution of such issues as fiscal reform and who gets repaid first, city Treasurer Benjamin Blakney said. The city intends to sell about $300 million in short-term notes to banks, two pension boards and the investment firm Merrill Lynch to avoid going broke before major tax payments come due in February and March. A $375 million note issue collapsed in September amid worries about the city's fiscal condition. Bond-rating agencies have dropped Philadelphia's credit rating this year to junk-bond levels, the lowest among major U.S. cities. Unless it receives a cash infusion, the city has warned it will not be able to meet payroll as early as Dec. 28 for city workers. Finance Director Elizabeth C. Reveal, in a letter Monday, set deadlines of Friday for commitments to buy notes and next Wednesday for closing the deal. ``There are open issues which clearly are still being looked at and quite frankly are still being discussed,'' Blakney said. ``We will continue as expeditiously as possible to resolve those issues.'' He said interest rates were less of a stumbling block than structural aspects of the transaction. While declining to go into details, he said major unresolved issues included fiscal reform and whether all note holders would be repaid simultaneously. Representatives from a consortium of banks met privately with Gov. Robert P. Casey on Thursday and Mayor W. Wilson Goode on riday. The banks reportedly have sought a fiscal control board, double-digit interest rates and assurances they would be repaid before other note buyers. Goode described his meeting with the bankers as ``very constructive,'' said his press secretary, Karen Warrington. ``The mayor feels they're continuing to make progress and the parties are working to pull together a package that could avoid a missed payroll,'' she said. Members of the city pension board and the state teachers pension fund met but did not vote on any proposals related to the note sale. The city Board of Pensions and Retirement is awaiting a report from Ian Lanoff, a Washington pension-law expert, who was hired to advise them on the note transaction. Blakney said Lanoff was ``fine-tuning some of the salient details'' of a response to the city's proposal. Similar responses were being drafted by the banks, Merrill Lynch and consultants to the state Public School Employees' Retirement Board, he said. Goode and other Democratic leaders have urged higher taxes, spending cuts, long-term deficit financing and other steps to stem the red ink. Action on those steps is not expected until the state Legislature reconvenes early next year.

DOC.HEAD: Widow of Civil Rights Leader Medgar Evers Testifies Before Grand Jury
DOC.TEXT: Myrlie Evers, the widow of slain civil rights leader Medgar Evers, testified for an hour Friday before a grand jury investigating her husband's 1963 assassination. ``I'm filled with a little apprehension, a lot of hope and faith,'' Evers said as she left the Hinds County Courthouse, where the grand jury met amid speculation it may issue a new indictment in the 27-year-old case. The panel Thursday summoned a former police detective who investigated the slaying scene at Evers' Jackson home. Grand jurors also examined the rifle used to kill Evers. Byron De La Beckwith, 70, a white supremacist from Signal Mountain, Tenn., has said he is the target of the grand jury investigation. He has also said he is innocent. Beckwith was arrested after the slaying, but two 1964 trials ended with all-white juries deadlocked on verdicts. The original murder indictment was dismissed in 1969. Beckwith was a Greenwood fertilizer salesman at the time of the slaying. Evers, 37 when he died, was field secretary for the Mississippi branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. Assistant District Attorney Bobby DeLaughter spent nearly six hours with the grand jury Thursday. DeLaughter, who has spent 14 months looking into the slaying, couldn't comment on the secret proceedings. But he did say he views reopening the case as a way to help right an old wrong. ``This single, cowardly act of the person responsible for Medgar Evers' assassination has probably done more to hurt the state and to hurt the perception of Mississippi and Mississippians across the nation, and possibly the world, than any other single act I can think of,'' DeLaughter said. ``If it's possible to right that wrong, I certainly think we have a responsibility of doing that. If we could pick up where the previous investigation left off, produce more evidence, I think we have an obligation of doing that,'' DeLaughter said. State Fire Marshal John Chamblee, a Jackson police detective sergeant at the time of the June 12, 1963, slaying, would not comment Thursday after leaving the grand jury room. One piece of evidence seen taken into the grand jury room was a 1917 model 30.06 Enfield rifle equipped with a scope. At the two 1964 trials, a Jackson police fingerprint expert testified prints found on the scope matched Beckwith's. Testimony in the trials also showed Beckwith obtained the rifle in 1960 and acquired the scope about one month before Evers was shot. Beckwith testified that the rifle was stolen from him. Evers' 57-year-old widow, now a Los Angeles public works commissioner, spent most of Thursday in the district attorney's office at the courthouse. ``I'm here to assist in any way I possibly can with the grand jury hearing,'' she said. ``It's something that needs to be put to rest. Justice needs to be done for the state of Mississippi and for Medgar's family. I'm hopeful this time.''

DOC.HEAD: Bushes Sending Cards Wishing for `Harmony To Our World'
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and his wife, Barbara, are sending 145,000 Christmas cards expressing the wish that the new year will bring ``harmony to our world.'' The cover of the card shows a watercolor of the Oval Office, with a colorfully decorated Christmas tree standing alongside the president's desk. The artwork was done by Mark Hampton, an interior designer, artist and writer involved in the restoration of the White House and Blair House, the government guest house. The cards were printed by Hallmark. The White House said the Republican national Committee was paying for the printing and mailing costs. The message in the card reads: ``The president and Mrs. Bush extend their warmest wishes for a merry Christmas and a new year that will bring harmony to our world and happiness to you and those you love. 1990.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Asks For `Quick Readout' on Minority Scholarship Flap
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS Thursday to Friday in 5th graf, The White; 9th graf, Williams on; 12th graf, On Thursday, and 14th graf, Also on
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, seeking to avoid a damaging civil rights dispute, said Friday he has asked his staff ``to get a quick readout'' on an Education Department ruling that could bar colleges from directing scholarship funds to minorities. ``We're looking at it right now,'' Bush said at a news conference when asked about the surprise decision which drew an immediate outcry from civil rights and education leaders. The Education Department's assistant secretary for civil rights, Michael L. Williams, on Wednesday announced that it was illegal for federally supported institutions to offer scholarships specifically for minorities. He cited Title VI of the 1964 Civil Rights Act, which prohibits discrimination on the ground of race, color, or national origin in any program or activity receiving federal financial assistance. The White House acknowledged Friday that it was caught off-guard by the decision. Presidential press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said that while Bush supports affirmative action programs for minorities, he is against quota systems. ``This is a kind of an in-between case that is not clear exactly where it comes through, how it would be applied, what it means,'' Fitzwater said. Bush defended Williams, saying he was ``an extrardinarily sensitive person. I don't think anyone would accuse him of doing it on a racist basis.'' Williams, 37, is a black lawyer who prosecuted racial crimes in the Reagan administration's Justice Department and served as deputy assistant secretary for law enforcement in the Treasury Department before moving to Education. Williams on Friday told Louisville civil rights activist Rev. Louis Coleman that the issue of ``race-specific'' scholarships was ``still under discussion,'' Coleman told The Associated Press. Coleman quoted Williams as saying the issue was now ``in other hands,'' suggesting that higher officials in the Bush administration had moved in to prevent a further widening of the rift between Bush and civil rights groups. Bush this fall vetoed a major civil rights bill passed by Congress on the grounds it would create quota systems in the employment of minorities. Civil rights groups said the veto showed the administration's insensitivity to minority problems. On Friday, civil rights leaders Jesse Jackson said the Education Department's premise that minority scholarships are illegal because ``we now live in a color-blind society ... is patently false and morally reprehensible.'' He said the president has the power to overrule Williams and ``we must write and telephone President Bush and register our protest and outrage.'' Also on Friday, Deputy Secretary of Education Ted Sanders met the leaders of six national educational associations to assure them that scholarships already granted to minority students will not be affected. Sanders said the department hopes to issue a clarification on the issue in the next few weeks, department spokesman John Bertak said. Educators say they are not clear what programs or how many people could be affected by the ruling. Federally funded programs to assist minorities are apparently not involved and private grants are permissible. Targeted would be college and university programs that set aside funding specifically for certain minorities. Robin Robinson, director of financial aid at American University in Washington, said her school's $1.1 million Frederick Douglass program, aimed mainly at minorities from local high schools, should be safe because other factors besides race are considered. But she said, ``we're just waiting to see what the intent of it (the ruling) is.'' The House Education and Labor Committee is to open hearings Wednesday on the scholarship issue, with Williams among those testifying, committee officials said.

DOC.HEAD: U.N. Leader to Visit Palestinian Refugees, Urges Peace Conference
DOC.TEXT: The president of the General Assembly said Friday that he will visit Palestinian refugee camps in the Israeli-occupied territories and Jordan next month. Guido de Marco made the announcement the day after the 159-member U.N. body voted overwhelmingly in favor of sanctions against Israel for occupying the West Bank and Gaza Strip, and to convene an international peace conference. De Marco, who is the foreign minister of Malta, also repeated the call for a Middle East peace conference at a news conference Friday, saying it ``must become a reality.'' General Assembly resolutions are not legally binding, but they carry moral weight as the expression of the will of the international community, especially in the post-Cold War era when the United States and the Soviet Union are cooperating on many issues. By contrast, resolutions passed by the 15-nation Security Council are considered legally binding. The United States has been trying to prevent any reference to a Middle East peace conference in a draft resolution providing more protection for the Palestinians. The United States maintains such a reference might be misinterpreted by Iraqi President Saddam Hussein as linking the Israeli-Palestinian issue to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, which the United States refuses to do. De Marco told reporters his trip to the Palestinian camps was to ``give the human problem more political importance than it has had so far.'' The visit would be the first time the president of the General Assembly has been to the camps, U.N. officials said. De Marco's itinerary was not disclosed, but the trip was expected to take place in the first week of January and will probably include meetings with government leaders in Israel and Jordan, the officials said. The United States and non-aligned members of the Security Council are at an impasse over the reference to an international peace conference in the draft resolution, although it merely states longstanding U.S. policy. Negotiations are continuing, and the council is to meet again Monday. Some Arab members have indicated that if the the stalemate persists in the council they would try to raise the issue in the General Assembly. De Marco said Friday that he did not want to force a contradiction between the positions of the assembly and the council, and therefore hoped the issue could be resolved without recourse to the assembly. De Marco, in line with usual U.N. policy, said that a peace conference should include all interested parties, including Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization, but should not preclude bilateral negotiations. Israeli officials have rejected a peace conference, saying that the primary vehicle for peace should be bilateral negotiations with its neighbors. They have said Israel would refuse to accept a settlement imposed upon it and would not negotiate with the PLO.

DOC.HEAD: Heavy Snow in The Rockies
DOC.TEXT: A snow storm took aim at the northern Mississippi Valley on Friday after blasting the Rockies with up to 16 inches of snow and a new storm moved into the Northwest. A cold front crossing the Rockies produced heavy snow in the mountains of Colorado from Thursday into Friday, with up to 10 inches of new snow at Wolf Creek Pass. Many other ski areas in Colorado received at least half a foot of fresh powder. Wind gusts of 60 to 70 mph were reported in the Denver area during the morning and gusts to 74 were reported at Rustic, west of Fort Collins. Jeff Schwartz, a spokesman for EG&G-Rocky Flats, said an 82 mph gust was recorded at Rocky Flats nuclear weapons plant outside Denver. The snowstorm reached blizzard-like intensity Friday morning in the area of Aspen, Colo., where schools were closed because of slippery roads and whiteout conditions, said Paul Gard of the National Weather Service in Denver. One Colorado traffic death was blamed on the weather. The cold front produced 6 to 12 inches of snow in the mountains of western Wyoming during the night and snow spread across the state's northern mountains during the morning. Snowfall totals at midday ranged up to 14 inches at Deer Haven Lodge. The cold front also gave Utah heavy snow, with up to 8 inches in southwestern and central sections of the state, from Cedar City to Salina. Ski resorts east of the Wasatch Front received 12 to 16 inches of new snow. The cold front produced 3 to 6 inches of snow in southern Idaho on Thursday and westerly wind blowing at 20 to 40 mph on Friday caused considerable blowing snow, closing Interstate 84 east of Burley to the Utah state line. In Montana, a small weather disturbance behind the cold front spread light snow across southern sections of the state. Snow spread into South Dakota during the morning and freezing drizzle developed in southwestern Nebraska, changing to light snow during the afternoon. By Saturday morning, snow was expected in parts of Minnesota and Wisconsin, the National Weather Service said. A strong Pacific storm system bore down on the West Coast, with showers developing along the coast of Washington state. It was expected to produce heavy snow during the weekend in the mountains of Washington, Oregon and northern California. Elsewhere Friday, a few light showers developed over the Carolinas.
