Afternoon temperatures remained below freezing across most of the area from the northern half of the high Plains region to New England, with readings only in the teens over parts of northern New England and upstate New York. Caribou, Maine, reported a temperature of just 9 degrees at midday. Mount Washington, standing to an elevation of 6,288 feet, reported a temperature of 3 above zero, along with northwesterly wind at 50 mph. Friday's low in the Lower 48 states was 3 below zero at Marquette, Mich.

DOC.HEAD: Teen-Ager's Heart Tumor Led to Abuse Charges Against Cult Members
DOC.TEXT: Criminal charges were filed against a couple belonging to a secretive sect that shuns formal medical care after their son was found close to death from an unattended heart tumor. The couple are members of End Time Ministries. A tenet of the Christian cult is that doctors and hospitals are instruments of the devil. Death was a ``high probability'' when William Myers, 16, of Lake City was taken Oct. 22 to Gainesville's Shands Hospital by his parents nearly seven months into his illness, court records show. The once-husky Myers arrived at the hospital weighing less than 100 pounds. He suffered not only from the heart tumor but also from liver and kidney failure. He was unable to walk because of running sores on his feet. ``You've seen those pictures of people in Nazi concentration camps, their arms and legs about as big around as a finger? That's about how he looked,'' said Beryl Mayo, a Columbia County sheriff's investigator. The youth told Mayo that he had never in his life been taken to a doctor. An emergency heart operation saved the youth's life and he remains hospitalized. His parents, Charles and Marilee Myers were charged Dec. 5 with child abuse. They are free on bond pending an arraignment. The state Department of Health and Rehabilitative Services would not comment, as a matter of policy, on the case and would not say if the teen was still in his parents' custody. The prosecutor could not immediately be reached. Several hundred End Timers live in this community of 10,000 people in northern Florida, forming a tight community nearly impervious to outsiders. Their leader is Charles Meade, who brought his distinctive religious beliefs to Florida from Indiana in 1984. Meade teaches that illness is a sign of sin and that faith is the only true medicine. The doctrine helped shield his followers from prosecution two years ago when the Myers' 4-day-old grandson died after a three-day nosebleed. Doctors testified at the inquest that an injection of vitamin K would have saved the boy's life. No charges were filed. But a third-degree murder conviction against Christian Scientists, whose 7-year-old daughter died in Sarasota of complications from diabetes, convinced prosecutors to pursue the case against the Myerses. The Myerses could not be reached for comment. Their attorney, Karin Moore, refused comment through her secretary. A woman answering the phone at Meade's house refused to discuss the case or End Time Ministries. Lake City optician Anne Conner said the End Timers have made neighbors in the housing development where they live uneasy. Two sentries carrying walkie-talkies continually watch the neighborhood, Conner said. They stopped cars and asked motorists why they were in the area until the sheriff told them to stop. Conner, after researching the group's history, held neighborhood meetings to share what she had learned. An Iowa-based group that monitors medicine-shy religious bodies has charged the sect's beliefs have led to the deaths of a dozen children in Florida, Montana, South Dakota and Illinois. ``It scared the heck out of me to think that this was going to happen in this town,'' Conner said. ``I guess I felt threatened.''

DOC.HEAD: Bar Probing Former Prosecutor For Alleged Misconduct in Murder Trial
DOC.TEXT: A former prosecutor faulted in an unfair murder trial that wrongly put a man in prison for 21 years is under investigation by the Florida bar for alleged misconduct in another murder case. The bar launched an investigation of Frank Schaub this week following a Florida Supreme Court decision citing ``instances of misconduct too numerous to list'' in the 1987 trial of Frederick Charles Nowitzke. The court unanimously threw out Nowitzke's murder convictions and death sentence Dec. 6 and suggested Schaub's conduct warrants disciplinary action. ``The nature of the complaint is interfering with justice,'' said Barbara Malatino, an administrative assistant in the bar's Tampa office. ``All he ever did was prosecute the very best he knew how,'' said Mack Futch, a longtime friend and assistant to Schaub. ``I've never known him to do anything unethical. In my time, I've never heard of a vigorous prosecution resulting in an ethics investigation.'' It is the second high-profile murder case in two years in which Schaub has been publicly criticized. After two decades behind bars, James Richardson was freed last year after a judge ruled the former Arcadia fruit picker didn't get a fair trial in 1968 in the poisoning death of one of his children. Seven of Richardson's children died from a pesticide-tainted lunch in 1967. The bar regulates lawyers and can recommend the state Supreme Court take disciplinary action, from reprimand to removal from legal practice. Schaub retired in 1988 after 16 years as state attorney and 12 as a circuit judge. He still is a licensed lawyer. Nowitzke was convicted in the 1985 shooting deaths of his mother Frances Carroll, 53, stepbrother Brett Carroll, 11, and the wounding of his stepfather, former major league pitcher Clay Carroll, 49, in their Bradenton home. The Supreme Court particularly criticized Schaub for personally attacking Detroit psychiatrist Dr. Emanuel Tanay, who testified the defendant was insane at the time of the shootings. With the jury present, Schaub asked Tanay whether he had once been called a ``hired gun'' and implied Tanay charged $600 an hour for his services when Schaub knew his fee was $150 an hour, the court said. He also made derogatory remarks about Tanay's hometown and ``insulted the witness generally,'' the court found. ``After sitting through 13 days of Mr. Schaub's courtroom antics, I think it's more than appropriate,'' said assistant public defender Jim Slater, who represented Nowitzke, 31. Dade County State Attorney Janet Reno, appointed by Gov. Bob Martinez to investigate the case, concluded last year that Schaub suppressed evidence and knowingly used perjured testimony at Richardson's trial. Richardson, 54, is suing Schaub, former DeSoto Sheriff Frank Cline, the state and DeSoto County in U.S. District Court in Tampa, alleging they conspired to violate his civil rights. The case was scheduled for trial in January but has been postponed until March because the 69-year-old Schaub is ill.

DOC.HEAD: Air Travel Tax Could Draw $240 Million Over Holidays
DOC.TEXT: More than 23 million holiday fliers are expected to pay a record $240 million in U.S. air travel user taxes during the 17-day Christmas-New Year holiday period, a trade group said Friday. Peak travel days will be Friday and Saturday, Dec. 21 and 22, with more than 1.6 million passengers traveling each day, and Tuesday and Wednesday, Jan. 1 and 2, when about 1.5 million daily passengers are expected, according to the Partnership for Improved Air Travel, an association of air travel businesses. The holiday travel period begins on Dec. 19 and ends on Jan. 4, according to the group. A 25 percent increase in user taxes for the Aviation Trust Fund went into effect on Dec. 1. This included a 10 percent increase in the airline ticket tax. Airline passengers, private pilots and business aviation and air cargo shippers now will pay about $5 billion a year for user-financed airport improvements, the association said. The association is pushing such improvements to reduce air traffic delays and airport congestion. It uses the annual surge in holiday air travel to illustrate what it says are the limits of the current aviation infrastructure to handle higher volumes of passengers predicted as a daily occurrence a decade from now.

DOC.HEAD: Crowd Attacks Panama Legislators, Driven off by Police
DOC.TEXT: Police use tear gas and buckshot to rout demonstrators who attacked legislators minutes after the National Assembly passed a law Friday allowing firing of public workers who back a coup. Unofficial reports said three legislators were among at least 10 people injured, none seriously. Hundreds of enraged government employees set upon lawmakers with rocks and clubs as the legislators were leaving the National Assembly after the vote. Police fired buckshot and tear gas canisters that forced the demonstrators to retreat from barricades they had thrown up in downtown Panama City. The law followed a Dec. 5 coup attempt led by a Noriega ally, former Col. Eduardo Herrera, and is retroactive to Dec. 4, the day before the attempt. Friday's clash was the second in less than 24 hours. Many merchants in the area had shuttered their businesses and posted armed guards. Many said they feared the kind of looting they suffered last year when U.S. troops invaded and deposed Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. Riot police and protesters clashed for more than two hours Thursday night in an earlier demonstration against the legislation. The government says manyThe choice of Martin to replace Elizabeth Dole, who resigned to head the American Red Cross, will assure the continuing presence of at least one woman in Bush's Cabinet. Another congresswoman defeated in an effort to unseat a Democratic senator, Patricia Saiki of Hawaii, is considered a frontrunner for the top position at the Education Department, where Lauro Cavazos was forced to resign this week. Bush called Martin, 51, a ``distinguished public servant and cherished friend.'' The president was scheduled to meet with Martin at the White House on Monday. The announcement got a somewhat chillier reception from labor leaders. Lane Kirkland, president of the 14.2 million-member AFL-CIO, said that during her 10-year tenure in Congress her voting record ``has not reflected a sensitivity to the needs of workers.'' Bush's announcement, made hastily before he boarded a helicopter for Camp David, Md., appeared designed to end a week of turmoil within the administration on a positive note. Cavazos resigned Wednesday - after being told to leave by White House Chief of Staff John Sununu, according to administration sources. And Bush's choice as the new Republican Party chairman, William Bennett, bowed out Thursday when he found out how drastically new ethics rules would limit his outside income. Martin, in Illinois on Friday, was informed only an hour ahead of the formal announcement that she had landed the job, an administration source said. Martin declined to be interviewed, but issued a brief statement saying her nomination was ``a high honor.'' ``I look forward to appearing before the Senate for the upcoming confirmation hearings,'' she said, thanking Bush for his ``confidence and support.'' Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., whose Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee will hold Martin's confirmation hearings, commended her on her nomination. He said the department needs someone who could ``stand up for hard-pressed families against the constant pro-business tilt of the White House.'' In making his announcement, Bush said Martin had served as an ``unofficial adviser'' to him on legislative matters in the past. She backed him in his first presidential bid in 1980, helped him prepare for his vice presidential debate with Democrat Geraldine Ferraro in 1984 and was a national co-chairman of his presidential campaign two years ago. It was also apparent that Bush felt he owed her something for her party loyalty in giving up a safe House seat to make the uphill bid against Sen. Paul Simon. She had been passed over in Bush's first round of Cabinet appointments after the 1988 election, partly because of her own interest in the Senate. ``She's a mother who knows the need for child care. She's a professional who understands the business-labor relationship. And, as a congresswoman, she spent years dealing with the concerns and aspirations of the working Americans from every walk of life,'' Bush said. Rep. Saiki had also been considered in the running for the labor post, as well as for the education slot. Martin and Saiki were seen as likely nominees for several reasons, political analysts said. They are women; they are seen as being owed something because they gave up House seats with Bush's encouragement to make the Senate bids; and, as Capitol veterans, they could help him push administration policy in Congress. In addition, Saiki, an Asian-American, would add a minority member to a Cabinet that lost Cavazos, a Hispanic-American. Besides the Cabinet openings before Bush this week, the high-profile job of RNC chairman was added to the equation when Bennett, the former drug policy director, said he'd changed his mind about taking the job. Three Cabinet secretaries are among those frequently mentioned as contenders for the RNC post - Samuel Skinner of Transportation, Robert Mosbacher of Commerce and Jack Kemp of Housing and Urban Development - along with former Rep. Thomas Loeffler of Texas and longtime Bush campaign strategist Rich Bond. If Skinner, Mosbacher or Kemp took the job, that would give Bush yet another Cabinet opening to fill. Besides Saiki, those also considered potential choices for education secretary include Lynne Cheney, chairwoman of the National Endowment for the Humanities; former New Jersey Gov. Thomas Kean, now president of Drew University, and former Tennessee Gov. Lamar Alexander, now president of the University of Tennessee. Cheney, the wife of Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, has also been mentioned as a candidate for the Labor post. Martin has never had a close alliance with organized labor. According to the AFL-CIO's scorecard, she voted ``right'' on workers' issues 29 percent of the time. When Bush tapped Mrs. Dole for the labor post two years ago, his action was seen as a way for Republicans to mend fences with organized labor leaders who had had a hostile relationship with the Reagan administration. Analysts say more Cabinet changes might follow soon. Kemp, Skinner and Mosbacher are all said to be itchy, as well as Attorney General Dick Thornburgh.

DOC.HEAD: U.S., Soviets to Destroy Remaining Virus Stocks
DOC.TEXT: The United States and the Soviet Union have agreed to destroy their remaining stocks of live smallpox virus by the end of 1993, the World Health Organization said Friday. The nations held the virus stocks, frozen in top security labs, for possible use in biological warfare. WHO announced the world was free of smallpox in October 1979. No case of the disease has been confirmed since. U.S. and Soviet officials at a three-day meeting confirmed their countries have stopped vaccinating soldiers against smallpox, a WHO statement said. The 11-member WHO smallpox committee agreed all stocks of the virus must be destroyed by Dec. 31, 1993. The agency said this will end fears of accidental infection or intentional misuse. Smallpox, a highly contagious and sometimes fatal disease, causes high fever and skin eruptions. U.S. and Soviet scientists, meanwhile, will record genetic characteristics of various virus strains so research can continue, WHO said. U.S. stocks are at the Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta. The Soviets keep theirs at Moscow's Research Institute for Viral Preparations. The CDC also holds stocks donated by Japan, the Netherlands and Britain, WHO said. The WHO committee urged all countries to end smallpox vaccination of soldiers, citing unconfirmed reports that one or two countries still do so. WHO officials declined to identify the countries.

DOC.HEAD: Libyans Newly Linked to Terrorist Attack on Pan Am Flight
DOC.TEXT: A detonator fragment from the bomb that brought down Pan Am Flight 103 links Libya to the 1988 attack that killed 270 people, a newspaper reported Friday. The report quoted unidentified senior sources as saying indictments have been held up because any U.S. action against Libya would risk alienating Arab members of the multinational force against Iraq in the Persian Gulf. In its report, The Independent said the evidence came to light three months ago and is based on a detonator fragment found in a field close to the southern Scottish town of Lockerbie. The plane blew up over that town. The fragment matched a detonator found in a radio-cassette bomb seized from two Libyan agents at Dakar airport in Senegal in February 1988, 10 months before the Flight 103 attack, the newspaper reported. The two men were later released by Senegalese authorities. Investigators have said the bomb that exploded on the Pan Am plane was also hidden in a radio-cassette recorder. Reports of possible Libyan involvement have appeared recently in the French and U.S. media. But the paper said it is the first time that senior sources confirmed that proof exists ``implicating Col. Moammar Gadhafi's regime.'' It quoted one of the sources as saying: ``Not only do we now know Gadhafi was responsible, he also knows we know.'' Some previous reports speculated the bombing was planned by a German-based cell of the radical Syria-based Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine-General Command, headed by Ahmed Jibril. The bomb was reportedly made with Semtex, a Czechoslovak explosive. Terrorist experts and Western news reports have theorized that Jibril's organization was hired by Iran to avenge the deaths of 290 people aboard an Iran Air jetliner accidentally shot down by the U.S. Navy in July 1988. Jibril, a former Syrian army officer, has denied involvement in the Pan Am attack. Scottish police have also said that they were investigating Mohammed Abu Talb, who was convicted in Sweden of carrying out several attacks against American and Israeli targets in 1985 and 1986. In a separate story, The Independent suggested Libya may have masterminded the Pan Am attack to seek revenge for the U.S. air strike on the Libyan capital of Tripoli in 1986. There were some U.S. servicemen aboard the Pan Am flight. Unidentified sources cited by The Independent said both the Senegal device and the fragment found near Lockerbie were from the same Swiss manufacturer. A spokesman for Scotland's senior law officer, the Lord Advocate, declined to comment on what he called ``media speculation.'' He said ``indictments are not being drawn up'' at this time. The plane was blown up over Lockerbie on Dec. 21, 1988, while on its way to New York. All 259 people on board and 11 others on the ground were killed. The flight originated in Frankfurt, Germany, with a stop at London's Heathrow airport.

DOC.HEAD: Arrested Ukrainian Lawmaker Ends Hunger Strike
DOC.TEXT: A Ukrainian legislator who was arrested for allegedly assaulting a KGB agent has ended a political hunger strike after 13 days, according to news reports. The legislator, Stepan Khmara, has become focus for anti-government protests in the Ukraine ever since his arrest on Nov. 17. Demonstrators at a human rights rally in Moscow on Dec. 8 demanded his release from prison, and his case has been championed by nationalist groups in the Ukraine. Keston College in Britain, which monitors religious affairs in the Soviet Union, reported Khmara was in critical condition and being treated by doctors after ending his hunger strike Thursday. The Tass news agency on Friday also reported he had ended the hunger strike. According to Keston College, Khmara's arrest stemmed from an incident Nov. 7 when he stopped to help a woman who said she had been attacked by a man near a Kiev underpass. Khmara asked the man who he was and the man didn't reply, although he later turned out to be KGB Col. Igor Grigoriev. Ukrainian prosecutors allege Khmara beat and robbed Grigoriev, who reportedly still is hospitalized, and the Communist majority in the Ukrainian parliament voted to deprive Khmara of his parliamentary immunity from prosecution, Tass said. Khmara was charged with ``abusing the authority of his office,'' according to Keston College, and he began the hunger strike Nov. 26 in Lukianivka Prison to protest his arrest. Parliamentary opposition groups, including the nationalist group Rukh, began picketing the prison where Khmara was incarcerated, Tass reported. Khmara, who has been active in the struggle for the legalization of the Greek-Catholic church in the Soviet Union, called off his hunger strike at the request of a clergyman, Vlodimir Sterniuk, according to Keston College. The legislator reportedly was moved from the prison infirmary to the General Military Hospital. Tass did not report on his condition Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Shamir Proposes Disarmament, Water in Regional Talks for Peace
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir on Friday proposed regional talks on water sharing and disarmament. He also indicated Israel is ready to discuss dismantling the nuclear weapons it reportedly possesses. His proposals reflect growing worry over conflicting reports of Iraq's nuclear capability and a drought that is draining water reserves in the Mideast. Shamir spoke on Israel television on his return from talks with President Bush in Washington. ``I would like to add to the agenda of the peace talks today a discussion of regional ideas ... to start with solving regional problems that are important to all countries in the region, like the water problem.'' ``It is conceivable that we will also have to find a way to add to these talks the very heavy subject that has been discussed a lot recently and that is reducing the amount of weapons in the region,'' he added on Israel television. When asked if Israel was ready to dismantle nonconventional weapons, Shamir answered: ``I said that Israel is ready to participate in such an effort that would reduce the amount of weaponry and that would limit weapons.'' Shamir added that in his term as foreign minister 10 years ago he had advocated and presented ``a concrete proposal for a region free of nuclear weapons.'' Israel has repeatedly refused to respond to foreign reports it has about 100 nuclear bombs, giving it the world's sixth-largest nuclear stockpile. However, officials have said that Israel would not be the first to use atomic weapons in the Middle East. Shamir's proposals came amidst concerns the United States will support calls in the United Nations for a broad Middle East peace conference to deal with the Arab-Israeli conflict. Such a move would be a radical departure from the U.S. position supporting Israel's proposal for Israeli-Palestinian talks on limited autonomy for the residents of the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. Israel opposes an international conference. The Israeli initiative has been in deadlock since it led to the fall of a broad coalition government in March 1988. Shamir, who now leads a right-wing coalition, has said peace with Arab neighbors must come before any settlement with the Palestinians. Shamir made his proposals Friday in the wake of recent reports that Iraq is on a crash program to become the first Arab state with nuclear weapons. Experts differ on how close the Iraqi arsenal is to being ready. Some say Iraq will be able to build a usable bomb within five years. Others say it will take 10 years. In proposing the focus on water, Shamir is reacting to statements by experts who say the region will face dangerous depletion of its water sources by 1995. Israel has depleted all its reserves and may have to resort to importing water if there is another drought year. Syria and Jordan already ration water, and some areas get water only a few times a week. Egypt also faces severe problems as its population multiplies.

DOC.HEAD: East Bloc's First Non-Communist Prime Minister Leaves Post
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki, trounced in last month's presidential election, left office on Friday by telling Parliament he had tried not to raise national expectations beyond what could be attained. ``This government's role was to make this painful beginning,'' Mazowiecki said in an address ending his 15-month term as the former East bloc's first non-Communist leader. ``We did not try to arouse hopes which could not be fulfilled,'' Mazowiecki told Parliament, in apparent response to criticism by President-elect Lech Walesa and others that his government had moved too slowly toward economic and social reforms. Parliament then voted 224-16 to accept his resignation. There were 122 abstentions. Meanwhile, an aide to Walesa said the president-elect had resolved the ``main problems'' in negotiations to select a new prime minister. The aide did not disclose the makeup of the Walesa government. Mazowiecki was beaten Nov. 25 in the first round of Poland's first popular presidential election by Stanislaw Tyminski, an unknown emigre promising an economic quick fix. Walesa on Dec. 9 defeated Tyminski by a wide margin. Mazowiecki submitted his government's resignation two days after the first-round vote, but agreed to stay on in a caretaker capacity until Parliament accepts Walesa's new government, a process expected to take a few weeks. Surrounded by his Cabinet, the prime minister somberly accepted a standing ovation following the vote. Mazowiecki cited the disappearance of store lines, the improved selection of consumer goods, the stabilization of the currency and development of a private sector as ``signs of permanent changes'' made in Poland during his tenure. He also listed the establishment of an uncensored press, freely elected local governments, a permanent border with united Germany and a democratic political system as among his government's accomplishments. ``We are building a democratic system, and we all have to respect democratic rules,'' Mazowiecki said. But this peaceful transition ``is testimony to how far along the road Poland has moved from a totalitarian state to a democratic state.'' He said newly emerging political factions should continue to exist and develop, but they should not let their ``grudges'' block the country's higher good. ``We face a difficult period now. In order to get through it together, a new consensus of the main political forces is necessary,'' he said. ``We underwent the transition from a centralized economy governed by ideology with an economy that was in a state of decay, destroyed by hyperinflation, to a rational economic system, where there is the basis of competitive market and a market balance,'' he said. After Mazowiecki's speech, the leader of the Solidarity caucus, Walesa ally Mieczyslaw Gil, said Mazowiecki's name would symbolize ``Poland's return to the family of free nations.'' But he said more should have been done to help farmers and fight unemployment.

DOC.HEAD: Excitement Runs High as Haitian Election Campaign Winds Down
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with U.S. comment on hopes for peaceful election, minor editing. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) - Haitians expressed hope Friday that the presence of hundreds of foreign observers during this weekend's national elections would ensure their right to vote. The capital city was peaceful during the day that officially ended the campaign for Sunday's vote. About 10,000 people, many singing, attended a closing rally for the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, a radical, populist priest believed to be the front-runner among 11 presidential candidates. Police moved through the crowd, searching handbags and clothing for weapons, but there were no incidents. To the chants of ``Hallelujah!'' people carried placards reading ``Aristide Will Save Haiti'' and sang: ``It's you we're looking for. Now ... we are saved.'' Aristide, carrying poinsettias, was mobbed by a throng of screaming fans before he briefly addressed the crowd. ``We are the flowers of brotherhood,'' the Roman Catholic leader said. ``We are carrying the flowers to victory.'' Haiti has been ruled by dictators virtually since it won independence from France in 1804 and established the world's first black republic. Two elections held the past four years have been rigged or halted because of violence. But many Haitians said Friday they believed foreign observers would make a difference this time. ``Even if 100 people get killed, the election will go on,'' said Jean-Claude Bajeux, a civil rights activist who spent many years in exile during the Duvalier family dictatorship. About 3 million people are registered to vote for president, bicameral legislature, mayors and county officials. The government has set up 14,500 polling places, and they will be open from 6 a.m. to 6 p.m. Sunday. The elections gained new vigor a month ago when Aristide declared his candidacy. He is the favorite of the poor who make up most of this Caribbean nation's 6 million residents. An advocate of liberation theology, or church involvement in the struggles of the poor, Aristide was expelled from the Salesian order in 1988 for allegedly fomenting revolution. He remains a priest, however, and has said he would renounce the priesthood to comply with Vatican rules against holding public office if he wins the election. Marc Bazin, a former World Bank economist and finance minister fired by the dictatorial Duvalier regime for investigating corruption, is believed to be the favorite of the middle class. He has a considerable following in the countryside. Bazin campaigned Friday in the mountain town of Tomassin, overlooking the wealthy suburb of Petionville. ``People like me, a working man, will vote for Aristide because he stands for change,'' said a street vendor who would only give his first name, Antoine. ``The bourgeoise will vote for Bazin.'' Election observers from the United Nations, Organization of American States and the Caribbean Economic Community will monitor the vote. Former President Jimmy Carter, who has monitored elections in Panama and Nicaragua, arrived Friday afternoon with a team of 34 observers from the Council of Freely Elected Heads of Government. President Bush sent former Gov. William Janklow of South Dakota as head of an eight-member U.S. government delegation. ``The election in Haiti offers a historic opportunity for the Haitian people to freely choose their leaders after decades of dictatorship,'' said White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. A State Department spokesman appealed for Haitians to shun violence in the final days of the campaign. ``The United States supports Haiti's electoral process and encourages all Haitians to conduct the final days of the campaign in a peaceful atmosphere,'' said spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler in Washington. At the request of the interim government of President Ertha-Pascal Trouillot, the United Nations sent 64 unarmed military advisers to work with Haiti's notoriously ill-disciplined army to prevent election violence. Until 1986, the Duvalier family enforced its rule for 29 years with the help of a brutal private militia known as the Tonton Macoutes. The dictatorship ended in 1986 after Jean-Claude Duvalier fled to exile in France. Many holdovers from the Duvalier regime have remained intent on keeping their hold on power and have sabotaged elections twice since Jean-Claude was deposed. The elections in 1987 were aborted after army-backed thugs massacred 34 voters at the polls. The army dissolved the independent Electoral Council and held rigged elections in 1988. There has been relatively little violence during this year's campaign. Fears of a bloody election were heightened on Dec. 5 when unidentified assailants threw a grenade and opened fire on people leaving an Aristide rally, killing seven and wounding more than 50 others. Aristide blamed the attack on Roger Lafontant, self-proclaimed chief of the Tonton Macoutes and avid Duvalier supporter, and demanded his arrest. Lafontant denied his involvement. Lafontant returned from exile to run for president, but was disqualified on technicalities by the Electoral Council. He said this week he was the head of the Tonton Macoutes and the Duvalierist movement, and that he was determined to keep Aristide from becoming president.

DOC.HEAD: Howell, Others on `Last Flight' Home from Gulf
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 8th graf: ``Only one,'' Floridian ex-hostage calls for military action
DOC.HEAD: With AM-US-Gulf Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Nearly 50 jubilant Westerners who had been trapped in Iraq and Kuwait touched down on American soil Friday, led by the U.S. diplomats who had refused to leave without them. First to bound off the plane was Nathaniel Howell, the ambassador to Kuwait, who had spent more than three months in the besieged U.S. embassy. ``It's great to be home,'' Howell declared. ``I'm delighted to bring home with me the last planeload of Americans who want to leave Kuwait.'' The group was greeted in the biting December wind by Secretary of State James A. Baker III, who saluted them for being ``victorious over an uncivilized and brutal ordeal.'' But Baker added: ``While your ordeal has ended, that of the Kuwaiti people continues. As you were freed, now too we must see Kuwait freed of Iraqi occupation.'' The hostages were welcomed by a crowd of cheering friends and family members waving flags and bearing balloons. A young woman wearing a ``Free Kuwait'' sweatshirt handed out red roses. The hostages were whisked off to a private reception area where they were to be helped with emergency loans, plane tickets and accommodations. Only one, Wayne Cox, 40, of Orlando, Fla., would talk with reporters. He had been hiding in Kuwait with his wife, Layla, and their three children. Cox praised President Bush's policies and advocated military action to liberate Kuwait. ``It can't go on much longer,'' he said. ``It's just devastated. Cars are completely stripped everywhere, houses burned, stores burned.'' Howell noted that he had left the flag flying when he left the U.S. embassy in Kuwait, and he vowed it would reopen in time - with new staff. ``The ordeal of the Kuwaitis ... still persists. The people there must be freed,'' he said. Baker said Iraq's Saddam Hussein deserved no reward for his release of the hostages. ``There must be no thanks or praise for the release of innocent people who he never should have kidnapped in the first place,'' Baker said. He said Saddam's aggression and the ordeal of the hostages ``jars our sense of human decency and civility.'' Howell and the four remaining members of his bare-bones embassy staff left Iraq on Thursday on what was expected to be the last U.S. charter flight to evacuate Westerners from Iraq and occupied Kuwait. After an overnight stop in Frankfurt, Germany, many of the hostages were flown to Andrews Air Force Base outside Washington aboard a C-5 military transport plane. The passengers included 23 Americans, 10 non-U.S. citizen family members, as well as 15 people going to Canada, officials said. Howell, 50, had been winding up a three-year stint in Kuwait and was preparing to leave when Iraq invaded the emirate on Aug. 2. Shortly thereafter, Saddam ordered the closure of all foreign missions in Kuwait and cut off services to those embassies that defied him. Howell and others on the embassy staff held our for more than three months, living mainly on rice, tuna and boiled water from the embassy swimming pool. The diplomats left only after they were satisfied that all Americans in Kuwait had been given a chance to leave. Hundreds of Western hostages have departed Iraq and Kuwait since Saddam last week agreed to let them go. Any remaining Americans who wish to leave can take commercial flights, according to the State Department.

DOC.HEAD: Fire Damages 11 Homes, Dozens Left Homeless
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 15th graf, `Janis Foley ...' to CORRECT spelling of Janice, sted Janis.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos BX8,9,11,13,14
DOC.TEXT: A suspicious fire fanned by high wind sped through a crowded neighborhood Friday, damaging 11 three-family houses and leaving more than 100 people homeless, many of them needy immigrants, authorities said. Emergency officials who went to evacuate residents said they had trouble communicating the urgency of the problem to people who did not speak English. ``They were just reluctant to leave. They didn't realize the scope of what was going on,'' said Deputy Fire Chief Dan Doherty. No deaths or serious injuries were reported. Seven firefighters from Revere, Boston and Chelsea suffered smoke inhalation or other injuries. Three civilians were treated for minor injuries, police said. Mayor George Colella declared an emergency in the working-class suburb north of Boston and said 125 to 160 residents were displaced by the blaze. The Red Cross said it helped 132 people displaced by the early morning fire. Vin Ven, 25, who is three months pregnant, escaped with her father, mother, sister and brother, all of whom came here from Cambodia in recent years. ``Now it is burned, my place. Now I got no place to live,'' she said. Fire Chief James Connery declared the blaze a conflagration, the highest level of fire, and said it was the worst he had seen in his 35 years with the department. ``When you declare a conflagration, mutual aid automatically takes over,'' he said. All fire equipment in the Boston metropolitan area was made available to Revere, and at least 17 departments sent firefighters. The fire began in a vacant, boarded-up building. Connery said it may have been set, along with two of three other fires reported earlier in the night. ``We're leaning very strongly that way,'' he said. ``I can't tell definitely that they were deliberately set, but it certainly looks that way. There were too many fires in too short a time.'' Arson investigators were called in and a dog was brought in that can sniff out chemicals used to start or feed a fire. And police looked for a white car seen near three of the homes that burned. Temperatures in the 20s and wind blowing to 30 mph created a wind chill factor of near zero and ice covered the streets before the blaze was declared under control after four hours. Some fire engines were encased in ice. ``The only thing that really helped us was that the wind died down,'' Doherty said. ``That kind of gave us a little chance.'' The neighborhood, one of the most densely packed in Revere, is made up mostly of Asian, Hispanic and Portuguese residents. Janice Foley escaped her home with her four children and disabled husband after trying to hose down porches to keep sparks from igniting her second-floor apartment. ``The flames and sparks came across the street,'' Foley said. ``We ran outside and had to go onto the sidewalk, then everything started dropping through.'' Foley said she lost everything, including Christmas presents for her family and presents for 19 Head Start children she supervises. The houses are called triple-deckers, a style common in the Boston area that was developed in the early part of the century to accommodate burgeoning city populations. Often, a family would live on one floor and rent the two other floors. In addition to five homes that were destroyed, one was badly damaged, and five others suffered either exterior damage or water damage. Gov. Michael S. Dukakis visited the scene, and said the state will seek funds to help rebuild the neighborhood. Asked where the state will get money given the current fiscal crunch, Dukakis said: ``Well, if there isn't (any), we'll get it.'' Classes were canceled at the city high school so that those left homeless could be served by the Red Cross in the school gym. ``It's challenging all year long, but it's particularly difficult to find housing at Christmas time,'' said Amy Glick, a Red Cross nurse. ``What we'll need to do is work with each family on a case by case basis.''

DOC.HEAD: Court Document Shows Eastern Continued to Falsify Safety Records
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with comment from Eastern, the airline's trustee. No pick up. Version moved on financial wire.
DOC.TEXT: Beleaguered Eastern Airlines continued as recently as last month to falsify vital safety and maintenance records, according to a confidential informat cited in a government document unsealed Friday. Eastern angrily denied the allegations contained in the document, which is an affidavit to support a raid earlier this month on the airline's Miami headquarters. The document details a lengthy pattern of doctoring safety logs and other records to keep the airline's jets in the air. Release of the document was a public-relations setback for Eastern, which has been operating under bankruptcy court protection since March 1989 because of a strike that has still not been resolved. Eastern said there has been no conspiracy to cut corners on safety, as the government has alleged in a criminal case in Brooklyn. The airline has continued to lose enormous amounts of money but its court-appointed trustee, Martin R. Shugrue Jr., has predicted Eastern will start breaking even sometime next year. Shugrue also has been leading an aggressive publicity campaign for Eastern in attempt to win more customers. In response to the latest allegations, Shugrue said the government has a ``personal vendetta'' against him and ``a vendetta against the company.'' Federal investigators using a search warrant went into Eastern's offices on Dec. 1 and carried out boxes of documents and computer records, said U.S. Attorney Andrew J. Maloney. According to a confidential informant, Eastern ``supervisors are under so much pressure to avoid delays that record falsification is the norm,'' the affidavit said. Maintenance workers at Hartsfield Airport in Atlanta routinely falsified log books to hide faulty navigation, radar and other electronic equipment, as well as bad tires and windshields that leaked air, informants told investigators. Confidential informants told investigators that ``flight delays caused by necessary repairs or maintenance were simply not tolerated by Eastern's upper management,'' the document said. One informant in Atlanta said ``he witnessed supervisors on almost a daily basis falsifying log books to make it appear that inoperative cockpit instruments had been repaired when in reality they had not been repaired,'' the affidavit said. Last Friday, U.S. District Judge I. Leo Glasser of Brooklyn ruled that the affidavit unsealed Friday should be made public. However, he allowed Eastern a chance to appeal. The appeal went before a three-judge panel of the U.S. Court of Appeals on Thursday and it ruled in suppport on Glasser on Friday. In July, prosecutors in Brooklyn filed criminal charges against Eastern, alleging a pattern of falsifying safety records and other maintenance documents to keep its jets in the air. The airline and several of its top managers are scheduled to go on trial in on the charges in Brooklyn federal court next year. During a Miami news conference, Shugrue accused the government of embarking on a ``headline-hunting exercise'' to damage Eastern. Eastern said in a statement ``the FAA's most recent inspections revealed that Eastern was safe and that there was no evidence to suggest that maintenance records were being falsified.'' The airline said that based on its own investigation of specific allegations it was confident that a grand jury would agree ``that the charges contained in the affidavit are without merit.''

DOC.HEAD: EC Leaders Pledge Billion-Dollar Aid Package for Soviets
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with Britain to join unity talks, figure for aid for Bulgaria and Romania. Picks up graf 7 pvs, `The European...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto ROM6
DOC.TEXT: European Community leaders agreed Friday on a $1 billion food aid package for the Soviet Union and said it is worth the price if it helps keep President Mikhail S. Gorbachev in power. The European leaders also were drafting a statement on the Persian Gulf crisis, with Italy and France pushing to give Iraq assurances it would not be attacked if it withdraws from Kuwait. The leaders approved the emergency aid package, with the proportion of grants and loans still to be decided, at the opening of a two-day summit that is scheduled to launch the 12-nation bloc on a radical path toward European unity. ``It is not in the interests of Europe or Britain that the Soviet Union should fall into anarchy or should lapse into the hands of some backward-looking tyrant,'' said British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd. For the longer term, they agreed in principle on two-year $1.4 billion package of technical assistance for 1991-92 to help the Soviet Union in the fields of energy, transportation, distribution and telecommunications, summit spokesman Pio Mastrobuoni said. Aid for the hard-pressed economies of Eastern Europe was also under discussion, with $140 million approved for Romania and Bulgaria, Mastrobuoni said. Despite Britain's continuing objections to certain aspects of European integration, Italian officials said Britain is ready to fully participate in two special conferences opening Saturday on economic and monetary union and on political unity. ``The conferences are going ahead with all 12 aboard,'' said Mastrobuoni. ``There are no prejudices or insurmountable obstacles at the start.'' The government heads are preparing broad guidelines on political union, including the possibility that the 12 countries, at some future date, would speak in one voice on security and foreign policy. The European leaders stressed during their private talks that the Soviet Union doesn't face famine but is hampered by an inadequate distribution system and black market profiteers. ``It is no good having food rotting in a siding in Leningrad rather than rotting in a grainstore here,'' said British Prime Minister John Major, making his international debut since replacing Margaret Thatcher last month. At the same time, Gorbachev needs breathing room to carry out his economic reform program. But his political hold is under constant challenge from various segments of Soviet society. Earlier in the week, the United States joined 20 other countries in promising or delivering food aid. Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany, who has been in the forefront of the food aid drive for the Soviets, denounced attempts in the Soviet Union to undermine Gorbachev. He warned that a Gorbachev fall from power would cost the world a lot more than would sending emergency aid now. Because of the problems of getting food in from the countryside, the Europeans singled out Moscow and Leningrad for the emergency assistance. Italian Premier Giulio Andreotti said the EC would draw immediately from community-held stocks and promised the Europeans would try to make sure the supplies reached the hungry - and not the black market. On the eve of the summit, President Bush urged the Europeans in a letter to stand firm and united against Iraq as the Jan. 15 deadline set by the U.N. Security Council for possible military action approaches. The Persian Gulf crisis figured to dominate discussions at a state dinner at the Renaissance Chigi Palace Friday evening, and it was also the focus of many of the bilateral talks. Italian officials said Andreotti and French President Francois Mitterrand agreed on the need for a ``clear and explicit message'' from Europe that the U.S.-dominated multinational force would not attack Iraq if Kuwait were liberated. The two countries also agreed on the need for an international peace conference on the Middle East, and said they would welcome an EC-wide appeal that it be held. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein has tried to link a resolution of the gulf crisis with the issue of Israel's occupation of Palestinian territories. An international conference would deal with such issues, but it is opposed by Israel. The United States has rejected Saddam's attempt to link the issues. Major struck a noticeably more conciliatory tone than Mrs. Thatcher, whose denunciation of plans for a single European currency at the last summit isolated Britain and precipitated her downfall. ``I don't think anybody in the community wants confrontation,'' said the 47-year-old prime minister. But he stressed that Britain had not changed its opposition to the single currency and other key unity proposals. ``If we were to leap ahead without proper understanding of what it (a single currency) means, it could be very serious,'' Major said.

DOC.HEAD: Mexican Vote Fraud Riots Ignite Political Battle
DOC.TEXT: The opposition swapped charges with Mexico's long-entrenched Institutional Revolutionary Party on Friday after a vote fraud riot killed three people, injured scores and set off a political frenzy. Foes of the party, called PRI for its Spanish initials, said 62 years of one-party rule and what it calls rigged elections have led to frustration and violence. Herberto Castillo, a founder of the center-left Democratic Revolutionary Party (PRD), cautioned Friday, ``The Mexicans are a tiger. The government should watch out. There are lots of riot police. But there are a lot more people.'' The government party accused Castillo's party of ``savage aggression.'' A PRD rally to protest purported vote fraud in Tejupilco, a town of about 7,000 in Mexico state, turned into a riot Wednesday after police fired tear gas grenades into the packed town square and shots rang out. Two police officers and one civilian were killed and scores of people, including many police officers, were injured. The state government says armed PRD supporters tried to seize City Hall. The PRD denies it, and says riot police provoked the melee by attacking women standing near the City Hall entrance. Luis H. Alvarez, president of the conservative National Action Party (PAN), said the violence shows democracy cannot be delayed. He said ``the nation could find itself in immersed in chaos'' unless the PRI and the government allow clean elections, according to news reports Friday. PAN and the PRD are Mexico's major opposition parties. PAN boasts Mexico's first and only opposition governor. The PRD claims vote fraud robbed it of victory in the 1988 presidential election. The president of the governing party, Luis Donaldo Colosio, said the Tejupilco incident exposed the ``real face of the PRD: intolerance.'' He spoke with reporters after a heated session of Congress Thursday. The PRD filed a complaint with the National Human Rights Commission on behalf of Tejupilco citizens, claiming constitutional rights to free speech and free assembly were violated. The party also announced it would hold another rally Sunday in Tejupilco, 80 miles southwest of Mexico City. ``It won't be a demonstration designed to provoke violence. It will be rally designed to defend the constitution,'' Castillo said. President Carlos Salinas de Gortari concedes he is moving more slowly on political reform than economic reform, but says the slower pace is necessary to prevent chaos during a time of radical change in Mexico.

DOC.HEAD: Moslem Leader Urges U.N. Intervention in Religious Unrest
DOC.TEXT: A top Moslem cleric said Friday he wants U.N. troops deployed to help control religious violence that has left hundreds of people dead around India. Sayed Abdullah Bukhari claimed only a neutral force can protect the Moslem minority from Hindus in the dispute over a religious site. ``My heart weeps, my chest bleeds and the mind reels in confusion when I see my people being massacred,'' Bukhari, chief clergyman of India's 105 million Moslems, told about 20,000 people at the Jama Masjid, India's largest mosque. ``There is a limit to our tolerance. Can't the United Nations send its forces to protect the millions of Moslems of India?'' Bukhari asked. At least 267 people have died in Hindu-Moslem clashes in several Indian cities the past eight days. About half the deaths have occurred in Hyderabad, 750 miles south of New Delhi. The violence in at least seven cities stems from Hindu fundamentalists' campaign to construct a temple on a site now occupied by a mosque in Ayodhya, 300 miles east of New Delhi. Hindus claim the 16th century mosque was built on the ruins of a temple destroyed by Moslem conquerers. Moslems say the mosque was erected on a vacant plot. At least 380 people were killed in month-long nationwide riots when the Ayodhya campaign began on Oct. 30. The conflict also helped bring down the government of former Prime Minister V.P. Singh after a fundamentalist party withdrew support for Singh's coalition government. Moslems make up 12 percent of India's 880 million people, the world's second largest Moslem population after Indonesia. Hindus in India account for 82 percent. Also Friday, Chief Minister Marri Chenna Reddy, the highest elected official in Andhra Pradesh state, promised to resign, saying he was ``morally responsible'' for the widespread killings in Hyderabad. Reddy said he would step down after the party elected a new leader, possibly Saturday. Bukhari accused police in Uttar Pradesh state of killing Moslem youths and singling out Moslems for arrests. ``I appeal to the United Nations to save the Moslems from the cruel and barbaric policemen,'' he said. Bukhari's accusation was aimed at the Provincial Armed Constabulary, a special force of Uttar Pradesh police that Indian human rights organizations and Moslems previously have accused of selectively killing Moslems. The identities of those killed in the clashes have not been revealed in keeping with Indian press policies, but a majority of those killed are believed to be Moslems, according to independent and witness reports. Indian newspaper editors say disclosure of the victims' religion could aggravate unrest.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Delegation Asks Europeans To Free Noriega Accounts
DOC.NOTE: Eds:LEADS with 3 grafs to UPDATE with other nations possibly to be visited. Pick up 3rd graf, `Swiss officials ...'
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. delegation was in Europe on Friday asking foreign governments to unfreeze Manuel Noriega's bank accounts to finance his legal defense, but Swiss officials warned their job won't be easy. Most of the delegation's activities are classified, said Assistant U.S. Attorney Michael Sullivan, who told a federal judge here the group consists of State and Justice department officials visiting Austria and Switzerland. Other European nations also may be on the delegation's itinerary, said U.S. attorney's office spokeswoman Diane Cossin. She refused to identify the countries. The government has said Noriega had accounts in France. Swiss officials expect to hold talks with the delegation next week, the nation's justice ministry spokesman Joerg Kistler said in Bern. But he said if there is any evidence that the accounts contain illegal drug money, Swiss laws require confiscation. ``We can only unfreeze in cases where it is clear that drug money is not involved. The Americans have to prove that to us,'' Kistler said. U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler, who has pressed the government to find a way to allow the deposed Panamanian leader to pay his own lawyers, welcomed the U.S. delegation's efforts. ``I'm satisfied at this time they are making a good faith effort to unfreeze funds for the defense,'' Hoeveler said. The judge closed much of a hearing Friday over the objections of media attorneys. He explained later in open court that ``some of the areas are legitimately classified.'' After the December 1989 invasion of Panama and the capture of Noriega, U.S. authorities asked European governments to freeze about $20 million in 27 bank accounts. Hoeveler ordered $6 million of that amount unfrozen in June, but prosecutors returned to him last month, saying European governments had stepped in with their own forfeiture proceedings. The judge warned he would hold a formal hearing to show whether the accounts were drug-related, as the government originally contended. Such a hearing would force the government to reveal much of its evidence to the defense. The government responded by sending the delegation to Europe. The only delegation member mentioned in open court was Myles Malman, who is an assistant U.S. attorney and one of Noriega's prosecutors. State Department officials refused to comment on the delegation, and the Justice Department's Washington office did not immediately return telephone calls from The Associated Press. The judge has offered the defense temporary appointments as government-paid lawyers. But Noriega lead attorney Frank Rubino says that arrangement would impose a maximum of $75 an hour, far less than the $350 an hour he says is appropriate in a complex drug-trafficking case. Rubino also said the defense could not be ready before June. Hoeveler said he would set a new trial date for Noriega, although some of his co-defendants could be tried on the planned date of Jan. 28. The judge said he wanted a contempt hearing soon against Cable News Network to determine if CNN violated a court order by airing a taped prison telephone call between Noriega and his defense team. The judge subsequently lifted the ban against broadcasting the tape, but only after warning CNN it still could face contempt fines. Noriega is confined in the Metropolitan Correctional Center outside Miami facing charges of accepting $4.6 million in bribes to turn Panama into a way station for Colombian drug traffickers.

DOC.HEAD: Keating Aide Contradicts Riegle
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 7th graf: ``The committee,'' identifyijng all five
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Donald W. Riegle Jr. initiated a meeting between senators and thrift regulators on behalf of Charles H. Keating Jr., a former Keating aide testified Friday in contradiction of the Michigan Democrat's sworn statement. James Grogan was the first Keating insider to testify in the Senate Ethics Committee hearings, and did so only under a grant of limited immunity that prevents his statements from being used against him in court. Riegle, A Michigan Democrat and chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, has told the panel ``I did not arrange the meeting April 2'' (1987) between the top thrift regulator and four Senate colleagues - who were intervening for Keating's failing Lincoln Savings and Loan. Riegle did not attend the session. ``Is there any doubt in your mind that Sen. Riegle arranged the meeting with the senators?'' committee special counsel Robert S. Bennett asked Grogan, who was Lincoln's corporate counsel. ``No sir,'' Grogan answered. The April 2 meeting is important because the top regulator at the time, Edwin J. Gray, has testified that Sen. Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz., tried to negotiate a deal for Lincoln that would have waived a rule prohibiting risky investments. DeConcini has denied the allegation. The committee is looking into the relationships of the ``Keating Five,'' with Keating. It wants to know whether the five - in addition to DeConcini and Riegle, they are John Glenn, D-Ohio, Alan Cranston, D-Calif., and John McCain, R-Ariz. - committed any improprieties in interceeding on Keating's behalf with S&L regulators. Grogan said he later ``got feedback the (four) senators were miffed'' at Riegle's absence, since negative news stories about Lincoln's condition made the session potentially ``politically explosive.'' After Grogan testified all day Friday, the Ethics Committee scheduled a Saturday session to question him further. Riegle's office issued a statement saying Grogan's testimony ``shows no improper activity or ethical violation by Sen. Riegle in the Lincoln matter.'' Unspecified statements of Grogan's were incorrect, the statement said, adding, ``This will be clear in the days ahead.'' Grogan also told the committee that Riegle tried to hide his role in initiating the meeting. The Keating executive said Riegle asked him to invite the other senators and to ask McCain and DeConcini, in turn, to invite Riegle to attend. ``Sen. McCain reacted very negatively'' to the suggestion, Grogan said. ``He said he would not invite Sen. Riegle to the meeting. He was very unhappy with that concept.'' DeConcini did write an invitation to Riegle to meet with regulators - not for the April 2 meeting, but to a session a week later between all five senators and the San Francisco-based regulators who were investigating Lincoln. At that session, the senators were advised that criminal referrals regarding Lincoln would be sent to the Justice Department. The committee is investigating whether the five senators' intervention for Keating was related to the $1.3 million he and associates donated to their campaigns and favorite causes. Grogan denied there was a connection, testifying he ``never got the impression'' that ``any action we were requesting would require a contribution.'' But he added, ``I believe senators only have so many hours in the day and if you make a contribution you have a better chance of getting time in front of a senator to explain your position.'' Most of Grogan's testimony concentrated on Riegle's actions, but he also said that Keating dealt personally with DeConcini when the businessman saw a chance to initiate a settlement in his feud with regulators. Grogan also testified that in discussions between himself, Keating and Cranston, topics often included both fund-raising and the senator's intervention with regulators. In one case in 1987, Grogan said Cranston promised to call chief regulator M. Danny Wall the same day that Grogan delivered a $250,000 contribution for Cranston-backed voter registration groups. And in one instance in late 1986, Grogan said he was asked by Cranston's chief fund raiser to establish a $300,000 line of credit for the senator. The credit was established but never used. Grogan said the request by fund raiser Joy Jacobson came during a phone conversation in which Grogan was expressing alarm about proposed legislation that was damaging to Lincoln. He said that after a discussion about the legislation, Ms. Jacobson ``said, `Now I want to switch gears, and I want you to know this is totally unrelated.''' ``She ... asked me if it would be possible that Lincoln could make a loan to Sen. Cranston for use in his (re-election) campaign. ``My interpretation was, it was a personal loan,'' Grogan said. Ms. Jacobson explained, Grogan said, that Cranston ``was in a tight race, money was tight...he might have to buy TV time.'' Grogan testified the line of credit was arranged after Lincoln received a legal opinion that it was proper. Grogan said that Riegle volunteered to arrange a meeting between senators and Gray during a visit the senator made in March 1987 to Keating's parent company, American Continental Corp. of Phoenix. Keating at the time was telling every politician who would listen that the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, headed by Gray, was treating Lincoln unfairly and leaking damaging material on the thrift to the news media, Grogan said. Grogan testified Riegle volunteered that ``he knew Ed Gray, would talk to Ed Gray ... and thought he could set up a meeting.'' During the same visit, Grogan said, Riegle discussed with Keating a fund-raising luncheon that Lincoln's owner was to host March 23 for the senator at the Keating-owned Ponchartrain Hotel in Detroit.

DOC.HEAD: General Strike Turns Ugly in Morocco, More Than 100 Hurt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, The government ... to CORRECT spelling of word `forbearance.' Picks up 5th graf, `At no ...'
DOC.TEXT: A general strike called to demand higher wages for state workers degenerated into rampaging and street clashes Friday that injured more than 100 people - most of them police, officials said. The northern city of Fez suffered the worst violence, with about 300 people reported under arrest. Reports reaching Rabat said youthful demonstrators in Fez attacked hotels, shops, banks, telephone centers and other property and burned buses and cars. The General Moroccan Workers Union, one of two unions calling the strike, claimed up to 25 people were killed in Fez. The government denied any deaths. It said about 70 police were hurt, but that an estimated 20,000 demonstrators escaped harm because of police forbearance. ``At no time did (police) use their arms,'' a government statement said. The second union, the Democratic Workers Confederation, said it could not confirm the report of deaths in Fez, a city of about 500,000 people. In Tangier in northern Morocco, a 17-year-old boy was shot in the stomach in a confrontation between police and strikers, hospital sources said, speaking on condition of anonymity. They listed about 50 known injured in clashes there. Lesser clashes also were reported in Kenitra, north of Rabat, and the southern city of Agadir. Police threw tear gas canisters to disperse young rioters in Fez, many of them from Fez University, where pro-fundamentalist Moslem students and progressive students have been in conflict. The government said youths from outside Fez ``took advantage of the strike.'' In Tangier, youth threw up street barricades in Beni-Makada district as police moved in. The government had warned against the strike. It said it would investigate the incidents and that Premier Azeddine Laraki would make a statement Monday before Parliament. Thousands of workers who took part in general strikes in 1979 and 1981 were fired or arrested. The unions said the government must bear responsibility for Friday's incidents. The walkout apparently hit the education sector the hardest. Up to 60 percent of university teachers and students obeyed the strike call, said sources, speaking on condition of anonymity. The Education Ministry claimed that institutes and special schools were not affected. Last-ditch negotiations between the government and the unions failed on Thursday. The unions complained they received nothing but ``the traditional promises'' in response to their specific demands. Laraki announced salary increases and special family subsidies on Tuesday, but gave no figures.

DOC.HEAD: Neighborhood Bully Who Torched Boy Gets Maximum Sentence
DOC.TEXT: A teen-age bully who tied up an 11-year-old boy and set him on fire during a robbery was sentenced Friday to a maximum three years in juvenile detention. The victim, David Opont, was burned over 50 percent of his body in the March attack. He was released from the hospital in August. His 14-year-old attacker was convicted in October of attempted murder for tying up Opont and setting him on fire. The defendant, whose name was withheld because of his age, also was found guilty of kidnapping, robbery and other offenses. Family Court Judge Joseph A. Esquirol Sr. said it was ``perhaps one of the most horrendous events I've had to preside over in a long judicial career.'' The teen-ager will be held for a year in a secure juvenile detention center and allowed no visits home, Esquirol said. He will be placed in a less restrictive residential center in the second year. Court authorities will decide later where the boy will spend his third year of detention. The sentence could be extended each year afterward until he is 21 if he fails to show progress in his rehabilitation, Esquirol said. Before sentencing, psychiatrist Dr. Walter Flegenheimer said the deeply troubled 14-year-old ``receives gratification from acts of violence, from acts of rendering people helpless.'' The personality traits, if exhibited by an adult, would be classified as ``a sadistic personality disorder,'' Flegenheimer testified. The doctor recommended that the boy be held in a restricted setting where he could not hurt anyone else and said he would require years of therapy to overcome his deep-seated problems. David was abducted on the day before his 12th birthday as he and some friends walked to school in the East Flatbush section of Brooklyn. Doctors say he is making a good recovery, though his skin is permanently disfigured and he continues with physical and psychiatric therapy. The attack shocked the city and evoked an outpouring of sympathy and get- well messages from across the nation. While in the hospital, David was visited by former President Reagan, the Rev. Jesse Jackson, Bill Cosby and other celebrities.

DOC.HEAD: Chicago Generic Drug Company Founder Sentenced in FDA Bribery Case
DOC.TEXT: The founder of a Chicago generic drug company has been fined $25,000 and sentenced to three months in a halfway house for bribing two U.S. Food and Drug Administration officials. U.S. District Judge John R. Hargrove suspended nine months of a one-year term for defendant Kun Chae Bae and ordered him to perform 1,000 hours of community service while he serves three years on probation afterward. Hargrove, who imposed the sentence Thursday, said it was a compromise between the need to send a message to other drugmakers and a reward for Bae's cooperation with federal prosecutors in a continuing investigation of the generic drug industry. Bae pleaded guilty last summer to paying a $10,000 illegal gratuity to Charles Y. Chang in return for swift approvals of My-K generic drug applications while Chang was chief of the FDA's generic drug review branch in Rockville. Bae also pleaded guilty to a gratuities charge for giving Joseph Micelli, an official at the FDA's medical directorate in Philadelphia, a $400 videocassette recorder, a trip to Chicago and $500 in travel expenses. Prosecutors there said Bae bribed other employees at the Defense Personnel Support Center in return for their help in obtaining supply contracts for his company. The defendant was instrumental in Chang's conviction on racketeering charges and was a key government witness at the October perjury trial of Marvin Seife, former director of the FDA's Division of Generic Drugs. Seife was convicted. Bae told Hargrove that he experienced hunger and poverty as a youth in war-torn South Korea, but seized the opportunity to be educated in the United States. He said he ``worked very hard'' to become a success here. ``I had a dream to do the best I could,'' Bae said remorsefully. ``Now I am a convicted felon ... and I have to explain that to my children and grandchildren.'' Prosecutors Gary P. Jordan and Geoffrey R. Garinther credited Bae with full cooperation in the probe, which has led to the convictions of 16 FDA and generic drug officials and companies. Bae, who started My-K Laboratories with $1,000 in 1973 and sold it for nearly $20 million in 1988, now owns a Chicago-area bank and numerous rental properties and is believed to be among the richest of the generic drug defendants. Defense attorneys William G. Hundley and Ann C. Tighe requested probation for Bae. They said he has been active in community work since he sold My-K Laboratories. After Bae sold the company, he gave its employees $1 million and donated another $300,000 to their profit-sharing plan, Hundley said.

DOC.HEAD: Former Homeland Leader Detained
DOC.TEXT: Former Prime Minister Kaiser Mantanzima of Transkei has been detained in connection with last month's failed coup attempt in the black homeland, a news report said Friday. Mantanzima was detained Thursday under Transkei's Public Security Act, the independent South African Press Association quoted homeland official Gen. Richmond Mankahla as saying. No other details were immediately available. The press association said Mantanzima earlier this week asked South Africa to send troops to his constituency, where he is chief, and remove it from Transkei control. In the Nov. 22 uprising against the military government of Maj. Gen. Bantu Holomisa, 11 rebels and seven loyalist soldiers were killed, including coup leader Col. Craig Duli. Holomisa accused South Africa of complicity. South Africa's white-dominated government denied the charge. Transkei is one of four black homelands granted nominal independence by South Africa. No other country recognizes their sovereignty. Six other homelands are part of South Africa. The Pretoria leadership set up the homelands in the 1970s and 1980s as part of a plan to create separate states for blacks. Transkei, made up of three separate enclaves in southeastern South Africa, has about 2.75 million residents. Mantanzima was the first prime minister after independence in 1976, serving until 1979. His brother George succeeded him and was ousted by Holomisa in a 1987 coup.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-US-Gulf Bjt
DOC.TEXT: ``I don't want to draw deadlines in the sand here, but there would have to be some compelling reason for me to change it.'' - President Bush, refusing to say if he would bend on his insistence that Secretary of State Baker's trip to Iraq must occur by Jan. 3. --- ``Saddam Hussein is not too busy to see ... Kurt Waldheim, Billy Graham, Mohammed Ali, Ted Heath, John Connally, Ramsey Clark, and many, many others on very short notice. It simply is not credible that he cannot ... make a couple of hours available for the secretary of state on an issue of this importance.'' - President Bush. --- ``I can't think of anything more damaging ... than an indication from Congress that they are not supportive of the president's policies.'' - Defense Secretary Dick Cheney. --- ``Welcome home and thanks for a job well done. As you were freed, now too we must see Kuwait freed of Iraqi occupation.'' - Secretary of State James A. Baker III, welcoming home Ambassador Nathaniel Howell, who led a four-month holdout of American diplomats at the besieged U.S. Embassy in Kuwait City.

DOC.HEAD: Defendant in Mail Bombings Convicted in Unrelated Trial of Blocking Justice
DOC.TEXT: The man accused of two fatal mail bombings was convicted Friday of obstructing justice when he paid witnesses to lie in court in an unrelated bomb possession case. A federal jury found Walter Leroy Moody Jr. guilty of all 13 charges against him in a five-day trial. Moody, 56, faces trial in mail bombings in Georgia and Alabama last year that killed a federal judge and a city councilman. The jury convicted Moody of conspiracy, obstructing justice and obstructing a criminal investigation, inducing someone else to commit perjury, bribing a witness and witness tampering. Moody was expected to be sentenced in 60 days. He could receive 69 years in prison and nearly $2.3 million in fines. The trial hinged on the testimony of two women who said Moody paid them to lie in court when he appealed a 1972 bomb possession conviction. Moody had concocted a story and paid the women to back it up. The appeal failed. A third woman also testified that Moody had paid her to lie at his 1983 trial in Florida for attempted murder. That case ended in a mistrial. The women had been indicted with Moody but were granted immunity in exchange for their testimony against him. Prosecutor Louis Freeh urged jurors not to believe Moody's claims that he was manipulated by the female witnesses. ``I'm saying he's a fake - he is a sham,'' Freeh said. Defense lawyer Ed Tolley argued that the evidence showed Moody did not know what he was doing. ``He left a trail a child could follow,'' he said. Also Friday, Judge Anthony Alaimo acceded to Moody's request to exclude a possible verdict of guilty but mentally ill. After his attorney spent most of Thursday building an insanity defense, Moody stood up and told the judge he objected. A finding of insanity could have put Moody in a psychiatric institution and he didn't want to risk that, his lawyer said. The recent trial was unrelated to the 70-count indictment against Moody charging him with sending two deadly mail bombs. The December 1989 mail bombs killed 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals Judge Robert Vance in Alabama and Savannah attorney and City Council member Robert Robinson. No trial date has been set.

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Says China Will Expand Privately Run Markets
DOC.TEXT: The official newspaper China Daily, acknowledging the importance of private enterprise, said Friday that China plans to increase the number of its free markets by more than 10 percent in the next five years. The announcement reflects a shift in public pronouncements since last year, when private vendors came under strong criticism. The economy remains largely controlled by the Communist government. However, China Daily noted Friday a growing reliance on free markets, which chiefly sell food, clothing and furniture. It said the number of free markets will increase by more than 10 percent by 1995. The newspaper said unofficial statistics show China's urban residents now buy 60 percent to 70 percent of their vegetables and non-staple food from free markets. Farmers sell about half their products at the markets, it said. Chinese buy staple foods at state-run stores, where they use ration coupons that let them make purchases at a discount. They turn to free markets to supplement food supplies and buy items unavailable from state outlets. ``Since free markets reappeared in China 11 years ago, they have been playing an increasingly important role in the daily lives of urban and rural residents,'' China Daily said. After the government's violent crackdown on the pro-democracy movement in June 1989, private enterprises were targets in wide-ranging attacks on capitalism. State-run media carried reports rebuking private businessmen, accusing them of making too much money and of tax evasion. Official regulations still prohibit the free markets from selling most raw materials and many consumer items, including tobacco, liquor and cotton. The State Administration for Industry and Commerce said 72,130 free markets now operate in China. According to government statistics, 4.8 percent of the enterprises in China are privately owned.

DOC.HEAD: Commander of Bolivian Drug Cartel Held
DOC.TEXT: Federal prosecutors Friday unsealed two indictments against a Bolivian immigrant reputed to rival leaders of the Colombian cocaine cartels. Julius C. Beretta, DEA special agent in San Diego, described Jorge Roca Suarez as ``one of the most significant cocaine traffickers in the United States, on par with Medellin or Cali cartel leaders.'' Roca, his wife, Cirila Roca, his sisters, Beatriz Roca Torres and Vilma Roca, and two others were brought to federal court Friday, but their arraignments were postponed while they hire lawyers. Roca's mother, Blanca Suarez, was also charged with participating in the money laundering and cocaine conspiracy charged in indictments unsealed in Los Angeles and San Diego. The indictments depicted a family style drug cartel in which Roca's sisters, brothers, cousins and in-laws were key operatives, shuttling shipments of cocaine and money between countries. They also alleged that threats, murder and kidnappings were methods used by Roca, a resident immigrant, to protect his vast cocaine cartel. Sometimes, the indictments indicated, piles of cash were stuffed into refrigerators, vacuum cleaners and other appliances for shipment to Bolivia. Roca was arrested Thursday at his 19-room San Marino estate. His wife and the four others were arrested nearby. Another 17 defendants were being sought. The 12-count indictment unsealed in Los Angeles charges the defendants with an array of tax evasion, money laundering and fraud offenses involving export of millions of dollars. Federal authorities in San Diego simultaneously unsealed an 18-count indictment there charging Roca, a sister, his mother and 17 others with cocaine smuggling, conspiracy and related crimes. The U.S. Attorney's office said Roca is the nephew of Roberto Gomez Suarez, once described as the ``cocaine king of Bolivia.'' Gomez is jailed in Bolivia and is a fugitive from U.S. federal drug trafficking charges. In a press release, U.S. Attorney Lourdes Baird said that Roca broke away from his uncle's operation and launched his own cocaine trafficking and money laundering organization which operates in Bolivia, Panama, Mexico and the United States. She said Roca directed a cadre of lieutenants, mostly family members, who helped control all aspects of the Bolivian cocaine trade.
