DOC.HEAD: Vista Chemical Merges With German Company in $590 Million Deal
DOC.TEXT: Vista Chemical Co. has agreed to be acquired in a $590 million cash tender offer by the German energy and chemical company RWE-DEA. RWE-DEA will offer to buy all of Vista's outstanding common shares for $55 per share, according to a definitive agreement signed by both companies. The tender offer will begin by next Wednesday, they said. ``This merger agreement, which was consummated on an entirely friendly basis, not only provides the best value for Vista shareholders, but also represents a sound and exciting future for our employees,'' John D. Burns, Vista's chairman, president and chief executive officer, said Thursday. Burns said that as part of the RWE group, Vista will be able ``to implement all appropriate investment projects designed to strengthen and enhance our joint operations.'' Houston-based Vista produces commodity and specialty chemicals used in a variety of products such as household laundry detergents, shampoos, cosmetics, automobile trim and fittings, vinyl packaging materials, home siding and wire and cable coatings. Vista's earned $63.3 million for the 1990 year ending Sept. 30 on sales of $719 million. The company, formed in 1984, has about 1,850 employees and owns or leases nine principal manufacturing and production facilities. RWE-DEA, formerly known as Deutsche Texaco AG, is involved in oil refining, marketing, exploration and production of oil and natural gas either directly or through subsidiaries. The Hamburg-based company, which has about 6,200 employees, also manufactures a wide range of petrochemical basics and chemical products. For the fiscal year ending Dec. 31, 1989, RWE-DEA had a net income of $120 million. RWE-DEA is an independent operating subsidiary of RWE AG, a publicly held holding company that is involved in electricity, mining, oil and chemicals, machinery, construction and waste management through its six subsidiaries. RWE AG owns more than 99 percent ot RWE-DEA's stock. ``The combination of Vista and RWE-DEA provides a unique opportunity to expand significantly into the global chemicals market,'' said Armin Schram, RWE-DEA's chairman. ``We do not anticipate that the transaction will result in any significant changes in Vista's structure of operation,'' he said, adding that no layoffs are anticipated, and Vista plans to keep its corporate headquarters in Houston. The $590 million offer is expected to be completed by early next year, and the merger should be accomplished on July 1, 1991. At least two-thirds of the common stock must be tendered. Vista cannot solicit takeover proposals, but the company may withdraw its recommendation of the tender offer and terminate the merger agreement if it receives a better proposal from a third party.

DOC.HEAD: UtiliCorp Seeks Other Utility's Customers
DOC.TEXT: UtiliCorp United Inc. said it would pay $346 million for the electricity utility operations of Centel Corp., marking the largest acquisition in UtiliCorp's six-year expansion. The deal would add 136,000 electricity customers in Kansas and Colorado to UtiliCorp's operations. UtiliCorp, based in Kansas City, provides gas and electric service to customers in eight states and British Columbia. The transaction requires approval from state and federal regulators. ``We have had an interest in the Centel property for some time because it enables us to further balance our electric and gas operations and our summer and winter peaking sources of revenue,'' said UtiliCorp Chairman and President Richard C. Green Jr. Chicago-based Centel said in August that it wanted to sell its electricity properties to the highest bidder and concentrate on its telecommunications operations. Centel provides local exchange service to more than 1.6 million customers and operates cellular communications franchises in 15 states. In Kansas, Centel serves 65,000 customers in Dodge City, Concordia, Great Bend and other communities in central and southwest Kansas. Under the deal, UtiliCorp will pay Centel $210.5 million in cash and pick up $21.3 million of Centel's liabilities. In addition, Centel's 8 percent interest in the Jeffrey Energy Center in Kansas will be picked up by a financial institution or insurance company for $114 million, Green said. Jeffrey comprises three coal-fired generating plants 30 miles northwest of Topeka. UtiliCorp will pay $12.4 million a year to lease Centel's share of the facility. At the end of 25 years UtiliCorp will recover Centel's interest in the facility at market value, Green said. Excluding the latest deal, UtiliCorp has invested $420.8 million in acquiring regulated utilities and $390 million to acquire unregulated properties since 1984. Green said that he would like to make about $700 million in acquisitions in 1991 to sustain UtiliCorp's growth and continue diversifying its revenue. Green told securities analysts that UtiliCorp expects record financial results for the fourth quarter and 1990. UtiliCorp said it expects to earn $58.2 million, or $2.10 a share, in 1990, compared with $48.3 million, or $2.04 a share, in 1989. For the fourth quarter, which ends Dec. 31, UtiliCorp expects to earn $20.3 million on $224 million in revenue, compared with earnings of $13.9 million on $237 million in revenue a year earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Throws Out Copyright on Popular Computer Program
DOC.TEXT: Ashton Tate Corp. cannot claim copyrights to its popular dBase software because the company failed to disclose the program was based on one developed by NASA's Jet Propulsion Lab, a judge ruled. The JPL program is in the public domain, and U.S. District Judge Terry Hatter's ruling Thursday could make one of the most widely used computer programs in the world available to anyone without charge. ``We're surprised and alarmed,'' said Ashton Tate President William Lyons. He said the ruling is wrong and the company will ask Hatter to reconsider. Ashton Tate will appeal if Hatter does not change it, Lyons said. It appeared unlikely the federal judge would do so because his brief ruling was so strongly worded. ``This was not an unclear document in regards to what the judge wanted to do, although it may be a little unclear about why he did it,'' said Steve Hess, a specialist in personal computers with Creative Strategies Research International, a consulting and market research company in Santa Clara. Hess said if the ruling stands, it likely will be the end of Ashton Tate, which built its fortunes around dBase, a product that sorts, retrieves, and indexes huge quantities of information. The ruling may also open the door for additional challenges to copyrights issued to cmputer companies that did not entirely disclose to the U.S. Copyright Office all similar predecessors to their products, Hess said. ``This thing could have some very wide implications,'' Hess said. Hatter's ruling stems from a copyright infringement lawsuit Ashton Tate filed in Los Angeles against competitors Fox Software Inc. and The Santa Cruz Operation Inc., accusing them of selling software that mimics dBase. Hatter dismissed the suit. Former JPL employee Wayne Ratliff devised dBase, and Ashton Tate essentially developed as a way to market it. Over a decade, Ashton Tate copyrighted various updated versions of dBase, including one bug-ridden version two years ago that nearly caused the downfall of the company. In his written ruling, Hatter said that when Ashton Tate applied for a copyright, it failed to mention the National Aeronautics and Space Administration-JPL link. Ashton Tate ``repeatedly failed to disclose material information to the United States Copyright Office,'' Hatter's ruling said.

DOC.HEAD: Newsstand Operators Sue Daily News Drivers' Union
DOC.TEXT: Newsstand operators sued the striking Daily News drivers' union, saying it encouraged a campaign of violence to stop vendors from selling the paper. Two newsstand owners filed the class-action lawsuit Thursday in U.S. District Court in Manhattan on behalf of the city's approximately 12,000 news vendors. It seeks more than $30 million in damages from the Newspaper & Mail Deliverers' Union of New York and its president, Michael Alvino. The drivers union is one of nine that have been on strike against the paper since Oct. 25. Theodore Kheel, an adviser who often has spoken for the striking unions, said he had not seen the lawsuit and could not comment on it. The complaint alleges that the drivers union ``has carried out a campaign of violence, threats and intimidation that has created fear among the news dealers for their safety and the safety of their property.'' The lawsuit seeks damages from the union for alleged violations of antitrust and labor laws and the Racketeer Influenced, Corrupt Organizations Act. The Daily News brought a similar racketeering lawsuit against the unions last month. Both suits detail allegations of ``attempted murder, arson, assault and vandalism'' and accuse the drivers' union of ``a long history of racketeering.'' Plaintiffs in the vendors' lawsuit are Kishor Mehta, who operates 11 newsstands in Co-op City, a large development in the Bronx, and Nasir Naveed, who owns a stand in Brooklyn.

DOC.HEAD: Business Inventories Rose 0.4 Percent in October
DOC.TEXT: Business inventories rose 0.4 percent in October, the government reported today, a moderate increase that analysts say is unlikely to accelerate already growing unemployment. The Commerce Department said inventories held on shelves and backlots totaled a seasonally adjusted $813.9 billion, up from $810.8 billion in September. At the same time, the department said business sales outpaced inventory growth, rising 0.9 percent to a seasonally adjusted $551.8 billion. Sales had fallen 0.8 percent the previous month to $547.2 billion. The activity pushed the ratio of inventories-to-sales down to 1.47 from 1.48 in September. The ratio means it would take 1.47 months to exhaust the backlog of goods at the October sales pace. Many economists do not consider a 1.47 ratio to be excessively high. But a larger increase could be worrisome since a major rise in inventories in relation to sales could cause growing production cutbacks and job layoffs as businesses attempt to sell off the backlog. Even with the low inventory accumulation, industrial production still fell 1.7 percent in November, the Federal Reserve reported today. At the same time, 200,000 factory jobs were lost that month, according to Labor Department statistics. ``The pace of accumulation has been and remains extremely conservative by historical standards,'' economists at Fuji Securities Inc. in Chicago wrote in their weekly newsletter Perspectives. ``It is far too slow to jeopardize the already-weakened economy with a purge of unwanted inventories.'' Although inventories grew in all three categories, overall growth slowed from 0.7 percent in August. And the revised 0.4 percent increase in September was smaller than the 0.5 percent first reported. Manufacturing inventories edged up 0.1 percent while wholesalers posted a 0.2 percent gain. On the retail level, however, the accumulation rose 1.0 percent. At the same time, manufacturers' sales jumped 1.7 percent. Sales on the wholesale level rose 0.1 percent and on the retail level, 0.2 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Airline Freebies War Escalates
DOC.TEXT: Northwest Airlines has become the fourth carrier to join a freebie war that is spreading through the sagging air travel industry. ``Northwest's promotion parallels offers by other airlines but is the only one to include free travel to Europe and Hawaii,'' the carrier said in a statement Thursday. Delta Air Lines fired the opening salvo early this week, offering free flights or first-class upgrades to anybody who completes eight ``segments'' of travel. A segment generally means any separate flight or connecting flight that costs more than a minimum amount. Late Thursday, American Airlines and United Airlines announced their own programs offering free flights, to be taken later next year, for anybody who racks up either eight segments of flight or three round trips. American acknowledged its offer was in response to Delta, and United acknowledged it was responding to the other two. Northwest's program also requires three roundtrips or eight segments, spokeswoman Christy Clapp said this morning. Airlines typically rush to match cheap fares and promotions offered by their competitors for fear they could otherwise lose passengers. Analysts have said the latest deal seems to be getting a head start on promotions that generally come out after the winter holiday season, as the sluggish months of January and February set in. They said the airlines need to avoid offering broad deals that are too good for passengers or run the risk of compounding troubles brought on by high fuel prices and sluggish demand for air travel.

DOC.HEAD: Wholesale Prices Rise 0.5 Percent in November
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Top 5 grafs new with comment and market reaction; picks up 5th graf pvs, In another
DOC.TEXT: Wholesale prices rose 0.5 percent in November, the government said today, a worrisome number but mild in comparison to the three-month burst of inflation after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait sent energy costs spiraling. ``It's another terrible number. We have not gotten rid of inflation,'' said economist Michael K. Evans, a Washington consultant. Faced with the disappointing news, the stock market suffered a broad decline in early trading today. Most economists had anticipated a wholesale price rise of 0.1 percent to 0.3 percent. The seasonally-adjusted November rise in the Labor Department's Producer Price Index for finished goods, which measures inflation one stop short of retail, follows three months of steeper increases. Prices rose 1.1 percent in October and August and 1.6 percent in September. The November increase, although tame by comparison, still translates into a 6.1 percent annual inflation rate. In another economic report today, the Federal Reserve said industrial production weakened in November for the third straight month, falling back 1.7 percent to the lowest level since last January. It was the steepest decline since output in manufacturing plunged 2.0 percent in December 1982 as the nation began crawling out of the last recession. And the Commerce Department reported that business inventories rose 0.4 percent in October, a moderate increase that analysts say is unlikely to accelerate already growing unemployment. For the year so far, wholesale prices have risen at a 6.9 percent annual rate, compared with 4.9 percent for all of 1989. In November, energy prices rose a scant 0.1 percent, after soaring 8 percent in October, 13.8 percent in September and 9 percent in August. Gasoline prices fell 2.6 percent and fuel oil dropped 7.3 percent. However, natural gas costs, which had been largely unaffected by Persian Gulf turmoil, rose 5 percent. Food prices rose 0.8 percent last month following a 0.9 percent jump in October. The department said fresh and dried vegetable prices leapt 12.3 percent and fish prices were up 8.1 percent. Costs also rose for fresh fruit, rice, beef, pork and sweets. Prices fell for eggs, dairy products, chickens and turkeys, pasta and shortening and cooking oils. Prices excluding the volatile food and energy categories - considered a better barometer of underlying inflationary pressures by most economists - rose 0.5 percent after no change in October. Tobacco prices were up 3.7 percent in November and 15 percent over the past year. Passenger cars rose 1.8 percent as some manufacturers curbed incentive programs. Costs also rose for medicines, tires, floor coverings and textile house furnishings. Prices fell steeply for glassware and edged down for lawn and garden equipment and sporting goods. Until today's inflation report, most economists believed that Federal Reserve policy-makers, meeting Monday, would stimulate the economy with another cut in interest rates before the end of the year. However, the Fed has nudged short-term rates lowers three times since early November and may hesitate to cut them again if inflation worries persist. Reduced rates stimulate the economy by making it cheaper for consumers and businesses to borrow, but they also tend to foster inflation by creating more demand for goods than producers can meet. The various changes in November pushed the index for all finished goods to 122.9, up from 114.9 in November 1989. That means a hypothetical selection of goods costing $100 in 1982, cost $122.90 last month, up from $114.90 a year earlier. Price pressures earlier in the production process were more modest. Intermediate goods were up only 0.1 percent and the price of crude goods fell 6.2 percent. An example of the three processing stages would be bread for finished, flour for intermediate and wheat for crude. Most analysts believe the economic slump should keep wholesale price rises under control through 1991 if peace prevails in the Persian Gulf. ``Basically, the surge has pretty well spent its force,'' said economist Robert G. Dederick of Northern Trust Co. in Chicago. ``We may be surprised at how low the numbers are in the spring.'' Economist Donald Ratajczak of Georgia State University is predicting that in 1991, the weak economy will hold price increases down to 2.2 percent, the best since 1986. Dederick said the economic slump, which most analysts believe is the beginning of a recession, has dampened demand from consumers and businesses to the point where goods producers can't get price increases to stick. ``I would think producer prices are headed lower. How long they stay down depends on the depth of the recession and the vigor of the recovery,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: SEC Request Rejected At Southland Hearing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. bankruptcy judge today turned down a federal agency's request for 45 more days to review the bankruptcy reorganization plan of Southland Corp., the Dallas-based owner of 7-Eleven convenience stores. Judge Harold Abramson said the extension sought by the Securities and Exchange Commission is too long for an opinion that is not required in the bankruptcy proceeding. Abramson had asked the SEC for a statement about Southland's ``prepackaged'' bankruptcy plan, in which a creditor-approved blueprint for re-emerging from bankruptcy reorganization is filed at the time a company seeks refuge from creditors. Ordinarily, a company presents a reorganization plan months or even years later and creditors often challenge it. The SEC had wanted more time to prepare a statement, saying Southland's use of prepackaging would set a precedent for other large bankruptcy reorganizations and merited a lengthier review. Southland filed for bankruptcy protection in October, using the prepackaging tool. Abramson said the SEC has had months to look over Southland's restructuring, which he noted began in March. ``I can't give you that long,'' Abramson told an SEC attorney who asked for the 45-day extension. ``If the commission could make some kind of statement by Dec. 31st or the first week of January, that would be helpful to the court,'' Abramson said. ``Otherwise I'll excuse you from that request.'' ``The buck stops here anyway,'' Abramson said. The judge indicated testimony in the Southland confirmation hearing could last until early next month. At the time of filing, the company listed $2.53 billion in assets and $3.38 billion in liabilities and said it was overwhelmed by debt left from its $4.9 billion debt-financed takeover in 1987. Southland, which had sales of almost $8 billion last year, is the largest of the few companies that have tried a prepackaged bankruptcy. Company officials believe prepackaging will allow the company to get out of the bankruptcy process in six months. In addition to speeding up the bankruptcy process, proponents of prepackaging say it assures a fairer deal for a greater number of creditors. That's because a prepackaged plan must be approved by at least 50 percent of the bondholders holding at least two-thirds of a company's debt. If a judge approves, the terms of the plan are then imposed on the dissenting minority, preventing holdouts from seeking better repayment terms. Southland in March said its Japanese affiliates, Ito-Yokado Co. Ltd. and Seven-Eleven Japan Co. Ltd., were willing to spend $430 million for stock in the reorganized company. The terms of the prepackaged plan were agreed to in October, just before the Chapter 11 filing. Other companies - notably Atlantic City resorts owned by Merv Griffin and Donald Trump - have used prepackaging in bankruptcy proceedings. Republic Health Corp., a Dallas-based owner of 14 hospitals, filed a prepackaged Chapter 11 plan last December and emerged from bankruptcy in April. The company had posted a profit by the end of August.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Up On Hints That U.S.-Iraq Talks Might Be Off
DOC.TEXT: Oil prices shot up today on speculation the United States and Iraq would not be able to set up top-level diplomatic meetings on the Persian Gulf crisis. Light sweet crude oil for January delivery was up $1.43 per barrel at $27.85 early this afternoon on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Oil had opened higher in New York amid continued reports that U.S. and Iraqi officials were quarreling over a date for Secretary of State James A. Baker III to visit Baghdad. Iraq has insisted that Baker go to Baghdad on Jan. 12, three days before the U.N. Security Council's deadline for Iraqi President Saddam Hussein to either withdraw his troops from oil-rich Kuwait or risk a military strike. But the White House wants Baker to visit Iraq no later than Jan. 3. The diplomatic logjam had pushed crude prices up $1.07 per barrel on Thursday and the surge continued today. The rally got an additional lift around midday when two senators announced Bush was ready to call off the talks with the Iraqis because of the disagreements. The White House said Bush had not given up hope for the talks, but he planned a mid-afternoon statement on the situation that had the oil market on edge as crude traders wondered what Bush would say. ``The focus is on whether or not these talks are going to go ahead,'' senior oil analyst Ann-Louise Hittle of Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. said this morning. ``Obviously, the U.S. and Iraq are still at a stalement.'' As crude moved ahead, futures prices for refined petroleum products were also on the rise. Home heating oil was up 2.93 cents at 77.50 cents per gallon for January delivery. Unleaded gasoline was up 2.48 cents at 68.05 cents per gallon for January delivery. Energy analyst Thomas P. Blakeslee of Pegasus Econometric Group Inc., in Hoboken, N.J., said heating oil had been the weaker of the futures contracts, with supplies adequate and demand sluggish in the unseasonably warm fall. ``It won't get cold,'' Blakeslee said. ``It's a little chilly out there today, but there's no forecast for any types of freezing temperatures.'' Natural gas was up 2 cents at $2.24 per 1,000 cubic feet for January delivery.

DOC.HEAD: NCR Board Rejects AT&T Tender Offer
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 14th graf, `AT&T spokesman ...,' to UPDATE with AT&T reax to amended lawsuit. SUBS 25th graf, ``NCR stock ...,' to UPDATE stock price.
DOC.TEXT: NCR Corp.'s directors unanimously rejected American Telephone & Telegraph Co.'s $90-a-share cash tender offer for the computer maker, NCR said today. In a statement, NCR called the hostile takeover bid ``grossly inadequate and unfair.'' ``Clearly, AT&T is attempting, for its own purposes, to take advantage of NCR's artificially and temporarily depressed stock price,'' NCR Chairman Charles E. Exley Jr. said in the statement. ``We cannot and will not permit them to seize for themselves the enormous values that are building steadily within NCR,'' Exley said. ``Having `just said no' to this grossly inadequate offer, we are focused on implementing the business strategy that will continue to build very real and very significant value for NCR shareholders, customers and employees.'' NCR's board met Thursday in New York, the company said. It was the board's first meeting since AT&T launched the $6.1 billion tender offer Dec. 5. Under Securities and Exchange Commission rules, NCR had 10 days - until next Wednesday - to advise stockholders on the bid and to file an opinion with the SEC. NCR also said it filed amendments today to a lawsuit it had filed earlier in U.S. District Court in Dayton, Ohio, its headquarters city. The suit seeks to have NCR's anti-takeover plan declared valid. The amendments allege that AT&T's government filings for its tender offer are ``false, manipulative and misleading'' and that they violate federal securities law. The amendments also allege the phone company filings: -Failed to disclose that its tender offer is conditional upon NCR's board approving a friendly transaction with AT&T. -Failed to disclose facts about ``AT&T's own failures in the computer business.'' -Falsely indicated AT&T may be willing to wait 18 months to complete a business combination with NCR. -Failed to disclose that combinations of computer companies in recent times ``have resulted in failure.'' AT&T spokesman Walter Murphy said the phone company had not fully studied the amended suit, ``but we believe their claims are completely without merit. Our tender offer materials are complete and accurate.'' Earlier today, AT&T said it was disappointed by the NCR board's rejection of the tender offer. ``Our $90-per-share price is a full, fair offer, as we believe NCR shareholders, if given the opportunity to decide, would agree,'' the phone company said in a statement. `We are now examining our options for the next steps we will take. AT&T is determined to conclude the merger with NCR. We still would much prefer to reach a negotiated agreement.'' Industry analysts say the most likely next step for AT&T would be to launch a proxy battle to try to unseat NCR's directors. NCR has in place a strong anti-takeover plan that could be removed if AT&T gains control of the board. Exley has said he would be willing to enter into negotiations with AT&T if it raised its offer to $125 a share, or a total of about $8.5 billion. AT&T rejected the higher price as ``outrageous and totally unjustified.'' Analysts said they believe Exley is exploring several options to fight the takeover bid, which he has called an attempt by AT&T to rescue that company's unprofitable computer line. ``I think Exley's trying to find somebody who will bail him out of this predicatment without taking control of the company,'' said John Jones of Montgomery Securities Inc. in San Francisco. Jones said Exley may seek another company that would buy a major stake in NCR but allow the company to pursue its own course. Exley has said he has been in contact with other companies that might be interested in some sort of combination with NCR, but he also said he is not interested in a ``white knight,'' or another merger partner that would save NCR from the AT&T bid. ``The deal (with AT&T) is either going to get done in two weeks or it's going to be drawn out for months,'' Jones predicted. AT&T's tender offer expires Jan. 4. NCR stock was down $1.50 to $88.62{ a share by early afternoon today on the New York Stock Exchange. AT&T shares fell 50 cents to $30.50. Also Thursday, AT&T filed a motion in U.S. District Court in Dayton seeking to have a filing by NCR last week dismissed. The filing asks the court to declare the company's anti-takeover plan valid. In addition, the Ohio Senate Judiciary Committee scheduled a hearing for Tuesday to review the takeover. NCR spokesman Mark Feighery said Exley plans to testify.

DOC.HEAD: California Billionaire Grabs 9 Percent of Chrysler
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS 1990s to 1980s in 3rd graf; adds new 5th graf of background on Kerkorian's disclosure requirement
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp. said Friday California billionaire Kirk Kerkorian had acquired more than 9 percent of its outstanding stock, and the financially struggling automaker strengthened its ``poison pill'' antitakeover defense in response. Chrysler declined to comment on the move by Kerkorian, who has ties to the entertainment industry in southern California and is known for other takeover forays. It wasn't immediately clear why Kerkorian had invested in Chrysler or how much he spent. But the move came against a background of a mild resurgence in big-time takeover maneuvering that were the hallmark of the 1980s. In recent weeks, for example, Hollywood entertainment giant MCA Inc. has been acquired by the Matsushita industrial conglomerate of Japan for more than $6.6 billion, and NCR Corp. has been fighting a $6.1 billion takeover offer from American Telephone and Telegraph Co. Investors who acquire more than 5 percent of a company's stock are required to disclose that information to the Securities and Exchange Commission within 5 days after they go over the 5 percent threshhold. But Kerkorian's disclosure statement wasn't immediately available at the SEC headquarters in Washington, which closed early today at 2 p.m. Chrysler is considered the weakest of the Big Three automakers and there has been persistent speculation that it might be purchased or merged with another company in the future. Trading in Chrysler stock was halted on the New York stock exchange pending Chrysler's announcement. At the time trading was halted, Chrysler stock was selling for $11.875 a share, down 37{ cents a share from Thursday's close. In response to Kerkorian's move, Chrysler's board of directors on Friday approved an amendment to its so-called ``poison pill'' share purchase rights plan. That amendment lowers the threshold for the company's anti-takeover mechanism to kick into action when 10 percent of its stock has been purchased an investor. Previously the threshold was 20 percent. If the mechanism goes into effect, shareholders are able to buy stock at less-than-market value, making it harder for a corporate raider, for example, to amass large quantities of stock. The largest Chrysler shareholders are the Wellington Group, with about 9.2 percent, and Sanford C. Bernstein & Co. Inc., with about 8.3 percent, which hold stock for some institutions, such as pension funds.

DOC.HEAD: Analysts Take Hope in October Sales Figures
With AM-Economy, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Business sales outpaced inventory accumulation in October, the government said Friday, giving some analysts hope that the economic downturn might be less severe than past slumps. ``In previous recessions, manufacturing activity fell off dramatically because of the build-up in inventories,'' explained economist Mark M. Zandi of Regional Financial Associates in West Chester, Pa. ``Businesses had to cut back their payrolls'' while they depleted their backlogs. The Commerce Department said inventories held on shelves and backlots in October expanded 0.4 percent to a seasonally adjusted $813.9 billion, up from $810.8 billion in September. The revised 0.4 percent increase in September was smaller than the 0.5 percent first reported. At the same time, the department said business sales rose 0.9 percent to a seasonally adjusted $551.8 billion. Sales had fallen a revised 0.5 percent the previous month to $547.2 billion. September sales first were reported to have been off 0.8 percent. The October activity resulted in an inventory-to-sales ratio of 1.47, down from 1.48 the previous month. The ratio means it would take 1.47 months to exhaust the backlog of goods at the October sales pace. The ratio reached 1.74 in January 1982 during the last recession. ``The fact that inventories remained lean suggests that although we're in a slowdown, there's not a lot of inventory correction needed and that will keep the slowdown mild and of shorter duration,'' Zandi said. Evelina Tainer, an economist with First National Bank of Chicago, said the ratio suggests ``unemployment will go up, but not as much as in past recessions.'' Nevertheless, inventories on the retail level rose a hefty 1.0 percent while gaining just 0.1 percent on the manufacturing level and 0.2 percent on the wholesale level. While saying inventories overall have been kept under ``pretty good control,'' economist Robert Brusca of Nikko Securities Co. International in New York said he still was ``concerned over the retail level, particularly if this is a disappointing Christmas shopping season.'' The Commerce Department said Thursday that retail sales in November fell 0.1 percent. Since the Thanksgiving weekend traditionally is the start of holiday shopping, many analysts said the report pointed to weak sales. Manufacturers' sales jumped 1.7 percent in October while sales rose 0.1 percent on the wholesale level and 0.2 percent on the retail level.

DOC.HEAD: Coal Production to Set Record, Officials Say
DOC.TEXT: U.S. coal production and consumption should top more than 1 billion tons for the first time in 1990, marking the fourth consecutive record year, industry officials said Friday. ``What we have seen is consistent, steady growth from year to year,'' said John Grasser, spokesman for the National Coal Association in Washington. ``It's not what you'd call robust and dramatic, but it's steady growth.'' The industry group's forecast predicts 1990 production will reach 1.02 billion tons, 41 million tons more than the record 981 million tons produced in 1989, Grasser said. The 4.2 percent increase in bituminous, subbituminous, lignite and anthracite production is the largest year-to-year increase since 1983 and 1984, he said. ``This is just that natural steady progression from year to year,'' Grasser said. ``Eighty percent of the coal goes to the utility sector. That's obviously our largest customer and that's where we've seen the largest growth.'' He said demand was helped by an increase in exports to foreign customers and an unusually high demand for utility stockpiles. West Virginia, the nation's third largest producer, was running nearly 14 percent ahead of last year's production figures through October with 144.2 million tons mined, said Kathy Sloan of the state Division of Energy. Wyoming has ranked No. 1 in coal production since 1988. Kentucky passed West Virginia as the leading producer in 1972. ``From what industry officials tell me, we have a pretty decent shot at coming even with Kentucky and maybe even passing it,'' said Mark Polen, vice president of the West Virginia Coal Association. ``It's going to be pretty close.'' While 1990 will be remembered as a banner year for the coal industry, Grasser said the outlook for 1991 isn't quite as positive. ``We are predicting a flat or even slight decline next year due in part to the recession and the slowing of the economy,'' Grasser said. National Coal Association forecasts for 1991 predict that production will decline by 1.47 percent, while consumption will increase by 1 percent. However, Richard Lawson, president of the National Coal Association, said the Persian Gulf crisis may help the industry next year. ``The recent and volatile increase in oil prices could have a positive effect on coal burn next year, especially if the Middle East situation is not resolved quickly,'' Lawson said. Recently enacted clean air legislation also could begin having some effects on the coal industry, officials said. ``It's dicey to predict how that act is going to work because we're not sure how the utility companies will respond to it,'' Polen said.

DOC.HEAD: Tribune Expects Big Earnings Decline, Knight-Ridder Expects to Improve
DOC.TEXT: Tribune Co. said Friday its operating profit will slide substantially more than 25 percent this year because of the weak advertising climate and rising costs of a strike at its New York Daily News. Company executives failed to specify how much the seven-week-old strike by nine of the 10 labor unions at the newspaper is costing. The paper has continued to publish despite the strike although circulation is down sharply. The executives repeated earlier assertions that they intended to continue publishing the paper as long as it continues to progress. In a separate appearance before securities analysts at the annual PaineWebber media outlook conference, Knight-Ridder Inc. said it expected earnings would be up modestly in 1990 compared with results in 1989 that excluded a gain on the sale of a newspaper. Chairman James Batten said the Miami-based newspaper and information services company has ``a realistic chance for at least a flat year'' in earnings per share next year. The companies made their appearances on the closing day of the weeklong conference that has featured mostly glum earnings forecasts due to advertising demand that has weakened along with the economy. A top advertising forecaster, Robert Coen, has estimated ad spending will rise only 4.9 percent this year, its slowest pace of growth since 1975, and grow 4.6 percent in 1991. Tribune, which publishes the Chicago Tribune and five other newspapers in addition to the News and owns six television stations, earned $3.17 a share for all of 1989. Operating earnings amounted to $433 million last year. But the tough advertising climate helped push operating earnings for the first nine months of this year down 25 percent from a year ago as a double-digit decline in the newspaper group more than offset gains in broadcasting and entertainment operations. Fourth-quarter earnings, while not out yet, also are below levels of last year. The News employees went on strike on Oct. 25 and newsprint operations were depressed by a strike at Canadian mill that has just been resolved. Scott Smith, chief financial officer of the Tribune, said operating results are down by about 20 percent in the last three months of the year excluding the effect of the strikes and substantially more if they are included. He said the decline in operating profit for the full year ``will be substantially larger than 25 percent'' including strike costs. Smith told analysts that earnings per share excluding losses at the Daily News and the newsprint mill should amount to about $3 compared with $3.17 a year ago, and said earnings will be below $3 a share next year. He said the company would disclose the magnitude of the losses at the Daily News when it reports its 1990 earnings early next year. Daily News Publisher James Hoge said the newspaper continues to hope a reasonable settlement can be reached to end the strike but that the paper will continue to publish as long as it was making progress toward regaining circulation and advertising. He said daily circulation has reached about 600,000 after sinking as low as 250,000 shortly after the strike began. It was more than 1.09 million before the strike. Hoge has previously said the Daily News lost $115 million betwen 1979 and 1989 and that losses by the end of 1990 will rise to about $200 million. Financial analysts, who were the only attendees allowed to ask questions at the session, did not ask about the size of the News losses. Knight-Ridder, which owns 29 daily newspapers including The Miami Herald and The Phildelphia Inquirer, said it anticipates earning $2.90 to $2.97 a share in 1990 compared with $2.86 a share excluding a gain on the sale of a newspaper in 1989. The advertising climate has weakend along with the economy in the fourth quarter, but Knight-Ridder aides said earnings per share should at least match the 1990 figure in 1991. Revenue is expected to rise 2 percent to 3 percent next year with slightly higher revenue from newspapers and a double-digit increase from business information services, said Robert Singleton, senior vice president for finance.

DOC.HEAD: Delta Pride Workers Ratify Contract, Ending 3-Month Strike
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs the 3rd graf to update with union recount of vote results. Neel is cq in 18th graf. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Union workers overwhelming approved a new contract Friday with Delta Pride Catfish Inc., ending a bitter three-month strike that brought out allegations of racial discrimination. The plight of the workers in one of the nation's most economically depressed regions attracted support from the NAACP and other civil rights organizations and led to a national boycott of Delta Pride products. The contract vote was 479-1. Union officials said the lone vote against appeared to be a misunderstanding over wage provisions in the pact. ``This is a great Christmas present,'' said Sarah White, a shop steward who has been with Delta Pride since 1983, one year after the nation's largest catfish processor opened. ``I feel good about this contract and I've talked with several co-workers and they are satisfied. ``We finally got some of the things we wanted ... including things that should make the workplace better for all of us.'' The strike began Sept. 13 when members of United Food and Commercial Workers Union Local 1529 rejected a contract. About 900 workers walked off the job at Delta Pride's Indianola and Inverness plants. A third plant in Belzoni employs non-union workers. The company had no immediate comment on the contract vote. Provisions in the contract include wage increases and assurances that striking workers will be rehired, union officials said. The contract grants immediate raises of 60 to 65 cents an hour for all workers with at least one year of seniority. Pay averaged $4.05 an hour before the strike. The pact also establishes a worker-management health and safety committee to monitor conditions at the plant. While there were scattered reports of violence, including rock-throwing, early in the strike, officials said recent weeks were quiet. Aaron Henry, president of the Mississippi NAACP, said the worker's anger arose from ``a combination of race and economics coupled with the philosophy of the plantation.'' Besides wages, the union also raised concerns about working conditions. A common complaint among workers has been about repetitive motion injury. Workers complained that they were timed with a stopwatch when skinning, gutting, slicing and packaging fish. The also complained of limited restroom breaks - six five-minute bathroom breaks per week. Violators risked dismissal. White, who has two children, said the three months she has been on strike created financial problems but ``the union helped take care of our bills and provided groceries for us. We really sacrificed but we had help with the basics.'' White, 32, of Moorhead, said she planned to be in St. Louis this weekend to attend a support rally for the striking workers. ``Now I can tell them it is over and tell them to start buying catfish ... we need the hours at work,'' she said. E. Dale Cline of Memphis, Tenn., the federal mediator who helped work out the new contract, said he is ``tickled to death that this is finally over.'' Union spokesman Neel Lattimore said the contract goes a long way toward improving working conditions. ``We feel like there is language in the contract to make Delta Pride more sensitive (to working conditions) and by all of us working together we can get along,'' he said.

The stock market recorded a broad loss today, weighed down by disappointing inflation news. The day got off to a rocky start when the Labor Department reported that the producer price index rose 0.5 percent in November. That came as an unpleasant surprise to traders who had been expecting a considerably smaller increase, given a recent letup in the rise of oil prices. Separate government reports showed a 1.7 percent drop in industrial production last month, and a slowing in the operating rate of the nation's factories, mines and utilities to 80.9 percent of capacity from 82.4 percent in October. Analysts said that mixture of news provided stock-market investors with little encouragement about the outlook for the economy and corporate profits.

DOC.HEAD: The AP
Oil Rises, Falls on Developments in Diplomatic Standoff
DOC.TEXT: Oil prices rallied Friday as traders speculated President Bush might scrap diplomatic meetings with Iraq, then crude fell back sharply when Bush's news conference rhetoric was not so harsh. Light sweet crude oil settled at $26.55 per barrel, up 13 cents, at the New York Mercantile Exchange on contracts for delivery in January. Crude for delivery in most later months closed lower. In early trading, crude had jumped up by $1.68 per barrel amid continued quarreling between the United States and Iraq over a date for Secretary of State James A. Baker III to visit Baghdad. Two senators said in Washington that Bush might be ready to abandon the idea of the talks, adding to oil's rally. After Bush said in the afternoon that he was discouraged but still hoped the talks could be held, crude plunged more than $1 per barrel in about a half hour. ``It was probably a little over-bought on the whole situation,'' said Ann-Louise Hittle, a senior oil analyst with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. ``Once he came out and didn't do anything, it was easy to sell off, probably a little bit of buy-the-rumor, sell-the-fact.'' Oil traders often run up prices by buying crude futures contracts when rumors hit the market, because they don't want to run the risk of getting left out of a rally. They are more likely to sell off their oil contracts on the basis of facts that indicate adequate supplies or sluggish demand. During the week, crude hit its lowest prices since Aug. 3, the day after Iraq invaded Kuwait. But after the close of $25.35 per barrel on Wednesday, it began moving higher. Oil had been steadily dropping since Nov. 30, when Bush first proposed the talks with Iraq and traders began believing a peaceful solution to the crisis could be at hand. Once the diplomats showed they could not even agree on dates to meet, the war fears began resurfacing. ``The last few days, it seemed like the peace talk has diminished,'' said Ed Kevelson, a trader with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. For the week, crude finished 3 cents higher on January delivery contracts. Refined petroleum products moved in tandem with crude on Friday, rising in early trading then dropping to show little change at the close. Home heating oil was up .67 cent at 75.24 cents a gallon for January delivery. Unleaded gasoline was up .61 cent at 66.18 cents a gallon for January delivery. Heating oil has shown the most weakness of late, with supplies adequate and demand sluggish amid unseasonably warm fall weather. ``It won't get cold,'' said Thomas P. Blakeslee, an energy analyst with Pegasus Econometric Group Inc., in Hoboken, N.J. ``It's a little chilly out there today, but there's no forecast for any types of freezing temperatures.'' For the week, heating oil fell 3.93 cents for next-month delivery, while gasoline fell .29 cent. Natural gas for January delivery closed Friday at $2.262 per 1,000 cubic feet, up 4.2 cents for the day but down 8.8 cents for the week.

DOC.HEAD: Airline, Casino, Studio Tycoon Once Steam-Cleaned Car Engines
With AM-Chrysler-Kerkorian
DOC.TEXT: For a highflier like Kirk Kerkorian, an auto maker like Chrysler Corp. is a pretty down-to-earth investment. The World War II pilot-turned-tycoon, who sold MGM-UA Communications Co. last month for $1.3 billion, is known for trading casinos and airplanes the way some people do cars, more Las Vegas glitter than Detroit grit. But Kerkorian's 9 percent stake in Chrysler, revealed Friday, returns him in an odd way to his business roots. After dropping out of trade school and a stint with the Civilian Conservation Corps, the first business he set up was steam-cleaning auto engines for used car dealers. Besides MGM-UA, Kerkorian is best known for investments in airlines - and for being one of the biggest players in Las Vegas, the highest-rolling city in America. ``He's got a reputation for being smart, and you don't have to check your wallet after shaking hands with him,'' Bally Manufacturing Chairman Robert E. Mullane once said of Kerkorian. Among other achievements in his 73 years, Kerkorian is noted for twice building the world's largest hotel in Las Vegas, only to see the record fall to others. His latest project there is a $700 million theme park and 5,000-room hotel on the Strip. He has hung a f ``At no time did (police) use their arms,'' a government statement said. The second union, the Democratic Workers Confederation, said it could not confirm the report of deaths in Fez, a city of about 500,000 people. In Tangier in northern Morocco, a 17-year-old boy was shot in the stomach in a confrontation between police and strikers, hospital sources said, speaking on condition of anonymity. They listed about 50 known injured in clashes there. Lesser clashes also were reported in Kenitra, north of Rabat, and the southern city of Agadir. Police threw tear gas canisters to disperse young rioters in Fez, many of them from Fez University, where pro-fundamentalist Moslem students and progressive students have been in conflict. The government said youths from outside Fez ``took advantage of the strike.'' In Tangier, youth threw up street barricades in Beni-Makada district as police moved in. The government had warned against the strike. It said it would investigate the incidents and that Premier Azeddine Laraki would make a statement Monday before Parliament. Thousands of workers who took part in general strikes in 1979 and 1981 were fired or arrested. The unions said the government must bear responsibility for Friday's incidents. The walkout apparently hit the education sector the hardest. Up to 60 percent of university teachers and students obeyed the strike call, said sources, speaking on condition of anonymity. The Education Ministry claimed that institutes and special schools were not affected. Last-ditch negotiations between the government and the unions failed on Thursday. The unions complained they received nothing but ``the traditional promises'' in response to their specific demands. Laraki announced salary increases and special family subsidies on Tuesday, but gave no figures.

DOC.HEAD: War or Peace Overshadows Other Market Influences
DOC.TEXT: For weeks the nation's farmers and grain and soybean traders had been waiting with anticipation the Bush Administration's decision on extending export credits to the Soviet Union. That decision came Wednesday, and it was disappointing. The United States will grant $500 million to $1 billion in export credits to the Soviet Union to buy much needed grain and other food products. Traders were expecting a credit package of $1.5 billion. Remarks by Sen. Robert Dole, R-Kan., led the markets to believe the administration could grant the Soviets $3 billion in credits. Farmers and traders were pressing for the granting of export credits to the Soviets because U.S. exports have been lagging tremendously. This year, corn exports are 36 percent behind levels last year, wheat shipments are down 23 percent and soybean exports are at their lowest levels in 16 years. ``Our exports are so far behind, if we don't start giving stuff away we are going to end up with excess inventory,'' said William Biedermann, an analyst with Allendale Inc. in Chicago. But analysts said credits of less than $1 billion won't allow the Soviet Union improve this country's grain exports. They won't allow the Soviets to fulfill their longterm grain-buying agreement with the United States. The Soviets are committed to buy 1.2 million metric tons of wheat and 600,000 metric tons of corn by year-end. The apparent lack of generosity by the United States has riled some traders. Analyst Daniel Basse, of AgResource Co. in Chicago said the amount of the credits are equivalent to a mini-embargo. He says that since other nations are offering the Soviets as much as $12 billion in food aid, there's some pretty intense competition for their business. Other grain-exporting nations have freely given export credits to the Soviets, which put pressure on the U.S. to extend export credits. Bumper crops have given the Soviets access to soybean meal and corn from South America and wheat for Europe and Canada. Disappointment with the smaller-than-expected offering of export credits extended to the livestock and pork market. A larger credit line had been expected to lead to meat purchases by the Soviets. But they are now likely to confine purchases to grains. Beidermann said farmers, particularly those who do not participate in government programs, have been hard hit by the declining exports. He said there is no reason for the United States to be reluctant to sell its grain to the Soviets because the nation has so much. In granting the credits, President Bush lifted a 15-year ban imposed because of the Soviet prohibition of free emigration. The Jackson-Vanik amendment barred closer U.S.-Soviet economic ties until Soviet Jews and others were free to emigrate in large numbers. This year, 150,000 Soviet Jews have moved to Israel and 50,000 to the United States. Kremlin officials said this past week that a further liberalization in immigration laws was planned. Biedermann said a big question remains, whether the amount of export credits granted Wednesday is part of bigger pie. The next prominent opportunity for the United States to announce export credits to the Soviets will come in February, when President Bush will travel to Moscow to meet with Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev.

DOC.HEAD: Martin, A Chicagoan Who Built Political Career in Rockford
With AM-Cabinet Shuffle. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: A few days before her Senate-race loss, Rep. Lynn Martin stood in a Chicago alley and argued with a man who said he was disgusted with her TV ads. Cars honked, but Martin didn't budge. The native Chicagoan was near her old neighborhood, and like most politicians in that brawny town she wasn't ready to yield an inch. ``Not mine!'' she told the man, who said her Senate campaign ads were nasty. ``Usually before you hang somebody you have some evidence.'' Her accuser was not convinced. Voters were not sold on her either. Sen. Paul Simon, D-Ill., crushed the Republican challenger in a 980,000-vote landslide that even swept Martin's home county, Winnebago. Soon to be out of work for the first time in her 18-year political career, Martin accepted an invitation Friday to join President Bush's Cabinet as Labor Department secretary, replacing Elizabeth Dole. Simon immediately jumped on her bandwagon. ``I will vote for her and I wish her the very best,'' he said. The Senate must confirm the appointment. Despite representing Rockford, a blue-collar city that is Illinois' second-largest, Martin never forged any ties to organized labor during her 10 years in the House. Business groups gave her $358,439 in campaign contributions from 1983 through 1988. Labor groups donated only $3,900. ``I, of course, am pro-business,'' Martin said earlier this year. ``I think pro-business is pro-worker. ``It isn't a belief that business should always be protected. In things like the environment, who should be hired - there are a lot of things that business has to do a lot better with,'' she said. In one of the most significant business-labor debates of 1988, Congress passed a bill requiring a 60-day notice of large layoffs or plant closings. Martin voted no. ``The smaller companies who would be forced to give that 60-day notice would find themselves losing virtually all credit and any chance to survive,'' she said. Judith Lynn Morley Martin was born in Chicago on Dec. 26, 1939. A graduate of the University of Illinois, she taught high school economics, government and English before beginning her public career with a race for Winnebago County Board in 1972. Four years later, she was elected to the Illinois House, and in 1978 the Illinois Senate. When John B. Anderson ran for president in 1980, voters promoted Martin to the U.S. House, where she was re-elected four times. Declaring that Simon was too liberal for Illinois, Martin ran for Senate this year. But she was never able to overcome his statewide popularity, match his $8 million campaign chest or develop a clear campaign theme. Perhaps her favorite achievement in Congress, she said, was a House rule that established an anti-discrimination program. The Office of Fair Employment Practices mediates disputes between lawmakers and their staff members. ``It was a giant step forward,'' Martin said in August. ``You now see women who are administrative assistants. ... Minorities have a chance to complain if they feel there is racial prejudice.'' Few laws, however, carry her name. ``The fact is it's a Democratic majority,'' she said of the House, ``so that means you have to be more concerned with getting whatever you want done in the process. ``I think people would suggest I'm pretty good at that.''

DOC.HEAD: Interest-Rate Hopes No Sure Thing
DOC.TEXT: Wall Street analysts have some words of caution for all investors, consumers and business planners who have put ``lower interest rates'' on their holiday-season wish lists this year. True, interest rates have come down significantly since they hit their 1990 peaks around the beginning of autumn. True, also, the Federal Reserve seems committed to a policy of gradually but steadily loosening its credit policy, helping to foster lower rates as it seeks to cushion the impact of a developing recession. And true, too, the consensus prediction among financial analysts is for further declines in interest rates at least through the early stages of 1991. But at least a few Scroogian voices can be heard in the chorus of yearend forecasts being issued these days in the investment world. Quite a few potential pitfalls dot the road to lower rates this winter, the skeptics say. Furthermore, they add, even if rates are indeed headed for further declines, the circumstances that permit that to happen may be pretty unpleasant. One widely cited prerequisite for lower rates is a steady improvement in the news on inflation. Wall Street suffered a disappointment on that score Friday, when the Labor Department reported that the producer price index rose 0.5 percent in November. Traders had been expecting a considerably smaller increase, given a recent letup in the rise of oil prices. The inflation outlook could be scrambled further should the showdown in the Persian Gulf take an unexpected turn, sending oil higher once again. ``The Gulf crisis and oil prices are the obvious wild cards,'' observed Edward Taber at the investment management firm of T. Rowe Price Associates in his forecast for 1991. ``The less obvious factor which could alter our forecast is a much stronger economy than is currently in the consensus.'' That could occur, Taber contends, as a result of such forces as the Fed's easing, heavy deficit spending by the government, tight inventories at many businesses, and any revival of consumer spending. ``Should this alternative become reality, we would expect rates to move markedly higher throughout the year,'' he said. The stock market struggled with such doubts through the past week, changing directions at least half a dozen times. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials closed Friday at 2,593.81, up 3.71 from the week before. The New York Stock Exchange composite index dropped .36 to 178.71; the American Stock Exchange market value index fell .71 to 305.74, and the NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market was down 2.71 at 368.83. Volume on the Big Board averaged 155.85 million shares a day, against 200 million in the previous week. Wary analysts recall that interest-rate hopes also ran high last year about this time. The Dow Jones industrial average reached a then-record closing peak of 2,810.15 last Jan. 2. But it tumbled 266.91 points, or 9.5 percent, over the next four weeks as rates unexpectedly turned higher, following the lead of interest rates in Japan and Germany. If rates keep declining now, some observers say, they could be signaling a deeper-than-expected recession, chilling any joy over cheaper money. With all this, though, many optimists remain on Wall Street offering assurances that the economy and the markets can ride out the storm. ``Will lower interest rates revive economic growth? They always have in the past,'' said Edward Yardeni, chief economist at Prudential-Bache Securities. ``Interest rates should hit their lows around March if the economy starts to show some signs of life during the first quarter as we expect. ``If, however, the economy continues to fall during the first quarter, then interest rates will fall as low as necessary to revive economic growth.''
