DOC.HEAD: Bankruptcy Hearing Begins with Arguments Over Disclosure
DOC.TEXT: Southland Corp.'s bankruptcy plan confirmation hearing began Friday with attorneys clashing over efforts by the parent of the 7-Eleven convenience store chain to disclose reorganization options. Southland filed for Chapter 11 reorganization in October with a ``prepackaged'' plan already approved by most of its creditors. U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Harold Abramson must confirm the plan for it to take effect. Abramson said he would first hear arguments over Southland's attempts to inform creditors of the Dallas-based company's financial condition and options, then hear arguments on the merits of the reorganization plan. The hearing is expected to last for several weeks. At the time of the bankruptcy filing, Southland listed $2.53 billion in assets and $3.38 billion in liabilities and said it was overwhelmed by debt left from its $4.9 billion debt-financed takeover in 1987. During opening statements, attorneys for creditors who oppose the plan argued that Southland did not give them enough time for its consideration, used a complicated ballot and withheld information about the compensation of the company's founding family. Southland's attorney, Mike Sutherland of Dallas, said the company followed existing regulations for a prepackaged filing. He said the dissenting creditors want Abramson to give them ``more leverage than they have.'' Southland is the largest of a handful of companies to try a prepackaged filing, first used about a year ago. The company's case has drawn extraordinary attention in the legal community because of its precedent-setting use of the prepackaging. Proponents of the prepackaging device say it reduces the time a company stays in bankruptcy and assures a fairer deal for a greater number of creditors. Ordinarily, a company presents a reorganization plan months or even years later after filing for bankruptcy and creditors often challenge it. Often a small number of creditors, called holdouts, will vote against any reorganization in hopes of a separate deal that is better, leaving the majority to accept repayment on terms that aren't as good. When a judge approves a prepackaged filing, its terms are imposed on all creditors. Peter Wolfson, attorney for some of the dissenting creditors, said the company doesn't have the support for the plan that it has portrayed. But he acknowledged that, in most aspects, the company's plan is supported by a majority of the people that Southland owes money. Under the plan, creditors end up with control of 25 percent of the company. Southland's Japanese affiliates, Ito-Yokado Co. Ltd. and Seven-Eleven Japan Co. Ltd., get 70 percent and the rest is left to the the company's founders, the Thompson family of Dallas. Jere and John Thompson, sons of Southland founder Joe Thompson, lose their posts as the company's chief officers. They remain directors and continue to be paid $600,000 annually, under the plan. Their brother, Joe Thompson Jr., would also remain a director of Southland. Abramson began the hearing by refusing to give another 45 days for the Securities and Exchange Commission to review the Southland plan. SEC attorney John Lee said agency officials wanted the extension because Southland's plan would set a precedent for other prepackaged bankruptcy cases. Abramson said the extension was too long for an opinion that is not required by the Bankruptcy Code. The judge asked the SEC to present a statement of position to help him form a ruling. ``If the commission could make some kind of statement by Dec. 31st or the first week of January, that would be helpful to the court,'' Abramson said. ``Otherwise I'll excuse you from that request.'' ``The buck stops here anyway,'' Abramson said.

DOC.HEAD: Chrysler Beefs Up Takeover Defenses After Investor Buys Automaker's Stock
LaserPhoto LA5
DOC.TEXT: California billionaire Kirk Kerkorian has bought 9.8 percent of the stock of Chrysler Corp. for about $272 million, making him the company's largest shareholder and prompting the struggling automaker to beef up its takeover defenses. A statement issued through a Los Angeles public relations agency said the purchase was made as an investment. Chrysler spokesman Arthur Liebler confirmed that a discussion took place last wek between Kerkorian, of Beverly Hills, Calif., and Chrysler Chairman Lee Iacocca. ``That's when Kerkorian said that he's supportive of Chrysler and he described himself as a passive investor,'' Liebler said Friday. Nevertheless, Chrysler's board of directors on Friday lowered from 20 percent to 10 percent the amount of stock an investor may hold before the company's anti-takeover mechanisms take effect. Those mechanisms include offering current Chrysler stockholders shares at less-than-market value. That makes a hostile takeover more difficult and expensive. Through a spokesman, Kerkorian indicated he was surprised by the board's action. ``It is hard for us to see how the steps taken by the board today are in the best interest of all the shareholders,'' the statement said. It did not say when Kerkorian bought the stock or what range he paid for the shares. A woman answering the telephone at Kerkorian's Tracinda Corp. in Beverly Hills, who did not identify herself, said no corporate officers were available and all comment was coming from the agency. More light may be shed in papers that must be filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission when an investor acquires 5 percent of a company's stock. Kerkorian had not filed the papers by the time the offices closed at 2 p.m. EST. Chrysler first announced the purchase, saying Kerkorian had acquired between 9 percent and 10 percent of the company's 224 million shares of outstanding common stock. About an hour earlier, trading in Chrysler stock was halted on the New York Stock Exchange, with shares at $11.87{. Trading resumed about two hours later and Chrysler stock rose to $12 a share, down 25 cents from Thursday's close. Chrysler shares regained the 25 cents and closed for the day at $12.25. The purchase makes Kerkorian Chrysler's largest shareholder. The Wellington Group has about 9.2 percent, and Sanford C. Bernstein & Co. Inc. about 8.3 percent. Both hold stock for institutions, such as pension funds. According to Chrysler's latest proxy statement, Iacocca owned about 192,000 shares of stock, or less than a tenth of 1 percent. Kerkorian, 73, is known as a high-rolling airline and Las Vegas casino investor. On Nov. 1 he completed the sale of MGM-UA Communications Co. for $1.3 billion to Pathe Communications Corp., owned by Italian financier Giancarlo Parretti. There has been speculation for months that Chrysler, which is struggling to be profitable this year, could be subject to a takeover or may offer some of its equity to another automaker. Last month, about the same time Kerkorian sold MGM-UA, Chrysler broke off talks with the huge Italian automaker Fiat SpA. Those talks had included discussions about business and commercial arrangements. Analysts speculated Kerkorian's move was purely for investment. ``He figures he has himself as close to a no-lose proposition in the (stock) market,'' said auto analyst Charles Brady of Oppenheimer & Co. in New York. ``The stock has bottomed out and everybody has said everything bad about it (Chrysler) as they can. ``I think it's a genius move. Barring nuclear war in the Middle East, he gets his money back.'' Kerkorian personally owned about 70 percent of the MGM-UA stock and controlled another 10 percent through a foundation. The sale last month to Pathe netted him an estimated $1 billion. ``Until he files the (SEC forms), nobody really knows what his true intentions are,'' said auto analyst Mary Anne Sudol of Fitch Investors Service Inc. ``It could be the vague old `for investment purposes only' or it could be something else.'' Chrysler, like the other domestic automakers, has been hurt this year by sagging sales in a flagging economy. It took a $214 million loss in the third quarter on $6.5 billion in revenue, compared to $331 million in earnings on $7.6 billion in revenue in the 1989 period. Chrysler is the smallest of the Big Three, with $23 billion in revenue through September compared to $95 billion for General Motors Corp. and $73.5 billion for Ford Motor Co.

DOC.HEAD: Inflation Disturbingly High as Economy Slumps
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf: ``Faced with,'' to give closing stock average. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Wholesale prices rose 0.5 percent in November, the government said Friday. Analysts called it a disturbingly high increase at a time when the economy is slumping and energy costs are moderating. In a separate report, the Federal Reserve said U.S. manufacturing had suffered its steepest one-month plunge in eight years. The seasonally adjusted November rise in the Labor Department's Producer Price Index for finished goods, which measures prices one stop short of retail, looked tame in comparison with monthly increases topping 1 percent from August through October. November's increase translates, however, into a worrisome 6.1 percent annual rate. ``It's another terrible number. We have not gotten rid of inflation,'' said economist Michael K. Evans, a Washington consultant. Faced with the disappointing news after forecasts of a price rise of only 0.1 percent to 0.3 percent, the stock and bond markets retreated. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrial stocks dropped 20.55 to 2,593.81, closing out the week with a net gain of 3.71 points. Interest rates rose in the bond market, with long-term government bonds falling $5 for each $1,0wd, searching handbags and clothing for weapons but there were no incidents. To the chants of ``Hallelujah!'' people carried placards reading ``Aristide Will Save Haiti'' and sang: ``It's you we're looking for. Now ... we are saved.'' Aristide, carrying poinsettas, was mobbed by a throng of screaming fans before he briefly addressed the crowd. ``We are the flowers of brotherhood,'' he said. ``We are carrying the flowers to victory.'' Haiti has been ruled by dictators virtually since it won independence from France in 1804 and established the world's first black republic. Two elections held the past four years have been rigged or halted because of violence. But many Haitians said Friday they believed foreign observers would make a difference this time. ``Even if 100 people get killed, the election will go on,'' said Jean-Claude Bajeux, a civil rights activist who spent many years in exile during the Duvalier family dictatorship. About 3 million people are registered to vote for president, bicameral legislature, mayors and county officials. The government has set up 14,500 polling places, and they will be open from 6 a.m. to 6 p.m. Sunday. The elections gained new vigor a month ago when Aristide declared his candidacy. He is the favorite of the poor who make up most of this Caribbean nation's 6 million residents. An advocate of liberation theology, or church involvement in the struggles of the poor, Aristide was expelled from the Salesian order in 1988 for allegedly fomenting revolution. He remains a priest, however, and has said he would renounce the priesthood to comply with Vatican rules against holding public office if he wins the election. Marc Bazin, a former World Bank economist and finance minister fired by the dictatorial Duvalier regime for investigating corruption, is believed to be the favorite of the middle class. He has a considerable following in the countryside. Bazin campaigned Friday in the mountain town of Tomassin, overlooking the wealthy suburb of Petionville. ``People like me, a working man, will vote for Aristide because he stands for change,'' said a street vendor who would only give his first name, Antoine. ``The bourgeoise will vote for Bazin.'' Election observers from the United Nations, Organization of American States and the Caribbean Economic Community will monitor the vote. Former President Jimmy Carter, who has monitored elections in Panama and Nicaragua, arrived Friday afternoon with a team of 34 observers from the Council of Freely Elected Heads of Government. President Bush sent former Gov. William Janklow of South Dakota as head of an eight-member U.S. government delegation. ``The election in Haiti offers a historic opportunity for the Haitian people to freely choose their leaders after decades of dictatorship,'' said White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. At the request of the interim government of President Ertha-Pascal Trouillot, the United Nations sent 64 unarmed military advisers to work with Haiti's notoriously ill-disciplined army to prevent election violence. Until 1986, the Duvalier family enforced its rule for 29 years with the help of a brutal private militia known as the Tonton Macoutes. The dictatorship ended in 1986 after Jean-Claude Duvalier fled to exile in France. Many holdovers from the Duvalier regime have remained intent on keeping their hold on power and have sabotaged elections twice since Jean-Claude was deposed. The elections in 1987 were aborted after army-backed thugs massacred 34 voters at the polls. The army dissolved the independent Electoral Council and held rigged elections in 1988. There has been relatively little violence during this year's campaign. Fears of a bloody election were heightened on Dec. 5 when unidentified assailants threw a grenade and opened fire on people leaving an Aristide rally, killing seven and wounding more than 50 others. Aristide blamed the attack on Roger Lafontant, self-proclaimed chief of the Tonton Macoutes and avid Duvalier supporter, and demanded his arrest. Lafontant denied his involvement. Lafontant returned from exile to run for president, but was disqualified on technicalities by the Electoral Council. He said this week he was the head of the Tonton Macoutes and the Duvalierist movement, and that he was determined to keep Aristide from becoming president.

DOC.HEAD: Motorola To Build Next-Generation Chips With Toshiba
DOC.TEXT: Motorola Inc. will produce its next generation of computer memory chips in Japan under a joint venture with Japanese electronics manufacturer Toshiba, a spokesman said Friday. The four-megabit dynamic random access memory chips will be manufactured at a factory in Sendai, Japan, that is co-owned by Motorola and Toshiba - rather than at Motorola's new chip plant in Austin, Texas, said Motorola spokesman Dan Rogers. When production of the dynamic RAM, or D-RAM, chips begins in the third quarter of 1991, it will mark the first time Motorola will offer that particular chip in large quantities, Rogers said. The demand for faster computers has spurred a growing demand for another type of semiconductor, static random access memory chips, which are even faster than the dynamic RAM chips to be produced in Japan. Motorola, based in this northwest Chicago suburb, decided to build the dynamic RAM chips in Japan, and use its MOS-11 factory in Austin to produce static RAM chips beginning in 1992, the company said in a news release. ``Rapidly increasing demand worldwide for our ... fast static RAMs and microprocessors is straining our existing production capacity, so MOS-11 will be used to meet this need,'' said Jim George, vice president of Motorola's MOS Memory Products Division in Austin. Static RAM chips are more expensive to produce but are four times faster than a dynamic RAM chip of equal memory. That speed makes the static RAM chips desirable for computers used in the workplace, an industry analyst said. ``There is a definite demand for static RAMs, which are potentially more profitable than dynamic RAMS. The demand for that high-speed static RAM is growing by leaps and bounds,'' said Millard Phelps, an analyst at the San Francisco investment firm Hambrecht & Quist. Motorola entered a long-term agreement with Toshiba in 1986 to produce dynamic RAM chips. ``We are not going to be a leader in the D-RAM industry. The Japanese have taken over that market,'' Rogers said. ``That's why we've gone into a partnership agreement rather than going out on our own. It's a very expensive business to be in.'' Toshiba officials dismissed as speculation published reports that they pressured Motorola into producing the dynamic RAM chip in Japan. ``We never mentioned to Motorola that Toshiba didn't want Motorola to produce the chip in the United States. If Motorola wanted to make the chip there, it could have. It's their decision, not ours,'' said Tedsou Kadoya, general manager of public communications for Toshiba America Inc. Motorola also produces computers, pagers, cellular phones, two-way radios, and defense and aerospace electronics.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mixed, Gold Rises, Silver Sinks
DOC.TEXT: The dollar registered a mixed showing against foreign currencies on Friday amid new doubts over whether diplomatic talks between the United States and Iraq would succeed. Gold was higher. But silver prices sank below $4 an ounce on the lack of decisive war moves and a large selloff by institutional investors. Over the past few days, silver has traded at the lowest price levels in 16 years. The dollar strengthened as traders anticipated Middle East saber-rattling from President Bush at a news conference, but the currency eased in value when Bush's comments showed he wasn't yet ready to scrap the diplomacy option. Bush scolded Saddam Hussein for failing to agree on a date for Secretary of State James A. Baker III's diplomatic trip to Baghdad. ``The dollar came off a little bit after overanticipating,'' said Francoise Soares-Kemp, manager of the corporate advisory desk at Credit Suisse in New York. ``Bush was tough but he didn't declare war in the next 24 hours.'' Overall the dollar gained against the yen, which is generally weakened on Middle East war fears because Japan's economy is so dependent on imported oil. The dollar closed at 132.85 yen in New York, up from late Thursday's 132.17. In Tokyo, the dollar rose 0.57 yen to a closing 131.87 yen and later in London, it was quoted at 132.85 yen. Jitters in Eastern Europe, particularly unrest in Albania, pumped up the dollar against European currencies. ``There is some concern about European prospects with all this pressure on their Eastern borders,'' said Soares-Kemp. ``This takes some of the pressure off the dollar.'' The dollar moved slightly higher against the German mark, closing at 1.4825 marks compared to late Thursday's 1.4790. In London, the dollar was quoted at 1.4845 German marks, up from 1.4805 marks late Thursday. But the dollar also strengthened against the British pound in New York, with sterling weakening to $1.9370 from late Thursday's $1.9450. In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.9390, down from $1.9440 late Thursday. Brokers said the dollar also got support from the 0.5 percent rise in the U.S. producer price index for November, when a gain of only 0.1 percent was expected. The poor performance suggested the Federal Reserve may have less room to lower interest rates, traders said. Higher interest rates generally make a currency more attractive. Beneath it all, though, the market retained a bearish tone amid the potential for outside events, including the declining U.S. economy, to weaken the dollar. ``There is room for the dollar to go lower, from both an economic standpoint and also if peace breaks out in the Middle East,'' said Jack Barbanel, managing director for First Global Asset Management Inc. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Wednesday's prices, included: 1.2735 Swiss francs, up from 1.2660; 5.0405 French francs, up from 5.0255; 1,119.75 Italian lire, up from 1,115.25; and 1.1583 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1607. Other late dollar rates, compared with late Thursday, included: 1.2730 Swiss francs, up from 1.2660; 5.0475 French francs, up from 5.0305; 1.6745 Dutch guilders, up from 1.6700; 1,121.25 Italian lire, up from 1,115.75; and 1.1594 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1595. Gold rose in New York, closing up $2.40 a troy ounce to $376.70 on the Commodity Exchange. Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $375.75, up $2.40 from late Thursday. In London earlier, the precious metal traded at $373.75 per ounce, up from $372.25 bid per ounce late Thursday. In Zurich, the bid price was $373.25, up from $372.25 late Thursday. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold rose 76 cents to close at a bid $374.24 per ounce. Silver plunged on the New York Commodity Exchange, closing down 6.9 cents to $3.937. In London, silver traded at a bid price of $3.97 a troy ounce, down from Thursday's $4.02.

DOC.HEAD: Insurers Should Help Pay Court-Ordered Damages, Lawsuit Contends
DOC.TEXT: Charles Keating Jr.'s insurance companies should be required to pay part of any court-ordered damages arising from the collapse of Keating's financial empire, a class-action lawsuit contends. The suit was filed in U.S. District Court by the federal government and investors in Keating's Phoenix-based American Continental Corp. It contends that 21 insurance companies are liable for as much as $110 million. The policies ``impose an obligation on the respective insurance company defendants to provide insurance coverage for the acts of the insured defendants that caused damage and losses to the plaintiffs,'' the lawsuit says. The suit asks that the court to ``determine immediately the scope and amount of coverage'' the policies provide. The suit was filed by four investors and the Resolution Trust Corp., the federal agency empowered to dispose of the assets of failed savings and loans. It was brought on behalf of more than 20,000 people who bought American Continental junk bonds through Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, Keating's California-based thrift. Federal regulators seized Lincoln Savings in April 1989, one day after American Continental and 11 of the thrift's subsidiaries filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code. Keating, members of his family and his former top executives are defendants in lawsuits filed by the government and investors seeking more than $1.3 billion in damages. The federal government is seeking $1.1 billion in a fraud and racketeering suit that blames Keating and his associates for the failure of Lincoln Savings. In a separate suit, more than 17,000 investors who put about $200 million into American Continental securities are demanding their money back. The 21 insurance companies named as defendants in the class-action suit filed Thursday sold policies covering actions taken by Keating and his executives that can be tied to the collapse of American Continental and Lincoln Savings, according to the suit. The insurance companies contend that some of the policies are ``self consuming,'' which means the proceeds are being used to pay the legal bills run up by Keating and the others in various civil suits. The lawsuit argues, however, that policy provisions that allow deductions for legal fees are vague, ambiguous and unenforceable. ``As a result of this dispute, proceeds of certain policies are wasting and elderly plaintiffs are losing their rights to certain recoveries,'' the lawsuit says. ``Unless this court determines the rights and obligations of the parties, many of the insurance policies may be wasted or diminished to zero ...'' A federal judge last May ordered National Union Fire Insurance Co. of Pittsburgh, one of the insurance companies, to pay for legal bills of Keating and his associates under two of its policies. The investors requested each insurer last May to deposit the amount of the policies into interest-bearing accounts to pay any court-awarded damages. But the companies have been reluctant to do so, the suit contends. The suit was assigned to Judge Richard Bilby and probably will be consolidated with other pending Keating suits, according to the court clerk's office.

DOC.HEAD: Court Document Shows Eastern Continued to Falsify Safety Records
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS new 15th graf to show Eastern's belief about where the affidavit's allegations came from, picking up 16th graf ``Last Friday,'' DELETES extraneous word ``the'' from 2nd graf
DOC.TEXT: Beleaguered Eastern Airlines continued as recently as last month to falsify vital safety and maintenance records, according to a confidential informant cited in a government document unsealed Friday. Eastern angrily denied the charges contained in the document, an affidavit to support a law-enforcement raid earlier this month on Eastern's Miami headquarters. It details a lengthy pattern of doctoring safety logs and other records to keep the airline's jets in the air. Release of the document was a public-relations setback for Eastern, which has been operating under bankruptcy court protection since March 1989 because of a strike that has still not been resolved. Eastern insisted there has been no conspiracy to cut corners on safety, as the government has charged in a criminal case in Brooklyn. In response to the latest allegations, Eastern's court-appointed trustee, Martin R. Shugrue Jr., said that the government has a ``personal vendetta'' against him and ``a vendetta against the company.'' Eastern has continued to lose enormous amounts of money but Shugrue has predicted the troubled carrier will start breaking even sometime next year. Shugrue has been leading an aggressive publicity campaign for Eastern in attempt to win more customers. During a Miami news conference Friday, Shugrue was visibly shaking. His voice rose in anger at times as he accused the government of embarking on a ``headline-hunting exercise'' to damage Eastern. Eastern said ``the FAA's most recent inspections revealed that Eastern was safe and that there was no evidence to suggest that maintenance records were being falsified.'' The airline said that based on its own investigation of specific allegations it was confident that a grand jury would agree ``that the charges contained in the affidavit are without merit.'' Federal investigators armed with a search warrant went into Eastern's offices on Dec. 1 and carried out boxes of documents and computer records, according to Andrew J. Maloney, U.S. attorney for the Eastern District of New York. According to a confidential informant, Eastern ``supervisors are under so much pressure to avoid delays that record falsification is the norm,'' the affidavit said. Maintenance workers at Hartsfield Airport in Atlanta routinely falsified log books to hide faulty navigation, radar and other electronic equipment, as well as bad tires and windshields that leaked air, informants were quoted by investigators as saying in the document. Confidential informants told investigators that ``flight delays caused by necessary repairs or maintenance were simply not tolerated by Eastern's upper management,'' the document said. One confidential informant in Atlanta said ``he witnessed supervisors on almost a daily basis falsifying log books to make it appear that inoperative cockpit instruments had been repaired when in reality they had not been repaired,'' the affidavit said. In a point-by-point denial of the allegations, Eastern said it believed much of the information had come from 13 machinists, nine of whom have been on strike since 1989. Some of the information came from an employee who had been involved a dispute with the company over a disciplinary action, Eastern said. Last Friday, U.S. District Judge I. Leo Glasser of Brooklyn ruled the affidavit unsealed Friday should be made public. However, he put his ruling on hold to allow Eastern a chance to appeal. The appeal went before a three-judge panel of the U.S. Court of Appeals in Manhattan on Thursday. The appelate court ruled Friday that the document should be made public. In July, federal prosecutors in Brooklyn filed criminal charges against Eastern, alleging a pattern of falsifying safety records and other maintenance documents to keep its jets in the air. The airline and several of its top managers are scheduled to be tried next year. Travel agents said Eastern's bookings are not likely to immediately fall off after Friday's disclosure of the affidavit, although news stories about the document could raise concerns among some travelers. ``Very often, we tend to see that unless there's some very dramatic and negative aspect to some carrier, that what seems to drive the consumer more than any other factor is the price,'' said H. Wayne Berens, president of Revere Travel Inc., in Trenton, N.J. Berens said many of his customers who have flown Eastern recently believe they have gotten good value.

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: Mikhail Gorbachev.
DOC.TEXT: Here are some weekly commodity price trends: Wheat futures retreated for the third straight week but other grain and soybean futures advanced on the Chicago Board of Trade. Wheat for delivery in December settled Friday at $2.53 a bushel, unchanged from a week earlier; December corn retreated to $2.23\ a bushel from $2.26; December oats dropped to $1.08{ a bushel from $1.10; January soybeans fell to $5.88{ a bushel from $5.95. Livestock and meat futures gained on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. December live cattle climbed to 80.97 cents a pound from 79.92 cents; January feeder cattle rose to 89.17 cents a pound from 88.87 cents; December hogs advanced to 50.67 cents a pound from 49.27 cents; February frozen pork bellies slipped to 64.20 cents a pound from 64.70 cents. DOC.HEAD: Bush Picks Lynn Martin For Labor Post; One More Cabinet Job to Fill
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 4th graf pvs, Bush called, with Martin meeting Bush at White House on Monday. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Friday he would nominate Rep. Lynn Martin of Illinois to head the Labor Department, choosing a longtime friend who lost her congressional seat last month in a failed Senate bid. The choice of Martin to replace Elizabeth Dole, who resigned to head the American Red Cross, will assure the continuing presence of at least one woman in Bush's Cabinet. Another congresswoman defeated in an effort to unseat a Democratic senator, Patricia Saiki of Hawaii, is considered a frontrunner for the top position at the Education Department, where Lauro Cavazos was forced to resign this week. Bush called Martin, 51, a ``distinguished public servant and cherished friend.'' The president was scheduled to meet with Martin at the White House on Monday. The announcement got a somewhat chillier reception from labor leaders. Lane Kirkland, president of the 14.2 million-member AFL-CIO, said that during her 10-year tenure in Congress her voting record ``has not reflected a sensitivity to the needs of workers.'' Bush's announcement, made hastily before he boarded a helicopter for Camp David, Md., appeared designed to end a week of turmoil within the administration on a positive note. Cavazos resigned Wednesday - after being told to leave by White House Chief of Staff John Sununu, according to administration sources. And Bush's choice as the new Republican Party chairman, William Bennett, bowed out Thursday when he found out how drastically new ethics rules would limit his outside income. Martin, in Illinois on Friday, was informed only an hour ahead of the formal announcement that she had landed the job, an administration source said. Martin declined to be interviewed, but issued a brief statement saying her nomination was ``a high honor.'' ``I look forward to appearing before the Senate for the upcoming confirmation hearings,'' she said, thanking Bush for his ``confidence and support.'' Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., whose Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee will hold Martin's confirmation hearings, commended her on her nomination. He said the department needs someone who could ``stand up for hard-pressed families against the constant pro-business tilt of the White House.'' In making his announcement, Bush said Martin had served as an ``unofficial adviser'' to him on legislative matters in the past. She backed him in his first presidential bid in 1980, helped him prepare for his vice presidential debate with Democrat Geraldine Ferraro in 1984 and was a national co-chairman of his presidential campaign two years ago. It was also apparent that Bush felt he owed her something for her party loyalty in giving up a safe House seat to make the uphill bid against Sen. Paul Simon. She had been passed over in Bush's first round of Cabinet appointments after the 1988 election, partly because of her own interest in the Senate. ``She's a mother who knows the need for child care. She's a professional who understands the business-labor relationship. And, as a congresswoman, she spent years dealing with the concerns and aspirations of the working Americans from every walk of life,'' Bush said. Rep. Saiki had also been considered in the running for the labor post, as well as for the education slot. Martin and Saiki were seen as likely nominees for several reasons, political analysts said. They are women; they are seen as being owed something because they gave up House seats with Bush's encouragement to make the Senate bids; and, as Capitol veterans, they could help him push administration policy in Congress. In addition, Saiki, an Asian-American, would add a minority member to a Cabinet that lost Cavazos, a Hispanic-American. Besides the Cabinet openings before Bush this week, the high-profile job of RNC chairman was added to the equation when Bennett, the former drug policy director, said he'd changed his mind about taking the job. Three Cabinet secretaries are among those frequently mentioned as contenders for the RNC post - Samuel Skinner of Transportation, Robert Mosbacher of Commerce and Jack Kemp of Housing and Urban Development - along with former Rep. Thomas Loeffler of Texas and longtime Bush campaign strategist Rich Bond. If Skinner, Mosbacher or Kemp took the job, that would give Bush yet another Cabinet opening to fill. Besides Saiki, those also considered potential choices for education secretary include Lynne Cheney, chairwoman of the National Endowment for the Humanities; former New Jersey Gov. Thomas Kean, now president of Drew University, and former Tennessee Gov. Lamar Alexander, now president of the University of Tennessee. Cheney, the wife of Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, has also been mentioned as a candidate for the Labor post. Martin has never had a close alliance with organized labor. According to the AFL-CIO's scorecard, she voted ``right'' on workers' issues 29 percent of the time. When Bush tapped Mrs. Dole for the labor post two years ago, his action was seen as a way for Republicans to mend fences with organized labor leaders who had had a hostile relationship with the Reagan administration. Analysts say more Cabinet changes might follow soon. Kemp, Skinner and Mosbacher are all said to be itchy, as well as Attorney General Dick Thornburgh.

DOC.HEAD: AT&T, Ricoh Cooperate in Digital Fax Marketing
DOC.TEXT: American Telephone & Telegraph Co. and the U.S. arm of the Japanese company Ricoh have combined to market digital phone lines and digital fax machines, the companies announced Friday. Under the one-year pact, the two companies will share sales leads, recommend each other's services and equipment, share equipment for customer demonstrations and jointly promote their products, they said. The plan will involve AT&T's digital phone service called Accunet and Ricoh Corp.'s digital fax machines. Digital fax machines transmit documents in the ones and zeros of computer code, which eliminates most distortion that can be introduced into conventional analog transmissions. The machines are designed for use with digital phone lines.

DOC.HEAD: Prices Fall on Inflationary News
DOC.TEXT: News of higher wholesale prices and troubles facing Middle East peace talks sent bond prices skidding for a second day Friday. The Treasury's bellwether 30-year bond was down 25-32 point, or $7.81 per $1,000 in face amount, at closing. Its yield, which rises when prices fall, was up to 8.18 percent from 8.12 percent late Thursday. ``The market kind of got blindsided by a worse-than-expected (producer price index) report. That kind of rattled people. I expect the president's press conference did likewise,'' said Bud Sturm, senior economist for Fuji Securities Inc. in Chicago. Government economic data showed wholesale prices, excluding the food and energy categories, rose a higher-than-expected 0.5 percent in November after no change in October. Inflation generally erodes the value of government securities such as bonds and notes. At a White House news conference, President Bush said planned peace talks with Iraq are on hold because of a problems in setting a date with Iraq for peace talks. Traders said prices also dropped following hawkish testimony by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney before the House Armed Services Committee. Cheney said that if the economic attempts and diplomatic efforts to solve the crisis fail, the United States must have the option of using force to oust Iraq from Kuwait. The bond market's decline came after a sharp three-day rally that began last week following announcement of a 5.9 percent unemployment rate for November. ``I think today's market reaction gives some indication of how far the market got ahead of itself over the last week,'' said Sturm. In the secondary market for Treasury bonds, short-term maturities were down 1-16 point to \ point, intermediate maturities fell 5-16 point to 15-32 point and long-term issues lost 7-16 point to 25-32 point, the Telerate Inc. financial information service reported. The movement of a point equals a change of $10 in the price of a bond with a $1,000 face value. The Lehman Brothers Daily Treasury Bond Index, which measures price movements on all outstanding Treasury issues with maturities of a year or longer, was down 3.70 to 1,185.93. Yields on three-month Treasury bills rose to 7.06 percent as the discount was up 2 basis point to 6.85 percent. Yields on six-month bills were up to 7.07 as the discount rose 6 basis points to 6.75 percent. Yields on one-year bills rose to 7.08 percent as the discount was up 4 basis points to 6.64 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The yield is the annualized return on an investment in a Treasury bill. The discount is the percentage that bills are selling below the face value, which is paid at maturity. The federal funds rate, the interest on overnight loans between banks, traded at 7 5-16 percent late Friday, up from 7\ Thursday. Don Fine, chief market economist for Chase Manhattan Bank, said he believes the Federal Reserve will drop the federal funds rate to 7 percent within the next couple of weeks. In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds fell 7-32 point to 91}. The average yield to maturity was up to 7.47 percent from 7.45 percent late Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Bleak Economic Picture Depress Silver, Platinum
DOC.TEXT: Silver and platinum prices fell Friday on New York's Commodity Exchange as the latest economic indicators pointed to a severe slump in the manufacturing sector. On other markets, grains and soybeans were higher; livestock, pork and energy futures were mixed; and gold was higher. Silver and platinum futures plunged on news from the Federal Reserve that industrial production plunged 1.7 percent in November, the steepest drop since the last recession in 1982. ``That makes for a very weak industrial future,'' analyst Jim Steel of Refco Inc. in New York said. ``It means demand for industrial metals, silver and platinum supplies are not as great. But it will remain weak.'' Silver has been on a downward slide since the start of the year, as traders looked upon it increasingly as an industrial metal. A large percentage of silver is used by the film industry. It also is used by telecommunications companies and defense manufacturers. There are abundant supplies of silver, but platinum supplies are not as high. Platinum is a key component of catalytic converters, an automobile pollution control device, and in the aerospace industry. Silver settled 6.9 cents to 7.7 cents lower with the contract for delivery in December at $3.937 a troy ounce. Platinum was $2.30 to $3 lower with January at $412.20 a troy ounce. Gold futures moved in the opposite direction of silver and platinum, supported by a surge of oil prices early in the day. A stronger dollar and silver's weakness capped on gold's advance. Gold was $2.40 to $3.30 higher with February at $378.60 a troy ounce. Crude oil futures gave up much of a $1.68 gain in a late retreat, as President Bush was less aggressive than expected in discussing the Gulf crisis during an afternoon news conference. Analysts said there was expectation Bush would cancel talks with Iraq because of disagreement over the date for a planned meeting between Secretary of State James Baker and Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. Light sweet crude was 27 cents lower to 13 cents higher with January at $26.55 a barrel; heating oil was .23 cent to 1.09 cents higher with January at 75.24 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .60 cent lower to .61 cent higher with January at 66.18 cents a gallon; natural gas was unchanged to .042 cent higher with January at $2.262 per 1,000 cubic feet. Grain and soybean futures prices were slightly higher in lackluster trading on the Chicago Board of Trade. Traders were wary of taking positions pending an announcement of a list of commodities the Soviet Union will buy with $500 million to $1 billion in export credits, analyst Joel Karlin of Research Department Inc. said. Corn futures came under pressure with news that South Korea made a major purchase of Chinese corn. Wheat futures were boosted by a decision of the U.S. Agriculture Department to allow producers to place up to 300 million bushels of wheat in the farmer-owned reserve. The decision was made because of concern over falling prices and lagging exports. Wheat was 1{ cents lower to } cent higher with December at $2.53 a bushel; corn was unchanged to 1\ cents higher with December at $2.23\ a bushel; oats were a { cent higher with December at $1.08{ a bushel; soybeans were { cent to 1{ cents higher with January at $5.88{ a bushel. Livestock futures were higher and pork futures were mixed on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Hog futures gained on higher cash prices and views that a sharp sell-off Thursday was overdone. Pork belly futures were lower on technical selling. Live cattle were .05 cent to .38 cent higher with December at 80.97 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .10 cent to .32 cent higher with January at 89.17 cents a pound; live hogs were .22 cent to 1.07 cents higher with December at 50.67 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .10 cent to .72 cent lower with February at 64.20 cents a pound.

--- NEW YORK (AP) - NCR Corp.'s directors unanimously rejected American Telephone & Telegraph Co.'s $90-a-share cash tender offer for the computer maker, and alleged the phone company had violated securities laws. In a statement, NCR on Friday called the hostile takeover bid ``grossly inadequate and unfair.'' The move by NCR's board appears to set the stage for AT&T to escalate its bid. Industry analysts say the phone company may launch a proxy fight to try to unseat NCR's directors, a step AT&T says it has considered. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Wholesale prices rose 0.5 percent in November, the government said. Analysts called it a disturbingly high increase at a time when the economy is slumping and energy costs are moderating. In a separate report, the Federal Reserve said Friday U.S. manufacturing had suffered its steepest one-month plunge in eight years. --- DETROIT (AP) - California billionaire Kirk Kerkorian has bought 9.8 percent of the stock of Chrysler Corp. for about $272 million. That makes him the company's largest shareholder and prompts the struggling automaker to beef up its takeover defenses. A statement issued through a Los Angeles public relations agency said the purchase was made as an investment. Chrysler spokesman Arthur Liebler confirmed that a discussion took place last week between Kerkorian, of Beverly Hills, Calif., and Chrysler Chairman Lee Iacocca. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Most of the nation's largest banks are teetering on the brink of insolvency and tax money must quickly be injected into the government fund insuring deposits, warns a congressional report due out Monday. Bank failure costs could total $63 billion in a severe recession, it said. Even the mild downturn expected by most economists would leave the fund short of cash, said the report, which was written by three economists at the request of a congressional subcommittee. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Tribune Co. said its operating profit will slide substantially more than 25 percent this year because of the weak advertising climate and rising costs of a strike at its New York Daily News. Company executives on Friday failed to specify how much the seven-week-old strike by nine of the 10 labor unions at the newspaper is costing. The paper has continued to publish despite the strike although circulation is down sharply. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Beleaguered Eastern Airlines continued as recently as last month to falsify vital safety and maintenance records, according to a confidential informant cited in a government document. Eastern on Friday angrily denied the charges contained in the document, an affidavit to support a law-enforcement raid earlier this month on Eastern's Miami headquarters. It details a lengthy pattern of doctoring safety logs and other records to keep the airline's jets in the air. --- DALLAS (AP) - Southland Corp.'s bankruptcy plan confirmation hearing began with attorneys clashing over efforts by the parent of the 7-Eleven convenience store chain to disclose reorganization options. Southland filed for Chapter 11 reorganization in October with a ``prepackaged'' plan already approved by most of its creditors. U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Harold Abramson must confirm the plan for it to take effect. Abramson said Friday he would first hear arguments over Southland's attempts to inform creditors of the Dallas-based company's financial condition and options, then hear arguments on the merits of the reorganization plan. The hearing is expected to last for several weeks. --- PHOENIX (AP) - Charles Keating Jr.'s insurance companies should be required to pay part of any court-ordered damages arising from the collapse of Keating's financial empire, a class-action lawsuit contends. The suit was filed in U.S. District Court by the federal government and investors in Keating's Phoenix-based American Continental Corp. It contends that 21 insurance companies are liable for as much as $110 million. The policies ``impose an obligation on the respective insurance company defendants to provide insurance coverage for the acts of the insured defendants that caused damage and losses to the plaintiffs,'' the lawsuit says. ---

Disappointing inflation news and a rise in interest rates helped drive the stock market into a broad retreat Friday. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 20.55 to 2,593.81, closing out the week with a net gain of 3.71 points. Oil and gold rose, while bonds, silver and platinum fell. Other commodities were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Taj Meets Deadline; Other Two Trump Properties Face Saturday Deadlines
DOC.TEXT: Donald Trump's Taj Mahal Casino Resort met an extended deadline Friday to throw together a restructuring agreement and hand it over to state gaming regulators. The developer's other two casinos face deadlines Saturday to make bond payments. Analysts said one - the Trump Castle - probably wouldn't make its $18.4 million payment. The Trump Plaza Hotel and Casino was likely to make its $16.1 million bond payment, they said. Both are due by midnight Saturday. The Philadelphia Inquirer reported in Friday editions that Trump Plaza has just $17 million in the bank and Trump Castle has only $18 million handy. Failure to make payments could throw the casinos in default and perhaps put them under the protection of bankruptcy court. Ed Tracy, the head of Trump's three Atlantic City casinos and one non-casino hotel, would not comment on the status of the bond payments. Ten-day grace periods to pay the bonds would not start until Monday, Tracy said. ``When we have something to say, we'll say it,'' Tracy said. The state Casino Control Commission is only immediately concerned with the financial stability of the Taj Mahal and the ``pre-packaged'' bankruptcy plan it intends to file and leave by the spring. The commission has said it will likely look at the financial stability of the other two properties later. Friday's meeting began 1 hour and 40 minutes late as documents arrived at the last minute by facsimile machine. Attorneys from the state, the Trump Organization, Taj Mahal bondholders, Taj Mahal subcontractors and banks sought to make sure they all agreed on the final terms of the documents. Commission chairman Steve Perskie stressed, as he had in two previous hearings, that delay in producing the Taj Mahal documents could threaten the license of the 8{-month-old casino, the glitziest in Atlantic City. He had extended his Wednesday deadline for the deal's supporting documents until Friday. ``I am satisfied that with the submission of documents ... the licensee and other participants have met the conditions imposed by the commission,'' Perskie said. ``The commission recognizes that a lot of people have lost a lot of sleep. Tempers might have been frayed and tensions might have been high,'' he said. ``But the public interest is served by certainty. The schedule was neither arbitrary, unfair nor as it turns out unreasonable.'' State law makes the commission responsible for ensuring that each casino licensee remains financially stable. The commission has the power to take away a license. The casino commission wants to see the overall agreement by next Wednesday. Trump officials have said they intend to file that with the federal Securities and Exchange Commission by Monday. Perskie said he would rule Monday whether documents detailing the restructuring agreement should be released to the public. Other documents, including certificates of incorporation and new bylaws, were made public. The Taj Mahal failed to make a $47.3 million payment due Nov. 15 to bondholders, only to reach a restructuring deal the day after. The restructuring reduces the interest rate on the $675 million in bonds from 14 percent to 12 percent, spreads their repayment date over ten years instead of eight and gives bondholders half ownership in the Taj Mahal. Trump, who has not attended the hearings, can raise his 50 percent ownership to up to 80 percent if he can repay the bonds at rates higher than the restructured 12 percent. The Taj Mahal has set gross gaming records since its opening. But it has failed to consistently make the $1.3 million a day that analysts said it needed to break even. In a market already weakened by the recession, the Taj Mahal has siphoned away gaming business from the 11 other casinos, including Trump's other two properties. Raymond Neidl, a bond analyst with Dillon Read & Co. in New York, said it does not appear Trump Castle would make its payment, leaving open the possibility of a restructuring or bankruptcy. ``The market is assuming the payment is not going to be made,'' Neidl said. He said the situation looked better for Trump Plaza, which is in the center of the Boardwalk area and is considered a more attractive propoerty than the Trump Castle.

DOC.HEAD: Paper Maker To Charge $212 Million Against Earnings
DOC.TEXT: International Paper Co. said Friday it was charging $212 million against fourth-quarter earnings for costs associated with scaling down operations and installating environmental controls. The reserve fund is equal to $137 million after taxes, or $1.26 per share, the company said. International Paper reported $546 million in earnings, or $5.01 per share, in the first nine months of 1990. International Paper Chairman John A. Georges said the sale and liquidation of company assets would improve the company's earnings and cash flow during and after 1991. Asset sales were expected to generate up to $200 million in after-tax proceeds over the next three years, the company said. International Paper is a worldwide producer of paper and forest products with manufacturing operations in 22 countries. The company did not identify which facilities and business units it was selling, but said they either were not strategically important or not generating enough return on investment. Two-thirds of the fourth-quarter charge is to pay costs associated with the asset sales, the company said. The remainder is earmarked for paying for environmental controls at several wood-treating plants and for personnel costs associated with consolidation and improved productivity.
